HEADLINE: Bush's Record on Jobs: Risking Comparison To a Republican Ghost 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
For George W. Bush, the race has begun to escape comparisons to Herbert Hoover.
 With more than two million jobs having disappeared since Mr. Bush took office in January 2001, he finds himself in danger of becoming the first president since Hoover to oversee a decline in the country's employment. Economists disagree on how much blame, if any, Mr. Bush deserves for the long slump, but even White House aides view the economy as one of the only big threats to his re-election campaign. 
 Now, a turning point could be approaching. The Labor Department will release its jobs report for June this morning, and some forecasters are predicting that it will mark the beginning of a rebound. An increase in the nation's payrolls -- the odds of which are roughly even, Wall Street economists say -- would be the first since January.
Then the real test for the Bush administration will start. Mr. Bush has called the recently passed tax cut the main reason for economic optimism, and administration officials have repeatedly referred to it as the "jobs and growth" plan, part of its official name, to emphasize its goal.
"Listen, I'm interested in one thing," the president said during a rally last month in Fridley, Minn., to promote the tax cut. "I'm interested in helping people find work."
According to the White House's forecast, the increased consumer spending and business investment from the tax cut, combined with the economy's underlying growth, will easily push Mr. Bush's jobs record into positive figures. Even if the economy merely adds jobs at the average rate of the last 50 years, he will rank roughly in the middle of modern-era Republican presidents, who have held office during weaker periods of job growth than Democrats. 
But the length of this economic slowdown has surprised almost all economists, and some have begun to say there is a significant chance that the economy will not erase the jobs deficit by the end of 2004. Among the three best-known forecasting firms in the United States, Economy.com puts the chances around 33 percent, Global Insight at 25 percent and Macroeconomic Advisers at about 20 percent. Employment gains would have to average about 120,000 a month for the American work force to return by the end of next year to its size in January 2001.
While the difference between positive and negative numbers can be somewhat arbitrary, statistics are likely to play a central role in the speeches of the 2004 campaign, political strategists and economists say.
Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, has begun summarizing Mr. Bush's economic record as "$3 trillion deeper in debt, 3 million fewer jobs." (While private-sector payrolls have fallen by more than 3 million, the overall decline has been 2.4 million because of government hiring.) 
Democratic presidential candidates have made a practice of mentioning job losses during Mr. Bush's term. And the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group financed by unions and foundations, plans to grade Mr. Bush each month on how well the job market lives up to the White House forecast.
The tax cut "was presented as if it were a jobs plan," said Lawrence Mishel, the group's president. "It should be judged as such."
Republicans largely agree. 
"There's no reason why we should be satisfied with 6 percent unemployment," said N. Gregory Mankiw, chairman of the White House Council of Economics Advisers. He added that the economy's plight was worse than the jobless rate suggested, but that the tax cut was likely to help reduce unemployment by end of this year.
The $350 billion plan reduces taxes on all households that make enough money to pay income taxes, among other measures. The benefits go mainly to high-income people, who pay most taxes. 
Still, Mr. Mankiw said that this summer, when the White House releases its next official forecast, it will probably reduce predicted job growth over the next year and a half from the 5.5 million it forecast early this year. Economic growth has been slower in the last few months than officials expected, and companies typically hire new workers only after executives are convinced that a healthy recovery has taken hold.
Administration officials have attributed the economic torpor to the 1990's bubble in stock prices and business investment, the accounting scandals in corporate America and the uncertainty caused by the Afghanistan and Iraq wars. Outside economists overwhelmingly agree that the hiring slump, which is the worst in 20 years and the longest since before World War II, is not chiefly Mr. Bush's fault.
"He was unlucky," said John H. Makin, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group in Washington. "And I would say I don't think the bubble was the fault of Democrats. People got overexcited. It just started to unravel in the fall of 2000."
The main argument is whether Mr. Bush has done all he could to mitigate the slowdown. 
His aides say that without the three tax cuts passed since early 2001, the jobs decline would have been even worse. By reducing taxes on capital gains and dividends, the latest measure will also increase investment, encouraging companies to expand, the aides add.
Many Democrats argue that there are more effective ways to stimulate the economy than tax cuts focused on the wealthy. They have suggested sending money to state governments, which are now cutting programs to close deep budget deficits of their own, and giving larger tax cuts to middle-class and poor families. 
Similar measures are one reason -- along with chance -- that the six presidents with the best records of job creation since 1933 are all Democrats, some people in the party say.
"It seems to me that we should be putting money into the hands of people who will spend it immediately," said Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California and a member of the Joint Economic Committee. "The worst part is creating this huge deficit and giving it to the 1 or 2 percent of Americans who won't do anything but increase their wealth with it."
People from both parties agree, though, that Mr. Bush's re-election chances will be improved if his record on jobs falls somewhere between Gerald R. Ford's and Ronald Reagan's, and well away from Herbert Hoover's.

PERSON: Najeeb E. Halaby 

HEADLINE: Najeeb E. Halaby, Former Airline Executive, Dies at 87 

BYLINE:  By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2 

 BODY:
Najeeb E. Halaby, who was once a leader in the airline industry and was known more recently as the father of Queen Noor of Jordan, died today at his home in McLean, Va. He was 87.
 Mr. Halaby, formerly of Alpine, N.J., had lived in McLean in recent years. He also had a home on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. 
 At various times in his life, Mr. Halaby was a skydiver, test pilot, lawyer and businessman, most notably at Pan American World Airways. He started as a senior vice president at Pan Am in 1965, became president in 1968, chief executive in 1969 and then chairman the next year.
In 1972, he was forced to resign as chairman and chief executive when the board blamed him for the line's worsening financial crisis. Mr. Halaby's tenure coincided with one of the worst slumps in the airline industry, compounded by a general recession, inflation, increased competition and the high cost of introducing the Boeing747. 
Mr. Halaby had championed the jumbo jet, predicting correctly that it would become a mainstay of air travel. "A chief executive likes to leave a company better than when he found it," Mr. Halaby said upon his departure. "I believe I have."
After leaving Pan Am, Mr. Halaby wrote a book, "Crosswinds: an Airman's Memoir" (Doubleday, 1978), ran an international law practice and headed a company that provided aviation technology to Arab countries.
Mr. Halaby became the father-in-law to royalty in 1978, when his daughter Lisa wed King Hussein and became Queen Noor al-Hussein. Ms. Halaby had studied architecture at Princeton University and had met the king a year earlier, at a ceremony in Amman marking the delivery of the Jordanian airline's first Boeing 747.
At 42, the king was 16 years older than his bride. Mr. Halaby later acknowledged some initial unease over the romance. But he said the king's vigor, directness and charm had won him over.
Mr. Halaby first became well known when President John F. Kennedy named him administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration in 1961. News reports of the era called him the first Arab-American to rise so high in government. In fact, he was already a veteran of government service, having been a foreign affairs adviser to the Pentagon and then a deputy assistant secretary of defense from 1948 to 1952.
Nor did the term "Arab-American" fit Mr. Halaby neatly. "I have always wanted to be an American, not a hyphenated," Mr. Halaby said in a 1979 interview. His father, Najeeb Elias Halaby, was a Lebanese-Syrian who came to the United States as a youth. His mother, Laura, was a native of Texas.
Najeeb Halaby, often called Jeeb, was born in Dallas on Nov. 19, 1915, an only child. After his father's death in 1928, he lived in Los Angeles and Santa Barbara, Calif. He spoke a little Arabic as a boy, but "lost it" after his father died, he recalled later. 
Mr. Halaby was an indifferent student at Stanford University, where he was active in debating, acting and golf. He graduated in 1937 and attended the University of Michigan and Yale law schools, graduating from Yale in 1940. 
An avid flyer since he was a teen-ager, Mr. Halaby was a Navy test pilot in World War II. "I had a really fascinating war," he said jokingly years later. "Instead of slugging it out at Guadalcanal with the Marines, I was at Patuxent, Md., slugging it out with the elements, with aerodynamics and thermodynamics."
His 1946 marriage, to Doris Carlquist, ended in divorce in 1977. In 1980, he married Jane Coates, who died in 1996. In 1997, he married Libby Cater, who survives. In addition to Queen Noor, he is survived by a son, Christian, of Atherton, Calif., a daughter, Alexa, of Washington, and 10 grandchildren.
Mr. Halaby was, rather atypically for many businessmen of his era, an avowed liberal. He was outspoken about his political and philosophical leanings. He pressed for equal treatment for air crews of Hispanic descent and other minorities, including crew assignments on flights to South Africa.
Mr. Halaby's old airline, Pan Am, is no more. A prediction he made in 1971, while president of Pan Am, has not come true. "We know that worldwide supersonic flight will become as commonplace in the decades ahead as jet travel is today," he wrote. The Concorde supersonic transport is now in its final days of flight.
But Mr. Halaby was more prescient in other ways. In September 1970, after a wave of airplane hijackings by Arab commando groups, Mr. Halaby said Pan Am would cooperate with stricter security requirements, including armed guards aboard planes if necessary.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 4, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Najeeb E. Halaby, the former airline executive and federal aviation official, misstated the name of the agency he was named to lead in 1961. It was the Federal Aviation Agency; it later adopted the name Federal Aviation Administration.

HEADLINE: Brazil Ponders Nestle's Acquisition of Competitor 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 2 

 BODY:
When it finally comes to the crunch, a $230 million acquisition by Swiss multinational Nestle of Garoto, the maker of some of Brazil's favorite chocolates, promises to be the toughest test yet for the country's fledgling antitrust authorities.
 Brazil's monopoly watchdog, known by its acronym CADE, is expected to rule in the coming weeks on the purchase, sealed over a year ago by Nestle Brazil's chairman Ivan Zurita in a campaign to overtake Kraft Foods as market leader in this country of 175 million people, who eat about $1.1 billion in chocolate a year. 
 The sale would give the new company a 56 percent market share and a near monopoly in some sectors. Kraft and Cadbury Schweppes, which lost out to Nestle in the bidding for Garoto, petitioned CADE to block the deal. 
The justice and finance ministries, which also have a say in antitrust policy, have opposed the merger. Nestle was forced to sign an agreement that would allow the merger to be undone if CADE, a Portuguese acronym for the Administrative Council for Economic Defense, deemed it necessary.
If approved, the purchase of the country's third-largest chocolate maker by its second-largest will certainly have been a bold move by Mr. Zurita, who returned home to Brazil in 2001 after doubling Nestle's sales in Mexico. The acquisition would mean that Nestle would overtake Kraft's local operations. Kraft had bought Lacta, Brazil's most popular chocolate brand, in 1996.
Since then, Nestle had only managed to increase its market share to 32 percent from 30 percent, although national chocolate production had risen by 14 percent, to nearly 340,000 tons a year.
So Garoto, a company with a modern factory, strong domestic sales and a solid export base, was an interesting target, and an easy one, because at least 19 of the heirs of the Meyerfreund family, which owned Garoto, were squabbling over its future. Since then, four family members have made a big investment in a real estate project promoted by Donald Trump in the state of Sao Paulo.
CADE officials declined to comment before reaching a decision. 
Many industry insiders and market analysts are becoming increasingly vocal in their criticism of the deal.
"This merger should not be approved," said Genilson Fernandes Santana, a partner at MCM Consultores Associados in Sao Paulo. 
"The consumer will definitely suffer," he said, "because there will be less competition and, as a result, serious price hikes."
Projections made by MCM, using a model based on that used by the United States Justice Department, show prices rising by more than 21 percent for blocks of chocolate, nearly 17 percent for boxes of candies and almost 32 percent for solid confectioners' chocolate. In liquid confectioners' chocolate, the merged company would have a monopoly, allowing it to raise prices at will.
Caio Tomazelli, chief executive of Chocolates Prawer, an independent manufacturer from the southern city of Gramado that currently buys its raw materials from Garoto and Nestle, said the merger would mean "hyperconcentration in the supply chain."
"Short-term, we are going to be completely dependent on them if the merger goes through," he said. Mr. Tomazelli is already looking across the border in Argentina for alternative suppliers, but he predicted that it could take the sector more than five years to readjust.
Cadbury Schweppes, which was outbid by Nestle for Garoto, is complaining that Nestle's domination will make it virtually impossible for newcomers to enter the market. "Cadbury believes that Nestle simply wants to close the market," said Tito Amaral de Andrade of Machado, Meyer, Sendacz e Opice, a lawyer for Cadbury.
Despite what many consider to be obvious reasons for the antitrust agency to block the sale, neither Mr. Tomazelli nor Mr. Santana expects the regulator to do so. Founded in 1962, the agency only started to gain real power with new antitrust legislation in 1994.
Although it has started to flex its muscles, with trust-busting actions against the local steel industry, supermarkets and gas stations, and imposing conditions in Brazil on the 1995 acquisition by Colgate Palmolive of Kolynos, it has frequently been stymied by politicians when it came to bigger deals.
In 1999, under intense government pressure, CADE allowed Brazil's two largest beverage companies, Brahma and Antartica, to form AmBev, now one of the world's largest brewers.
And in the next months, its seven-member council is widely expected to bend again to the government's will and approve the merger of the country's two top airlines, Varig and TAM. The government has said the merger is the only way to save debt-ridden Varig, one of Brazil's most prestigious brand names.
In both those instances, the creation of a "national champion" has been used as a reason to justify the mergers. But in the Nestle-Garoto case, the winner would be a foreign multinational.
While the new, left-leaning government might be more willing than its predecessor to use anti-big-business rhetoric, analysts say that Nestle's total assets in Brazil, worth 2.6 billion reais ($940 million) in 2001, may ultimately be what count.
"Brazil is still under a lot of pressure to be seen to be receptive to foreign investment," said Mr. Santana. "The impact of a Nestle openly criticizing Brazil's investment climate at a time like this would be very damaging."
Some think it is more likely that the agency would impose restrictions on the sale rather than overturn it. Mr. Santana said the agency could veto the deal in certain sectors of the market where concentration would be particularly high, like raw chocolate supplied to confectioners. Alternatively, Nestle could be asked to spin off some of Garoto's big brands. Mr. Santana added that he did not expect any tough measures to be taken, but would like to be surprised.
"Time is playing in Nestle's favor," he added. "The more time passes, the more difficult it will be to undo the deal. The two companies have been under the same command for over a year now."
Nestle has signed a "reversibility" deal with CADE, meaning it cannot touch the managerial structure of Garoto until it receives antitrust approval. But some Garoto distributors are already preparing court cases against Nestle, saying they are being forced to cut their margins from 17 percent to 10 percent to 14 percent, said Oldemar Delgado, a lawyer representing a large distributor.
The former head of CADE, economist Gesner Oliveira, says the risks to competition are serious.
"A cold, technical analysis of the facts," he said, "would recommend a non-approval."
Then again, it was on Mr. Oliveira's watch that CADE approved the AmBev merger.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chocolate made by Nestle shares shelf space with products by Garoto in a store in Sao Paulo. Antitrust regulators in Brazil are expected to rule soon on Nestle's purchase of Garoto. (Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 30

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays (and most galleries and museums are closed today), but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting -- all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"CONTEMPORARY ART/RECENT ACQUISITIONS," the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 423-3200 (through July 27). Eighteen new acquisitions, made over the last two years, demonstrate the Jewish Museum's commitment to a program of acquiring with-it current works. All created since 1975, the objects include -- besides painting, sculpture and photography --examples of video and installation art. The artists, who hail from Canada, Germany, Israel and South Africa as well as the United States, include Nan Goldin, Robert Longo, Nancy Spero, Fred Wilson, William Kentridge and Michael Lombardi, among others. Their contributions range from film projections by Mr. Kentridge dealing with the troubles of his native South Africa as reflected in the lives of two fictional Jewish nonheroes, to a video film by the Americans Sanford Biggers and Jennifer Zackin that juxtaposes home movies made in the middle-class milieus of their respective black and white families. The new additions fit well into the complex picture of Jewish identity offered by the museum. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; $7.50, students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century, Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures. These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it." Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7.) The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes and Leonardo da Vinci meet. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through October). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Elie Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small, truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources place them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Smith).

"NOGUCHI -- THE BOLLINGEN JOURNEY: PHOTOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS, 1949-1956," Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum (temporary space), 36-01 43rd Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 204-7088 (through Oct. 13). More than 100 photographs and drawings recreate Noguchi's travels from 1949 to 1956, on a grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The project was for an ambitious book (never completed) on the spaces and structures -- religious, monumental, classical and communal -- of familiar as well as less-documented societies. Besides providing an elegant travelogue, the photographs give some idea of the many sources that Noguchi drew on for his work. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Glueck)

* "THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF CHARLES SHEELER," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). This majestic progression of 90 vintage prints will cause some ripples in the big familiar pond of American Modernism, within which Sheeler is known foremost as one of the chief instigators of Precisionist painting. But his most profound, original response to Cubism came through the camera, in tautly composed photographs of Pennsylvania farmhouses and barns, New York skyscrapers and Ford's River Rouge factory. Their confident fusion of abstraction and fact, reverence and scrutiny, puts them among the most radical art of their time; and they are an important precursor, at least in spirit, to Pop and Minimalism. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 31). This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Smith).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 1). From 1964 to 1966, Warhol shot 500 short, silent, black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing about 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag -- but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposed the mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours and admission: See above (Sarah Boxer).

* "WHISTLER, WOMEN AND FASHION," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-0700 (through July 13). A dandy, a wit and a social butterfly who cultivated his image as a star aesthete, James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) had a lifelong interest in fashion and women's clothes. This show honors the centenary of that painter's death by exploring his intense, unabashed involvement with fashion. He obsessed over what his female sitters wore, choosing the clothes they posed in and in some cases actually designing them himself. For Mrs. Frances Leyland, the fashionable subject of one of his most smashing pictures, "Symphony in Flesh Color and Pink" (1871-1874), he created an elegant, loose-fitting tea gown of diaphanous pink chiffon worn over a white underdress. The display includes many major images of women in their finery. It is a fitting tribute to a bravura brush. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Glueck).

"YARD," Socrates Sculpture Park, Vernon Boulevard at Broadway, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 956-1819 (through Aug. 3). This lively theme show stretches one of the most resonant of four-letter words (for American suburbanites, at least) from the domestic to the environmental, encompassing notions of family, nature, design and devastation. Oscillating between the real and the surreal, the work on hand also expands the sculptural medium to include photography, video and a large painting-based mural that epitomizes the blight that is American domestic architecture. Other works make similar points, especially Andrea Bowers's sadly telling video documentary about a tree-sitter trying to save a 400-year-old oak from an oncoming thruway. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to sunset. Admission: free (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

* CY TWOMBLY, "A Gathering of Time," Gagosian, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through July 12). Mr. Twombly is celebrating his 75th birthday with a suite of six new paintings and one Roman-candlelike sculpture. With the help of a skylight, they create one of the most beautiful sights, and immersive experiences, of the summer art season. Washes of pale aqua swabbed with turpentine to create drifting, dripping blooms of white have a festive and aqueous effect and push Mr. Twombly's longtime obsessions with walls, wounds, graphic vandalism and ecstatic marks toward Monet's "Waterlilies" (Smith).

"PUERTO RICAN LIGHT: JENNIFER ALLORA AND GUILLERMO CALZADILLA," Americas Society Gallery, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through July 20). Ms. Allora and Mr. Calzadilla are young conceptual artist and collaborators who divide their time between Puerto Rico and New York, and this show brings both places together. The centerpiece is a 1965 fluorescent sculpture by Dan Flavin titled "Puerto Rican Light (to Jeanie Blake)," which derives its illuminating power from solar energy gathered in San Juan and stored in batteries in the gallery (Cotter).

ALES VESELY, "Infinite Point," Carosso Fine Art, 42 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-5400 (through July 30). Mr. Vesely, a Czech sculptor, thinks in monumental terms. His materials are nature-made boulders and even mountains, combined with steel structures. Fortunately, he is a strong draftsman, drawing his projects -- built or unbuilt -- with such flair that even in two dimensions they have a vivid presence. Most impressive, among the projects here are drawings for "Mountain of Mountains," a sheer-sided peak rising from a "sculptural landscape" of desert rocks and mesas, and serving perhaps as a site for reflection on the balance between human and cosmic (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

"MARIKO MORI: WAVE U.F.O.," atrium at 590 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through July 31). This Japanese artist, whose past work blended science fiction, fashion and esoteric Buddhism, has been designing interactive spiritual hardware, and this podlike container is her most ambitious piece so far. It accommodates three electrode-wired participants at a time, and they are treated to a son-et-lumiere projection of their brain waves, followed by an eye-rinsing aurora borealis of Ms. Mori's devising. The high-tech work is fun while it lasts and must have cost someone a fortune to produce (Cotter).

DON NICE, "Paintings on Anodized Aluminum," Babcock, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 767-1852 (through Aug. 5). Since the 1980's Mr. Nice's primary format has been the totemic arrangement of images -- mostly flora and fauna and now abstract passages, too -- in cut-out structures around a central theme. Here the theme is almost always a bright, sunny landscape quickly observed, and surrounded by a heraldic framework that includes, along with abstract passages, stereotypical images of birds, fish, flowers and animals representing air, earth, fire and water. A departure is that he has adopted anodized aluminum for his support rather than canvas or paper, providing a lustrous, light-struck surface. This helps enliven his slick and decorative formula (Glueck).

JULES OLITSKI, "Spray Paintings of the 1960's," Ameringer Yohe Fine Art, 20 West 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 445-0051 (through Aug. 1). That the spray-painted Color Field paintings that Mr. Olitski made in the 60's once seemed such an important culmination of Modernist art history is something to ponder. Was it the merit of the paintings, which have, at their best, an expansive, confectionery prettiness? Or was it the mesmerizing rhetoric of their champion, the czar of formalism, Clement Greenberg? (Johnson).

"TAKE OUT," Zabriskie, 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 752-1223 (through July 18). This cleverly titled and conceived group show is about the art of subtraction. Paul de Guzman cuts the text and images out of art books, leaving intricate, three-dimensional grids. Robin Charles Clark selectively scrapes away the ink from dollar bills; Marla Hlady exposes the inner mechanics of toys; Courtney Smith carves Art Nouveaulike patterns into found cabinets; Noriko Ambe cuts organic landscapes into reams of paper; and Markus Baenziger paints lovely bunnies, birds and trees around simulated, scratch-off lottery tickets (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

MERLIN CARPENTER, "Children of the Projects," American Fine Arts, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 727-7366 (through July 19). Like a grunge-generation Philip Evergood, Mr. Carpenter has created a suite of brushy, intentionally clumsy and overbearingly sentimental paintings that allegorize the plight of poor urban children. A boy in huge sneakers resembles an op-ed cartoon about escapist dreams of athletic success. Two boys in hip-hop clothes, one aiming a handgun at himself, illustrate suicidal tendencies nurtured by poverty. Something is being mocked here, but it is not clear exactly what (Johnson).

DONNA MOYLAN, "Paintings on a Theme," Nicole Klagsbrun, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3335 (through Aug. 1). Ms. Moylan's partly abstract, partly representational meditations on global strife of the last two years are visually engaging and poetically affecting. Feathery gestures and painted whorls following the grain of plywood panels morph into smoking, apocalyptic landscapes, sparsely populated by wan, tiny people and by trucks and helicopters. She evokes a curiously contradictory mood of playfulness and mournful anxiety (Johnson).

"ONLINE," Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, (212) 929-0500 (through Aug. 9). Not about Web art, but about the traditional use of line, this 38-artist show includes too much that is only tangentially linear. But works like Daniel Zeller's intense fields resembling a zany topographical map, Hilary Harkness's fantasy of sexy girl sailors drawn with Ingres-like refinement and Beth Campbell's branching diagram of her possible futures suggest that a more focused investigation of the varieties of linear expression in contemporary art would be worth pursuing (Johnson).

TONY RAY-JONES, Ariel Meyerowitz, 120 11th Avenue, at 20th Street, (212) 414-2770 (through July 11). With a light, poetic touch and affectionate humor, Ray-Jones captured perfect moments of metropolitan pluralism -- a quartet of exotically costumed black men watched by elderly British ladies, for example -- as he explored dog shows, beauty contests and strongman competitions with a sharp sociological eye but no condescension. Ray-Jones died in 1972 at 30; this exhibition shows why he nevertheless has inspired succeeding generations of British photographers (Johnson).

JOEL SHAPIRO, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000 (through July). If the sculptures of Donald Judd and Elie Nadelman had children, they might grow up to look like the best works in Mr. Shapiro's exhibition. They are the ones beautifully fabricated in various woods: airy, floating jumbles of tenuously connected boxes that visually resolve from certain angles into figures jauntily dancing or assuming graceful yoga postures. A pair of giant bronzes, however, look ponderous and overscaled (Johnson).

* DO-HO SUH, Lehmann Maupin, 540 West 26th Street, (212) 255-2923 (through July 11). Mr. Suh's full-scale re-creation of his vacant New York apartment, including outer hallway and stairs leading to a nonexistent second story, is a wonderful blend of the mundane and the miraculous. From a distance, it is a ghost house, with translucent walls, stairs, doors, and kitchen and bathroom fixtures all made from sheer, slightly metallic blue, green and purple nylon. Inside you discover that everything from the door hinges to the toilet has been realized with loving attention to detail (Johnson).

* KARA WALKER, Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, (212) 929-2262 (through July 25). Ittakes an unflinching surrealistic imagination to get a grip on American history, the psychic legacy of slavery in particular. This inspiring exhibition of works on paper proves that Ms. Walker has what it takes. Drawing with seemingly effortless spontaneity and an uncanny knack for cartoon ventriloquism, she illuminates primitive and obscene fantasies lurking in the shadows of the American collective unconscious (Johnson).

CHUCK WEBSTER, "Plenty," ZieherSmith, 531 West 25th Street, (212) 229-1088 (through Aug. 8). Mr. Webster's playful semiabstract compositions, painted and drawn with brusque immediacy on small, distressed pieces of paper, include mandalas, crystalline fields, frames within frames, circulating sperms, bodily organs, spirals, glowing discs and other metaphysically suggestive motifs. Tacked up edge to edge and running almost all the way around the gallery, 163 of these pictures create an engaging, diaristic visual journey (Johnson).

"WORKS ON PAPER," Marvelli Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through July 12). Each artist in this fine show brings to paper a distinctive intensity: Dean Smith accumulates tiny, radiating pencil marks into iconic floral images; Guy Hindley draws crystalline topographical visions on Mylar; Andrea Frank paints trees and animals in washes of extreme delicacy; Tim Maxwell generates swirling cosmologies out of miniaturistically detailed fragments; Nicolas Touron draws sweet, small, surrealistic cartoons; and Kurt Lightner presents a patchy collage of shimmering color and light (Johnson).

JOHN ZINSSER: "BIBLE STUDIES"; DAVID MAISEL: "THE LAKE PROJECT PHOTOGRAPHS," Von Lintel Gallery, 555 West 25th Street, (212) 242-0599 (through July 12). Using only two colors, but working them to gorgeous effect, John Zinsser has produced a group of same-size nonobjective paintings loosely based on the 1960's Abstract Expressionism heritage. To a ground layer of enamel, he applies oil paint by different methods: brush, squeegee, palette knife. The enamel often shows through, producing what he calls a duochrome effect. The paintings are a lot about paint for paint's sake, but they are not without spiritual associations, justifying their Biblical titles. In another room, David Maisel also creates abstract imagery, with the aid of a camera and a cooperative reach of arid, eroded land called Owens Valley in California. His aerial photos of the colorful geological mayhem there have the force of abstract paintings (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

"- NOT(PAINTING) : EXTENDING THE FIELD," Ise Cultural Foundation, 555 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 925-1649 (through July 19). This group show organized by Koan-Jeff Baysa is about painting, but there is no actual paint in sight. Margaret Evangeline shoots holes with a gun through steel panels; Gyoko Yoshida inserts wood stretchers into silk organdy bags; Habib Kheradyar deals in fabric and moire effects; Kunie Sugiura's photographic works were made by leaving live chickens on sheets of photographic paper overnight; Monica Castillo's video records a ballet dancer spilling paint all over herself; and Emma Dewing composes a 21-foot-long wall work out of feathery splashes of cooled molten pewter (Johnson).

CINDY WORKMAN, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through Aug. 1). With found cartoons, comic book imagery and abstract elements dissonantly layered over pornographic photographs from the 1950's and 60's, Ms. Workman's large inkjet prints, laminated to sheets of transparent plastic, are curiously reminiscent of David Salle's early paintings. In contrast to his misogynistic gloom, however, her works offer an insouciantly feminist take on sex and power (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"BLINKY," Foxy Productions, 129 Bedford Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 218-9016 (through July 13). Visions of pop culture past and of utopias to come run through a group show at this storefront gallery. The artist team called A Constructed World offers painting of an extraterrestrial phenomenon, and Sarah Ciraci photographs of buildings, lifting off like spaceships. A jittery spaciness emanates from a video by the collective Paper Rad, which transformed Gumby cartoons into a narrative of apocalyptic danger and deliverance, while the work of Cory Arcangel, a member of the collective Beige, turns hacked versions of 1980's video games into beautiful little abstract videos that pulse to an electronic beat (Cotter).

* "THE NEW WORLD'S OLD WORLD: PHOTOGRAPHIC VIEWS OF ANCIENT AMERICA," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through July 19). From the mid-19th-century onward, photography played many roles in the frontier territories of North and South America: as a scientific instrument, a surveillance device, a definer of cultural identity and an aesthetic form. This beautiful show documents those uses and offers a sustained meditation on the shadow play of picture-taking and politics (Cotter).

"NOT NEUTRAL: CONTEMPORARY SWISS PHOTOGRAPHY," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through July 19). It is not a good sign when an exhibition appears to be contradicted by its title, but so it is with this gathering of photo-based work by nine artists born or living in Switzerland. Although beaming with competence and impressively diverse, nearly everything operates comfortably within the well-defined borders of received ideas (Smith).

BILL SAYLOR, "Softail-Project," Leo Koenig, 249 Centre Street, TriBeCa, (212) 334-9255 (through July 26). Abstraction Expressionism meets outlaw motorcycle gang culture in Mr. Saylor's bracingly ugly canvases. He paints winged skulls, charging sharks and a bear wrestling an octopus with impulsive gestures in dirty as well as garish colors. Best is the sculpture in the back room -- a standing, life-size polar bear with a wooden leg and a mystic third eye (Johnson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A large detail from an untitled piece by Kara Walker, on view with selections of her works on paper at the Brent Sikkema gallery in Chelsea. (Brent Sikkema NYC); "Autumn Colors at Jinling," by Mu Xin, at the Asia Society. (Rosenkranz Foundation)

HEADLINE: Toiling to Keep The Song Alive 

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
Two weeks ago the singer Paloma put on an all-black outfit -- bell-bottoms, a long-sleeved mesh of fishnet and a top emblazoned with an image of the Virgin of Guadalupe -- and headed to her Friday night gig at Guadalajara de Noche, a tiny Mexican restaurant under the No. 7 elevated line along Roosevelt Avenue in Queens. 
 That Sunday, Consuelo Santiago, the Mexican immigrant known as Paloma, left her Queens apartment to do a very different kind of work: cleaning other people's houses. Singing and cleaning are just two of the ways this 23-year-old cobbles together a living for herself and her 7-year-old daughter, Jennifer. She also designs outfits for other Mexican singers, and recently has looked into starting a home-based catering business. 
 Making a living as a musician in the restaurants where Latino immigrants eat in Queens, the New York borough with the most foreign-born residents, is not easy. Moonlighting is nothing new to struggling musicians, but whereas struggling American-born and educated musicians might have day jobs as office workers or waiters, these singers typically work in low-end immigrant jobs: cleaning houses, washing dishes, delivering packages. 
With the economy sputtering, neither their day jobs nor their night gigs are stable. Restaurant owners along Roosevelt Avenue -- the main immigrant strip that shifts from Ecuadorean to Irish to Filipino to Colombian to Mexican in a matter of miles -- say business is drastically slower than it was just a few years ago. Many restaurants have canceled their live entertainment, forcing local musicians to seek jobs farther away from home or simply to give up music altogether. 
Of those who still work, many lead double lives, spending weekdays in the lower echelons of the New York labor market and evenings and weekends as entertainers. The families whose houses she cleans, said Ms. Santiago, know nothing of her singing career. "I don't like to tell them," she said. "I have wanted to when I get mad, but no."
Guadalajara de Noche is a long and narrow place, an unwieldy layout for live entertainment. The small stage, about 6 feet by 2 feet, is crammed between the bar in front and the tables in the back. The Jackson Heights restaurant attracts the kind of crowd that thins at the end of the month as rent comes due. It is usually a mixture of couples and families, and at the bar, a familiar Roosevelt Avenue scene: tired Mexican men, back from some laborious and underpaid job, drinking Coronas and looking melancholy.

Sad songs
The karaoke-style sound system Paloma uses for her Tex-Mex music is set for what might be called stereophonic echo chamber, incongruously making her seem as if she is welcoming a crowd of thousands to an arena rather than a dozen or so to a cozy restaurant. Her favorite songs are sad ones, like "La Tequilera," about a woman who drowns her sorrows with tequila, and she does a lot of Selena covers. 
As in many such places, customers with some singing ability occasionally ask to take the stage. Paloma is also spelled and, to some extent, upstaged by her daughter, who wears a matching outfit, and though she spends part of her mother's performance playing with a set of "Finding Nemo" stickers, Jennifer takes the stage with aplomb. If anything, she is more energetic than Paloma, perhaps because her diminutive size gives her some room to prance around the tiny stage.
The next evening, seven blocks away on Roosevelt Avenue, the band members of Embajada Musical plays accordion-heavy, polka-inspired Mexican norteno music in the Azteca Restaurant, as they do every Saturday and Sunday. The show starts at 10, but on this evening the only customer in the room at that time was a thin, white-haired man sitting at the bar in a Maradona soccer shirt and Yankees sweat pants. The 15 tables covered in pink tablecloths and adorned with fake flowers were empty.
Unfazed, Santos Lopez and his band, mostly restaurant workers by day, directed their high-volume show to the Maradona fan, the bartender and three blank-faced uniformed waitresses. Nearly an hour later, there were still only nine people in the restaurant.
Then, literally at the 11th hour, in a whoosh of perfume, a group of a dozen celebrating their friend's birthday swept in, and the place suddenly came alive. The waitresses kicked into gear, taking their drink orders of Corona and Negra Modelo. When the band diverged from its Mexican repertory to strike up a recent Colombian hit, "El Hijo de Tuta," in which a worker disparages the undeserved good fortune of his arrogant boss, everyone got up to dance.

Worrying About the Rent
The band members can relate. When they are not making music, they mostly work in low-paying restaurant jobs, washing dishes or busing tables. Mr. Lopez lost what had been a steady job when the Dew Drop Inn restaurant in Greenwich Village closed, and since then he has scraped together enough to support his girlfriend and child taking whatever temporary jobs he can, and repairing the occasional accordion.
It is a tricky task to run a band under such circumstances. "It's difficult when you work somewhere else and you have to learn new songs," he said in an interview during a break. "We can't rehearse. Our schedules don't let us."
Members have frequently dropped out. "People are always worrying about the rent," he said. "Sometimes they lose their job and it becomes necessary for them to leave the group to look for work. They come and go, come and go. That's why it's difficult to progress in music."
Natives, a huge Colombian restaurant less than a mile away on Northern Boulevard, has music almost all day on weekends. Last month, on Father's Day afternoon, Fabio Marquez (on the guitar) and Manolo Rodriguez (on the banjo), who bill themselves as Duo Internacional, were serenading tables. They alternated sets with Sofia Alvarez, a manicurist at nearby Northern Nail on weekdays who roamed the floor with a wireless mike, singing ranchera music over the restaurantwide sound system. 
Like Ms. Alvarez, they do not make a solid living through music, although both used to, Mr. Rodriguez in Venezuela and Mr. Marquez in Colombia. Mr. Rodriguez, who is 62, now counts on his family for support, but even so, he recently started a one-man company, Silver Cup Window Cleaning. When Mr. Marquez came to New York 17 years ago, a friend got him a job with a jeweler in Manhattan, and he supplemented his income playing in restaurants all weekend, often until 4 a.m. He lost his day job at the end of last year. When his wife died unexpectedly in April, he could not afford to miss playing guitar the next day.
Mr. Marquez and Mr. Rodriguez stroll the restaurant, waiting for tables to call them over and request songs. "Peruvians come here, Argentines, Colombians, even Americans, and you have to have a repertory for everyone," Mr. Marquez said during a break. "People ask for songs from their country. It brings back memories of when they were dating." At the table of Jose Alberto Ospina and Luzdary Gordaliza, who were with their two children, Mr. Ospina requested "Mi Negra" for his wife. "It's a song I have always dedicated to her," he said. 
It is not unusual for a client to ask the duo to leave the restaurant and serenade a girlfriend or a family member at their home, and the managers of Natives permit the pair to leave and return after such missions.

Stevie Wonder, Sort Of
Another group of Queens-based minstrels is the Mariachi Tequila Azul. Several local restaurants hire mariachi bands, the crowd-pleasing uniformed troubadours, including Guadalajara de Noche. Tequila Azul, however, no longer has a regular gig in Queens. Although its musicians work late nights at El Gran Rancho Jubilee, a Dominican restaurant in the East Elmhurst section near La Guardia Airport, most of their work is outside the city. On Monday and Tuesday nights, when they play at El Bandido restaurant in Spring Valley, N.Y., the audience could not be more different from the typical crowd in Queens. That restaurant caters to a suburban crowd, as evidenced by the pinatas hanging from the ceiling and its faux Mission decor. 
That calls for an adjustment in music. Instead of crooning the romantic mariachi classics Latin Americans would expect, they play recognizable tunes like "La Bamba," "Oye Como Va" and, of course, the Champs' oldie "Tequila." They are popular, even though they bungle the lyrics of "Margaritaville" or know just one line of a Stevie Wonder hit. (Their version: "I just called to say I love you/I just called to say I love you.")
After their weekend gigs in Stony Point, N.Y., they have recently been making late-night stops in Queens at El Gran Rancho Jubilee. There, they return to the Latin classics, fielding requests for songs from artists like Pepe Aguilar, Vicente Fernandez and Marco Antonio Solis.
Those late nights can be especially difficult for Marcos Trujillo, 25, who plays two string instruments, the guitarron and the vihuela. When the band plays until late, he heads straight to his seven-day-a-week job delivering newspapers starting at 4 a.m. He is not often well rested. "Sometimes you sleep on the road," he said in an interview in the Queens apartment he shares with the group's leader, Wilson Moreno, and several others. "Sometimes you sleep two hours in the day and two hours in the night. Sometimes, when there's not that much work, you sleep five hours."
Mr. Moreno delivers packages for Dynamex. His irregular schedule also gets to him, but at least he can still make music the way he did back home. "There is no other alternative here," he said.
"It must be difficult if one is married," he added. "But I don't have that problem."
Actually, Mr. Moreno does have a wife and three children -- in Ecuador. He sends them at least $800 a month, leaving himself just enough to pay the rent, car insurance and food. 
Like so many immigrants, Mr. Moreno is torn between providing for his children by sending dollars from New York or moving back home to watch them grow up. His oldest child is 16. Recently he has been leaning toward heading home, so El Bandido may soon need a new mariachi group, and Dynamex may have a vacancy for a deliveryman.
"In this country there is a lot of money," he said. "But happiness is not in money." For the present, though, he is grateful for the work. "It's an independent job where you are your own boss," he said, "and they pay us for what we like to do." 
The other singers echoed Mr. Moreno's words: while they wish they could do better financially, they were happy to have a place to perform and glad to make some extra money doing it, especially during difficult economic times. 
Paloma took the long view. "For me, it's something that helps me get ahead for my daughter," she said. "She wants to be in ballet or maybe in karate. And this is something that I've always liked doing."

Spanish Serenades Are a Side Order

Many immigrant musicians from Queens who play restaurants at night have much less glamorous work during the day. A sampling of those musicians performing this weekend in Queens:

PALOMA. At Guadalajara de Noche, 85-09 Roosevelt Avenue, between 85th and 86th Streets, Jackson Heights, (718) 397-9666, every Friday night, 9 to 11.

EMBAJADA MUSICAL. At Azteca Restaurant, 92-01 Roosevelt Avenue, at 92nd Street, Jackson Heights, (718) 672-7373, tomorrow night and Sunday, beginning at 10 p.m.

DUO INTERNACIONAL. At Natives Restaurant, 82-22 Northern Boulevard, at 83rd Street, Jackson Heights, (718) 335-0780, tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday, 7 p.m. to 1 a.m.

MARIACHI TEQUILA AZUL. At El Gran Rancho Jubilee, 23-04 94th Street, at 23rd Avenue, East Elmhurst, (718) 335-1700, Sunday, beginning at 10 p.m. (They may also perform here after midnight tonight and tomorrow.)

GRAPHIC: Photos: Wilson Moreno, left, and Jose Matamoros of Mariachi Tequila Azul, who are to play in Queens this weekend. (Lucian M. Read for The New York Times)(pg. E1); The singer Paloma with her 7-year-old daughter, Jennifer, at Guadalajara de Noche in Queens. (Lucian M. Read for The New York Times)(pg. E4) Map of Queens highlighting points of interest. (pg. HEADLINE: Graduates Hope They, and Liberia, Have a Future 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 1 

 BODY:
It was a glorious Tuesday morning last week, said Winston C. Holt, who was in the soccer stadium in downtown Monrovia amid a sea of grinning would-be college graduates in shimmering black caps and gowns. Their proud parents clutched camcorders and flowers.
 The occasion was commencement for the class of 2003 of the African Methodist Episcopal University. About an hour into the program, as Mr. Holt, an economics major, was listening to a guest preacher speak about facing the future, an explosion in the distance announced the first mortars. 
 "Boom boom boom," was the sound Mr. Holt said he heard. Cellphones began trilling with calls from friends outside. Mothers and fathers began fidgeting in their seats. Some got up and left. The explosions got closer and closer. 
The capital was under attack once more. In the next two and a half days, several hundred Monrovians died.
The deaths were nothing new. The class of 2003 has grown up during 20 years of off-and-on war in a failed state now run by an accused war criminal, in a country so poor that it does not even rank on the United Nations Human Development Index for 2002.
Yet as their country disintegrates and President Bush considers sending American forces here as peacekeepers, young middle-class Liberians continue, remarkably, to dream of a better future.
"You have to be educated," declared Mr. Holt, 26, who graduated that morning with a 3.0 grade point average. "You never know what could come your way.'
Striving under these circumstances requires not just pluck, but an appreciation of the absurd.
And so Mr. Holt attended lectures in development economics, his favorite subject, in a country where the president's son drives a custom-made Mercedes 4x4 while babies starve to death.
Mr. Holt's classmate Famatta Sanoe, 25, wants to work in a bank, in a city where the banks are shuttered because of gunfights between government and rebel forces.
Their friend and fellow graduate Benjamin Tulay, 24, wants to pursue a graduate degree -- in public finance, he thinks. But this is a country where government militias are accused of robbing ordinary citizens of cars, rice and cash as compensation for unpaid salaries.
In fact, just the other night Mr. Holt's father, the Rev. George Franklin Holt Sr., managed to keep his attackers at bay only by calling an old friend and fellow Freemason, Defense Minister Daniel Chea. Today bullet holes dimple the black gate of the Holt residence. Above is a handmade sign, etched lovingly last week by Winston Holt's nephew. "Congratulations Mr. Winston C. Holt," it reads, "for a job well done."
Liberia was founded more than 150 years ago by black Americans, and until recently, all through the cold war years, it was among Washington's staunchest African allies. Today it is best known as the epicenter of chaos in West Africa, a breeding ground for drugged-out mercenaries in wigs who range the region spreading disorder.
But the Liberia you see at A.M.E. University is of a different order. Accounting is the university's most popular major. Economics is popular too.
"I guess because our economy is so bad," Ms. Sanoe said breezily.
Case in point: during a two-day period this week, after the bullets stopped flying, the price of gasoline fell from $8.70 a gallon to its normal price of $3.62. The price of a enough marijuana for a joint remained unchanged -- less than $5.
Hardest of all in this mess is planning ahead. Ms. Sanoe, for instance, was planning to take a job application test at one of Monrovia's principal banks this month. Now she has no idea ifthe exam will be held.
Mr. Tulay was planning to apply for fall classes at the University of Liberia. Now he does not know when registration will begin. "We have a plan and the next day it's all shot off," he said.
Mr. Holt, for his part, was counting on a friend in the United States who had offered to help him continue his studies at an American college in exchange for his services as a church organist. Mr. Holt says he has not heard from the friend in quite some time. Being a practical sort, he is considering trying his luck in Ghana instead.
His father, a high school principal whose classrooms now shelter displaced people, has reluctantly offered his blessings. "Those who are ambitious, those that want to better themselves, those that want to continue their education, they have to leave," his father confided. "There's no room for them right here."
"I know he has a future," he said of his son. "We are praying to God to make a way for him."
In the face of Liberia's disintegration, the A.M.E. University is itself a symbol of determined adaptation. Classes are held inside a half-finished building that looks more like a abandoned construction site than a temple of higher learning, with piles of sand in the courtyard and rainwater flooding the corridors. The building once housed the Rev. Holt's high school, also supported by the A.M.E. Church in the United States. It was demolished in the war in 1990.
This time around, a mortar shell fell on a church office next door, pocking its mustard-colored walls with shrapnel. Worse, the college administration building, including the president's office, was ransacked. Computers, typewriters, petty cash and college souvenirs were stolen. The other day, Winston Holt saw militias roaming through downtown Monrovia in A.M.E. University T-shirts.
David Parker, the school's general services administrator, said he had not yet been able to tally the cost of the damage. He prays that vandals spared the computer diskettes on which university records are stored. The president, Dr. Louise C. York, was so rattled by the latest events that she said she was not speaking to anyone, "except God."
The latest fighting, between forces loyal to the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, and his rebel enemies, turned the school's year-end plans upside down. The baccalaureate ceremony, originally scheduled for earlier in June, was canceled because rebels advanced toward the capital.
Bishop Richard Franklin Norris of Philadelphia, who was to deliver the commencement address, was forced to cancel his trip.
Then, with a cease-fire in place and calm returning to the capital, commencement exercises were set.
But the promise of Tuesday morning lasted only an hour. Shortly after the program began, so too did the mortar shelling and machine-gun fire. No one knew where it was coming from, or from how nearby. But everyone knew that the rebels were making a second bid to take the city.
Students stirred in their seats. Some stepped outside to see what was happening. "You're still in there?" Ms. Sanoe's friends shouted over her cellphone. "They're coming. Get out of there. Get home."
What kind of commencement would this be, Mr. Holt wondered.
"Hearing those sounds, it was not encouraging," he said. "That day, you should be happy. Even some of the parents, they started to leave. They couldn't stand the tension."
The class of 2003 stayed put. They forced the rambling guest speaker to cut his speech short. They waited for the university president to call the names of 185 graduates. A benediction was read. Pictures were snapped. The band played a gospel song, "My God Will Do It."
The gunfire kept getting closer.
"We needed that degree," Ms. Sanoe said of their decision to stay. "We deserved it so bad."
Diplomas in hand, the class of 2003, the hardiest of their friends and family at their sides, streamed out of the stadium. People filed through downtown with mattresses on their heads and terror in their eyes, not knowing in which direction lay safety. 
Graduates who lived on Monrovia's west side, where fighting raged most intensely, had no way of getting home. Mr. Holt still has not heard from most of them.
That night there were no graduation parties. "We couldn't go anywhere," Mr. Holt said. "People just came home and listened to heavy artillery."

HEADLINE: Legal Reprieve For Wall Street Is Not Likely To Last Long 

BYLINE:  By LANDON THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Judge Milton Pollack's summary dismissal this week of three investor suits against Merrill Lynch has been embraced by an investment banking industry battered by years of litigation and criticism over its research practices.
 Bank executives quietly concede, though, that the decision is not likely to have a significant impact on the many arbitration cases in which investors aim to prove that they relied on fraudulent stock research when they incurred their losses. 
 Judge Pollack bluntly declared that it was the collapse of the Internet bubble that caused investor losses and not research analysts like Henry Blodget, Merrill Lynch's former Internet analyst. The ancient notion of caveat emptor was reaffirmed and by no less a legal authority than Judge Pollack, a 96-year-old judicial titan who has been handling complex securities law issues since the 1930's. 
Less noticed amid the excitement was that Judge Pollack appeared to be knocking down a straw man in throwing out the Merrill Lynch suits. Legal experts and analysts are in wide agreement that the class-action suits brought against Merrill Lynch were surprisingly frivolous: the investors were not clients of the firm and they did not make the case that they relied on Merrill Lynch's research when they made their investment decisions. 
Many of the plaintiffs were online investors, seeking short-term gains on volatile and risky stocks like 24/7 and Interliant.
A large number of other arbitration cases aim to show that clients of Merrill Lynch and other brokerage houses relied on analyst research in making their decisions.
Nowhere in his decision does Judge Pollack address this investor class, which, analysts say, has experienced billions of dollars of losses during the stock market collapse.
"These suits were an embarrassment, and Merrill should indeed be pleased," said E. Reilly Tierney, a brokerage analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton. "But what he didn't do was make clear what the threshold for reliance was."
E-mail evidence showing that Mr. Blodget and Jack B. Grubman, Salomon Smith Barney's former telecommunications analyst, disparaged the stocks they covered and acknowledged the influence of investment bankers on their research has spurred an increase in arbitration suits -- many of which are also considered frivolous. 
Arbitration lawyers say that there are many cases pending that clearly show that investors who were clients of investment banks relied on the research of Mr. Grubman and Mr. Blodget in making their investments. To make their case, they said, they plan to produce e-mail in which investors discuss the research with brokers, proof of quantifiable losses, and the research itself.
"I have a number of cases where there is clear evidence that investors relied on research," said Jacob H. Zamansky, an arbitration lawyer in New York who gained notice by winning a $400,000 claim against Merrill Lynch in 2001. "As long as you can show you are a customer of the firm and that you relied on its research, you should be able to win in arbitration. What the Pollack decision will do is weed out all the bad cases."
Arbitration suits have soared in the wake of the stock market crash. Through May, cases filed before NASD, which handles 90 percent of arbitration disputes, have increased 22 percent from the same period last year, and a growing number are now claiming that fraudulent research from firms like Merrill Lynch and Salomon Smith Barney caused clients of these firms to lose money.
Analysts estimate that arbitration and other civil litigation cases will eventually cost the big investment banks billions of dollars.
To be sure, lawyers for the investment banks will brandish the Pollack decision with gusto when they argue their cases in coming arbitration cases -- just as lawyers for investors have leaned on the e-mail evidence arising from the investigation into tainted research at Wall Street firms by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general.
And when arguing a case against a client who claimed to have read Mr. Blodget's research cover to cover, bank lawyers will point to the section of Judge Pollack's decision stating, "Blodget's opinions of possible future stock performance were replete with risk warnings of the potential that the stock price could drop significantly."
Still, by agreeing to settle with regulators this April, the banks with a big network of individual customers, like Merrill and Citigroup, have tacitly agreed to the claims made by regulators that some of the research they issued during the boom was fraudulent, even though they neither admitted to nor denied such accusations.
As long as arbitration lawyers can prove that their clients relied on fraudulent research, they have a chance to win cases, Judge Pollack's decision notwithstanding.
In fact, the ruling made no mention of whether Merrill's research was fraudulent. The judge's point, instead, was that even if the research was fraudulent, the plaintiffs could not prove that their losses were tied to the research because they were not Merrill Lynch clients.
The investors needed to demonstrate that they had relied on Merrill's research.
"Judge Pollack emphasizes that if there had been reliance, it would have been a very different case," said Alan R. Bromberg, a professor of securities law at Southern Methodist University. "For people who can prove that they relied on Merrill's research, they may have a case. But to say that I bought Blodget's stock after reading his research is not enough. Ultimately, a jury will have to decide: did you rely, and if you did, did you reasonably rely?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judge Milton Pollack has affirmed the notion of caveat emptor. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: Subway Cars' Last Stop: Under Sea, Not Ground 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: CAPE MAY, N.J., July 3 

 BODY:
The hollowed hulks of 50 obsolete New York City subway cars were dumped into the Atlantic Ocean off South Jersey today to begin a watery new life as a haven for fish.
 The 50-foot cars, known as Redbirds and long the workhorses of New York's numbered subway lines, became the latest and largest additions to a man-made artificial reef about eight miles off Cape May. 
 Bradley M. Campbell, New Jersey's environmental commissioner, seemed ecstatic after spending about 90 minutes watching a steam shovel push the dull-red hulks off a barge into about 70 feet of water. They all sank in seconds. 
"This is the biggest enhancement of our artificial reef system in one stroke," he said. "This is a win for New Jersey's fishermen, a win for the shore economy and a win for the marine environment because we're enhancing fish habitat."
Mr. Campbell expressed none of the misgivings about asbestos in the old cars that two years ago prompted the state to reject New York City's offer of 650 Redbirds. New York State passed on a similar offer. But New Jersey leaders have since changed their minds, and are eager to use the cars. Over the next two months, four more New Jersey reefs will each receive 50 of the cars.
Recreational and commercial fishermen extolled the subway cars as welcome additions to the artificial reefs, which are piles of old Army tanks and armored personnel carriers, tons of concrete and other construction debris, and scrap steel. The reefs first attract mussels, barnacles and tiny plants. Then sea bass, tautog and flounder come to feed on them. Later, bigger game fish, sometimes tuna and sharks, arrive.
Fishermen say the reefs, like all underwater structures, teem with marine life and become a boon to their hobbies and livelihood. 
New York City Transit called ocean disposal the cheapest and easiest way to get rid of the 40-year-old Redbirds.
Yet some jitters about asbestos in the cars linger. New York State, for instance, has passed up a chance to obtain 650 Redbirds for the 11 reefs it has built off Long Island since 1962. The state's Department of Environmental Conservation is still not convinced the asbestos is safe for marine life.
"There's conflicting opinion on whether the cars are safe or desirable," said Matt Burns, a spokesman for the department. "Our first choice is to use more benign materials."
Mr. Campbell, New Jersey's environmental commissioner, said he was satisfied the asbestos would not harm the environment. He said he based his opinion in part on a 2002 study by the federal Environmental Protection Agency that found that ocean disposal of the cars was safe.
That study was issued about a year after New Jersey's acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, rejected the offer of 650 cars for the reefs, citing concerns about the asbestos.
Asked today why the state had reversed its position, Mr. Campbell said, "We took a closer look at the science and we weighed the interests of our saltwater anglers more heavily, and then we struck a more balanced approach."
David Ross, the New York City Transit official overseeing disposal of the Redbirds, said the agency was satisfied the asbestos would not pose problems. "In the water, it doesn't have any health hazard at all," Mr. Ross said as he watched the old cars, one by one, sink into the ocean.
The asbestos, he said, is embedded in an epoxy substance in the floor tiles of the cars and between their exterior and interior walls. The substance was used for insulation, soundproofing and fire retardation. Mr. Ross said New York City Transit was satisfied the epoxy would remain intact, with the asbestos lodged in it, for decades in the ocean.
He said rocks in the ocean naturally contain asbestos. If any ever escapes from the epoxy, he said, it will be little different from asbestos getting loose from ocean rocks.
The Environmental Protection Agency study Mr. Campbell cited dealt with four New York subway cars dumped on an artificial reef off Delaware last year, and five others from Philadelphia's mass transit system placed on an artificial reef off Sea Girt, N.J., in 1990. The study's author, William Muir, an E.P.A. oceanographer, said he studied ocean water in and around the nine cars and found that asbestos levels did not exceed naturally occurring background levels at the two sites.
He also said that laboratory testing he performed on the epoxy from the subway cars shows that it did not dissolve, convincing him that there was little likelihood it would break up in the ocean.
The cars dumped offshore today were stripped of all doors, windows, hand grips, signs, wheels, engines, and oil and grease, Mr. Ross said.
"Anything you don't want in the ocean we take off," he said.
Nearly 1,000 of the Redbirds have already been dumped in the last two years on artificial reefs off four other Atlantic Coast states. Delaware got 567, while 200 went to South Carolina, 150 to Virginia and 50 to Georgia, Mr. Ross said.
New York City Transit has only about 100 Redbirds left, Mr. Ross said, and they will go to museums or serve as work trains in the subway system. Cleaning and ocean disposal of the 1,200 cars will cost Mew York City Transit about $16 million, he said, half the estimated cost of cutting up the cars and burying them.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 4 about the placement of 50 obsolete New York subway cars in the ocean off Cape May, N.J., to enlarge an artificial reef misidentified the equipment used to push them off a barge. It was a diesel-powered hydraulic excavator with a backhoe attachment, not a steam shovel.
