HEADLINE: French Exchange Students Get the Cold Shoulder 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
First it was French wines. Then French fries. Now it's French exchange students who are getting the cold shoulder from American families still smarting over France's opposition to the war in Iraq.
 Program coordinators and others say that the drooping economy, global tensions and the recent outbreak of SARS have all cut into the summer ritual of students from various countries spending the summer in American homes. 
 But the programs that seem to have it worst are those selling Americans on the virtues of taking home a little bit of France this summer. 
"This has been a horrible year," said Deborah Bertrand, the New York area manager for Loisirs Culturels a L'Etranger, a not-for-profit exchange program based in Paris. "Usually I have no problem finding host families. The only thing I can attribute it to is the anti-French feeling going on because of the Iraq war. My coordinators all up and down the East Coast are having the same problem."
Each year, L.E.C., as the program is known in France, signs up several hundred French teenagers whose parents have paid dearly for them to come to the United States for a summer tradition that has endured for more than three decades. But this year, even though the number of prospective visitors is one-quarter what it once was, the program has yet to find host families for nearly half the 250 teenagers who signed up.
The first wave began arriving on Monday, and unless homes can be found quickly, four Boston-bound teenagers in that group will get refunds instead of trips. At least 100 participants in the program who expected to come in August are also in limbo.
" 'Not this year' is what I hear a lot," said Mary Lou Church, an L.E.C. recruiter in Portsmouth, R.I., who is taking extra students into her own home this year rather than turn them away. "This year, with everything that happened with the war, people locally have just taken it personally. When I ask them, 'Would you open your home to a French teenager?' they look at me like, 'Are you out of your mind? Why would we, when they've been so ungiving to us?' "
Hers is one of the few programs in the Northeast that pays $100 to families to cover groceries and incidentals. So she believes that the economy is an unlikely culprit. "I start talking about exchange programs and they say, 'Great.' And when I say they're all from France, end of conversation."
Maybe not here, but in France they are still talking about "the little incident of Carcassonne," as Daniele Thomas Easton, the French honorary consul, put it. A group of 15 students from that city in southwestern France had planned to visit the United States in August at the invitation of the Springside School, a private girls' school in Philadelphia. After four American host families pulled out, the school retracted the invitation, suspending an informal exchange program that has existed since 1976.
When the incident was reported in the European press in June, the French Embassy in Washington interceded, and enough new families stepped forward in the Philadelphia area to receive 10 teenagers after all.
The strained hospitality is hardly one-way. In France in recent weeks, spectators at sporting events have jeered American athletes and renditions of "The Star-Spangled Banner," and one exchange program that sends Americans to France -- A.F.S. Intercultural Programs in New York -- said its French-bound program took longer to fill this year. Nonetheless, program coordinators say, French host families do not seem to be refusing American students who make the trip.
There is no precise count for the number of French students who enter the United States each summer on tourist visas. Nearly 100 organizations are members of the Council on Standards for International Educational Travel, with many of the largest handling anywhere from 300 to 500 French students each. At a minimum, that suggests that a few thousand French students a year head this way for short stays.
The harsh economy, terrorism and the outbreak of SARS have made finding host families a challenge, according to John Hishmeh, the council's executive director. But globalization, the Internet and cheap airline travel, he said, have conspired in another way as well. "Having a foreign student is no longer a novelty in a lot of communities," he said.
Ms. Bertrand, a Syracuse woman who is L.E.C.'s coordinator for New York and parts of Connecticut, said that most years she has been allowed to make pitches to French classes at five area high schools. This year, she said, only one school granted access. Ads in church bulletins drew little response, and appeals to local newspapers went ignored, she said.
She finally became so exasperated that she drafted an open letter to prospective hosts that was more cri de coeur than letters from the lovelorn.
It started with, "What is wrong with central New York people?" It ran in The Post-Standard in Syracuse, and in slightly altered form -- lambasting "Connecticut people" -- in The Advocate in Stamford, Conn.
"Are we so self-serving that we've lost touch with the true meaning of America?" it went on. "Are our lives so busy that we can't open our hearts and homes to children who want to learn about our culture? Or perhaps we're still in the anti-French mind-set?"
Though it was not the response she hoped for, her letter drew an immediate reply from John Vogler, a retired machine operator in Syracuse. "Where was France when we needed its support to back us in the war on terrorism against Iraq?" he wrote to his local newspaper. "As far as keeping Franco-American friendship alive, it died six months ago."
In a telephone interview, he added: 'That would be the last kid I'd want to take in right now. They can keep their wine and cheese. They'd all be speaking German if it weren't for us."
Things were not much friendlier in southern Connecticut, where L.E.C. also recruits. Wilfrid Malonga, the program's coordinator in Stamford, was so irked by the poor response he was getting that he altered his pitch. His new solicitations sought families who might be interested in being host to a "European" student, with no mention of the fact that the students happened to be French. He said he got more calls, but no takers once details were given.
"Two years ago, I was just inundated," said Mr. Malonga. "I had to select families. Now it's kind of slow." As a native Parisian, he says, he is trying hard not to take the backlash against all things French personally, as he hopes the students in France are doing. "They have nothing to do with the political situation in France, and they are admirers of this country," he said.
Jeremy Ahier, 17, one of the teenagers from Carcassonne who will be in Philadelphia in August, said through an interpreter that he was "most interested in learning more about the Amish." A friend who will be joining him on the trip, Pierre Robin, 17, said he wanted to visit museums and take in a baseball game.
Roland Stern, the managing director of L.E.C. in Paris, said that in years like this one, outreach programs mean more than ever.
Linda Alario, a lawyer who talked her husband into opening their home in Syracuse this year to a French student named Sandra LeClair, said: "I thought this is the year to do it. When the war began, so many people reacted as though the French did not have the right to express their opinion."
And when all else fails, the recruiters are recruiting one another. Late last week, Ms. Church, the Rhode Island recruiter, and her husband, a tugboat operator, bailed out the program when they agreed to receive Sebastien Plantet, a young man from Versailles who arrived on Sunday but had nowhere to go.
Ms. Thomas Easton, the honorary French consul in Philadelphia, expressed confidence that any French teenagers who made it to America this summer would not be disappointed. In the end, she said, they want what every teenager around the world wants, and will find it here.
"They want to be away from Mom and Dad for a while," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sandra LeClair, center, newly arrived from France, meets her host family in Syracuse: Jack Garofolo; his wife, Linda Alario, right; and their daughter Katie. Sandra, an exchange student, will visit for three weeks. (Kevin Rivoli for The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: In Blazing Bonus, 2 Sets of Fireworks Are to Fly on 4th 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
People going out to watch the fireworks along the East River tonight will get a bonus: two sets of fireworks, one in Midtown and the other downtown.
 Two barges of fireworks will be stationed on the river between Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn, with the best viewing from the South Street Seaport and the Brooklyn Heights Promenade. Four more barges of fireworks will be on the river at its traditional spot, between 23rd and 42nd Streets. 
 The 30-minute show, the 27th Annual Macy's Fireworks Spectacular, will start at about 9:20 p.m., and forecasters are said to expect clear skies tonight along with high humidity and temperatures in the 80's. 
The two shows along the East River will be nearly identical. The barges, which measure 350 to 500 feet, will fire 30,000 shells, including some classic fireworks like the blooming white peonies and happy faces.
"Happy faces are a standard," said Robin Hall, the show's executive producer. "People would shoot us if we didn't do the happy faces."
Businesses in downtown Manhattan, still coping with the aftereffects of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack and the sluggish economy, are hoping the fireworks will increase sales. 
"It'll bring throngs of people to Lower Manhattan," Carl Weisbrod, president of the Downtown Alliance, said about the fireworks.
The best place for viewing the fireworks from Manhattan will be the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Midtown and Lower Manhattan and the South Street Seaport. In Brooklyn, good viewing spots will be at the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, Empire Fulton Ferry State Park and Furman Street.
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said sections of the F.D.R. Drive below East 63rd Street would be closed to vehicle traffic after 3:30 p.m. today. In Brooklyn, Furman Street between Atlantic Avenue and Cadman Plaza West will be closed to vehicle traffic at 7 p.m. 
In Manhattan, pedestrian access to F.D.R. Drive will be limited to entrances at 23rd, 38th, 42nd and 48th Streets in Midtown after 7 p.m. There will be regular access to the drive in Lower Manhattan. The pedestrian walkways on the bridges will also be closed.
More than 4,000 police officers will be on special Fourth of July assignments, Commissioner Kelly said. That is a small reduction from the number of officers assigned last year, he said.
The police will also have 23 patrol boats on the waters, and the East River will be blocked to pleasure boats so it can be prepared for the fireworks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a Staten Island pier yesterday, workers prepared one of several barges that will stage tonight's fireworks show from two East River locations. (Mary DiBiase Blaich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Hospitals Seeking Split, Debt Is Glue 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
After a troubled marriage and a long separation, two of New York's premier academic medical centers, New York University and Mount Sinai, are moving toward outright divorce.
 But splitting up could prove just as tricky as merging. The hospitals' serious money problems present obstacles to dissolving the financial ties that still bind them, and officials say a final division probably remains years away. 
 It is no secret that the much-hailed 1998 union went bust; the medical schools and hospitals agreed in 2001 to give up on the idea and continue on their mostly separate ways. But in the last few months, they also set about severing connections in the few areas of operations they had successfully merged. 
The hospitals combined their information technology systems, but last week, they signed a 10-year, $380 million deal with I.B.M. to handle those functions -- a pact that explicitly provides for separate systems for the hospitals. The hospitals created a unified patient-billing office; recently, they have begun to take it apart. And as for the joint employee benefits function, "notice just went out to employees that it's being de-merged," said Sue Riley, chief financial officer of Mount Sinai Medical Center.
"We could, in fact, be functioning as two completely separate entities sooner than two years," she said.
Except for the debt.
After the merger, Mount Sinai and New York University Hospitals Center combined their debts, which total about $670 million. The problem, according to Wall Street analysts and hospital officials, is that they appear to be too weak, financially, to be able to redivide the debt -- which would mean refinancing -- and sever their ties.
After a series of credit downgrades, Mount Sinai N.Y.U. Health, the merged entity, is rated at the highest junk-bond status, making refinancing on its own prohibitively expensive. Hospitals often issue debt through New York State's Dormitory Authority, allowing them to pay low interest rates. But the authority requires hospitals to have at least an A- rating, several steps above Mount Sinai-N.Y.U.'s.
The Federal Housing Administration often helps troubled hospitals issue bonds, but under current rules, Mount Sinai-N.Y.U. would not qualify, because it has suffered three straight years of losses. In addition, federal tax law generally prohibits refinancing the hospitals' debt more than once during the lifetime of the debt, and most of their bonds were refinanced as part of the merger.
"Until they find a way of segregating their obligations, they can't really finalize the separation," said Bruce Gordon, a senior vice president at Moody's Investors Service. "But it isn't clear they can do that." 
Hospital officials say they plan to apply to the F.H.A. for a waiver of the usual standards and are exploring other options, including the possibility of petitioning Congress for a change in tax law.
N.Y.U. Hospitals operates on a roughly break-even basis, while Mount Sinai expects to lose about $70 million this year. N.Y.U. is especially eager to sever the connections between them, analysts and hospital officials say, and might consider unconventional steps, like paying off a significant part of its debt early, to enable a refinancing. 
An N.Y.U. Hospitals spokeswoman said the top executives of the medical center who could discuss the matter for the record were all on vacation this week and unavailable for comment. But recent developments were confirmed by other N.Y.U. officials.
"It's like you've moved out a long time ago, and now you're finally sitting down to work out divorce papers," said an N.Y.U. Hospitals trustee who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "It's a milestone even if it's no surprise. And then you find that there's no easy way to separate the financial accounts."
The view from Wall Street is that the partners are probably stuck with each other for several more years, at least. "No one feels that that's an untenable circumstance," said Dr. Kenneth Davis, president and chief executive of Mount Sinai. "We all feel that there are more important issues on each of our campuses that we're dealing with now."
Mount Sinai has taken difficult steps to improve its finances, and officials there say those measures have begun to pay off. Dr. Kenneth Berns was moved aside this year as the hospital's chief, and replaced by Dr. Davis, dean of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. The medical center has closed some outpatient clinics and eliminated 500 jobs. And after a hiatus of more than two years, it resumed advertising, at a cost that officials declined to divulge.
Dr. Davis says that after dropping sharply last year, the number of patients is up, thanks to advertising, the recruitment of new doctors, and other factors. Ms. Riley said that by the end of this year, the month-by-month profit and loss picture should be much improved.
Many hospitals in New York merged in the 1990's, hoping to gain financial strength. The results were a mixed bag -- some good, some bad, some in between. But the combination of Mount Sinai and N.Y.U is widely seen as the biggest failure.
On its face, it was a strong merger of esteemed institutions. On one side was N.Y.U. School of Medicine and N.Y.U. Hospitals Center, including the main hospital on First Avenue, N.Y.U. Downtown Hospital and the Hospital for Joint Diseases. On the other was Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Mount Sinai Medical Center, including the main hospital on Fifth Avenue, and Mount Sinai Queens.
The union fell victim to many forces, notably turf wars, as forces on each side resisted yielding autonomy.
"Politically, you couldn't have had joint department chairs overnight, or sharing of some specialties," said M. Craig Kornett, senior director at Fitch Ratings, a Wall Street bond-rating firm. "But gradually, over five or six years, you could have done it, and you could have saved a lot of money."
A stated central reason for the merger was the hospitals' prediction that they would jointly negotiate better reimbursement rates from insurance companies, but that never happened. After merging, "they said that the added leverage would not provide improved rates, and we were just perplexed by that claim," Mr. Kornett said. "It seemed like they never really tried."
Mount Sinai has had more economic trouble than N.Y.U. in part because of its longstanding commitment to treating the residents of East Harlem, including many poor patients with limited or no insurance.N.Y.U. does not do nearly as much indigent care, partly because of its location, and partly because the main hospital is next to Bellevue Hospital Center, which carries much of that burden.
Mount Sinai was also hit hard by damaging publicity last year after an organ donor involved in a partial liver transplant died. A yearlong shutdown of the transplant program followed.

HEADLINE: No Major Taxes Will Rise, but Many Pockets Are Hit 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 3 

 BODY:
As he promised, Gov. James E. McGreevey did not raise New Jersey's sales tax, income tax or any other broad-based tax in the budget fight that ended this week.
 But it may be difficult to convince many New Jerseyans that the state is not claiming more of their paychecks, particularly if they are college students, smokers, gamblers, limousine drivers, theatergoers, real estate brokers or spouses planning a divorce. 
 Tucked away in the 300 pages of the $24 billion budget for fiscal year 2004, which began on Tuesday, are an assortment of strategically targeted tax and fee increases and financing cuts that will cumulatively hit the pocketbooks of millions of New Jersey residents in some way, seen or unseen. Cuts to higher education will lead to tuition increases at state universities, and cuts in aid to arts groups are likely to bring higher ticket prices. 
Mr. McGreevey won the highly publicized battles to raise taxes on casino and billboard companies, but he also imposed less-noted fee increases on an assortment of businesses: real estate brokers, alcohol manufacturers and distributors, restaurant and beauty shop owners and nursing home operators, and any business that deals with hazardous chemicals or uses a refrigeration unit or steam boiler.
In all, the McGreevey administration imposed more than $40 million in fee increases, including charges for limo drivers, real estate transfers and divorce filings.
While the grab bag of charges and surcharges may appear chaotic, it was guided by the logic of political survival. Mr. McGreevey remembers well the wrath New Jersey voters unleashed on their last Democratic governor, Jim Florio, for pushing a $2.8 billion tax increase through the State Legislature more than a decade ago.
So when the treasurer's office found itself facing a projected budget gap of more than $4 billion, the administration adopted an a la carte strategy of cuts, tax increases and higher fees, wagering that the public might be less offended by a series of levies than by one or two big ones.
"The main principle was, we didn't want a sales or income tax increase," said Eric Shuffler, a McGreevey aide and the key negotiator in the budget talks. "The second rule was, we didn't want to do anything that would start a rebellion."
While that strategy is a dramatic departure from the Florio years, many other states now struggling with fiscal problems have employed a similar approach. Arturo Perez, an analyst at the National Conference of State Legislatures, said that 40 states were facing significant budget problems this year, and that only 3 had thus far instituted broad-based tax increases.
Governor McGreevey said he was particularly gratified that New Jersey had also avoided resorting to some of the drastic cuts being enacted elsewhere, like aid to public schools, early release for nonviolent prison inmates or removing legal immigrants from the Medicaid rolls.
"This is a responsible budget," he said this week. New Jersey Republicans, who pressured Mr. McGreevey to reduce his proposed tax increases to $600 million from $800 million, are quick to disagree. They accuse Mr. McGreevey of cleverly overstating the budget problems so he could sell tax increases to the public while increasing spending. This year's budget includes $700 million more in outlays than last year's.
"One thing is said and just the opposite is done," said State Senator Joseph Malone, a Republican from Burlington. "The residents of the state should not be subjected to this form of torture. Abbott and Costello could not have written a script for the past two weeks."
With the entire State Legislature up for re-election this year, Republicans are also blasting the governor and fellow Democrats for New Jersey's onerous property taxes. The new budget cut the NJ Saver property tax rebate to $250 from $500, and Mr. McGreevey has frozen aid to municipalities for two straight years, forcing many towns and cities to raise their rates.
But Democrats are hoping that the public will be willing to place the blame on the weak economy so long as any new taxes are imposed craftily. McGreevey administration officials tried to foist the most visible taxes on groups unlikely to generate much sympathy: smokers, casino operators and billboard owners. They also tried to avoid taxing items that could easily be transformed into incendiary political symbols the way Mr. Florio's proposed tax on household paper products inspired anti-tax advocates to print the governor's likeness on rolls of toilet tissue.
Administration officials discussed taxing cable television, but were worried that Republicans might respond with ads accusing them of "taxing my 'Sopranos,' " an administration official said, so the idea was dropped. A tax on dog kennels was proposed and ultimately scrapped for fear that it might stoke the fiery passions of pet owners.
The administration did fight for one tax that would affect the vast majority of New Jerseyans: a surcharge on every monthly telephone bill in the state, which would have generated $116 million. But that provision was dropped during the final day of bargaining with Republicans.
"It's hard to imagine anyone who gets hit by more than two of those fees," Mr. Shuffler said.
But others suspect that the aggregate total of taxes will ultimately anger voters.
"All taxes are income taxes, because they come out of someone's income," said Murray Sabrin, an anti-tax advocate who has run for office as both a Libertarian and Republican. "What Governor McGreevey did was impose nuisance taxes, and people will notice."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Slip After Disappointing Report on Unemployment

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks fell modestly yesterday after the government reported that the unemployment rate jumped in June and payroll jobs declined. But the three major gauges still finished the week higher, after closing out a very strong second quarter on Monday.
 While stocks fell, Treasury yields moved sharply higher. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 3.66 percent, from 3.53 percent on Wednesday. Although the yield is up from a more than four-decade low of 3.11 percent just three weeks ago, it is still low historically and only back up to where it was in early May. 
 One reason for these two performances is that the jobs data, combined with a later report that showed that the service sector had expanded for the third consecutive month, left investors with the same ambiguous outlook for the economy that they have had for a while: While forecasters and many Federal Reserve officials say they expect the economy to pick up, there is still no concrete evidence in the data that an upswing has begun.
"We expect better performance in the second half of 2003, but I wouldn't bet the ranch on it," said Joseph Liro, an economist and market analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research.
Still, Mr. Liro said the bond market sell-off could be a positive sign. "This is a reflection in the bond market that the economy is going to be better in the second half and inflation is not going to be a problem," he said. "I am taking that as good news."
Trading was moderate in a shortened session that ended at 1 p.m. ahead of the Independence Day weekend. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 72.63 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,070.21, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 8.05 points, or 0.8 percent, to 985.70. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 15.27 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,663.46.
For the week, the Dow was up 0.9 percent and the S.& P. 500 climbed 1 percent. It was the eighth positive week for these two market gauges in the last 10. The Nasdaq climbed 2.4 percent and was up for the seventh week in the last 10.
Among the stocks leading the market lower yesterday were 3M, I.B.M., Wal-Mart Stores, Pfizer, Citigroup, Cisco Systems, Microsoft and Intel. AT&T fell after Standard & Poor's reduced its credit rating on Wednesday to BBB, from BBB+. The BBB rating is two notches above noninvestment grade, or junk bond, status.
While stocks were up for the week and the S.& P. 500 had its best quarter in the three months ending June 30 since the fourth quarter of 1998, the broader market has had trouble making headway since June 17, when the Dow and the S.& P. 500 reached their recent highs. The Nasdaq, which is loaded with the technology stocks that have helped lead the market rebound that began on March 11, reached a 2003 high on Wednesday of 1,678,73.
Mr. Liro said he thought this lack of clarity about the economy could lead to a sell-off in the stock market in the third quarter. He noted that the third quarter has been bad for stocks recently, with the Dow falling in four of the last five third quarters.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the unemployment rate rose in June to 6.4 percent, a nine-year high, from 6.1 percent in May, while nonfarm payroll jobs declined by 30,000. Both moves exceeded market expectations.
On the service economy, the Institute for Supply Management's index for nonmanufacturing companies rose to 60.6 in June, from 54.5 in May. A reading above 50 means the sector is growing.
In the bond market, where trading also ended early, the price of the 10-year note fell 31/32, to a price of 99 25/32. 
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 25/32, to 110 20/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.69 percent from 4.58 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: More Taxes, A Few Cuts, But Little Pain In New Budgets 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 3 

 BODY:
Six months ago, political leaders around the New York City region were sounding alarms. They warned that state and local governments were facing the worst fiscal crisis since the 1930's and predicted dire budget cuts that in the eyes of many legislators would cripple services.
 In the end, though, New York State, New York City and New Jersey all managed to put together budgets that avoided the deepest cuts, and they paid for them with borrowing or tax increases that have yet to arouse a public outcry. 
 In short, political leaders in all three places made the political calculation that it was better to raise taxes than to hack away at government spending.
In Connecticut, meanwhile, a fierce battle is being fought over the same issue, as the Republican governor remains at loggerheads with a Democratic legislature over whether to raise taxes or cut spending to close a $1 billion shortfall. Gov. John G. Rowland has vowed not to sign any budget that includes more than $250 million in new taxes. 
Across the country, in most of the states whose fiscal years were winding down in recent days, legislators have wrestled with the effect of three years of declining revenues. The taxes-versus-cuts debate is continuing in California, where Gov. Gray Davis and the Legislature are locked in a battle over how to resolve a $38 billion shortfall. Governors in 19 states proposed to shrink spending in real terms for the first time in two decades, making cuts in every area: kindergarten, medical services, colleges, police, prisons and aid to local governments, according to a report by the National Association of State Budget Officers.
The relative calm afterthe budget battles in New York and New Jersey has more to do with perception than reality, budget analysts said. Both states are still in trouble, because they rely heavily on one-time borrowing to put off spending cuts -- $4.2 billion in New York, and $1.6 billion in New Jersey. That means they will face large deficits next year, of about $6 billion in New York and about $2 billion in New Jersey, the analysts said. 
Both states also enacted large tax increases just to support a small increase in the current level of spending, a risky way to go about solving a budget shortfall because it does nothing to rein in future spending growth. Health care and education costs, usually the biggest expenses, tend to rise each year far above the rate of inflation because of labor agreements and laws requiring services for the poor, budget experts said.
In New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council also decided to raise income, sales and property taxes rather than to cut too deeply into city services, as Mr. Bloomberg had threatened to do in April. Unlike the state, the city has not relied on borrowing, partly because state law forbids it. 
Yet the city still faces a $2 billion gap next year, and raising taxes will be harder to sell to voters the next time around. Mayor Bloomberg's popularity has already taken a beating for the steep tax increases he has approved over the last six months.
"What neither the state nor the city did was bring spending into line with fiscal reality," said Diana Fortuna, an analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission.
Budget experts said lawmakers' and executives' reluctance to tackle the hard job of reducing spending permanently has only put off the day of reckoning. Many taxpayers may feel a sense of temporary relief, but it is only a matter of time before the public realizes that there are more deficits looming despite the recent tax increases, the experts said.
"It's the eye-of-the-storm effect," said Edmund J. McMahon, a conservative analyst with the Manhattan Institute.
One reason for the pervasive sense that the crisis has passed is the annual game of expectations played in the capitals and City Hall. Gov. George E. Pataki came out in January with a budget that threatened to cut school aid by $1.4 billion and Medicaid by $1 billion, prompting hospital workers' and teachers' unions to protest. Mayor Bloomberg presented a plan in April that would have eliminated after-school programs, shuttered swimming pools and cut the police force to its lowest level in 10 years.
In New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey proposed a plan in February that eliminated financing for the arts, cut money for higher education and reduced health insurance for the poor.
The psychological effect on taxpayers was to make them more willing to accept tax increases, even though spending on those services was being held flat or reduced slightly in most cases.
"This is an expectations game," said Alan G. Hevesi, the New York State comptroller, who has criticized the state's budget because it relies heavily on borrowing. He added, "The bottom line is a huge portion of the problem has been postponed until next year."
Some New Jersey lawmakers, like Assemblyman Joseph Malone, a Republican from Burlington, accused the Democratic governor and legislators of manipulating public opinion. "One thing is said and just the opposite is done," Mr. Malone said. "The residents of the state should not be subjected to this form of torture." 
In New York State, legislative leaders won a bitter fight over taxes with Mr. Pataki, a third-term Republican who swore that he would not raise income taxes. Legislative leaders were so certain that voters would prefer higher income and sales taxes to higher property taxes caused by a drop in state aid that they overrode the governor's veto of their $92.3 billion budget.
The Legislature's leaders -- Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader -- also persuaded Mayor Bloomberg to adopt similar tax increases for city residents. Those taxes, along with the restoration of $800 million in school aid and other programs Mr. Pataki had wanted to eliminate, made it possible for the city to escape the severe cuts Mr. Bloomberg outlined in April.
Another reason the New York State and New York City budgets have not rankled many legislators, or, according to public polls, their constituents, is that the tax increases were intended to hit a small number of high-income New Yorkers harder than everyone else. The income tax increase for people making more than $100,000 affected only about 5 percent of residents. The sales tax increase, affecting everyone, was relatively small.
In New Jersey, Mr. McGreevey also tried to limit the number of people affected by new taxes. He fought for and won legislative approval for higher taxes on cigarettes, real estate transactions and casinos, but backed away from raising broad-based taxes on sales or income.
Directing tax increases at a few thin slices of the public is smart politics, but it does not address the underlying problem, which is the inexorable growth in spending, some budget analysts said.
Scott Pattison, the executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers, said New York and New Jersey were not the only states resorting to borrowing and one-time revenues to weather the storm. Many large states still have not adjusted to the truth: the boom in tax revenues of the 1990's has ended. "These are elected officials; they just don't want to have any pain," Mr. Pattison said.
The rise in spending means New York State will face a $6 billion deficit next year, while New York City and New Jersey will each have to fill a shortfall of about $2 billion, budget officials said. 
"These numbers are still very large gaps," said Robert A. Kurtter, a senior bond analyst with Moody's Investors Service.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
A Desert's Unexpected Bloom

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: NISHINOMIYA, Japan, July 3 

 BODY:
It was 3:30 on a cloudless afternoon and the members of the Tigers New Era Fan Club were already assembled in the far corner of the right-field bleachers. The ragtag group of two dozen or so factory workers, shopkeepers and hangers-on were there to cheer the Hanshin Tigers, working their way through the team's fight songs even though game time was more than two hours away.
 "We're all crazy for the Tigers," said Yoshio Morita, a 55-year-old businessman draped in a black-and-yellow Tigers happi coat. Between slugs of beer and choruses of "The Wind of Mount Rokko," the Tigers' anthem, he ran through his game-day routine, which includes driving two hours from neighboring Shiga Prefecture to get to the stadium by 9 a.m. and line up for a ticket. 
 Morita's devotion, a tale repeated by many of the 53,000 fans packed into Koshien Stadium, is typical of the baseball fever in Nishinomiya, a city of 400,000 in the Osaka metropolitan area, Japan's second largest. The Tigers, Japan's oldest baseball franchise and long one of its worst, are on a march toward only their second championship since 1950, when the two-league system was started. Their sudden success this year has turned this recession-bit region into something bordering on a permanent party. 
 To understand the excitement, imagine what might happen if the Boston Red Sox or Chicago Cubs ever exorcised their demons and won the World Series. In fact, the baseball fates seem to be working on something of a parallel universe, with the Red Sox and the Cubs remaining stubbornly competitive at the halfway point of the Major League Baseball season.
 Unlike the Red Sox, who last won the World Series in 1918, or the Cubs, who last won in 1908, the Tigers last won the Japan Series just 18 years ago. But their record of ineptitude has left scars on their fans: the Tigers have finished in the bottom half of the six-team Central League 15 times since.
 As a result, Tigers fans, like those of the Red Sox and the Cubs, talk of a mystical burden their team must overcome. In Hanshin's case, the burden is known as the Curse of Colonel Sanders. After the team won its lone championship in 1985, fans assembled at the Dotonbori Bridge in Osaka's flashy entertainment district. One by one, those who resembled Tigers players jumped into the river to raucous cheers. But since no one looked like Randy Bass, the team's star slugger, fans stole a statue of Colonel Sanders from a nearby Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet and tossed it in.
 Legend has it that the Tigers will not win a championship until the colonel is found. Efforts to dredge the river and recover the statue have proved fruitless.
 This season, Tigers fans seem to be putting their fatalism behind them, and for good reason. The Tigers have become the fastest team to reach 50 victories, and they are already 30 games above .500, the first time they have reached that mark in a half-century. Their batters are hitting nearly .300 and their pitchers are the league's stingiest.
 Crucially, the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants, the league's pre-eminent team, have stumbled this season with their longtime star, Hideki Matsui, now playing for the Yankees. Coincidentally, the Tigers have benefited from the return of a former Yankee, pitcher Hideki Irabu, who returned from North America after six seasons and has already won 10 games. Another Major League Baseball refugee, Jeff Williams, a former Dodger, is the league's top closer.
 "We have a big chance to win it all this year," said Irabu, who also has the league's lowest earned run average. "It's right in front of our eyes."
 The Tigers have perhaps the best manager in Japanese baseball, Senichi Hoshino. Pugnacious and crafty, he leads much the way Earl Weaver did in Baltimore in the 1960's and 1970's, relying on strong pitching, scrappy hitting and aggressive base running. Like Weaver, he kicks dirt on umpires and screams at his players, a brand of leadership that the fans embrace.
 The passion surrounding the Tigers this year is about much more than victories. Like the Red Sox and the Cubs, the Tigers suffer from a permanent identity crisis. Since World War II, Osaka has been in the shadow of Tokyo, where the nation's government, media and business elite are centered. Home to many of the country's leading manufacturers, the Osaka region now has one of Japan's highest unemployment rates as companies move their factories to China.
 Because of Osaka's blue-collar roots and hard knocks, any victory over a Tokyo team and its white-collar fans is particularly satisfying. 
 "Basically, Hanshin fans are against centralization, against power and against money, all the things that the Giants represent," said Koichi Kunisada, an Osaka-based economist who embroiders the names of his favorite Tigers players in gold silk on the inside of his suit jackets.
While jaded fans in Tokyo have come to expect winners, people in Osaka cannot hide their fanaticism. On a major thoroughfare in the Amagasaki district, shopkeepers unfurled a banner that included the team's magic number on it even though it was still June and the Tigers needed 79 more victories or losses by their opponents to clinch the pennant. (The magic number fell to 54 on July 2.)
 "Some people might say we are brash, but we're simply having a good time," said Kenichiro Yoshioka, the 43-year-old camera shop owner who put up the sign.
 Politicians are also getting into the act. The governor of Osaka Prefecture, Fusae Ota, wants to clean up one of the city's dirtiest rivers, one that fans jump into to celebrate hometown victories. The government's economics minister, Heizo Takenaka, said a Tigers pennant run would change Japan's economic landscape just as it did in 1985, the last time the Tigers went all the way.
 The Tigers' success is already giving the ailing economy a lift. Tickets are suddenly scarce, even when the Tigers are on the road. The broadcast of a Tigers-Giants match-up earlier this season drew a record-high 30.2 percent share, twice the typical audience for a baseball game.
 Shops are also doing a brisk business in anything emblazoned with the Tigers logo, even stores in enemy territory. At the Keio Department Store above Tokyo's Shinjuku Station, the Hanshin Tigers shop sold 696 million yen ($5.8 million) worth of towels, megaphones and cellphone straps in June, five times the level in May. Shares in Hanshin Department Store Ltd., whose parent company owns the Tigers, have risen nearly 40 percent since the season began.
 In all, a Tigers championship could generate 113.3 billion yen ($945 million) in extra spending, according to the Japan Research Institute.
 The party, though, would come to an end if the Tigers reverted to their old ways and performed a late-season swoon. The biggest hurdle is shino roodo, or the Road Trip of Death that the Tigers endure every year. For three weeks in August, their crumbling, ivy-covered stadium here holds the national high school baseball tournament. Few Tiger squads have fared well over this stretch.
 Back in right field, Morita and his fellow merrymakers shrugged off such concerns. The Tigers, they say, are on destiny's road. 
 As the Tigers completed their victory against the Chunichi Dragons, the fans released thousands of whistling balloons in celebration. The customary "hero interview" was conducted near the dugout and broadcast over the stadium loudspeakers. Once finished, outfielder Shinjiro Hiyama received another round of cheers for hitting for the cycle in the game. A half-hour after the final out, the fans finally filed out, many hoarse from all the screaming.
 Yet Morita, who faced a numbing ride home through traffic, seemed energized. He taped the television broadcast of the game and planned to watch it again. 
 "I was so busy cheering," he said, "I didn't even see all those home runs."

HEADLINE: Reconciliation, Not Just Reconstruction 

BYLINE:  By Stuart E. Eizenstat; Stuart E. Eizenstat, deputy Treasury secretary from 1999 to 2001, is author of "Imperfect Justice: Looted Assets, Slave Labor and the Unfinished Business of World War II."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Despite efforts by American and British forces to restore order, Iraq remains perilous. Since President Bush declared an end to major combat on May 1, at least 21 American soldiers have been killed, while six British soldiers died in an ambush last week in southern Iraq.
 Bringing the rule of law to Iraq is essential, as is the political and economic reconstruction of the country. Yet these tasks may fail unless the Bush administration also provides justice for Iraqi victims of Saddam Hussein's terror. Healing these wounds will not only lay the groundwork for a stable nation, but will also reinforce the United States commitment to helping the Iraqi people. 
 Many of those who were victimized -- the Kurds in the north, so-called marsh Arabs in the south, Shiite opponents of the Baath Party regime -- represent the major political and religious factions in Iraq. If their grievances are not addressed, Iraqi society will bear permanent scars and endure continuing frustrations, leading to growing resentment and cycles of retribution. There are several ways to address the grievances of Saddam Hussein's victims and promote reconciliation.
The first is to establish a compensation fund for victims of torture, assassination or other human-rights abuses, or their families. A panel with both Iraqi and international representation would review claims and distribute funds. A small percentage of the revenue from Iraqi oil sales could be allocated for this purpose; 5 percent of such revenue already goes into a United Nations fund for victims of the Persian Gulf war.
Foundations recently created in Berlin, Vienna and Paris that have provided payments to more than a million victims of the Nazi era could serve as a model. As a condition to receiving any money, each Iraqi claimant should be required to sign a statement pledging support for a democratic Iraq and waiving claims against any interim or permanent Iraqi authority. A similar requirement was instituted for victims of Nazi crimes who received restitution.
The administration should also convene a property commission in Iraq to resolve the claims of the tens of thousands of Iraqis who were driven from their homes during the Saddam Hussein era. The restoration of propertyrights will be an important element in the establishment of stability and the rule of law in Iraq, particularly in northern Iraq, where serious disputes have already broken out. This commission should have the authority to resolve competing claims and award legal title, or compensation in lieu of property when return is infeasible or undesired by the claimant. The administration should work with the United Nations to form this commission.
With about one million internally displaced people in Iraq, the number of potential property claims may seem daunting. But there is a precedent. The Commission on Real Property created in Sarajevo after the war in Bosnia has so far been able to decide more than 250,000 property claims. Armed with legally binding decisions, large numbers of the dispossessed in the Balkans have been able to return home and resume their lives. A similar process in Iraq could avoid lingering bitterness.
A historical commission, consisting entirely of Iraqis, should also be established to document for future generations the ways in which the Baath Party committed such vast human-rights abuses. The South Africa Truth and Reconciliation Commission, created shortly after the end of the apartheid era, provides a model. By encouraging victims of apartheid to tell their stories, it gave them the opportunity to air their grievances and it educated the public -- white and black. It was one reason that a blood bath of retribution against the apartheid-era leaders was avoided.
Last, a war crimes tribunal should be created -- within Iraq, to make evidence-gathering easier -- with United States leadership and United Nations blessing, to bring to justice the most senior members of the Baath Party regime. As the Nuremberg trials did for postwar Germany, such trials would provide legitimacy for postwar Iraq. As in South Africa, those who confess to their crimes could be granted amnesty.
As has become increasingly clear in the two months since the official end of hostilities, the United States faces a difficult task in Iraq. Establishing instruments for justice may not be as dramatic as patrolling the streets of Baghdad, but it is equally important. Only through these institutions can the administration translate its ambitious goal of a stable, tolerant, democratic Iraq into reality.

HEADLINE: Bush Sends Baker to Georgia for Talks 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3 

 BODY:
President Bush has dispatched former Secretary of State James A. Baker III to the former Soviet republic of Georgia this week to discuss political and economic issues, the White House said today. 
 While in Georgia's capital, Tbilisi, on Friday and Saturday, Mr. 
Baker will meet President Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who was the Soviet foreign minister when Mr. Baker was secretary of state in the administration of the elder President Bush. 
 Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Baker would be traveling on behalf of the president to discuss with Mr. Shevardnadze "ways to advance political and economic reform in Georgia through free and fair parliamentary elections this fall." They will also discuss American-Georgian cooperation on counterterrorism and other security matters.
"The Baker mission reflects the United States' readiness to work with all Georgian citizens who are committed to advancing reform and fighting corruption in pursuit of a democratic, prosperous and stable Georgia," Mr. Fleischer said.
According to a June 16 report by the Russian news agency Interfax, Mr. Shevardnadze has said it will be impossible to make fundamental constitutional changes before elections on Nov. 2. The changes would involve establishing a two-house Parliament and a cabinet of ministers, reduced powers for the Parliament's lower house, and the country's territorial division, Interfax said.

HEADLINE: Bush Insists Liberian President Go Before Troops Come In 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3 

 BODY:
President Bush, enmeshed in an internal struggle in his administration over whether and how to send American peacekeeping troops to Liberia, strongly implied today that no soldiers would bedeployed until the Liberian president, Charles Taylor, steps down.
 "I recognize the United States has got a -- has had a, you know, unique history with Liberia," Mr. Bush said in an interview at the White House with reporters from African countries. 
 And, therefore, it's created a certain sense of expectations. But I also want to make sure that there are certain expectations met, as well. And one expectation is Mr. Taylor has got to leave." 
Later in the day, Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, told reporters that there were "sensitive discussions" with Mr. Taylor. She refused to provide details other than to say that Mr. Taylor was someone "who has murdered and looted and really put the country in extremis."
Mr. Bush, in his interview with the African reporters, made an unusual appeal for time in making a decision that will have repercussions on military strategy as well as on domestic politics.
He said that once his strategy was decided, "I will let people know whether or not I'm airborne." But until then, "I'm just gathering enough information to be rational in what we do."
Mr. Bush spoke as American military officials were meeting in Ghana with representatives from the Economic Community of West African States, a regional group of 16 nations, to discuss the makeup of a possible peacekeeping force. The group was said to be reviewing how American troops could be deployed alongside regional troops. A senior administration official said it was likely that American forces would be sent, but that Mr. Bush might not decide until Monday when he leaves for a trip to Africa.
The delay in the president's decision reflects the complex practical problems of deploying troops as well as divisions between the State Department and the Pentagon. State Department officials fear that uncontrolled violence in Liberia will undercut Mr. Bush's message of commitment to Africa on his five-day trip to the continent. But Pentagon officials do not want American troops to become entangled in a civil war when the military is already stretched thin because of large deployments in Iraq and Afghanistan.
At the same time, Mr. Bush has come under increasing political pressure at home to deploy troops to a country that was founded by freed American slaves and has longtime ties to the United States. On Wednesday, the leading Africa expert in the Congressional Black Caucus, Representative Donald M. Payne, Democrat of New Jersey, urged the administration not to delay.
"We do not want the blood of Liberians on our hands and cannot justify waiting another day," Mr. Payne said in a letter to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.
The United Nations, France, Britain and countries in West Africa have also urged Mr. Bush to intervene. But Mr. Bush, who denounced "nation building" in his 2000 presidential campaign, has long been skeptical of using American forces for peacekeeping operations. 
A million refugees have flooded into Liberia's capital, Monrovia, as the country has been engulfed by fighting in recent weeks between rebels and militias loyal to Mr. Taylor. He has been indicted on charges of war crimes by a court created jointly by Sierra Leone and the United Nations. Mr. Taylor has said he will go, but he has not said when.
Military officials in Washington and in Germany, who are readying force options for Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Mr. Bush, said preparations for Liberia continued today, but that no troops had been alerted for possible action. Officials said the options included sending 500 to 2,000 troops, but details like the precise size, makeup and command structure were all undecided.
"We're monitoring the situation and doing prudent planning," said Cmdr. James Graybeal, a spokesman for the United States European Command, which has responsibility for military operations in most of Africa.
Despite wariness at the Pentagon of deploying forces to a new mission when 146,000 American soldiers are in Iraq and 10,000 are in Afghanistan, there is a growing, if still somewhat tentative, support to send American peacekeepers for a short time.
Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican who heads the Armed Services Committee, offered his support for the mission. "At this point in time, our forces could accept that level of deployment," he said.
Africa specialists agreed that a Liberian mission would not unduly strain the military and that it would help burnish America's image on the continent and in the world, especially after its bruising diplomatic struggle with some European countries over Iraq.
"It's a way of showing we just don't throw our weight around to be tough, that we can also protect the little guy," said Herman J. Cohen, who was assistant secretary of state for Africa affairs in the first Bush administration. "It's an image builder if he does it, and the risks are low."
Chester A. Crocker, who was the assistant secretary of state for African affairs in the Reagan administration, said that the United States would not have to send a large force for it to be effective and that American involvement would lead other countries to take part. Mr. Crocker also said it was essential for Mr. Taylor to get out of the country as quickly as possible.
"You've got to get him someplace unless you want to have him chopped up in small pieces in downtown Monrovia," Mr. Crocker said.

HEADLINE: Plastic Is Back: Relearning Recycling's Dance 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK HEALY

 BODY:
New York City may be recycling plastic again, but the ever-changing rules of disposal have left many residents befuddled. 
 Since Tuesday, when the city re-imposed the recycling of plastic, residents have been deluging City Council members with questions about the new regulations. Can they recycle old strawberry containers? What about blue glass? Is the city still accepting recycled cardboard? When are the trucks coming? 
 The city dropped plastic and glass from its recycling program last year to save money in the face of huge deficits. But the promised $40 million savings never materialized, as costs of traditional waste disposal increased and more economical ways to recycle emerged. 
Now, the city has returned plastic to its list of recyclable materials, and will phase glass back into the program in April of next year.
"The recycling about-face is a little like the decision to abandon new Coke and return to Classic Coke," said Mark Izeman, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which supports recycling. "We spent years teaching New Yorkers how to recycle, then we told New Yorkers to forget everything they know and put glass and plastic into the trash, and we're now telling New Yorkers to go back to the original rules. It's going to take several months for New Yorkers to relearn the dance steps."
So plastic is back, but not all of it -- only bottles and jugs. All those little yogurt containers still go in the trash. All glass, too. It's garbage until next April, when it becomes recyclable. Metal, plastic bottles and jugs and drink boxes go into the blue recycling bins, paper and cardboard into the green bins.
Figuring out collection times is equally complex. The city plans to collect recyclable items every other week, but that schedule does not go into effect until August. Until then, trucks will be making their rounds every week. Regular trash collection will not be affected by plastic recycling services. 
City Councilman Michael E. McMahon, chairman of the Sanitation Committee, said that New Yorkers are still baffled by the details of the rules. While some want to know whether they can recycle glass (no) or orange juice containers (yes), most are concerned about being fined if they try to recycle the wrong materials at the wrong time.
"There's just a lot of general confusion," Mr. McMahon said. "I still don't know which week I should be putting out my curbside recycling. If I put it out on the wrong week, technically, I could get a citation."
Mr. McMahon said he planned to ask the Department of Sanitation to suspend fines on recycling violations for the next six months, as New Yorkers adjust to the new rules. 
Although the Sanitation Department is not currently issuing fines for plastic recycling, the department will continue to cite property owners for other violations, like throwing metal and paper into the garbage, said Kathy Dawkins, a spokeswoman for the department. The department has not decided when it will begin fining New Yorkers for violating plastic recycling rules. 
David Higby, solid waste project director for the group Environmental Advocates, said the city had not done enough to educate New Yorkers. Without education, the new rules will not be effective, he said.
The Sanitation Department said it planned to explain the new rules by putting out newspaper advertisements and sending fliers and brochures to New Yorkers.
The new rules are still a bit perplexing to Charley Beal, 45, a West Village resident who calls himself an "over-recycler." Mr. Beal is an old hand at sorting out paper and metal, but when it comes to recycling plastic, he said he stares hard at the triangle and number inscribed on the bottom of his strawberry cartons and Chinese soup cups, then just throws everything into the recycling bag. "I've erred toward recycling," Mr. Beal said. "When I'm in doubt, I put it in recycling."
But at 78th Street and Columbus Avenue, tenants are erring on the side of garbage, said Lou Martarano, 48, a resident who is on his building's condominium board. Mr. Martarano said he and other residents were still confused about the changing procedures, and were continuing to dump plastics down the trash chute.
A visit to a half-dozen apartment buildings in Morningside Heights shows that superintendents and apartment porters have an equally shaky understanding of the regulations. "We haven't gotten any notice from sanitation -- nothing," said a maintenance worker at 730 Columbus Avenue. "When will glass be recycled? I don't know. Management will tell us."
On the ground floor of 336 Central Park West, the building's superintendent, Vincent E. Gardiner, seemed more confident. 
Mr. Gardiner pointed to a printout from the Department of Sanitation's Web site he had posted near the elevator. Mr. Gardiner visited the site just Monday, but somehow the rules he found were from July 2002.
"I've read about it," Mr. Gardiner said. "It's very clear. We're recycling aluminum cans and metal. Cardboard is regular garbage. Plastics and bottles aren't being recycled, and glass is."
He was one for four.

HEADLINE: Democrats See Opening For Attack on Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3 

 BODY:
The jump in the unemployment rate gave Democrats a new opening today to attack President Bush's management of the economy and question the effectiveness of his signature tax cuts.
 In strikingly similar terms, many of the Democratic presidential candidates attacked Mr. Bush's policies as misdirected and unfair. The continuing loss of jobs from the economy allowed them to call into question Mr. Bush's vow that his latest tax cut, the third in three years, would create a million new jobs. 
 "This president has a failed economic policy on his hands, and he has no inclination to be flexible and change it," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, one of the nine Democratic presidential candidates, said in an interview. "He keeps doing more of the same thing he's been doing, which is more tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans. It's a repeat of the Reagan program times three. It didn't work then, and it isn't working now."
White House officials said Mr. Bush was concerned about the rise in unemployment, and they said the economy's sluggishness showed he had been correct when he pushed through a $350 billion tax cut this spring, as he had been in signing the two previous tax reductions.
"The tax cuts have helped create jobs and to promote growth in the economy," Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said.
Mr. Bush continues to be in an enviable political position, with high overall approval ratings, a loyal base and a huge fund-raising advantage. But for the first time, Democrats said, Mr. Bush is showing signs of vulnerability on both the economy and on his conduct of foreign policy. Some Democrats say the continued loss of American lives in Iraq, the failure to find any chemical or biological weapons and the general postwar chaos there have started to take some of the shine off the president's record as commander in chief.
At the same time, the economy is continuing to defy predictions that it will be turned around by the tax cuts and the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate reductions. The economy has shed nearly 2.5 million jobs since Mr. Bush took office. The growth in disposable income has been weak.
"The gap between the president's need to talk about positive trends in the economy and people's lack of income or job opportunity is explosive," said Stan Greenberg, a Democratic pollster.
A poll last month by Mr. Greenberg's firm found that Mr. Bush had a 61 percent approval rating. But 53 percent of the voters polled said the country should go in a different direction on the economy. And when offered two statements, one reflecting the Democratic criticism of Mr. Bush's tax cuts and the other reflecting the White House's argument in favor of them, the voters favored the Democratic position 56 percent to 41 percent.
A CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll released today found that 56 percent of Americans did not think the latest round of tax cuts would help their families' finances.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, another of the Democratic candidates, said: "We'll continue to bang away. This will clarify as we move toward the primaries, and more important, when we choose a nominee. Then there will be a face-to-face confrontation with a president who will have to defend a record of losing millions of jobs."
The White House has already begun counterpunching on the economy, focusing on promises by the Democratic candidates to roll back Mr. Bush's tax cuts, a step his supporters say would be a huge tax increase that would stop the economy's recovery in its tracks.
Moreover, said David Winston, a Republican pollster, voters are not taking out their economic anxieties on Mr. Bush.
"This is a different electorate since Sept. 11," Mr. Winston said. "They're not looking to assess blame. They're looking for what you've done to correct the problem."
But Mr. Winston added that voters would be looking for improvements in the jobs situation by next summer. "In a major way, it's how Americans judge the economy," he said.
Mr. Bush's political fate may depend on whether the economy and the presidential campaign follow the pattern of the early 1980's or the early 1990's.
In Ronald Reagan's first two and a half years as president, the unemployment rate surged from 7.5 percent to as high as 10.8 percent and then declined steadily, to 7.2 percent, by the time he faced the voters in 1984. He won a landslide re-election victory.
In the first two and a half years of the first Bush administration, the unemployment rate jumped to 6.9 percent from 5.4 percent. But the rise in joblessness continued, peaking at 7.8 percent in June 1992, after the Democrats had settled on Bill Clinton as their nominee. Mr. Clinton attacked the first President Bush on the economy and beat him in November.
The current President Bush is betting that his experience will be more like Mr. Reagan's than his father's. The Labor Department's report today that unemployment in June rose to 6.4 percent, from 6.1 percent in May, put joblessness at its highest level since April 1994 and well above the 4.1 percent level when Mr. Bush was sworn in two and a half years ago.
But administration officials, Republican strategists and many economists say they are confident the economy will turn around, helped along by the tax cuts, and that unemployment will begin declining by next summer, when voters start to make up their minds.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE INCREASES TO 6.4%, HIGHEST IN 9 YEARS 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Once again failing to live up to politicians' hopes and economists' expectations, the labor market got tougher for job seekers last month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.4 percent, the highest in nine years, and the economy lost 30,000 jobs.
 The Labor Department also said that job losses were much more severe in May than originally reported -- 70,000 outside of farming, rather than 17,000. In all, the economy has lost 236,000 jobs this year. 
 The figures were a gloomy conclusion to the first half of the year, especially given that the economy had shown a few positive signs in June. Economists said that hints of revival in both the manufacturing and service sectors might have lured job hunters into the labor market too soon.
Job losses occurred across almost all industries, but blacks had considerably more trouble finding work than whites. Many more people started looking for work, but the number of employed blacks shrank, while the number of employed whites grew.
"It's hard to put a positive spin on this report," said Ethan S. Harris, chief economist of Lehman Brothers. Not only did overall unemployment rise, he said, but "the rest of the report didn't look good, either." The unemployment rate in May was 6.1 percent.
The data put the White House on the defensive. Democrats charged that the latest package of tax cuts, signed by President Bush on May 28, had contributed little to the strength of the economy. Page A18. 
"This is another indication that these ideologically focused, supply-side tax cuts are not the way to get at the fundamental problem," said Senator Jon Corzine, a Democrat from New Jersey. "It's increasingly becoming clear the policies aren't having the result that was, at least, their stated intention. These have been very inefficient uses of resources to try to stimulate growth or jobs."
Claire Buchan, a spokeswoman for the White House, responded by saying much of the boost that will come from the most recent fiscal package has yet to be felt. "The withholding tables went into effect the day before yesterday," she said. "The child-credit checks will go out at the end of the month. Businesses have access to the expensing and the depreciation, so there is a lot of stimulus."
The Labor Department's report includes data from separate surveys of households and business and government payrolls. According to seasonally adjusted numbers from the household survey, 611,000 people joined the labor force in June, yet the number of employed people rose by only 251,000.
Mr. Harris said part of that gap might reflect steep drops in payrolls from earlier this year -- one survey catching up to the other. But he said encouraging signs coming from the economy might have been premature, at least for people seeking work.
"One thing I wonder about," he said, "is whether all the happy talk about the economy encouraged people to start job hunting again, only to find that the labor market wasn't nearly as strong as what they were hoping for."
The latest figures on new applications for unemployment benefits also offered little encouragement. Last week, 430,000 people filed first-time claims, up from a revised figure of 409,000 in the previous week, the Labor Department reported yesterday. Many economists regard any figure above 400,000 as a sign of continued weakness in the labor market.
Richard D. Rippe, chief economist of Prudential Securities, said that strong growth in jobs might not occur until the end of the year, because of increases in worker productivity.
"We can produce more output without adding a lot of workers," he explained. "What you're going to have to get is strong and consistent output growth before you're going to add workers. I don't think, even if the optimists on the economy are correct, that you're going to get strong job growth in the near term."
Last month's slackness in the labor market encompassed virtually all industries, with few noteworthy exceptions. Manufacturing suffered heavy losses of 56,000 jobs, while some of the largest gains came among restaurants and bars, which added 20,000 positions.
Much bigger differences arose between the employment of blacks and whites. Though the survey of households is considered a rougher picture than the survey of businesses, which does not tabulate workers by race, the figures from June sent a stark message. For every four white workers added to the work force in June, the number of employed whites rose by three. But for every four black workers added to the labor force, the number with jobs slipped by three.
In all, whites in the labor force rose by 461,000, and the number of employed whites rose by 321,000. But among blacks, 99,000 entered the work force, and the number of employed blacks fell by 73,000.
In the aftermaths of previous economic downturns, job opportunities for blacks have opened up more slowly than for whites, said William E. Spriggs, the executive director of the National Urban League Institute for Opportunity and Equality. This time, he said, blacks who lose their jobs seem less likely to drop out of the labor force and more likely to look for new ones. As a result, the unemployment rate -- especially for black men -- is rising.
"Given the high share of African-Americans that are long-term unemployed," Mr. Spriggs said, "it's just going to take a long time to clear that out." The Labor Department said that for blacks, the unemployment rate in June was 11.8 percent, up from 10.8 percent in May. For whites, it rose to 5.5 percent in June from 5.4 percent a month earlier.
In June, more than half of the unemployed had been looking for work for more than 12 weeks -- the highest figure since May 1983. The average time spent unemployed reached almost 20 weeks, a level not seen since 1984.
Longer job searches by women, as well as by blacks, may account for the longer duration of unemployment, said Robert Shimer, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago. Women who lose jobs, he said, have also become less likely to leave the work force.
Mr. Harris, the Lehman Brothers economist, said that with so many people seeking jobs for so long, "it makes the threat of unemployment more dire" for anyone who loses a job now. Though the jobless rate typically lags behind other indicators of the economy's health, its upward creep, he said, could limit consumers' appetites for new spending.
Yesterday did bring one promising sign, however, as the Institute for Supply Management said that its index of activity in nonmanufacturing industries surged to 60.6 in June -- a reading indicative of growth -- from 54.5 in May. Mr. Rippe, of Prudential, asserted that the stage was set for better performance.
"We are getting through some of the past problems, and we have all of the policy dials that we have available set to growth," he said. "Everything we can do from a macro policy perspective is being done, and the question is, will it work? I think it will."

HEADLINE: Israelis Sense They've Won 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, July 3 

 BODY:
Israeli officials are expressing growing confidence that after 33 months they have defeated the Palestinian uprising, or intifada. 
 The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Moshe Yaalon, told Israeli reporters on Wednesday that the developments this week might eventually be seen "as the end" of the conflict. "It is certainly a victory" for Israel, he was quoted as saying. 
 Some Israeli analysts criticized that conclusion as premature, if not hubristic. Yet for now, the American-brokered talks between the adversaries are being held on what appear to be largely Israeli terms. 
Negotiators who three years ago were discussing how to divide Jerusalem are debating how to return partial control of cities thatwere then under Palestinian authority.
"When the intifada began, the demand was, 'End the occupation, because the negotiations led to nothing,' " said Samir al-Mashharawi, a leader of the mainstream Palestinian faction, Fatah. "Now, Palestinian demands are to return back to the situation right before the intifada, and we are negotiating about this." 
He said that during one of his terms as an Israeli prisoner, he and other inmates demanded chairs and tables. In response, he said, the Israelis took their mattresses. The prisoners demanded them back. 
"After a month, they returned the mattresses, and we felt very happy we achieved something," he said. "Israeli diplomacy is based on this idea." 
How the Bush administration will press the peace plan forward is unclear. Violence could erupt again at any moment, and Palestinians have proven they can inflict tremendous pain -- including economic loss -- on Israel. It was no accident that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon chose an economic conference in Jerusalem today to declare, "For the first time since I entered the office of prime minister, there is a real possibility of an end to terror and the return to normal life." 
The Israelis appear to be filling in the details of a new American-backed peace plan, which Israel had resisted, to better suit its perceived interests. 
The Israeli Army will not withdraw from any more Palestinian cities until it sees that Palestinian security officers are acting against violent groups in Bethlehem and Gaza, where forces pulled back this week, a senior Israeli military official said today. 
Mahmoud Abbas, the appointed Palestinian prime minister, may be seen as an Israeli agent if he jails those who violate the truce. He hopes to gain strength as Israel makes concessions, and for now, the main Palestinian factions have voluntarily suspended attacks.
Israel says that it cannot risk being too indulgent and that Mr. Abbas must act against militants in the next two or three weeks or the peace process will freeze. 
Over the course of the conflict, Israel maximized its bargaining position, by taking back territory and encouraging settlers to set up new outposts to extend their grip on the West Bank. By contrast, the Palestinians, whose main demand is statehood, find their negotiating leverage much reduced. 
Mr. Mashharawi said they had shown that unless the Israeli occupation ended "there will be no peace and security in the region." And he warned of "another intifada" unless the Israelis moved swiftly to give Palestinians independence. 
Israelis say they have forced Palestinians to rethink violence. In March 2002, during a wave of Palestinian attacks, Mr. Sharon declared: "The aim is to increase the number of losses on the other side. Only after they've been battered will we be able to conduct talks." 
At the end of that March, Israel launched military offensives to seize Palestinian cities in the West Bank, control of which had been ceded under the Oslo peace process. 
Now, the senior military official said, "the Palestinians -- at least the ones who make decisions -- came to the conclusion that violence will not achieve their political goals." 
"I cannot say it is over," he cautioned, but he said that if the peace process succeeded, the Palestinian street might come to the same conclusion about violence "in a few weeks, and a few months." 
He said the American wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, as well as new pressure from European and Arab states, had also helped change the Palestinian view on violence. 
If the Palestinians end their uprising, their remaining levers for negotiations may be time and demography. With the Palestinian population growing rapidly, Jews will become a minority in Israel and its occupied territories within a few years, Israeli experts say. That may put either Israel's Jewish character or its democracy at risk if Palestinians do not form a separate state. 
The new American-backed peace plan, known as the road map, calls for a comprehensive Arab-Israeli peace and a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza in just three years. But Mr. Sharon has a longer time line in mind. The second of the peace plan's three phases -- a Palestinian state with "provisional" borders -- could ease Israel's demographic predicament without forcing it to confront the deepest disputes between the two sides, such as control of Jerusalem. 
The military official said that Israel would not begin substantive political negotiations over questions like Jerusalem until the Palestinians had fully broken up militant groups, confiscating their weapons, destroying their training centers, arresting their dangerous members and ending all "incitement" to violence. 
"They will have to get rid of all their terrorist capabilities," he said, acknowledging this could take years. 
The Bush administration does not appear to be pressing Israel to abide by the plan's schedule. A Western diplomat said the administration was more interested in commitments met than dates kept. 
As demanded under the plan, Israel has begun taking down some of the settlers' outposts, though new ones are going up. Little has been said about a freeze on further growth of established settlements called for in the plan's first phase.
To try to raise Mr. Abbas's popularity, Israel has begun releasing some of its more than 5,000 Palestinian prisoners, a step not in the plan. But as one senior Israeli official noted, there is a difference between releasing prisoners and conceding land: freed prisoners can always be arrested again.
