HEADLINE: Liberian President Again Says He Will Go 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 4 

 BODY:
With pressure increasing for his departure, President Charles Taylor of Liberia promised again today to step aside but said he would leave his country only after peacekeepers arrived to prevent bedlam between warring factions.
 President Bush repeated his call for Mr. Taylor to leave for the sake of Liberia's future. Bush administration officials, who are weighing whether to send troops to Liberia, have called Mr. Taylor's exit a condition for restoring stability. 
 Mr. Bush, who is scheduled to begin his first presidential visit to Africa next week, today ordered military experts to assess whether American troops should be deployed to monitor a fragile cease-fire between Liberian government forces and rebel forces. Meanwhile, the Economic Community of West African States agreed today to dispatch up to 3,000 soldiers for the mission. Most of them will probably come from Nigeria, the regional powerhouse.
Should Mr. Taylor decide to leave, there remains the question of where he will go, given that he is accused of crimes against humanity in connection with a war in neighboring Sierra Leone. President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria has discussed the possibility of offering refuge to Mr. Taylor and is scheduled to go to Monrovia, the Liberian capital, on Sunday, government and diplomatic sources said. The Liberian foreign minister has already met with Mr. Obasanjo in Abuja, the Nigerian capital.
"The important thing here is for international peacekeepers to come to Liberia as quickly as possible to take charge of the situation if I am going to step down," Mr. Taylor told reporters outside the presidential residence, according to news agency reports from Monrovia. "The ball is in the international community's court."
A diplomat who is monitoring the situation interpreted Mr. Taylor's remarks as yet another bargaining effort. Mr. Taylor, he said, would step aside only if he had no other choice. 
"He will do it, but if the U.S. decides not to deploy, my best guess is that he will try to maneuver to stay in power," the diplomat said.
In 1985 Mr. Taylor escaped from a Massachusetts prison, where he had been held for 15 months on an extradition request filed by the Liberian government, which accused him of embezzling $1 million. He returned to Liberia and began a guerrilla war in 1989, finally assuming power in 1997. Three years ago his foes started a rebel movement to oust him. 
Last month the rebel faction from the north, the so-called Liberians United for Reconciliation and Democracy, made two violent bids to take the capital, killing several hundred people and displacing tens of thousands in overcrowded shanties there.
The rebel factions enjoy the support of neighboring Guinea and Ivory Coast, whose presidents have made no secret of their dislike of Mr. Taylor. Liberia's war has scattered arms, mercenaries and disorder across West Africa. Mr. Taylor is under United Nations penalties and is barred from selling diamonds, buying arms and traveling overseas.
Meanwhile, talks resumed this morning in nearby Accra, the capital of Ghana, to determine the shape of a transitional government before elections can be held. Whether Mr. Taylor's senior aides or rebel officials will be allowed to take part in the interim body remains a bone of contention. The British ambassador to the United Nations, Sir Jeremy Greenstock, on a Security Council delegation to West Africa this week, has already said that the rebels should stay out of negotiations. The Americans, who count Guinea as an ally, have remained silent on the subject.
The danger exists, should Mr. Taylor suddenly step down, of a power vacuum in Monrovia and elsewhere in the country. In his remarks to reporters today, Mr. Taylor said the situation could become "extremely chaotic" if he left. 
Mr. Taylor had promised early last month that he would step aside, but later he said he would serve out the rest of his term until January.
The archbishop of Monrovia, Michael Kpakala Francis, a critic of Mr. Taylor and of the rebels, called it practical and wise to have an international force sent in before Mr. Taylor's departure.
"If he steps down before troops come, you'll have a problem," the archbishop said. Asked if he believed Mr. Taylor's pledge this time, he added: "We have to believe. If we don't believe, what do we do?"
If and when he leaves his country, Mr. Taylor faces another problem: the war crimes tribunal in Sierra Leone. Its prosecutor has said he will not drop the 17-count indictment. Earlier this week, however, Sir Jeremy said that Nigeria, like Britain, had no law compelling it to extradite anyone to a war crimes tribunal.

HEADLINE: Afghanistan, the Forgotten Land 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Far from "hedging its bets," as Sarah Chayes writes in "Afghanistan's Future, Lost in the Shuffle" (Op-Ed, July 1), the United States as well as the United Nations has provided significant military, political and economic support to President Hamid Karzai, not the regional leaders Ms. 
Chayes describes as "warlords." Yet Mr. Karzai's government has grown weaker, and Taliban and Qaeda extremists have reorganized in Kandahar and other Pashtun strongholds. Moreover, Mr. Karzai has rejected the idea of electing local and regional leaders. 
 Ms. Chayes does not mention Afghanistan's fractured ethnic relations or diversity. Not seeing the brutality inflicted upon the non-Pashtun peoples is tantamount to seeing Yugoslavia through the eyes of the Serbs or South Africa through the eyes of the Afrikaners.

CHARLES SANTOS
Director, Foundation for Central
Asian Development
New York, July 2, 2003

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Seoul Warns Europe Not to Raise Tariffs on Hynix Chips

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 4 

 BODY:
The South Korean government warned the European Union today that it would appeal to the World Trade Organization if Europe decided to extend heavy tariffs against Hynix Semiconductor.
 The ministry of foreign affairs and trade said such action would be comparable to the appeal that it had already filed against the decision by the United States Commerce Department to impose a tariff of 44.71 percent on Hynix memory chips. Most members of the European Union favor a 34 percent tariff on Hynix chips, which would slightly increase a tariff already in place. 
 South Korean officials fear that the tariffs will force Hynix into bankruptcy proceedings and liquidation, a process that many foreign analysts think would be healthy for the semiconductor industry and the Korean economy but that Korean officials fear would precipitate more business failures.
The Commerce Department issued its tariff ruling in June based on a complaint by Micron Technology of Boise, Idaho, which surpassed Hynix two years ago as the world's second-leading manufacturer of memory chips after Samsung Electronics. Micron was rebuffed last year in an attempt to buy the plants that produce Hynix memory chips, and it contended that Hynix had cut into its sales in the United States because of large infusions of credit provided by government-controlled Korean banks.
Infineon Technologies of Germany, which is challenging Hynix for third place in the manufacturing of memory chips, has lodged much the same complaint with European authorities. Both Micron and Infineon contend that Hynix is responsible for driving the price of memory chips well below $4 each, the average cost that it takes to make one.
At the heart of the complaints by Micron and Infineon is the role of the Korea Exchange Bank, the lead creditor for Hynix, which now owes more than $6 billion after three major infusions of cash. Both the Korean government and the Korea Exchange Bank have insisted that the bank acted independently. The government, through the Bank of Korea and the government-owned Export-Import Bank, owns a controlling 36 percent stake in the bank.
The European Commission imposed a provisional tariff of 33 percent on Hynix chips in April and is expected to impose the full 34 percent tariff on Aug. 25 when it meets for its final decision. Among the European Union's 15 members, only France and the Netherlands have been reported to oppose the tariff, which would remain in effect for as long as five years.
The South Korean government, in battling the tariffs, stated its case in in a letter to Linnet F. Deily, the United States representative to the World Trade Organization in Geneva, Bloomberg News reported.
The letter, according to Bloomberg, said that the United States had "failed to demonstrate the existence of a financial contribution by the government of Korea."
That is an argument that Korean officials have made repeatedly. The last hope of reversal of the Commerce Department's ruling, short of a long appeals process before the World Trade Organization, rests with the United States International Trade Commission, which will review the decision on July 31.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Computer memory chips made by Hynix Semiconductor in South Korea face increased tariffs from the European Union. The Korean government is also appealing a United States decision to raise tariffs. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Red Light, Green Light 

BYLINE:  By David Willis McCullough; David Willis McCullough's most recent book is "Wars of the Irish Kings."

 BODY:
 BANGKOK 8
By John Burdett.
318 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf.
$24.
 JOHN O'HARA'S "Butterfield 8" is a novel about a prostitute who wants to go straight -- but that's old news. John Burdett's quirky, talky and highly entertaining novel, "Bangkok 8," deals with what seems to be an entire city of prostitutes, and going straight is just about the last thing on anyone's mind. The setting is Thailand's clamorous capital two decades or so after the end of the Vietnam War. The characters include crooked cops from all ranks, a wide choice of prostitutes (both active and retired), respected (if not altogether honest) jade merchants, bemused agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation flown in from Washington, local drug dealers and a highly paid surgeon specializing in sex-change operations. And it all begins with a grotesque variation of an old-fashioned locked-room murder: an American Marine sergeant, driving his luxurious gray Mercedes while being trailed by two Thai detectives, is suddenly entangled in a swarming knot of snakes -- cobras and a python -- that kill him before the policemen can save him.
How was it done? Why was he driving that car and living in an expensive antique teak house that no ordinary marine could afford? Who was the woman in the car just before the attack? Why were the police even following him? It sounds like the promising beginning of what could turn out to be a better than average thriller. But thriller is not the right word for this novel. Toward the end, at just about the time when the pieces in a traditional mystery would begin to come together to produce a logical solution, the narrator confesses that this is not a whodunit, which should surprise no reader who has been paying attention. Anyone expecting to find a tidy trail of clues leading to a logical conclusion will end up as baffled as some of the book's F.B.I. agents.
What Burdett, a former lawyer who now lives in Hong Kong, is doing is seducing his readers into thinking not as logical Westerners devoted to the basic rule of cause and effect but as Thai Buddhists who accept and even celebrate life's illogical turns. The voice of Buddhism is the 32-year-old narrator, Detective Sonchai Jitpleecheep. Since the death of his partner, he seems to be universally regarded as the only surviving honest policeman in District 8, one of Bangkok's principal red-light districts, a place he calls the "essence" of the city, "its heart and its armpit." His partner, Pichai, was accidentally killed by one of the cobras trapped in the marine's Mercedes, and Sonchai has vowed to kill the man -- or woman -- who put them there. Sonchai and Pichai were born and raised in the whorehouses of Bangkok. Both of their mothers were prostitutes, enterprising country girls who had come to the city to cash in on the bordello boom created by the Vietnam War. A turning point in the boys' lives came when they were packed off to a Buddhist monastery to atone for killing a yaa baa (methedrine) dealer. After a grim year of meditation worthy of a prison sentence, the abbot ruled that karma demanded that they become policemen, uncorrupt policemen -- arhats -- and sent them to serve under his youngest brother, the enthusiastically corrupt commanding colonel of District 8. Deep in mourning after Pichai's death, Sonchai speaks of his love for his partner with a frankness unheard of in any of the gritty American television precincts.
There is nothing grim about the way Burdett presents Sonchai's mother and other Thai prostitutes. In a land with few opportunities for women, they have found a way to prosper and be independent. They are models of capitalism and free trade, entrepreneurs who, unlike the sullen Russian prostitutes in Bangkok, are not saddled with pimps. Indeed, the comic high point of this basically noir novel with a surprising number of comic turns comes when Sonchai's mother discovers Viagra, realizes its economic potential and makes plans to open a geriatric brothel called the Old Man's Club. Her business partner is her son's boss, the colonel.
Being an arhat is not Sonchai's only distinction. He is blond, with, as he describes himself, "straw-colored hair and sharp nose," genetic gifts of the mysterious American G.I. father he has never seen. As a result of visits abroad with his mother and her generous English-speaking lovers, he is also something of a linguist, the presentable "front man," that the Royal Thai Police showcase for sensitive dealings with foreigners. Which is another reason he is assigned to work with F.B.I. agents sent to investigate the marine's murder. His primary contact is Kimberley Jones, who becomes his Dr. Watson as they peel back layers of local corruption that rattle tea cups as far away as Washington. She may be an embodiment of the puzzled Westerner, but she is not above wearing a "So Many Men So Little Time" T-shirt when she goes on the town in District 8 with Sonchai.
They follow no tightly linked chain of clues that lead to an orderly conclusion without car chases (Bangkok traffic would not permit them) or shootouts. Although there are a few dramatic face-offs (including what might be called a bullwhip-in-a-china-shop confrontation set in a warehouse full of precious antiques), the solution finally comes not through deduction but meditation and a Buddhist sensitivity to the reincarnations of past lives. Everything is a red herring.
James M. Cain once recalled that when he went to Hollywood to become a screenwriter, the first thing he learned was that everyone in a 
B-picture talks "too smart." That is a problem with "Bangkok 8." Everyone talks too smart -- cops, doctors, prostitutes, homeless yaa baa dealers living under a bridge, a radio talk show host whose voice is overheard at irregular intervals throughout, even an honest, grieving detective sitting on the futon in his tiny windowless apartment. But all the smart talk does not diminish the overwhelming presence of the sprawling, chaotic, illogical city, with its jampacked bars and impassable streets, that invigorates this remarkable novel and makes it something to enjoy for its sheer bravado.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 16

HEADLINE: A Delicate Balance 

BYLINE:  By Jonathan D. Tepperman; Jonathan D. Tepperman is the senior editor at Foreign Affairs magazine.

 BODY:
 AFTER JIHAD
America and the Struggle
for Islamic Democracy.
By Noah Feldman.
260 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.
 THE question bound to preoccupy readers of Noah Feldman's "After Jihad" -- the only reason most readers will pick it up in the first place -- is to learn what kind of future the author envisions for Iraq. 
The reason the answer matters, and that Feldman himself is suddenly so newsworthy, is that he has just been tapped by the Bush administration to help draft Iraq's new constitution. His selection stunned most observers: although Feldman is extremely accomplished and has a background in Islamic as well as United States constitutional law, he's very young (in his early 30's), was raised an Orthodox Jew and worked for Al Gore during the Florida vote recount. Nonetheless, he's already been to Baghdad and back.
For good or ill, however, this slight book doesn't reveal much about how Feldman plans to handle his new responsibilities. He devotes just a few pages to Iraq: it's only one of the many op-ed-length chapters that make up this somewhat disjointed work.
Feldman's project in "After Jihad" is to focus on a more general question: how can political Islam and democracy be reconciled? The answer matters, he writes, because Islamism is one of the few vibrant intellectual movements alive today in the Muslim (especially Arab) world. Repressive governments have found it much harder to shut down mosques than political parties. Canny clerics have tapped into widespread anger while providing much-needed social services that corrupt governments have failed to offer. As a result, political Islam now seems the only alternative to autocracy for many of the planet's 1.2 billion Muslims. Should elections be held in their countries, Islamists of one stripe or another could dominate. 
According to Feldman, however, such a result needn't worry us. On a theoretical level, he finds nothing irreconcilable between Islam and democracy, and argues that they actually have a lot in common. As "mobile ideas," both view everyone as equal; both are flexible (adaptable to different cultures and circumstances) and relatively simple.
True, Islamism's image may have been tarnished in the West by extremists. But that savagery was the work of a few fanatics. "Sept. 11, and the sporadic attacks which have followed," he writes, "are the last, desperate gasp of a tendency to violence that has lost most of its popular support." In contrast, Feldman points to reassuring counterexamples like the rise of moderate Islamic parties in Indonesia, Jordan, Morocco and Turkey, and to the writings of reformers like the Tunisian exile Rachid Ghannouchi to show that fusions of Islam and democracy are not only possible, but inevitable.
With these arguments,Feldman has thrown himself into the center of an unruly brawl now raging in policy circles over what to do with the Arab world. One faction consists of the cautious staff members of the State Department, pessimists (or "realists," as they prefer to be called) for whom culture is destiny and the Middle East an unredeemable mess. Another camp is represented by thinkers like Bernard Lewis and Fouad Ajami, who are almost as critical of Arab states as the pessimists but advocate a new American imperium to remake the region. Still a third faction includes scholars like Graham Fuller and John L. Esposito, who have so much faith in Arab reformers that they oppose outside interference. 
And now Feldman has staked out territory squarely in the middle. On the one hand, he joins with Lewis and company in pushing for America to intervene on the side of democracy. Feldman is unabashed about his support for Western activism: "If these methods sound interventionist," he writes at one point, "that is because they are." Such language makes him sound at times like one of Donald Rumsfeld's wild-eyed neoconservatives. Where he parts company with the right, however, is in his unflinching insistence that democracy in the Arab world should be Islamic in character (although he hedges on just what that will mean).
Eying this debate from the outside, how should a lay reader sort out the battling experts' radically different views? Feldman himself provides a kind of answer. Deciding whether to trust in Islamic democracy is a bit of a gamble, he admits. Push for open elections in the Arab world, and the short-term result may be radical, anti-American governments. But ignore the urge for democracy and the United States risks engendering an even bigger backlash. Besides, Arab dictators run the real danger of bloody overthrow. Thus, "in the starkest terms, the question is whether to entertain the risk of disaster in the form of a revolution that is not certain but would be extraordinarily costly, or to take on the less costly risk of destabilization that definitely accompanies a process of democratization."
This account gets far more right than it gets wrong; uncritical support for Arab dictators (including, at one time, Saddam Hussein) has indeed been a disastrous policy, and a betrayal of America's revolutionary democratic example. The main problem with the choice Feldman offers, however, is his presumption that moderation will ultimately prevail. For that to happen, we have to rely on the Islamists not to interfere with future elections once they themselves win office. Unfortunately, Islamists have proven unreliable protectors of pluralism: for example, the Ayatollah Khomeini's mullahs assembled a broad-based republican coalition to topple the shah in 1979 -- and then proceeded to undermine and eliminate every rival. Absolutists and fundamentalists tend not to be good compromisers.
As for Iraq, Feldman is now almost uniquely well positioned to help shape the rules of the game there. And one of the few things Feldman does promise for that country's future is that it will be Islamic as well as democratic. A few words of caution, however. Iraq's main fault lines are ethnic, tribal and sectarian. Feldman says very little about the role of economics, class or culture in the development of democracy -- factors that could play an even greater role than religion. Furthermore, Iraq is famously split between two very different forms of Islam: Shiite and Sunni (to say nothing of half a million Christians). How can Islam play anything more than a symbolic role in government when future voters cannot even agree on the definition of "Islamic"? Untangling that knot may prove impossible. Let's hope that in trying, Feldman doesn't overlook the solution that has worked pretty well in the West: a secular constitution that favors no one religion at all.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Had Enough Of the Flag Yet?

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
THE week before Independence Day, the Dixie Chicks played the Washington MCI Center, a mere dozen blocks or so from the White House. "Well, what do you know, Washington, D.C.," said the singer Natalie Maines, prompting a standing ovation from the crowd. "If I'm not mistaken, the president of the United States lives here." Then, as The Washington Post reported, the cheers grew even louder.
 As we conclude this Fourth of July weekend, let us not forget the happy denouement to the saga of Ms. Maines, whose crime against America was to tell a London audience in March that she was "ashamed that the president of the United States is from Texas." What followed were boycotts, death threats and a ritualistic network TV flogging in which, as Jim Lewis put it in Slate, Diane Sawyer demanded that the Chicks "affirm their patriotism and their support for the troops" in the "tradition of a Stalinist show trial." 
 No matter. The Dixie Chicks have been able to exercise free speech happily all the way to the bank. They've posed nude for the cover of Entertainment Weekly with "Saddam's Angels" emblazoned on their flesh. Their album "Home" rebounded from its brief dip, returning to No. 1 on the country chart for weeks. Their tour has sold out from its first stop, that left-wing stronghold Greenville, S.C. The Dixie Chicks may be bigger than ever. 
From national infamy to renewed superstardom in a matter of weeks: that's the kind of story that restores your faith in an America where everything is possible. And most Americans, the Dixie Chicks no doubt included, not only have that faith in their country but love it as well. Yet you'd never know it from the more embittered cultural battles that have raged since 9/11.
"Read 'Treason' this Fourth of July, and let the fireworks begin" commands the full-page ad hawking the latest book by Ann Coulter. In it the author claims that every liberal in the country -- or at least every liberal Democrat -- "hates America" and is guilty of her titular crime, which, last time I looked, is punishable by death. (The Dixie Chicks escaped her noose by turning traitor only after her book went to press.) According to her book jacket bio, Ms. Coulter's expertise in delivering such sweeping condemnations derives from having been "named one of the top 100 public intellectuals by federal judge Richard Posner in 2001." What she doesn't add -- and this is typical of her own intellectual methodology in "Treason" -- is that the list was compiled not on the basis of smarts but on the number of times names turned up in the media during the Clinton-hating heyday of 1995 to 2000. Mr. Posner's book was titled "Public Intellectuals: A Study of Decline" (my italics), and by its ranking system, Ms. Coulter turns out to be far less of an intellectual than such conspicuous traitors as Sidney Blumenthal, Susan Sontag and Gore Vidal.
At least she doesn't slap the flag on the front of her book to wrap herself in it. (She chose instead an idealized photo of something she loves more than Old Glory: herself.) The same cannot be said of Dick Morris and Sean Hannity, who use the Stars and Stripes as a merchandising tool for their own self-aggrandizingly patriotic screeds cashing in on their TV celebrity. In this, they follow the lead of their employer, the Fox News Channel, which, like its less successful cable rivals, has exploited the flag as a logo to sell itself as more patriotic than thou.
Such flag-waving for personal and corporate profit has gotten so out of hand that last month, when the House of Representatives passed a constitutional amendment banning flag desecration for the umpteenth time, I for once found myself rooting for the Senate to follow suit. It would be fun to watch TV executives hauled on to Court TV. If NBC's post-9/11 decision to slap the flag on screen in the shape of its trademarked peacock wasn't flag desecration, what is? 
As patriotism is the last refuge of scoundrels, so the coercive patriotism of this historical moment is the last refuge of cynics. In "The Story of American Freedom," the historian Eric Foner observes that a similar phenomenon occurred a little over a century ago, uncoincidentally enough, in tandem with "America's triumphant entry onto the world stage as an imperial power" during the Spanish-American War. It was in the 1890's that "rituals like the Pledge of Allegiance and the practice of standing for the playing of 'The Star-Spangled Banner' came into existence," as well as Flag Day. Our leaders were then professing to spread democracy to Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Philippines with the same blithe self-assurance that our current leaders promise to bring the American way to Iraq and its neighbors.
The rituals we get to accompany our 21st-century imperial interlude include fights over the Pledge of Allegiance and a costumed president's re-enactment of Hollywood's "Top Gun." Most bizarre is the defense department's new Operation Tribute to Freedom, initiated on Memorial Day weekend, which offers talking points to those citizens too challenged to figure out for themselves how "to demonstrate public appreciation for American men and women in uniform." (One approved method: listing your name and "patriotic activities" on a government Web site.) When America's patriotism turns this "garrulous," as Alexis de Tocqueville once observed, it "wearies even those who are disposed to respect it."
But patriotism needn't make us so weary. Look around our culture, and it isn't hard to find a faith in America that is not defined by government-commissioned flag-waving, political demagoguery or cable news's jingoism-as-marketing-strategy. The most telling American fables don't come in the blacks and whites of our current strident political and cultural discourse, which so often divides Americans into either flag-draped heroes or abject traitors. The great American stories, from Huckleberry Finn's to the Dixie Chicks', have always been nuanced; they can have poetry and they can have dark shadows. They can combine a love of country with an implicit criticism of it.
One example this summer is the movie that could prove to be the redeeming Hollywood entertainment of this schlock-movie year: Gary Ross's adaptation of Laura Hillenbrand's "Seabiscuit," opening later this month. The title character, as almost everyone knows by now, is the misshapen race-horse-that-could of the 1930's that captivated the nation, becoming a bigger story than Hitler and F.D.R. on the eve of World War II.
The unlikely triumph of the horse, its jockey (Tobey Maguire in the film), its trainer (Chris Cooper) and its owner (Jeff Bridges) is right out of Horatio Alger, but as presented by Mr. Ross, the Depression background of economic injustice and deprivation is in the same sharp focus as the nail-biting foreground at Santa Anita. It's precisely this panoramic context that makes a classic American struggle against all odds all the more poignant. Not every American rooting for Seabiscuit, after all, got a piece of the purse. 
"Seabiscuit" could be a bookend to an unexpected film success that's been sweeping the country since late spring, the documentary "Spellbound," about eight young contestants in the National Spelling Bee of 1999. The kids it chronicles are almost a too-perfect American cross-section -- from a privileged child of the suburbs to the black daughter of a single mother in a D.C. housing project to (most stirringly) the daughter of non-English-speaking Mexican immigrants in the Texas Panhandle. The Bee is arguably as wacky as a Coney Island hot-dog-eating contest, and the parents who cheer the kids on can occasionally be as hard-driving as the appalling stage parents on Fox's insufferable weekly tots' talent contest, "American Juniors."
One such parent in "Spellbound" is an immigrant from India who drills his son tirelessly, prepping him on as many as 8,000 words a day in the family's beach house in San Clemente, Calif. "There is no way you can fail in this country," the father says while showing off the home he designed and built himself. "That's one guarantee in this country -- if you work hard, you'll make it." As the movie then demonstrates, that is far from the case. There are nine million children competing in the National Spelling Bee, most of them working hard, and, as in the races of "Seabiscuit," only one competitor comes in first.
As one of our best playwrights, Richard Greenberg, writes in another genuinely patriotic drama on tap this summer, the baseball play "Take Me Out," these all-American competitions reveal something about America that our current political debates avoid: "While conservatives tell you, leave things alone and no one will lose, and liberals tell you, interfere a lot and no one will lose, baseball says: Someone will lose . . . So that baseball achieves the tragic vision that democracy evades."
Even if their parents sometimes forget, the children in "Spellbound" understand this tragic vision implicitly, but are not defeated by it and do not deserve to be labeled un-American for recognizing it. Like Red Pollard, the washed-up jockey who makes good in "Seabiscuit," they will look for the second chances that America at its best affords those who lose the game.
Most Americans, whatever their age, don't need politicians or government boondoggles like Operation Tribute to Freedom or enforced flag-waving or fictionalized TV dramatizations of Jessica Lynch's rescue to tell them what it means to be an American. You see the wise, optimistic young citizens of "Spellbound," whether struggling or triumphant, and you see the whole package that is America, imperfect and heartbreaking as it sometimes is. That the Ann Coulters of 2003 look around our nation and see traitors everywhere is pathetic, but not so much so that they can spoil what we celebrate on the Fourth.

HEADLINE: Mutal Funds Report; 
Currency Hedges: Thick With Obscurity

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
BECAUSE of the dollar's swoon, many investors may be attracted to foreign bond and stock funds for the extra returns a weaker dollar can provide.
 But policies on hedging foreign currency risk are not always clearly stated on mutual fund Web sites or in fund prospectuses. Investors can easily be confused about how much currency exposure they are carrying, even if they pay close attention. 
 "It is hard to make hard-and-fast distinctions between funds," said Lynn Russell, a mutual fund analyst at Morningstar Inc. who focuses on global bond funds. 
Through hedging, a fund manager turns at least some of the value of foreign bonds or stocks back into dollars, aiming to minimize the drain on a fund's performance from a rising dollar. As a result, when the dollar falls against the euro, a hedged portfolio of euro-denominated stocks does not reap the full benefits of the currency shift. By contrast, a portfolio of foreign stocks that is not hedged will benefit when the dollar weakens and will be hurt when the dollar gains.
"The risk profile of an unhedged fund is going to be a lot more volatile than a fully hedged fund," said Eric Jacobson, senior analyst and fixed-income editor at Morningstar.
Hedging, of course, can be complicated. Some funds compete against a benchmark index that is partially hedged back to dollars. A global fund, which can include bonds or stocks from the United States, is effectively partially hedged to the extent that it holds dollar-denominated assets.
In addition, some portfolio managers have recently dropped their hedges as the dollar's decline has stretched into its 18th month. And some managers say on their fund Web sites and in fund prospectuses that their portfolios are hedged, without explaining that they are actually heightening currency risk by making bets on currency moves in an effort to bolster returns.
For those reasons, investors may be unable to discern the policies of their funds easily. "For the ones that fall in between or change their policies, it is a lot harder to know where you are," Ms. Russell said.
At Putnam Investments, Paresh Upadhyaya, a currency analyst, is trying to raise returns in global and international funds by making currency bets that magnify the effects of foreign currency movements against the dollar.
Bill Kohli, managing director for core fixed-income at Putnam and portfolio manager of its Global Income Trust, said he used these currency recommendations to improve the performance of his fund against its benchmark, the Lehman Global Aggregate Index. The index is 41 percent invested in dollar assets, so it is effectively 41 percent hedged, limiting the benefits of a falling dollar.
Mr. Kohli has increased the fund's foreign-currency exposure based on Mr. Upadhyaya's advice. Currently, Mr. Upadhyaya is advocating positions that favor the Canadian and Australian dollars, as well as the British pound, and that underweight the Japanese yen. To control the amount of risk added to the fund, Mr. Kohli increased its currency exposure by half of Mr. Upadhyaya's recommendation.
These added currency plays have added 4.7 percentage points to the fund's return, bringing the total return to 8.9 percent through June, Mr. Kohli said.
"If investors want to diversify their returns and they think they are in an environment where the dollar might decline, this is a good way to try to add to their returns," Mr. Upadhyaya said.
This currency strategy, however, is not clear in the prospectus. And the fund description on the firm's Web site does not say that the fund's hedging strategies include adding or reducing currency exposure to increase returns. Only in the annual report dated October 2002 is there a reference to how "our euro currency positions performed well" because the fund was "overweight the euro."
Some funds are clearer about what they do. The Pimco Foreign Bond fund states on both the company Web site and in the prospectus that it hedges at least 75 percent of its foreign exposure back into dollars. Its return through June is 3.4 percent because it has missed most of the gains from the weaker dollar, which has fallen 8.9 percent against the euro, 2.7 percent against the British pound, 16.6 percent against the Australian dollar and 14.3 percent against the Canadian dollar.
The Pimco Global Bond II fund has about 29 percent of its assets in United States bonds and the remainder in foreign bonds. It also hedges at least 75 percent of its foreign exposure back into dollars, giving it a return through the second quarter of 3.8 percent. The Pimco Global Bond fund, however, leaves its foreign bond exposure unhedged and has returned 8.3 percent through the second quarter this year. But it is open only to institutional investors.
The BlackRock International Bond Portfolio switched from a hedged strategy to an unhedged strategy at the end of March. Its return in the first quarter this year was 2.1 percent, compared with 4.1 percent in the second quarter. But the fund's prospectus gives its managers considerable leeway in dealing with currency risk. They can make extra bets on currency, the way Putnam's managers can, and they could start hedging again if they chose to do so.
Anne Ackerley, the head of BlackRock's private client group, which includes mutual funds, said the fund had changed to the unhedged strategy because investors apparently preferred the currency exposure.
She said the fund was unlikely to go back to hedging. While the fund can make extra currency bets, she added, they would be no more than one to two percentage points above the exposure of the fund's benchmark. These possible refinements are not in the prospectus.
ANDREW CLARK, senior research analyst at Lipper, said an analysis of total returns indicated that funds investing in emerging-markets bonds have relatively little foreign currency risk because they usually own debt from developing countries that is denominated in dollars.
For funds investing in developed markets, he said, about half of the returns, on average, are apparently driven by currency movements. In general, that means that the funds would be about 50 percent hedged.
But it is hard for investors to know. "There really isn't a good answer in the prospectus," he said, "and that's sad."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
A Burnout Cure That Few Companies Prescribe

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING

 BODY:
LESTER E. BADDEN acknowledges that after two decades at Nike, working in a fast-paced job that includes arranging for shoe designers to view live dissections of human cadaver feet, he needed to catch his breath. So, two summers ago, Mr. Badden, a senior design manager at the company, took a brief sabbatical. It is a perk for employees who have been with the company for at least 10 years. 
 Under the program, Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., grants eligible employees five weeks off, with full salary and benefits, to do just about anything they want. After they become eligible, workers can use the perk every five years. The program, intended to help prevent worker burnout, started in 1994, though Nike says it does not know how many employees have used it over all. 
 Mr. Badden, 56, said he had been eligible for the program since its inception but had always been too busy. He spent his sabbatical building a treehouse for his two young children and "fixing things around the house" in Portland, Ore., where he lives with his wife, Gerri, 49. 
As more workers across the country feel overworked, and often stressed, because of continuing job cuts in a sluggish economy, many would welcome such extra time to spend with their families or to rethink career goals. But paid sabbaticals, or leaves of absence with salary and benefits intact, remain rare in corporate America. Only 5 percent of employers offered them last year, according to a survey by the Society for Human Resource Management. 
Sabbaticals are used more today, though, than they were in the mid- to late 1990's, when they gained a toehold in the workplace. In 1997, only 3 percent of American employers offered paid leaves of absence, according to the group.
Jon Van Cleve, a consultant at Hewitt Associates, a human-resources consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., said sabatticals are unlikely to become widespread anytime soon. He cited their cost to employers and the slimmer payrolls at many companies, which have made it difficult for employers to maintain productivity levels, he said.
At companies that offer paid sabbaticals, managers say the leaves give employees a way to recharge their mental batteries and to come back refreshed -- and often more productive. "We're looking for energy and creativity, and it's hard to be like that without rejuvenating," said Louise J. Rothman, a senior vice president for human resources at Charles Schwab in San Francisco. Schwab, which started its program in April 2000, gives employees four weeks' paid leave for every five years they have worked at the company; the leaves cannot be combined. Other companies that offer paid leaves of several weeks include American Century and the Frank Russell Company, two financial services businesses; the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner; and Genentech, the biotechnology company. 
More widespread are unpaid sabbaticals. Last year, 17 percent of American employers offered unpaid leaves, with benefits intact, according to the Society for Human Resource Management; the percentage was unchanged from 1998. Frank J. Scanlan, a spokesman for the group, said he did not expect that figure to rise anytime soon.
Corporate recruiters and benefits experts warn, however, that sabbaticals of any type can pose a threat to some workers' careers.
"If you're on sabbatical, someone has not only taken over your tasks, they've taken on your role," said Peter Capelli, a business professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. "Individuals don't want to be away from the chase that long because they may feel they'll be forgotten and they'll lose out on the race to the top."
Mr. Badden, the design manager from Nike, said he harbored no such worries. But others who have taken sabbaticals said that while they did not feel that their careers had suffered, they sensed an ambient unease among colleagues.
Bruce P. Flynn, an estate and trust lawyer for 15 years at the Seattle firm of Perkins Coie, said that "some lawyers have a concern that they may lose clients if they spend a protracted amount of time away from the office." Mr. Flynn, 56, said he had delayed his eight-week sabbatical for several years because of a heavy workload. When he finally decided to take a leave, at the urging of his wife, Mary Ann, he informed his clients well in advance. By adding a month of regular vacation to the leave, he was able to spend 12 weeks from January to April traveling through South America and then relaxing at his condominium in Scottsdale, Ariz. 
"Most of them were very pleased that I had the opportunity," he said of his clients. "And it's not a bad way to expose your clients to other competent people."
He said that he returned to work "totally refreshed" and that his clients were not upset by his absence.
BUT in a world awash in cellphones and e-mail, it can be difficult to unplug from the workplace and receive a sabbatical's intended benefit. "I didn't totally disconnect, and I always knew what was going on," Mr. Badden said.
Citing layoffs and restructurings, Alan Johnson, a managing director of Johnson Associates, a compensation consulting firm in New York, said that "in this economy, most people would be nervous about being away from their jobs for a couple of months."
Though an employee cannot be dismissed, of course, for taking a company-promoted leave, an employer may be within its legal rights if it undertakes broader layoffs during that time that result in the loss of that employee's job, said Patrick W. Shea, an employment law lawyer at the Stamford, Conn., office of Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker.
Sometimes, employees may create their own sabbaticals and take their chances of having a job when they return. Although she did not qualify for her company's regular program, Amy J. Paulsen, 44, decided to leave her job as executive editor of Time's Teen People magazine about two years ago to sail around the world with her husband, Albert Nalle, a sculptor, and their two young daughters. The family financed the leave, from September 2001 to September 2002, by renting their New York apartment. Her job was filled by someone else, and she returned to a senior-level but short-term editing job at a sister publication, InStyle Specials magazine. She is now a part-time consultant for Teen People.
"I had no guarantee of a job when I came back," Ms. Paulsen said. "But we had made up our minds we were going to do this." She said she had hoped to land a senior-level, full-time magazine-editing job.
Some companies have used unpaid sabbaticals as a way to save money without resorting to layoffs. Last summer, Qwest Communications International, the telecommunications company based in Denver, offered employees a voluntary unpaid sabbatical, with benefits still intact, over July and August to reduce labor costs. 
In academia, sabbaticals have been common for decades as a way for scholars to undertake or complete time-consuming projects in their fields. In corporate America, paid sabbaticals were first offered by engineering and technology companies in the 1970's and 80's to help star employees avoid burnout. Many dot-com companies adopted them in the 1990's as a recruiting tool. These days, they are offered more often in industries like publishing, financial services and transportation, according to the Society for Human Resource Management. They are rarely offered by utilities or manufacturing companies, or by the government, the group's data shows. 
Statistics are hard to come by on the percentage of American workers who are eligible for paid sabbaticals who actually take them. But some employment experts suspect that relatively few eligible employees avail themselves of the opportunity. 
"The reality is that most people would find it hard to take time off," said Eileen P. Maraldo, vice president for benefits at Time Inc. "Most people would say they have a lot of work to do." 
Referring to the company's own sabbatical program, she added, "I can't say we promote it specifically or go out of our way to solicit people to take them." Time offers employees a six-month leave, at half salary, after 15 years of service, or a three-month leave, at 75 percent salary, after 20 years. Employees can take only one, not both, of the sabbaticals. Case by case, Time also permits longer, unpaid leaves like the one that Ms. Paulsen took.
ANECDOTAL evidence from various companies suggests that senior employees on the verge of retirement are more likely to take advantage of the programs. Of the 47 employees at Time who took leaves last year, 27 were retiring, Ms. Maraldo said.
Preparing to take a rest from the job often involves a lot of work. Most companies require employees to clear their plans with their supervisors and to make extensive arrangements with colleagues to cover their jobs, if necessary. "You can't just say, 'I'm out of here for six months.' You have to work it out with your manager," Ms. Maraldo said.
Sarah B. Renz, 39, a production services manager at American Century, based in Kansas City, Mo., said that before she went on a cruise to Tahiti in May 2001 as part of her four-week paid sabbatical, she made a list of all her meetings and responsibilities "and doled out work to different people on my team." American Century offers four weeks of paid leave after seven years of service, and another four weeks every five years thereafter.
Ms. Renz's boss, Diane D. Stanley, said co-workers did not resent her leave. "They know their time will come," she said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Wondering If Office Market Has Plumbed Bottom

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
HALFWAY through the year -- which has been more or less awful for New Jersey's office real estate market, as was 2002 -- the question increasingly being asked concerns how much longer things will go on like this. 
 Fresh statistics on market activity in the second quarter of 2003 are not exactly encouraging: the overall office vacancy rate for both lease and sublease space dropped a fraction of a point, to 19.1 percent from 19.3 percent in the first quarter, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Insignia/ESG's numbers were slightly different, showing vacancies up to 19.9 percent from 18.6 percent. 
 In certain areas, the overall vacancy rate was much higher. According to Cushman & Wakefield, it was 30.9 percent in a small submarket in western Morris County and 36.1 percent in a 114-building market along Route 78 in Somerset County and in a 61-building market on the northern stretch of Route 287 in Middlesex County. 
Still, Sam Buckley, Insignia's senior managing director, said there were signs of "bottoming out" and he added, "It has to stop getting worse before it can get better."
Christopher Kinum, Cushman's senior managing director, talked of "the bleeding" stopping. And Jeff Schotz, executive managing officer for GVA Williams, said, "There is reason to think and hope that we are poised to return to a semblance of health."
These brokers, and a number of others, said that as the quarter ended, there had been an increase in the number of deals for office space and pointed to that as a positive sign -- even though this was not yet substantial enough to affect quarterly market statistics. "There is action, there is life," Mr. Schotz said. "There is reason for optimism -- if not real tangible signs."
In late June, Barnes & Noble leased 75,000 square feet at 300 Mountain View Boulevard, Basking Ridge, for its college bookstore division, for example. The move represents the bookseller's entry into the New Jersey office market, said Tom Reilly of CB Richard Ellis, who represented Barnes & Noble on the deal. In addition, he said, the company will be the first tenant for the 133,960-square-foot office building, which the Gale Company built on speculation and which has stood empty for two years.
Another leasing deal that closed as the quarter ended was Tyco International's seven-year sublease of 146,000 square feet of space that Merrill Lynch had leased after its offices weredestroyed in the Sept. 11 attack on Manhattan. Tyco, the troubled conglomerate that is based in Bermuda, plans to set up a United States headquarters in the space at the Commons at Princeton complex in West Windsor, relocating from several other offices in New York City, New Hampshire and elsewhere.
MR. BUCKLEY said there were only a few Class A sublease spaces left, "fewer than people might suspect." 
"Those are starting to be leased, and once they are, then the market for direct leasing of Class A space and build-to-suit office space, can really pick up," he said.
"Right now," said the Insignia executive, whose company represents both owners and tenants, "there is almost no way to compete head to head with Class A sublet space on price -- because the tenant has already taken the space and can't use it, so anything they make in terms of rent is gravy."
Brokers said much of the activity was being generated by companies that might logically be expected to do well despite difficult economic times, or even because of them: pharmaceutical companies, law firms, finance and mortgage companies, and real estate service concerns.
Also, brokers said, some large established companies can be expected to take advantage of low interest rates and asking prices that have been stubbornly slow to come down from the highs of 2000. I.B.M., for example, recently renewed and expanded its lease at Washington Plaza in Piscataway; it now occupies a total of 78,353 square feet, bringing the building at 1551 South Washington Avenue to full occupancy.
Sedgwick, Detert, Moran & Arnold, a law firm, recently relocated to 3 Gateway Center in Newark from offices at 1 Gateway. The firm sublet the entire 12th floor for its new office. Also, Accenture, the consulting firm, extended and expanded its lease to 66,436 square feet of space at 5-95 Spring Street in New Providence.
A drug company, Pliva Inc., formerly Sidmak Laboratories, has just signed a lease for almost half the 140,000-square-foot building at 72 Eagle Rock Avenue in East Hanover owned by the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation. And a broker with knowledge of the deal said that Dendrite International, a pharmaceutical software company, was set to sublease 220,000 feet of space in a Bedminster building that had been occupied by Pharmacia before it was taken over by Pfizer.
In May, a real estate company, Advance Realty Group, bought a three-story, 56,000-square-foot office building at 310 Madison Avenue in downtown Morristown from the Jersey City Power and Light Company.
"Some fairly large deals have been consummated," Mr. Schotz said last week, "and even more interesting, right now there are at least 17 deals where companies are looking for space in excess of 100,000 square feet in central and northern New Jersey."
Mark Yeager, president of the Gale Company, said a number of "high-profile requirements" -- requests to find space for well-known companies -- had emerged in recent weeks. He also noted a surge of activity in the Montville-Woodcliff Lake area, where Toys "R" Us, Sony and Merck are already in place. Like Mr. Schotz, Mr. Yeager would not name particular companies now seeking space in New Jersey, but he said, "In the last four weeks, we've had a diversity in requirements, various industry types, interested in different parts of the state, for traditional office space, flex space and build-to-suit. 
"That is different. I don't think things are necessarily better, but they are different. When it goes from really bad to different, that is the first step to better."
Several brokers referred to their feelings and hunches about how and when economic conditions might change.
Pointing to the Barnes & Noble lease, Mr. Buckley said, "This may be the summer of the big deal." Entering the traditionally slow summer months, "people are going to be making their best below-market deals," he said.
Insignia's second-quarter figures showed a continued drop in annual rental rates, showing the per-square-foot asking rate to be down to $25.15 from $25.44 in the first quarter and $25.74 in 2002.
Jonathan B. Schultz, chief executive of the Schultz Organization/TCN Worldwide, a property management firm, agreed that "more midsize companies are taking advantage of current conditions to do lease renewals or expansions." But he added that he did not expect any discernible improvement in the market for some time.
"Even if the economy has pretty much hit bottom, the large companies need time to figure out what they are doing -- whether any more layoffs will be made, whether consolidations or downsizing might still be necessary," he said. 
"My opinion is that we are six to 12 months away from a complete bottom. The bottom to me is just before interest rates start going up -- and they just lowered interest rates another quarter point."
Mr. Yeager predicted that it would be the end of the year before the office market began to revive. "We are not yet where we need to be in terms of economic recovery," he said. "We're still kind of scuttling along the bottom. It's just a guess when we start to go up."

HEADLINE: Mutal Funds Report; 
Strategies For Bonds If Rates Head Up

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN

 BODY:
BOND investors learn early on that bond values rise when interest rates fall. Indeed, during the tumble in rates over the last year, bond fund holders have benefited mightily. But the opposite also holds true: as interest rates rise, bond prices fall, and some professional bond investors are worried that this could happen in the next year.
 In the 12 months through June, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note dropped to 3.52 percent from 4.83 percent, and yields of other government and corporate bonds of varying maturities also tumbled. In the same period, the average taxable bond fund had a total return of 11 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., while stock funds fell 0.4 percent, on average. 
 To stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve has cut interest rates repeatedly, including a quarter-point cut in the federal funds rate late last month, so that rates are now hovering at their lowest levels in nearly five decades. Now, a growing number of bond investors worry that if a recovery takes hold -- fueled by sweeping federal tax cuts and low borrowing rates for consumers and businesses -- rates could turn around and begin to climb within the next year.
Rising interest rates would have an especially negative effect on the value of longer-term bonds, which are more sensitive than short-term bonds to interest rate moves.
An increase of one percentage point in interest rates could result in a 4 percent decline in the value of the Lehman Aggregate Bond index, a benchmark consisting of corporate and government bonds, according to Mark Kiesel, an executive vice president of Pimco, whose Total Return bond fund is the world's largest.
A basket of longer-maturity bonds could fall by more than double that amount.
"It would not surprise us if we have one of the worst bond markets on record in the next 12 to 18 months," said Robert Rodriguez, a principal at First Pacific Advisors and manager of the FPA New Income fund, one of the most successful bond funds of the last decade.
Even managers who are less bearish than Mr. Rodriguez accept the likelihood of rising rates and falling bond values in the next year or two. "Interest rate risk has moved up in terms of importance because rates are so low right now," said Mr. Kiesel, who helps oversee corporate bond strategy at Pimco.
The negative outlook raises a question: Should bond investors act now to protect their gains? Or should they just sit tight?
There is no consensus, but some bond fund managers recommend that investors, especially those heavily weighted in bonds with maturities of 10 years or more, reduce or eliminate their exposure to an inevitable upturn in rates. Investors could reduce their allocation to bonds and bond funds over all, or shift from funds with longer-maturity bonds to funds that buy only short-term ones.
Mutual fund companies like Fidelity Investments, the Vanguard Group and Pimco have portfolios that invest primarily in short-term or "low-duration" bonds. Investors in Pimco Total Return, with more than $75 billion in assets, may want to consider Pimco Low Duration, with $12 billion in assets. Though the low-duration fund has a yield that is half a point lower than that of Total Return, it also has less than half the interest rate risk.
For every one-point increase in interest rates, the price of a bond or bond fund will fall by its duration number in percentage terms. That means a bond or bond fund with a duration of 8 years -- considered fairly long -- would be likely to lose about 8 percent of its value if interest rates rose by one percentage point. That loss would double, to 16 percent, if interest rates rose two points. Conversely, any declines in interest rates would send bond prices up in the same way.
Low-duration bond funds tend to lose no more than 2 percent of their value because of a one-point uptick in rates.
In recent months, some managers have shortened their funds' duration to reduce their interest rate sensitivity. In the last three years, for example, Mr. Rodriguez has cut the duration of New Income portfolio to 1.3 years from 4 years, lowering its rate sensitivity by about two-thirds. A year ago, the fund had a duration of 2.5 years. 
Some fund managers argue that an investor should not move aggressively into lower-duration funds. That would be a form of market timing, they say, and generally counterproductive to long-term investment goals. They recommend staying with bond funds that have middle-of-the-road maturity and duration levels and to hold on through shifts in the interest rate cycle.
"For most people, the middle is where they should be," said Kevin Grant, a Fidelity vice president who manages several broad-based portfolios, including the Investment Grade Bond and Spartan Investment Grade Bond funds.
Trying to anticipate interest rate swings by changing duration bets is a loser's game, he said. People who play it, he added, could find themselves in the position of investors who miss a recovery in the stock market because they cash out.
"The biggest problem with market timing is, what if the market goes against you?" Mr. Grant said.
He said interest rates could remain low, or even fall further if an economic recovery did not materialize and inflation stayed near historic lows. Indeed, he said, high unemployment and the Fed's recent decision to lower rates are signs that the economic stimulus that would push up interest rates could still be a long way off. 
MR. GRANT recommends that investors stick with a good, broad-based, intermediate-term offering, and consider controlling interest rate risk through dollar-cost averaging. In that technique, the investor buys the same dollar amount of bonds every month or quarter, and ends up acquiring more bonds when yields or interest rates are high and fewer when yields are low.
"I think you need to be thinking about a 10- to 20-year minimum investment if you are going to use this approach," he said.
But in many circumstances, a shift in duration can make sense. For example, many investors use bonds for short-term needs, like income for retirement or a child's college education.
The Vanguard Group offers a wide array of no-load, short-term taxable and tax-exempt bond funds that can be used as alternatives or to complement its intermediate and long-term offerings. Portfolios include Short-Term Bond Index, which holds an assortment of corporate and government bonds, and more specialized offerings like Short-Term Corporate Bond and Short-Term Federal, which holds government and agency bonds.
"For investors with new money to put to work, we're advising not to chase yield and therefore not to buy long-term funds," said Robert Auwaerter, the head of fixed-income investing at Vanguard. "Instead, they should buy a combination of short- and intermediate-term bond funds."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
How Much Does It Cost Not to Go To the Gym?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
YOU belong to a health club but visit it only once or twice a month. Your wallet is filled with gift cards to Barnes & Noble and the Gap that you promise you will use soon. You exhausted your prepaid cellphone minutes last month and faced hefty charges when you continued to make calls, but you are sure it will not happen again.
 You are, in the words of a new research study, an overconfident consumer. 
 Such irrational confidence in one's own behavior is hardly new. The flight of Icarus, the voyage of the Titanic and the bull market of the 1920's all attest to the timelessness of human hubris.
But the day-to-day economic consequences of this hubris have rarely been as large as they are now. As the economy has become more sophisticated and simple cash is involved in fewer and fewer transactions, people must plan ahead far more than they once did. They need to choose a health care plan and to estimate whether they are spending more money on their credit cards than they are earning in salary. Among a myriad of payment plans for long-distance phone service, Internet access and gym membership, they must decide which ones will cost least. 
They -- we, that is -- rarely succeed, according to recent research by economists from Stanford to Harvard. The loss of income from these mistakes is quickly becoming significant for many households.
Health club memberships offer a particularly clear case study, probably because they offer two opportunities for excess optimism. First, people overestimate the number of times they will make the effort to get to the treadmill or the weight room. Then they congratulate themselves for seeming to save money by buying an expensive gym membership that rewards frequent visitors.
Stefano DellaVigna, an assistant professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, and Ulrike Malmendier, an assistant professor of finance at Stanford, recently collected data at three health clubs in New England. Like many others, the clubs offer three basic membership plans. People can pay about $10 a visit, a monthly fee of about $70 or an annual fee of roughly $700.
Relatively few people pick the annual contract, leaving them with what seems like a fairly simple comparison. If they expect to go to the gym at least seven times a month -- or about twice a week -- the monthly package makes sense. Any less of a gym rat should pay $10 each visit.
This seems a good place to pause, set aside feelings of financial superiority and ask yourself how often you go to the gym. The answer for this overconfident consumer, who pays a flat monthly fee at his gym, is about once a week.
In the study, monthly members go about as often and, as a result, pay the equivalent of about $17 a visit. Only one in five members saved money by buying the monthly contract, the professors found when they studied the clubs' records. Over a six-month period, the average member would have saved more than $150 by paying for each visit. 
THE professors summarize their findings by quoting from one of the fictional diaries of Bridget Jones: "Monday 28 April. Gym visits 0, no. of gym visits so far this year 1, cost of gym membership per year $:370." 
Now extend this overconfidence across the consumer economy. People will spend more than $40 billion this year on retail gift cards, the plastic successors to gift certificates. That is up from about $13 billion five years ago, according to the consulting firm Bain & Company. A few pennies of every dollar on these cards will never be spent. Households will also rack up cellphone charges and credit-card interest fees because they made unrealistic assumptions about their own spending patterns.
Economists describe this as "time-inconsistent behavior." When the benefits of an action are far in the future and the costs are immediate, people do not give the benefits much weight. Tomorrow's buff body loses out to the dread of today's workout, and a reduced risk of cancer is obscured by the pleasure of a cigarette. When the costs are in the future and the benefits immediate, as when the purchase of a new BlackBerry requires only the flick of a credit card, the benefits eclipse the costs.
For Bally Total Fitness, Bank of America, Barnes & Noble and other companies, consumer overconfidence turns into millions of dollars of unexpected profits. For many households, it reduces income by hundreds of dollars a year. 
At a time when wages are barely keeping pace with inflation, a little humility might be a valuable thing.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Money Market Options Amid the Paltry Yields

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
YIELDS on nearly all money market funds have shriveled to fractions of 1 percent, so you might assume that it makes little difference which one you choose to stash sidelined capital safely. 
 But even small yields add up. A half-point of interest on $50,000, for example, is still $250 a year. Industry experts advise close scrutiny of money market funds for other factors as well -- including safety, convenience and fees. 
 "It's always important to choose wisely," particularly now that expenses take such a big bite out of gross yields, said Joel Friedman, director of fund services at Standard & Poor's. Moreover, he said, because money funds are actively managed and not insured, "there is credit risk."
Some funds are restricted to buying United States Treasury obligations. Others buy government-agency portfolios, while some venturesome prime funds can include commercial paper, which occasionally has defaulted. If a Treasury fund puts even 5 percent of its assets -- the legal maximum -- into other investments, it does not qualify for S.& P.'s highest rating, A-1m.
As the third quarter began, the Vanguard Admiral Treasury fund was the top-yielding fund, at just under 1 percent, largely because it holds expenses to 0.14 percent a year. The fund requires a minimum investment of $50,000.
"There is a wide degree of types" in this $2.1 trillion business, Mr. Friedman said, and they vary not only in quality but also in fund expenses and the average maturity of their portfolios. They also differ in services, like electronic bill-paying or the ability to write checks, and the ground rules for check services. 
Unlike savings accounts at banks, money funds are not federally insured, but the possibility that an investor will lose principal is considered extremely remote. Many fund sponsors, especially those whose expense charges approach 1 percent, are now waiving part of their fees rather than having their yields turn negative or, in industry parlance, "breaking the buck." By industry practice, yields vary with the market while maintaining investors' principal at $1 a share.
Fee waivers indicate how willing managers are to absorb costs to keep your principal whole. With about 4 percent of money fund assets now yielding one-quarter of 1 percent or less, according to iMoneyNet Inc., another rate cut by the Federal Reserve would put severe pressure on more managers. 
Maturities matter, too. A portfolio with an average maturity of several weeks will reflect changes in market rates faster than one whose holdings do not come due for many months. Be particularly wary of funds with high minimums that are intended for institutions, specialists say. Professional investors tend to bail out quickly when rates start to rise, possibly disrupting the portfolio.
And do not assume that the money fund into which your stockbroker sweeps sales proceeds and other cash will give you a favorable return. Various lawsuits contend that brokers have channeled clients' money into high-cost funds and received commission payments in return.
Finally, note that yields on tax-exempt money funds, about 15 percent of the market, are close to those on taxable ones. The tax-exempt funds' yield was 0.5 percent at the start of the third quarter, versus 0.58 percent for taxable funds.
"That's the attractive sector in the money fund business, one of the free lunches out there" these days, said Peter Crane, a vice president of iMoneyNet.
Advisers recommend against transferring money to a different money market account merely to get marginally higher rates or, worse, out of pique. Still, a well-considered shift to a fund that provides superior services and liquidity may be worthwhile.
"It always makes sense to shop," Mr. Crane said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Tax Cut May Add New Meaning to Stock Buybacks

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
SOON, investors may have another indicator for gauging how a company sees its own prospects: share repurchases.
 Of course, share repurchases are not new. But because of recent legislation and the experience of the bursting bubble, they may be primed to achieve a new level of usefulness as a signal of a company's true value. 
 In principle, a company ought to buy back its own shares when doing so is the best use of its ready cash. By that criterion, no investment would offer a higher return to shareholders than simply reducing the number of outstanding shares in the company, and thereby increasing -- in a purely mechanical way -- the value of each share held by the public. A company's managers might be most likely to buy back shares if they believed the current price understated the true prospects for future earnings. 
"If you don't have great ideas, maybe the best thing you can do is to distribute this money to shareholders," said Josef Lakonishok, a finance professor at the University of Illinois who owns part of a money management firm. But, he added, for companies with low price-to-earnings ratios, "a repurchase conveys a very important signal, that maybe the price of the stock is cheap."
In the past, however, a flurry of repurchases in the market did not necessarily suggest that stocks were ready to rise. Because of high tax rates on money paid out as dividends, companies often seemed to use repurchases as a substitute for enriching shareholders. And as the bubble of the late 1990's ballooned, some companies engaged in repurchases like clockwork -- apparently, on occasion, as a way of preserving their shares' value while funneling millions of stock options to executives.
The basic motivation for repurchases -- the one most related to the company's earning potential -- was hard to spot.
But that may change. The latest tax cuts brought income tax rates for capital gains in line with those for dividends. As a result, the income an individual might realize from a buyback will no longer be taxed at a lower rate than dividends.
"Just from a pure taxation issue, maybe repurchases become a touch less attractive because you are not really penalized as much for paying dividends," Professor Lakonishok said.
A continuing shift in the way companies pay top executives -- away from stock options and toward stock held with restrictions -- may also remove some artifice from repurchases. A study in the mid-1990's by Christine M. Jolls, a law professor at Harvard, showed that all other things being equal, grants of options were more likely to be associated with share repurchases than were grants of restricted stock.
In addition, Professor Lakonishok said, fast-growing companies with high price-to-earnings ratios may have used repurchases simply to bolster their share prices as the stock market shot up in the late 1990's. Such gimmicks, he said, have probably receded.
Looking back at the market's tumble, many companies that set up regular buybacks in the heady 1990's might think better of them now, said Byron R. Wien, a senior investment strategist at Morgan Stanley.
These days, he said, "they're no longer doing it on an automatic basis."
Given these changes, are Wall Street's gurus ready to start focusing on repurchases?
"Probably, but not for sure," Mr. Wien said. "We've seen the tax legislation go through, but I don't think we've seen the ramifications of it."
He noted, however, that share repurchases spiked in March, when the stock market slipped to its lowest levels since October. Perhaps companies' decisions to buy back shares have become more sensitive to stock prices -- and less influenced by other factors -- after all.
