HEADLINE: Investing; 
Despite TheirName, Balanced Funds Can Teeter

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN

 BODY:
AFTER the market's seesaw pattern of recent years -- its climb in the late 1990's followed by a plunge in the last three years -- many investors would like to see some balance in their financial lives. 
 Why not just buy a balanced fund? Because, financial advisers say, many balanced funds can leave investors feeling as wobbly as the rest of the market. 
 Balanced funds hold 30 to 40 percent of their portfolios in bonds and 60 to 70 percent in stocks, but the type and quality of stocks and bonds vary widely from fund to fund. As a result, financial advisers increasingly say investors should give these funds more scrutiny than those in other categories. 
Jonathan Murray, senior vice president for investments at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore, said, "From the late 90's through today, we continue to see very disparate returns among balanced funds." 
As a result, he said, prospective investors need to do more than the standard kick of a fund's tires for manager tenure and historical returns. "With balanced funds you have to factor in interest rate movements and the manager's ability to shift between different stock and bond allocations," he said. "There are many more moving parts under the hood than in the typical mutual fund."
"The last bull market really jumbled this category," Mr. Murray said. " 'Balanced' is too often a misnomer, and this is the fund category that is most vulnerable to misrepresentation and confusion."
Traditionally, he said, the funds devoted most of their equity holdings to large-capitalization value stocks and most of their fixed-income holdings to short- and intermediate-term Treasury issues. The category was considered a one-stop shop: because the funds were conservative and diversified, advisers recommended them to young investors, who had limited capital, and to retirees, who liked their relative safety.
But in recent years, some balanced funds have become much more aggressive than the traditional model. For example, the category's leader this year, Green Century Balanced, up 34.2 percent through the second quarter, has 70 percent of its portfolio in stocks, primarily small-capitalization growth stocks, and 30 percent in bonds, mostly junk bonds. It invests only in companies that it believes are committed to environmental improvement.
"We are fairly high in non-investment-grade bonds," said the fund's manager, Jackson W. Robinson. "We don't own Treasuries because the biggest polluter in the world is the U.S. government. There are some wonderful green companies whose debt has junk status, but we are looking at companies where the credit situation will improve. Being a balanced fund has nothing to do with the nature of your equity or debt portfolios."
Other funds near the top of the list for the second quarter of 2003 were Scudder Flag Value Builder, up 21.2 percent; Dean Balanced, up 17.8 percent; and Eaton Vance Balanced, up 16.2 percent. But in 2002, Green Century lost 37.1 percent, and the others lost 18.9 percent, 27.4 percent and 14.7 percent, respectively.
Over the last five years through June, the leaders include Oakmark Equity and Income, up 11.2 percent, annualized, and Dodge & Cox Balanced, up 8.5 percent. Among the losers over that time were Atlas Balanced, down 5.8 percent, annualized, and CDC Nvest Balanced, down 4.5 percent.
Mr. Murray prefers to look at 10-year performance, and to study periods within the 10 years, but some balanced funds have not been around that long. 
Mr. Murray said that for investors who have sufficiently examined the role a balanced fund could play in their portfolios, the research department at Legg Mason recommended Dodge & Cox Balanced, which returned 12.3 percent for the second quarter and has a 10-year annualized return of 11.8 percent; American Balanced, up 12.8 percent for the quarter and 10.5 percent for 10 years, annualized; and MFS Total Return, with 9.8 percent for the quarter and 9.4 percent for 10 years, annualized. 
Advisers say Dodge & Cox Balanced typifies the traditional balanced fund. 
"Our basic goal is to preserve and enhance capital," said John Gunn, president and chief investment officer at Dodge & Cox. "Our typical investor should be someone who is more comfortable with a narrower range of returns over time. Both the fixed income and the equities have a long-term time horizon and low turnover. Basically we think it is a good fund for anyone who doesn't want the potentially wide swings of a straight equity portfolio."
That pleases Dr. Gerry Feldman, 61, a gynecologist, of Pikesville, Md. "I'm very conservative; I don't want upswings and downswings," he said. "This balanced fund just smooths everything out. I am aware that some of these balanced funds aren't really balanced, and I weeded those out."
Some advisers argue that the weeding burden should not be on the investor, and they contend that balanced funds should shun riskier stocks and debt altogether. Erika Safran, principal at the Financial Asset Management Corporation in Manhattan, called some of the riskier balanced funds "ridiculous for investors." 
"It is important to realize how misleading this category can be and how educated investors have to be," Ms. Safran said. "You can't just go and buy a balanced fund. Why is a balanced fund like Green Century up over 30 percent? Because it primarily has a small-cap-growth allocation. There is nothing conservative or balanced about it. Ten years ago, a balanced fund was a balanced fund." But today, she said, balanced funds will not necessarily give conservative investors one-stop shopping.
Ms. Safran recommends Vanguard Wellington, up 12.6 percent for the quarter and 10.5 percent for 10 years, annualized; Oakmark Equity Income, up 13.2 percent for the quarter and 11.2 percent for five years, annualized; and Dodge & Cox Balanced.
EVEN though advisers see the category as confusing, it has been popular with investors. According to Lipper, the fund research company, some 210 funds have balance as their objective. Inflows into balanced funds for the second quarter totaled $5.90 billion, according to AMG Data Services, up 28.1 percent from the comparable period last year.
Morningstar Inc. recently tried to help investors by creating two new categories, moderate allocation and conservative allocation. "We were noticing that asset mix was really having a great effect on returns," said Josie Raney, a Morningstar fund analyst. Most funds that use the name "balanced" were previously categorized as domestic hybrid by Morningstar but now fall into the new moderate-allocation category. Lipper, however, retains "balanced" as a category name. Morningstar's conservative-allocation category holds income-oriented funds with sizable bond holdings.
Still, advisers say, investors need to study a potential holding in detail before investing because some funds are more aggressive than any of these labels implies.
One way to pare down the choices, Ms. Raney said, is to go to Morningstar.com, which has many interactive tools for screening funds. One important tool gives an analysis with nine investment subdivisions.
"The new categories aren't designed to be the be-all, end-all of fund appraisal," she said. "But they do try to strike the right balance between differentiating between asset allocations while still providing sizable peer groups for judging performance."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Bear Market Legacy: More Investors Who Shun Risk

BYLINE:  By ERIC BAUM

 BODY:
AFTER years of stock-market losses, investors have flocked to conservative mutual funds, even though they were not initially rewarded for their prudence, according to a new study by Lipper, the financial research company.
 Lipper found that, in a down market, investors were attracted to funds that had minimal monthly losses, and not necessarily to the best-performing funds over all. 
 The company measured funds' month-to-month losses from September 2001 to March of this year. The funds that had the smallest total losses received the highest rankings for capital preservation, indicating that they are more conservative. Positive returns were not considered; that way, steady performers received higher ratings than funds that balanced big losses with gains. 
For the first several months of the study, Lipper found that the funds with the best ratings for capital preservation generally did not have the best total returns. It wasn't until the first quarter of 2003 that the rankings for capital preservation and total return had converged, the study found.
Nevertheless, throughout the 18-month period, investors preferred to buy the most conservative funds. The funds that ranked in the top 20 percent for capital preservation, a total of 743 funds, had a net inflow of more than $80 billion. Over all, there was a negative outflow of $29.4 billion from stock funds for the period; that means investors pulled $109.4 billion out of all the remaining stock funds, according to the study, which was released late last month. It can be read at www.lipperweb.com/usa/products/studies.shtml#Risk. 
"Over the past year and a half, the 20 percent of stock funds with the best risk ratings accounted for all of the new investments into stock funds," said Sean McLaughlin, a spokesman for Lipper, referring to the ratings for capital preservation. "People pulled more money out of the rest of the funds than they added, and despite a terrible market they continued to add more money to lower-risk funds." 
Buying relatively conservative stock funds allowed some investors to sleep at night during the bear market. Donald Riskind, a retired executive in Evanston, Ill., added more than $50,000 to his stake in Tweedy, Browne Global Value fund, one of the top-ranked funds for capital preservation, or lower risk, in November 2001. The fund lost 4.7 percent of its value in 2001, but that was still 16.8 percentage points better than its peers among foreign stock funds. In 2002, it lost 12.1 percent, which was four points better, according to Morningstar Inc. 
"It's our feeling that you can't get out of the market and go only into bonds," Mr. Riskind said.
Funds ranked high for capital preservation can be found in many investment categories. These include CGM Realty, a real estate fund, which earned 16.46 percent for the 18-month period, and was up 36.13 percent in the second quarter; FBR Small Cap Financial A, a financial services fund, which was up 25.67 percent in those 18 months, and was up 11.72 percent in the second quarter; and Pimco's NFJ Small Cap Value A, which returned 11.78 percent in those 18 months and 15.27 percent in the second quarter.
Some funds that were ranked among the best for capital preservation in 2000 have since produced lackluster results. For example, Liberty Utilities A, a midcap value fund, lost 46.84 percent during the study period and underperformed its category average by 20.30 percentage points. For the second quarter, the fund gained 18.35 percent. Also, AmSouth Value, a large-cap fund, fell by 29.40 percent and underperformed its peers by 3.77 points in the the study period. It gained 18.36 percent in the second quarter.
Mr. Riskind's financial adviser, Joseph Taiber, a senior consultant at DiMeo Schneider & Associates in Chicago, warned that funds that lose relatively little money in a down market may not excel when stocks rise. "If you look at a manager that typically captures 85 percent of a down market, they often fall short of capturing 100 percent of an up market," Mr. Taiber said. "Investors are flocking to exceptional down-market performers, but they're typically better off finding appropriate funds and sticking with them."
MARTIN VOSTRY, an analyst at Lipper who is the author of the study, said value funds were historically better than growth funds at capital preservation, but there were exceptions in the period. The Baron fund, a small-cap growth fund, was highly ranked for capital preservation and attracted new money when other growth funds did not, Mr. Vostry said. Value funds, as defined by Lipper, buy discounted stocks and are typically more conservative than growth funds, which seek companies with big earnings potential.
Mutual fund companies known for growth investing, like Putnam Investments, Janus Capital Management and AIM Investment Management, lost more assets during the bear market than competitors specializing in value investing. Many value-oriented funds offered by American Funds, Franklin Templeton Investments and Evergreen Investments that were often overlooked during the market bubble have attracted investors since the market's downturn.
Howard Present, director of global product management at Evergreen, predicted that investors who recently lost money in aggressive funds -- a group he calls the "perma burned" -- will stay with their newly acquired moderate investing habits. 
"Will there be a larger market for the firms that have an aggressive understanding of risk in a bull market?" he said. "Our answer is yes."

HEADLINE: Business; 
A National Stage for Puff Pastry and Duck Jerky

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE HAMLIN

 BODY:
CHOCOLATE was clearly the front-runner, but wasabi, cheese, citrus flavors and beverages made of tea and fruit were not far behind last weekend at the 47th annual Summer Fancy Food Show, the nation's largest showcase of specialty foods.
 Over three days, 2,300 exhibitors showed off both domestic and imported products to 24,000 people at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Retailers who were considering adding the new foods had to sample them on the spot, however, because only marketing material, not food, could be removed from the building. 
 Specialty foods represent $25 billion in annual sales, according to the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade. And the business is growing. "We're now projecting a steady 4 to 6 percent rise in sales every year for the next five years," said Ron Tanner, vice president for communications and education at the trade group, which sponsors the show. The group had 350 members 20 years ago; it has 2,100 now. 
Retailers and producers attribute the increase in sales to increasingly sophisticated, quality-conscious consumers, concerned about food sources and drawn to organic and additive-free foods. Even in a sluggish economy, there is still power in the "treat factor" -- the ability of shoppers to treat themselves to, say, a $16 pound of premium coffee or a $3 bag of four cookies made of natural ingredients.
The strongest sales, he said, are on the West Coast and in New England and the Middle Atlantic states.
For owners of small businesses, participation in the show is a significant investment, but many said it was important, because it can bring the exposure that makes the difference between profit and loss. The cost of a booth is about $3,000, but lodging, transportation and shipping can raise the expense of participating for three days to $10,000 to $12,000, Mr. Tanner said.
Several producers said their business had increased 30 percent to 40 percent after an appearance at the show. Orders might not come on the spot, but they tend to trickle in for months afterward, exhibitors said.
"It's important to be here, no matter how established you are," said Trish Karter, who owns the Dancing Deer Baking Company in Boston. "It's a chance to really meet and talk to customers, to show them what's new, to hear what's doing well and what's not. Anybody can bake a great cookie; it's everything else that's the hard stuff." 
The company, which started with a single type of molasses cookie, had $4 million in sales last year.
Ms. Karter, working at her booth at the Javits Center, listed some of the challenges that face a small company: "packaging, marketing, production, developing recipes, being flexible enough to fill retailers' demands -- like creating a baking mix in four days -- and just understanding a very complex retail market."
"Only the tough survive," she said.
IN 1994, Ms. Karter, who has an M.B.A., and her husband at the time, a business analyst, invested in a small wholesale Boston bakery. Shortly thereafter, they produced their first retail product, a small line of packaged cookies. They were soon contacted by a buyer for Williams-Sonoma, the national cookware shop and catalog retailer that was beginning to sell packaged food in its retail stores. 
Ms. Karter quickly applied "everything I learned in business school and then some" to pay invoices, add staff and still maintain quality.
For retailers, the show is a way to gain exposure to a wide range of products. "I consider this an extraordinary learning experience," said David Levine, owner of A Touch of Italy, a specialty-food shop in Fort Myers, Fla.
Standing in front of a table filled with artisanal cheese from Italy, Mr. Levine said he was learning as fast as he was tasting, gathering "information that my customers really want to know, and expect to learn."
All retailers can turn into customers. But for the small specialty-food producers, attention from a big national retailers -- like Williams-Sonoma or the Whole Foods Market, or from one of the smaller regional chains like Central Markets in Texas, Straub's in Missouri and Wegman's on the East Coast -- is the equivalent of being a finalist on "American Idol."
If a big company or chain likes a product it sees, it will often suggest reformulations or even new ideas. In the case of Dancing Deer, Williams-Sonoma wanted a gingerbread mix, and fast.
"In four days we created it from scratch, and although we didn't know it then, beat out a lot of competition," Ms. Karter said.
Nina Robertson, the owner of Good Wives Inc. in Lynn, Mass., said that getting orders from Central Markets and Straub's allowed her business, previously a food service company for institutions, to become a successful specialty-food company. In the food show's awards competition last week, she had a winner. Her Good Wives Seafood Thermidor Puff Pastries, which are frozen, handmade cocktail pastries, won in the snack food or hors d'oeuvre category.
Laura Logan, the owner of Austin Special Foods Company in Austin, Tex., said that just one of these star merchants can make a product line succeed. Ms. Logan, whose Chipotle Double Fudge Chunk Cookie was a winner last week in the cookie and cracker category, said that it was only two years ago that she "no longer had to call my brother for money" for her company, which she started eight years ago in her home. 
But money is still tight; she had to accept the cookie award in absentia, she said, because she could not afford a booth at the show this year. "I was there last year and it was terrific," she said, "but I was subsidized by the State of Texas," which, like some other states, had a pavilion at the show.
RETAILERS said the selection this year was especially impressive, noting the cheeses from both the United States and Europe. 
"Pretty amazing, huh?", said Ari Weinzweig, an owner of Zingerman's, a food store and mail-order retailer in Ann Arbor, Mich. Mr. Weinzweig, who travels extensively and imports many of his artisanal products directly, has come to the show since 1984.
He said there had been big changes in packaging, which is less gimmicky than before, and in the variety and quality of the products.
"It used to take years for producers to catch up with a very small buying audience," he said. "Now, because of really smart consumers, and lots of them, the pace has gotten so quick it's about six months between great product and buying public."
Consumers are finding specialty foods at a much larger range of stores, said Mr. Tanner, of the specialty-food trade association. The products are now sold on Web sites and in gift stores, juice bars, coffee shops, department stores, discounters and household stores like Bed Bath & Beyond. Hardware stores are selling condiments with their barbecue grills. Even Victoria's Secret, he said, is selling specialty foods.
So what can consumers expect to find starting this fall in the specialty-foods category? The list may include wasabi and ginger, often together (two products, combining both ingredients, won food show awards) as well as rich, combined pure fruit juices; a multitude of bottled waters with "nutrients added"; and low-carbohydrate snacks like duck jerky. Shoppers may also see multitudes of new cookies, salsas, Asian condiments and organic products.
There will also be chocolate, in vast amounts and forms. On its way for the holiday season is a chocolate voodoo doll from the Chocoholics Divine Desserts Company in Stockton, Calif. The product is meant to be assigned a persona and then eaten, head first.

HEADLINE: Mutal Funds Report; 
At Last, a Quarter When It's Safe to Look

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
THE stock market ended June with its best quarterly gain since the end of 1998, but the historical comparisons for mutual funds were even more impressive.
 With the exception of one fund group -- bear funds, which bet that stock prices will fall -- every category tracked by Morningstar Inc. and Lipper posted double-digit gains in the second quarter. 
 "This is the first time that has happened since the first quarter of 1987, where funds were up this much, this broadly," said Martin Vostry, a research analyst at Lipper. 
On average, diversified domestic equity funds rose 16.1 percent in the quarter, according to Morningstar. Funds specializing in technology and communications rose more than 24 percent, and international funds gained 18.9 percent. And the continued decline in interest rates helped bond funds post positive returns. 
Analysts cited a variety of factors for the improved performance of domestic stock mutual funds, including the quick end to major fighting in Iraq, a reduction in taxes and a cut in interest rates. Many investors believed that stock prices had simply fallen to very low levels.
"The rebound is simply about the fact that stuff got reasonably cheap after a bear market unwinding the excess," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund research at Morningstar. "It all gets back to valuations." 
Low interest rates allowed many companies that were formerly investment grade to refinance debt and bolster their share prices. At the $700 million Fidelity Leveraged Company Stock fund, David Glancy, the manager, posted a gain of more than 50 percent in the quarter by investing in companies rated BBB+ or lower. 
"These companies are doing what the consumer has been doing: cutting debt service cost," Mr. Glancy said. "As their problems start to ebb a little bit, that is when you get big moves in the stock price." 
As an example, he pointed to the AES Corporation, the independent power producer based in Arlington, Va., which is one of his fund's biggest holdings. Over the first six months of the year, AES not only refinanced a large portion of its outstanding debt, but last month it also raised equity in the stock market. At the end of the fourth quarter last year, he said, some AES bonds were trading at 45 cents on the dollar and its stock was trading at 70 cents a share. "Six months later, the debt is trading at par, or $1, and the stock is at $6," he said. 
Inflows into stock funds accelerated as the quarter progressed, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services. But inflows into bond funds remained heavy, he said, though they began to ease as the quarter unfolded.
The high-yield bond market rallied sharply, bolstered by investors' strong demand for higher returns. 
The Vanguard Group, the big mutual fund company, became so concerned about the size of the inflows into its $9 billion High Yield Corporate bond fund that last month it closed it to new investors. 
"We have taken in a little under $1.5 billion into the fund this year, and that is a rather extraordinary amount for that fund," said Gus Sauter, Vanguard's chief investment officer. "But it wasn't until credit spreads between investment grade and high yield started to narrow and high-yield bonds started to take off that we saw a flow of cash. It had the symptoms of a mania." 
According to Mr. Adler at AMG, about $10 billion in new money went into high-yield funds in the quarter, bringing the total for the first half of the year to about $21 billion. That is much more than the $11.7 billion that went into high-yield funds for all of last year and ahead of the record 12-month total of $17.9 billion for 1997.
Bond funds of all stripes did well in the second quarter, because of the continued fall in interest rates, but high-yield funds fared best, posting an average return of nearly 9 percent, according to Morningstar data. 
Those gains were impressive for bond funds, but they pale compared with the performance of some riskier segments of the domestic and global stock markets. 
In the United States, technology and telecommunications funds, which had been battered, were two of the best performers. Both gained more than 24 percent. Funds investing in biotechnology stocks, a sector in which only a handful of companies are now profitable, rose more than 18 percent, according to Lipper. 
The strong performance in technology resulted from a "mixture of improving sentiment and improving fundamentals," said Kevin Landis, the chief investment officer at Firsthand Funds, which specializes in technology stocks.
"Over the next few months, we will be able to look back and see if it was a little bit of one and a lot of the other," Mr. Landis said. "If it turns out the fundamentals really do suport it, then there is room for sentiment to continue improving." 
Returns on foreign stock funds were also impressive. 
Largely because of the performance of the South Korean stock market, emerging-markets stock funds rose more than 23 percent, according to Morningstar. Latin American stock funds were up more than 21 percent. Even funds focusing on Japan, which has been in a decade-long slump, scored a double-digit gain, rising nearly 14 percent. 
Given the widespread gains in the stock market, bear market funds had big losses, dropping an average of 18.9 percent for the quarter, according to Morningstar. Not everyone, though, is counting out the bears for the next quarter.
After all, there have been confident predictions about second-half recoveries the last three years. And current economic indicators are not entirely reassuring.
"Other than the stock market going up, not many leading indicators have shown much to suggest a pickup in the second half," said Mr. Vostry at Lipper. "There is a huge amount of stimulus that in just about any other economic time would be truly inflationary. Whether this works remains to be seen." 
Tom McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities, is optimistic about the market's prospects. What happened in the second quarter is merely the "appetizer" in the current run, he said. 
"The next course is the main course, and that is when business starts to get better and earnings start to improve," he said. 
THOMAS F. MARSICO, head of Marsico Funds, with $21 billion under management, said earnings for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index should be about $52 a share this year, and $61 next year. 
"With interest rates staying at around 4 percent, we think the stock market could trade at 20 to 22 times earnings," he said. "That could put the S.& P. 500 in the 1,200-to-1,300 range over the next 18 months." It ended the quarter below 1,000.
Robert Hagstrom, manager of the Legg Mason Focus Trust, which was up more than 30 percent for the quarter, said the market's prospects rested almost entirely on the economy.
"If the data is weak, my guess is that stocks will have a very modest return from here," he said. "If the data show increasing demand, then we have a good chance of good performance."

HEADLINE: Italy's Designer Outlet Mall Drains Its Cities of Shoppers 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY

DATELINE: SERRAVALLE SCRIVIA, Italy 

 BODY:
THE name of the mall was carried along in whispers at the men's wear shows in Milan two weeks ago, written on scraps of paper, covertly passed from one fashion editor to another -- from Vicky McGarry of Men's Journal to Michael Nash of Vibe to Stefano Tonchi of Esquire. It was almost as if this outlet mall, McArthurGlen Serravalle, set in the middle of the Italian countryside, had developed the cachet of a hot Los Angeles club, the kind of place so inside you have to know someone who knows someone to find it. 
 And the mall itself has a vaguely unreal dimension: it is a hilltop mirage floating on the landscape two minutes from the autostrada in an agricultural no-place, in the center of an imaginary triangle formed by Genoa, Turin and Milan. Not long ago, grapes and grain were the mainstays of this sleepy town in the Piedmont. Now its future is banked on less essential commodities, ones for which consumers have an insatiable appetite: premium brands. 
 Serravalle is Italy's first designer outlet center. Until fairly recently, the country thatsome historians say invented commercial capitalism in the Middle Ages had to stand behind England, France and the United States in terms of participation in one of capitalism's more curious economic flowerings, the outlet mall. 
Financed by the McArthurGlen group, a London-based operator of 12 designer outlet centers in Europe, Serravalle opened in the fall of 2000 with 150,000 square feet of retail space rented to 64 shops and restaurants. Its developers gambled that Italian consumers would forgo their historic affection for the main streets of urban centers and act like Americans, motoring an hour into the countryside for the chance to buy last season's Prada pumps at 80 percent off retail cost. And they have.
These days there are 146 stores, selling not just Prada but Versace, Trussardi, Cerruti, Loro Piano, Frette, Dolce & Gabbana, Swarovski and even Bulgari, whose windows are filled with pearl earrings and diamond-studded watches marked one-third off. On a given Sunday, 35,000 visitors have been known to show up. More than six million people have visited thus far, the developers claim. But some locals insist that number must be an understatement, given the gridlock that routinely forms on the A-7 highway leading there. 
"In the beginning we got mostly locals and Japanese," said Lorenzo Aletti, the marketing coordinator for McArthurGlen in Italy. "Now we get 49 percent from the region, and the rest are Japanese, Koreans, Americans and Russians, who are the new rich for Europe. 
On a weekday morning a while back, Katsuhiko Yamato and Hiroki Hamaguchi, two travelers from Osaka, moved nimbly through the Dolce & Gabbana shop, selecting with laser concentration from among the piles of shredded jeans at 50 percent markdown, suits for $400, belts for $30 and a stack of deeply discounted shirts. After paying for their bounty, the two men checked their merchandise behind the counter and hurried to the nearby Prada shoe boutique. 
"Our itinerary is Florence, Milan and Serravalle Scrivia," said Mr. Hamaguchi, referring to a route that bypassed high culture and Da Vinci's "Last Supper" in favor of shinier commercial shrines. 
"We get people coming in and saying, 'Can we buy the whole shelf?' " said Maurizio Messina, the manager of the Bally store here. And they can. Unlike luxury shops in the designer-barnacled cluster of 18th-century streets in Milan known informally as the Golden Triangle, at Serravalle there are no quotas imposed. "I have customers who come every three months and buy 100 handbags at a time," Mr. Messina said.
The bargains are just one part of the appeal. "There is a theatrical Disneyesque-type attraction beginning to happen at Serravalle," said Julia J. Calabrese, McArthurGlen's chief executive officer.
The mall is an enfolding environment, a hillside farm rendered postmodern village in pastiche. Gently curved streets conduct pedestrians inward. Buildings have ochre stuccoed walls and porticos. Tasteful cast-iron trash cans are surmounted by acorn-shaped lids consistent with an Italo-rustic theme. Perhaps as important, chrome displays and cool recessed lighting cast the merchandise in a flattering light that is far from the bare-bulb reality that the goods are not this season's and failed to sell when they were. 
"For myself it is like Montenapoleone Street, but in the fields," said Fabio Bellini, 28, a chauffeur in Milan, referring to the Fifth Avenue of Milan, a street typically thronged on weekends with orange-tanned men draped in silk sweaters and women whose appearance suggests that personal grooming is a sacred rite. 
"Some people don't mind spending full price; for myself, I like a bargain," said Mr. Bellini, who stopped in at Frette, the high-end linen store, to purchase a terrycloth bathrobe for his wife, a set of towels and some Egyptian cotton sheets, before heading to Pal Zileri's men's wear store and then the Toys Center Outlet to get a gift for his infant son, whom he calls Super Mario.
"This is fall-winter 2002," a saleswoman at Versace explained late last month, referring to a $6,500 evening dress (reduced from $14,000) that she was holding for a client from Genoa. Unlike some American outlet malls -- where chain retailers dump their disasters, and where manufacturers sell specially produced discount lines -- at Serravalle, mustard-colored blazers, mesh leather hot pants and bump-toed clown shoes are nowhere to be found. 
Instead there is quarry to freshen a bargain-hunter's blood: Prada loafers that would cost $350 in the United States at $150; cashmere Loro Piano jackets for $400; Alberta Ferretti spring frocks for $85; seasonless-looking Jean Paul Gaultier dresses reduced from $1,000 to $134; $300 cashmere blankets from the high-end stationer Pineider. There were clothes priced so low that the regional competition, a department store mall called Foxtown, 50 minutes and a Swiss border crossing away from Milan, seemed likely to be undercut, outflanked, forgotten. "Foxtown, you get maybe 20 percent off," said Monica Giordana, a data processor from Milan. "At Serravalle sometimes they are throwing it in the street."
At Serravalle, too, there is the custom of displaying what people in the outlet mall industry call double pricing. That is, the pre- and post-markdown prices are shown in the window, with the same intoxicating effect on bargain hunters that gamblers feel when the dealer breaks the seal on a new deck.
"Originally, there was some resistance to double pricing," Mr. Aletti said. Bulgari, for one, was reluctant to submit its pricey baubles to tactics reminiscent of warehouse refrigerator sales. "They did not want to do it at first," Mr. Aletti said. Now the double prices are posted discreetly in Bulgari's window. At a third of their original Italian retail price, Bulgari bracelets cost a fraction of what they might in New York. 
If the assembled fashion editors seemed to bypass the jeweler's wares during the men's wear season, they were still to be found stuffing their bags with Nikes ($35), Dolce & Gabbana jeans ($29), Prada mules ($79) and Pineider stationery ($10), and walking to waiting limousines as laden as glamorous pack mules with bulky shopping bags.
"So far, we don't have Gucci or Ferragamo or Tod's, but we're working on it," said Ms. Calabrese of McArthurGlen. So far, the chain has not made quite the same imprint on the Italian landscape that outlet megamalls like New York's Woodbury Commons have in the United States. Still, Italian retailers seem to have glimpsed the future and concluded that it will be populated with shoppers eagerly hunting for luxury goods in settings that make Disneyland look uncontrived. 
The second McArthurGlen Italian outlet mall is already in the works. Replete with Ionic colonnades and tasteful replicas of Roman ruins, it is set to open outside Rome in early 2004.

HEADLINE: The Back Page: A How-To Manual; 
A Century of Small Wars Shows They Can Be Won

BYLINE:  By MAX BOOT; Max Boot is a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations and author of "The Savage Wars of Peace: Small Wars and the Rise of American Power."

 BODY:
AFTER a series of smashing military victories, the president declared the war over. Yet far from giving up, the forces resisting American occupation switched to guerrilla tactics. Isolated sentries were killed by assailants who pretended to be friendly civilians. Patrols in the countryside ran into booby traps. One carefully staged ambush wiped out half an infantry company. American forces responded with harsh countermeasures that led to charges of brutality.
 That may sound like a portrait of today's Iraq, but it actually describes the Philippines a century ago. Having kicked out the Spanish in 1898, the United States decided to keep the archipelago for itself. Many Filipinos resisted American rule. President William McKinley thought the struggle was over by early 1900, when the regular Filipino armed forces were routed, but the resilient insurrectos proved him wrong. 
 The United States eventually won, but it was a long, hard, bloody slog that cost the lives of more than 4,200 American soldiers, 16,000 rebels and some 200,000 civilians. Even after the formal end of hostilities on July 4, 1902, sporadic resistance dragged on for years.
There is no reason to think that the current struggle in Iraq will be remotely as difficult. But the Philippine war is a useful reminder that Americans have a long history of fighting guerrillas -- and usually prevailing, though seldom quickly or easily. 
Many lessons of those counterinsurgencies were set down in "The Small Wars Manual," written by a group of Marine Corps officers in the 1930's. This book, which was reprinted in the 1980's, was intended to draw on the experience of leathernecks who had battled "bandits" (as the authors preferred to call all resistance movements) in Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and elsewhere during the early years of the 20th century.
In contrast to major wars, the manual warns, "in small wars no defined battle front exists and the theater of operations may be the whole length and breadth of the land. . . . In warfare of this kind, members of native forces will suddenly become innocent peasant workers when it suits their fancy and convenience." Confronted with such elusive foes, the manual counsels a two-pronged approach to "establish and maintain law and order."
On the one hand, occupying forces must stay on the offensive against rebel groups, hunting them down wherever they hide. "Delay in the use of force . . . will always be interpreted as weakness," the authors warn. On the other hand, the manual is keenly aware of the limits of firepower in an ambiguous environment.
"Peace and industry cannot be restored permanently without appropriate provisions for the economic welfare of the people," they write. They also warn that the "hatred of the enemy" usually inculcated among combat troops is entirely inappropriate during an occupation. Brutal repression -- of the kind carried out by some American soldiers who used a torture technique called the "water cure" to extract information from Filipino suspects -- only creates more recruits for the rebels. "In small wars, tolerance, sympathy and kindness should be the keynote to our relationship with the mass of the population."
However skillful they are in the application of carrots and sticks, the manual teaches, American troops cannot win a permanent victory by themselves: "Native troops, supported by marines, are increasingly employed as early as practicable in order that these native agencies may assume their proper responsibility for restoring law and order in their own country."
American troops followed this advice with a great deal of success in combating insurgencies from the Philippines to, in more recent years, countries like El Salvador. So did the British in postwar Malaya. 
In Vietnam, by contrast, The Small Wars Manual was conspicuously neglected. Gen. William Westmoreland tried a conventional big-unit approach, with disastrous consequences. The relations of American soldiers with civilians were not, for the most part, characterized by "tolerance, sympathy and kindness." Nor did the Americans turn over the fight to "native troops . . . as early as practicable."
Of course, the biggest problem in Indochina was outside the army's control. The guerrillas operating in South Vietnam had a virtually impregnable base in North Vietnam. That made it impossible to isolate the battlefield, as the United States Navy had been able to do in the islands of the Philippines.
In Iraq, American forces may also find it difficult to cut off the insurgents they now face, since the country shares long borders with Syria and Iran, both hostile to the United States. From Washington's standpoint, the good news is that both countries should be much more vulnerable to American pressure than North Vietnam was, because they lack a superpower patron.
In many respects, the American campaign in Iraq has been straight out of The Small Wars Manual. Security sweeps in Sunni areas of central Iraq are combined with efforts to reopen schools and hospitals. This is not bleeding-heart humanitarianism but, as the manual reminds us, a vital step to winning hearts and minds.
Achieving that goal also requires that American troops avoid the sort of excesses committed in the Philippines. Brig. Gen. Jacob Smith was court-martialed for ordering his men to "kill and burn"' indiscriminately -- a case as shocking in its day as the My Lai massacre in Vietnam was. 
While the behavior of American troops in Iraq has been for the most part exemplary, one area where they have lagged is in using indigenous security forces. In the early years of the 20th century, United States occupiers generally set up constabularies trained and led by Americans but made up of local enlisted men. Quasi-military organizations like the the Philippine Scouts proved to be formidable instruments of counterinsurgency because their soldiers knew the local culture and language. This is especially important in fighting foes without uniforms, where the chief challenge is simply to identify the enemy. Small wars place a great premium on accurate intelligence.
As the Afghanistan experience shows, it will take a long time to set up a new military in Iraq. Until then, the occupation authorities will not be able to proceed to the last two sections of "The Small Wars Manual": "Supervision of Elections" and "Withdrawal."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Evolving Opinions; 
Heartfelt Words From the Rehnquist Court

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
CHIEF JUSTICE WILLIAM H. REHNQUIST was asked some years ago whether his views on any major legal subject had "evolved" during his decades on the Supreme Court. He considered the question for a moment, cocked an eyebrow and said in a self-mocking tone, "Oh, you mean have I shown a capacity for growth?"
 His wry response reflected not only an awareness of his own reputation as a rock-ribbed conservative, but his acknowledgment that evolution, far from a neutral word in this context, connotes a one-way path toward greater enlightenment. Indeed, the "one-way ratchet" in constitutional law, the observed phenomenon by which rights expand but never seem to contract, is a familiar concept among students of the court. 
 Call it growth, evolution or something in the water: something was going on during this Supreme Court term. In the absence of a unified field theory, it could be that webs of personal association and experience have led the justices to see old problems in new ways. Consider:
* Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, skeptical throughout her judicial career of any government policy that took account of race, suddenly embraced affirmative action at the University of Michigan Law School as not only tolerable but good for the country.
* Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority opinion rejecting immunity for the states under the Family and Medical Leave Act described the burdens facing women in the workplace with a heart-felt sensitivity that left women's rights leaders, having expected the worst, wondering whether Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was his ghostwriter.
* Justice Anthony M. Kennedy's eloquent apologia for the court's previous failure to accord "dignity" and "respect" to gay relationships stunned even those who had assumed, based on his libertarian streak and a demonstrated openness to gay-rights issues going back to an opinion he wrote as a federal appeals court judge in 1980, that he would probably vote to overturn the Texas sodomy law. In both its rhetoric and analysis, his opinion took the court much further than necessary to accomplish a simple invalidation.
Justices do change. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a law-and-order conservative when he joined the court in 1970, ended his career 24 years later as a passionate opponent of the death penalty. Justice John Paul Stevens, whose liberal vote is now almost taken for granted, voted with the anti-affirmative-action bloc in the 1978 Bakke case. And Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. said after his retirement that he regretted his vote with the 5-to-4 majority in Bowers v. Hardwick, the 1986 decision repudiated by the court's new gay-rights majority.
Times change, too. The Supreme Court has become a gay-friendly workplace where employees feel sufficiently comfortable in their open identity to bring their partners to court functions. Justice Powell's comment to one of his law clerks while Bowers v. Hardwick was pending in 1986 that "I don't believe I've ever met a homosexual" (untrue, considering that the clerk was, in fact, gay) could not be uttered in the court -- or the Washington or the legal profession -- of today.
Of course, not everyone responds to change in the same way, as shown by Justice Antonin Scalia's bitter dissent in the Texas case, warning of "a massive disruption of the current social order." It was as if he and Justice Kennedy, born within four months of each other 67 years ago, both Roman Catholic, both Harvard Law School graduates, both elevated to the court within 15 months by President Ronald Reagan, were speaking from parallel universes. So the bare facts of biography are not enough to explain Anthony Kennedy.
A close friend from his Sacramento childhood, the writer Joan Didion talks about his growing up in the shadow of the California Legislature. His father was a lawyer and lobbyist, and the Kennedy home had a constant flow of people and ideas. "There was a world outside their personal world that came into that house," Ms. Didion said. His decision to go to the London School of Economics after Stanford surprised his friends. "He wanted to live in a larger world," she said.
In the last few years, that world has included New York, which neither Justice Kennedy nor his wife, Mary, knew well before all three of their children, now married, moved there. Now they visit frequently. After Sept. 11, 2001, Justice Kennedy worried to Washington acquaintances that the atmosphere of freedom he so admired about New York might be in jeopardy.
These are simply pieces in a mosaic; no one would suggest that having grown children in New York necessarily makes a life-tenured judge more attuned to personal liberty "in its spatial and more transcendent dimensions," as the justice wrote in his Texas opinion. Yet this term may serve as a reminder that even in late middleage, people are open to new ideas. In fact, it may be harder than ever to avoid new ideas; in the isolation of their chambers, some justices surf the Internet.
Extensive foreign travel has made both Justice Kennedy and Justice O'Connor more alert to how their peers on other constitutional courts see similar issues. Justices have always traveled, teaching or taking part in seminars. But these are trips with a difference. 
Along with Justice Ginsburg and Justice Stephen G. Breyer, Justices O'Connor and Kennedy have held extensive sessions with judges in Europe. Justice Kennedy has met with numerous Chinese judges, here and in China. Justice O'Connor has been involved in the American Bar Association's reform initiative for Eastern Europe. With emerging democracies groping toward the rule of law, with colleagues on the federal bench volunteering for constitution-writing duties in Iraq, it is not surprising that the justices have begun to see themselves as participants in a worldwide constitutional conversation.
From this perspective, Justice Kennedy's citing of the European Court of Human Rights in his Texas opinion was a natural development. Justice O'Connor, in the Michigan case, linked affirmative action to the acquisition of "the skills needed in today's increasingly global marketplace" and to the maintenance of integrated leadership for the military. 
It is tempting to suppose that her invocation of diversity as "essential" to "the dream of our nation, indivisible," was aimed not just at a domestic audience but at the constitution-building world in which she is a star participant.
And what of chief justice Rehnquist's solicitude for the usefulness of the Family and Medical Leave Act in erasing the "pervasive sex-role stereotype that caring for family members is women's work"?
His daughter, Janet, is a single mother who until recently held a high-pressure job and sometimes had child-care problems. Several times this term, the 78-year-old Chief Justice of the United States left work early to pick up his granddaughters from school.
Not evolution, perhaps, but life.

HEADLINE: Page Two: June 29-July 5; 
READING FILE

 BODY:
Teachers Are Paid Well, One Economist Says
 ARE public-school teachers underpaid compared with other professionals? 
 Not by many measures, writes Richard Vedder, an economics professor at Ohio University, in "Comparable Worth," in the summer issue of Education Next, published by the conservative Hoover Institution. 
Using Labor Department data, Professor Vedder said he found that weekly pay for teachers in 2001 was within 10 percent of the pay for accountants, biological and life scientists, editors and reporters. 
Teachers, moreover, enjoy longer vacations and work fewer days a year than most professional workers. Using the National Compensation Survey of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Professor Vedder found that the average hourly wage in 2000 for all "professional speciality" workers was $27.49. Elementary-school teachers earned $28.79 an hour. Secondary-school teachers earned $29.14 an hour and special-education teachers earned $29.97. Teachers also received benefits totaling more than 26 percent of their salaries; the average for private industry is below 17 percent. 
The problem, Professor Vedder says, is not low salaries, but inefficient hiring. According to rules typically negotiated by unions, teachers in high-demand specialties, math and science, earn the same as teachers in fields like English, which have a surplus of applicants.

Imposing or Proposing A Stance Against Abortion
Hard line" 70's feminism has been rejected by women, but "its ideology lives on in law and politics -- like light rays from a dead star," writes Mary Ann Glendon, a professor at Harvard Law School, in the conservative Catholic publication "First Things." 
Legalized abortion is the legacy, writes Professor Glendon, who has advised the Vatican. Two 1973 Supreme Court decisions left little room for states to maneuver. Roe v. Wade overturned a Texas statute that banned abortion except when the mother's life was in danger. Doe v. Bolton, issued the same day, is less well known, but had more impact, she writes. It said that doctors must be allowed to consider emotional and psychological factors in deciding whether an abortion after fetal viability is necessary to preserve a pregnant patient's health. With Doe the court "signaled the doom of legislative efforts to provide even modest protection of unborn life," she writes. "And it was Doe's broad definition of 'health' as 'well being' that the court would later use to strike down even bans on the cruel procedure known as partial birth abortion."
As a result, "we have become a society where nearly everyone has been touched by abortion, if not personally, then through friends and family members," she writes. That ubiquity has allowed people "to take refuge in slogans like 'Who am I to be judgmental?' and the famous 'Personally, I'm opposed but I can't impose my opinions on others.' "
"Impose," Professor Glendon says, is the wrong word. "When people advance their moral viewpoints in the public square, they are not imposing anything on anyone. They are proposing. That's what citizens do in a democracy -- we propose, we give reason, we vote."

Save the Bandtail Pigeon, An Oregon Hunter Says
A longtime hunter in the coastal range of Oregon takes stock of his favorite prey, the bandtail pigeon, in the summer issue of The Double Gun Journal, a publication for sportsmen and collectors.
"Over the years -- principally in the 1950's, 60's, 70's, into the early 1980's -- I hunted bandtails in scores of locations in the Coast Range," Worth Mathewson writes. But in the early 1980's, "I began to curtail my pigeon shooting -- then quit entirely. It wasn't a pleasant decision. It was based on the sharply declining numbers of this large wilderness pigeon."
What caused this? "Its declines have had nothing whatsoever to do with habitat, lack of food sources, changes in farming practices or anything else so commonly, and correctly, associated with reduced numbers of birds shot for sport. The bandtail suffered gravely from overshooting. Nothing else."
The author said there are signs of recovery; last year, British Columbia and Washington managed to hold brief shooting seasons. But the bandtail is one of the slowest-reproducing game birds, so it will be many years, Mr. Mathewson says, before strong flocks return. But the author recalls: "There have been mornings in years now long passed, where almost instantly I have been engulfed with the flocks. If I was shooting well, everything was over sooner than I wished. I nearly always made a point of lining up the birds on a log or stump to admire them."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
Will Anyone Throw Money, Lots of It, at a Glass House?

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere (COMPILED BY CHRISTINE BOCKELMANN)

 BODY:
If buying a home is a "big vote of confidence in the economy," as one economist recently asserted, is buying a really big home a really big sign of confidence?
 After a year on the market, a 35,000-square-foot glass house outside Princeton, N.J., has attracted interest, and its owner expects it to sell this month. 
 John Boulton, a retired electronics magnate, predicts that he will soon receive a suitable offer for his custom-built, two-story house, on 48 acres in Franklin Township. The property is called Chalan Farm, and the asking price is $12 million. 
Mr. Boulton began building the home in 1992. It is constructed of energy-efficient, high-tech glass and has 360-degree views, an eight-car garage and a swimming pool in the master bedroom. The design is inspired by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe; Mr. Boulton, as a young electrical engineer, worked with him on the landmark Seagram Building in Manhattan. 
Mr. Boulton, who invented such things as a remote-control music system sold in the 1960's at Hammacher Schlemmer in New York City, put Chalan Farm on the market a year ago when his wife, Prudence, required medical care in Manhattan. 
An auction of Chalan Farm was conducted in May by the J. P. King Auction Company, with a $3 million minimum bid, but it did not sell. The auction did help identify prospective buyers, however, said J. Scott King, executive vice president of the auction company. 
Mr. Boulton said he has been contacted by a number of "serious contenders," including Somerset County, which is considering turning the house into a historical museum; several foundations; and two wealthy individuals -- separate bidders -- who would live in it.
Offers are due on July 15. Mr. Boulton said "we'll decide that day" which is accepted, but he would not say how close to $12 million he expects the offers to be. Jane L. Levere

HEADLINE: CITY PEOPLE; 
Devoted to Mom and Pop

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL

 BODY:
BODEGAS are an icon of New York's Latino neighborhoods, but these mom-and-pop grocery stores where owners greet children by name, longtime customers buy on credit and neighbors discuss the latest news are also a throwback to Main Street America.
 Their role was underscored 10 days ago at a news conference in front of a bodega in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, when Mayor Bloomberg announced an anticrime program designed to protect these businesses from robberies. 
 "As you know, bodegas play a vital role in the daily life of New York City," the mayor said before a dozen television cameras. "We're going to do everything we can to combat robberies committed against bodegas and ensure that New York City's bodega owners will see their businesses flourish." 
For the mayor, the event may have been no more than a routine news conference about a modest new crime-fighting program, cost: $10,000. For Jose Fernandez, the short, slight Dominican man in the crisp white shirt standing to the mayor's immediate right and fitting right in with the crowd of politicians and police officers, it was a shining moment, the pinnacle of five years of work.
Mr. Fernandez, 35, is the president of the Bodega Association of the United States, the group that pushed for the new initiative. As Ramon Murphy, the association's general secretary, described the event, it was "the greatest achievement in bodega history."
Maybe. One thing is certain. Less than a month after Mr. Fernandez telephoned Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly to express concern about a spate of recent crimes against bodegas in the city, the mayor came to the Bronx to announce a pilot program to fight the problem. Under the program, which will go into effect at 10 bodegas in 10 precincts, security cameras will be installed and systems will be put into place to allow rapid police response if a crime is committed. The City Council has set aside $5,000 to expand the program to more stores.
The event put a spotlight on Mr. Fernandez and his organization. Some have compared him to Fernando Mateo, a successful businessman who organized livery cab drivers, but Mr. Fernandez shuns that comparison, noting that he started as a bodega owner, whereas Mr. Mateo came from outside the livery world.
The association, which claims to have 7,000 members, some from as far away as Philadelphia, is the main instrument of Mr. Fernandez's political muscle. It was born out of a conversation that he had back in 1997 with Mr. Murphy and Arsenio Morales, Mr. Murphy's business partner, when the three men were seated on milk crates in the back of a van outside of Mr. Fernandez's grocery.
The group has had minor success, securing meetings with borough presidents, landing a $115,000 state contract for training bodega owners about regulations on cigarette sales, and getting some press coverage.
But most of their efforts have been only moderately successful. 
Most recently, when the group protested against the new cigarette tax's potential to harm bodega owners, the mayor dismissed their concern as "a minor economic issue." (In response, Mr. Fernandez called the mayor a "traitor.")
However, with a dozen killings of grocery store workers in the past year, according to the association, and data from the association's telephone survey showing that 75 of 205 bodega robberies in the Bronx from May 2002 to May 2003 were not reported to the police, Mr. Fernandez saw a chance to make his mark.
AS he tells it, on a Friday he called the commissioner's office and told the secretary that he was giving a news conference that afternoon and wanted to speak with the commissioner. The commissioner called back, met with Mr. Fernandez on Monday and announced the program three weeks later.
Or, as Commissioner Kelly described the exchange in an interview after the news conference: "He called me, and I called him back. We try to be responsive."
The city's plan made news in the city's major daily papers and graced the cover of the Spanish-language tabloid Hoy.
Mr. Fernandez, a serious and unassuming man, came to New York in 1983, at the age of 15, and, like so many Dominicans before him, settled in Washington Heights. He earned a bachelor's degree from Lehman College, and, in 1997, after four years working as a counselor for children in a domestic violence shelter, he gave up a steady salary with benefits, borrowed money from his credit card and relatives, and made a $40,000 down payment for a small grocery store in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.
His education did not make up for a lack of experience. His bodega cost him $120,000, far more than it should have, he now realizes. Unable to pay off his loan, he lost his business. It was during this period that the meeting in the van took place.
"The difference between me and other people is that they don't stand up for themselves," Mr. Fernandez said. "They go to work in a factory. I started an association."
By that time, he translated his political talents into a job as a community liaison for State Assemblyman Adriano Espaillat, who represents upper Manhattan. Two years later, he again pieced together loans and bought a bodega in the Belmont section of the Bronx. This time the cost was only $30,000, and the business, Cristian Deli Grocery, was a success.
His family runs the store, and Mr. Fernandez, who lives in Lodi, N.J., spends most of his time working out of the association's new office on West 179th Street in Washington Heights, outfitted with dark-stained wood furniture that give it something of the air of a small corporate boardroom. The association's $250,000 annual budget is financed through corporate donations and fund-raising events.
The day after the press conference, the office was buzzing. Executives from Goya Foods, a New Jersey company that is a main supplier of food to bodegas, had arrived to speak with Mr. Fernandez, and the phone was ringing with people calling for appointments.
"For me it was a miracle," Mr. Fernandez said. "I feel proud about myself, and I feel surprised at the same time, because I never thought I was going to get the attention of the mayor to help the bodegueros. I always felt I was fighting and fighting, but I was frustrated because no one was listening to me."
The cause of bodega safety has a long way to go. With the money from the police and the City Council, about 60 stores will get security equipment and added protection. But at least 2,000 New York bodegas need help, Mr. Fernandez said.
Meanwhile, the association also has some mundane work to do. Mr. Fernandez said his group has signed up 7,000 stores as members, some of them as far away as Philadelphia. But that figure was impossible to verify, since most of the sign-up sheets are still in stacks. Things are so hectic that association employees haven't had time to enter the information into the Excel spreadsheet that serves as the organization's database.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 20, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 6 about Jose Fernandez, president of the Bodega Association of the United States, misstated the amount of money the City Council has allocated for installing security cameras at bodegas. It is $50,000, not $5,000.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
Walk a Dog and Help the Planet

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR

 BODY:
Dogs being walked in New York City probably aren't committed to preserving endangered plant life. 
 But these days, the people on the other end may be, at least if they are members of Dogwalking for Rainforests, a pet walking, training and sitting collective that donates 30 percent of its fees to causes around the world. 
 The agency was started a year ago by Joan Roney, a longtime New York dog walker and pet trainer who had also been an advocate for local groups and community gardens. She decided to merge the two kinds of services, and today she has four full-time and two part-time workers who help select causes to assist -- including a Brazilian student newspaper, a Lower East Side women's bookstore, a rain forest preservation group in Brooklyn and a group of 86 Ecuadorean indigenous communities. 
Dog walking has become increasingly competitive as the economy has soured, Ms. Roney said, but added that her business quadrupled after she began making donations. Members of the collective help decide where donations should go and clients make suggestions.
So far Dogwalking for Rainforests has donated $6,500. 
While some other dog-walking services contribute to animal-related causes, Ms. Roney said many of her new clients were attracted by the unusual world view behind her donations.
"It's one of the reasons I contacted her," said Jodi Barish, who uses the service for her mixed-breed dog, Thangka. "It seemed less about just someone out to make money. It just makes you trust them a little more, that they're going to take very good care of your animals." 
And Ms. Roney's old clients? 
"They think that I'm, uh, they find me endearing," she said.
 TARA BAHRAMPOUR

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Sure-Fire Mo rning Wreckers: Green Eggs and Spam

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
When it comes to precious time, the Internet gives but, alas, it also takes away. In 0.15 seconds you can get a list of nail salons in Natchez, but there's a dark side: the time spent deleting spam. 
 A survey of 1,528 people by McAfee Security, which sells a SpamKiller program, found that nearly half of Americans spend more than 40 minutes a week hitting the delete key. (The level of outrage while doing so? Not tallied.) And 49 percent call spam the No. 1 technology time waster, dwarfing the 24 percent who picked a sure ex-champion -- multiple-choice phone labyrinths. 
 The survey noted that people delete spam an average of 30.6 times a week but read to children just 2.81 times. Dr. Seuss has been spammed. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: Personal Finance In the Classroom 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Reading, Writing and Now Checkbook Balancing" (June 22), which discussed the state of financial education for teenagers in high school: 
 Financial education at the college level is equally essential for securing a young adult's financial future. As the article noted, many new college students are unprepared for the financial realities that they face once they leave home. Furthermore, evidence shows that many of today's college students will continue to struggle with their finances throughout their lives.
While I recognize the importance of financial education before college, there are some topics, such as retirement and tax planning, marital finance, and insuring one's life and property, that are more age-appropriate for college students.
Our program at Smith College offers courses on basic finance. We build upon this with more advanced courses covering investing, retirement, interpreting financial news and entrepreneurship. Some of our students go on to offer workshops on financial topics in local high schools.
I hope that other colleges and universities will also find a way to incorporate financial literacy into the curriculum. Clearly, we cannot afford to neglect this "fourth R" at any educational level.

MAHNAZ MAHDAVI
Northampton, Mass., June 26

The writer, an associate professor of economics, is the director of Women and Financial Independence: the Smith College Program in Financial Education.

HEADLINE: Doctors' Testimony Under Scrutiny 

BYLINE:  By ADAM LIPTAK

 BODY:
Feeling under siege by malpractice lawsuits, medical societies are setting up tribunals to review the testimony of doctors who act as expert witnesses in such lawsuits. Doctors whose testimony does not pass muster can be suspended or expelled from the societies.
 Lawyers who represent plaintiffs in malpractice cases say such reviews and the threat of sanctions are meant to intimidate witnesses. They say the mere existence of the grievance procedures has made it harder to find experts, whose testimony is crucial in most malpractice cases. 
 The idea for the grievance procedures seems to have started with the American Association of Neurological Surgeons, which has prevailed in three court battles over their legality. Societies of obstetricians, gynecologists and spine doctors followed, and societies of anesthesiologists and ear, nose and throat specialists are expected to vote on establishing similar procedures this summer and fall.
"There are probably another 10 that are studying it closely," said Russell M. Pelton, a lawyer in Chicago who represents the neurosurgeons' association.
The American Medical Association supports the moves, said Dr. Donald J. Palmisano, the association's president-elect.
"The giving of expert testimony should be considered the practice of medicine, and it should be the subject of peer review," Dr. Palmisano said. "If someone comes into court and gives junk science, we don't want fraudulent testimony in court."
But the trend troubles plaintiffs' lawyers.
"Not only does this appear to be a form of intimidation of witnesses that violates the federal Civil Rights Act, but this is a sort of restraint of trade that could also be an antitrust violation," said Robert Peck, the president of the Center for Constitutional Litigation, which often represents the American Trial Lawyers Association.
"It's extremely widespread," Mr. Peck said. "It leads us to believe that many doctors are afraid to come forward because they fear retaliation."
Some lawyers say the effect of the grievance procedures is already being felt in the legal system.
"It's more difficult to get a good neurosurgeon as an expert than any other specialty," said Norman D. Tucker, a Michigan lawyer who represents patients.
Dr. Albert L. Strunk, vice president for fellowship activities at the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, said he was not convinced that review of expert testimony by medical societies would prevent poor-quality testimony. The college has a grievance program that has heard occasional complaints about such testimony.
"When a medical society disciplines one of its members for this sort of thing, it just plays into the hands of the personal injury lawyers," Dr. Strunk said. "They say this is the medical profession closing ranks to stifle doctors who are speaking out on behalf of a patient who has been injured."
Dr. Strunk also said the college asked members to sign a statement affirming that any testimony they give will be complete and accurate and that they will submit their testimony to peer review.
Plaintiffs' lawyers say that request is a form of intimidation, too.
"It's a ploy by A.C.O.G. to discourage its fellows from giving expert testimony," said James Cook, an Iowa lawyer who represents plaintiffs in malpractice cases.
The neurosurgeons' association has heard more than 30 complaints over the past 20 years, all but one of them about expert testimony given on behalf of plaintiffs, Mr. Pelton said. Only members of the society can file a grievance.
The hearings resemble trials, with witnesses and lawyers. They are usually held during annual conventions. The doctor bringing the complaint must prove "unprofessional conduct, not a difference of opinion between professionals," Mr. Pelton said. "Due process is observed."
One doctor was expelled from the association after such a hearing, he said, and 8 or 10 others have been suspended, usually for six months.
Dr. Gary J. Lustgarten, a neurosurgeon in Florida, was suspended for six months over expert testimony he gave in a 1998 case involving a patient's death during spinal disk surgery. Among other things, he was said to have misstated the doctor's responsibility.
Dr. Lustgarten's office said he was on vacation and could not return a call seeking comment. 
Dr. Lustgarten sued the association on antitrust and other grounds, drawing what he called a "painful but apt" comparison between "a professional peer review program and the sending of masked riders in the night."
"In the 19th century, motivated by animus and economic interest, the Ku Klux Klan terrorized witnesses who would appear in courts and give testimony not to the Klan's liking," he told a federal court in Georgia in 2001. The neurosurgeons' association, he suggested, was doing something similar.
Dr. Lustgarten dropped his suit after the federal appeals court in Chicago found for the association in a similar case that year.
In the Chicago case, Judge Richard A. Posner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit endorsed the grievance procedure as lawful and valuable. The case was brought by Dr. Donald C. Austin, a Michigan neurosurgeon who was suspended for six months after testifying in a case in which the patient emerged from surgery with a paralyzed vocal cord.
Judge Posner wrote that membership in medical societies brought with it privileges and obligations.
"By becoming a member of the prestigious American Association of Neurological Surgeons, a fact he did not neglect to mention in his testimony, Austin boosted his credibility as an expert witness," Judge Posner wrote. "The association has an interest -- the community at large has an interest -- in Austin's not being able to dazzle judges and juries and deflect the close and skeptical scrutiny that shoddy testimony deserves."
"This kind of professional self-regulation furthers rather than impedes the cause of justice," he added. "More policing of expert testimony is required, not less."
Mr. Peck, of the Center for Constitutional Litigation, said the legal system was capable of evaluating expert testimony without help from medical societies.
"Juries are remarkably good at this," he said. "Judges are very good at this. The juries' appreciation for things you might think are difficult to convey is outstanding."
Plaintiffs' lawyers say that only testimony on behalf of plaintiffs seems to land doctors in trouble.
"They are not reviewing the highly outrageous testimony they see from defendants' experts," Mr. Tucker said.
The medical societies say their procedures are evenhanded and are not meant to discourage testimony for either side, but rather testimony that is biased or irresponsible.
The sanctions can have serious consequences.
Dr. Austin told the court that his suspension was "disastrous" and "catastrophic," as it caused what the appeals court called his moonlighting income for expert testimony to drop to $77,000 from $220,000 annually.
Judge Elaine E. Bucklo of United States District Court in Chicago, who dismissed Dr. Austin's case in 2000, said that was all but inevitable.
"Who, after all," Judge Bucklo wrote, "wants an expert who has to acknowledge that he was suspended from his professional association for ethical violations he was found to have committed as an expert witness?"
