HEADLINE: Not Counting on 911, Companies Hire Private Ambulances 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
A growing number of big companies in Manhattan are bypassing the 911 system for their medical emergencies, and signing up instead with private ambulance services that hold out the promise -- explicitly or not -- of better, faster service.
 The ambulances run by these services do not answer 911 calls, responding instead only to callsfrom their corporate customers. The ambulance companies say their crews are less busy than those who answer 911 calls, are more likely to be close to the scene of an emergency, and are familiar with their clients' high-rise buildings -- all leading, at least in theory, to faster responses. 
 These services make up a tiny niche in the ambulance industry, averaging perhaps a dozen calls a day, compared with the thousands that go to 911. But the niche is growing fast, roughly doubling in size in the last year, with more than 100 corporate clients, who each pay thousands of dollars a year. 
Officials at the Fire Department, which runs the 911 medical system, dismissed the private services as marketing gimmicks, and disputed the idea that they were any faster or better than the city system. "We strongly believe that circumventing 911 is not in the best interest of the patient," Deputy Commissioner Francis X. Gribbon said.
It seems odd that such services would boom in a sluggish economy, especially when New York City's Emergency Medical Service, once troubled, is much improved. In some cases, the explanation dates to the attack on Sept. 11, 2001, when hundreds of 911 calls went unanswered. The experience raised the fear at some corporations that in another major crisis, the city system might be too overwhelmed to help them.
But the broader reason for the surge appears to be wider availability of the services and more aggressive marketing.
"I think the market was always there" but not exploited, said Dr. Daniel E. Weiner, chairman of the emergency department at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He said the hospital had changed its view of ambulance services and emergency rooms, once seen as expensive burdens. "Now we think of the E.R. as the front door to the hospital, the big generator of admissions."
Roosevelt Hospital started an ambulance service for Midtown corporations in the 1980's, but hospital officials say it languished because little effort was put into it. Last year, the hospital turned over operation of the service, FastCare, to MetroCare, a large ambulance company. At the same time, Roosevelt began actively seeking new customers, especially in its booming Columbus Circle neighborhood, and urging old clients to use the service more. Officials say they have won new business and raised the call volume by 40 percent.
Last September, Empress Emergency Medical Service, another big ambulance company, started a similar service, Emergacare, affiliated with New York University Hospitals Center, serving companies in the financial district. 
FastCare says it has 56 clients in 72 locations, including Viacom, Newsweek, The New York Times and Lincoln Center. Emergacare claims about 50 clients but says they do not want to be identified publicly. The clients generally employ anywhere from several hundred people at a single site to several thousand.
The vice president for employee relations and development at Viacom, Betty Panarella, said Viacom did not have an in-house medical department, and spoke of a "comfort level" supplied by FastCare.
Several corporate executives who were interviewed said an essential part of the appeal was their belief that the service was faster than 911, though they could cite only anecdotal evidence and did not know what 911 response times were. "We think it's so, but we've never really analyzed it," Ms. Panarella said.
One executive, who insisted that his company not be identified, said, "Sept. 11 made a lot of our people edgy about what could happen in a big crisis, and if this reassures them, it'sworth the price."
Richard Gregory, executive vice president of Emergacare, said that its downtown clients had felt the Sept. 11 trauma keenly and that many signed up because of it.
Emergacare charges companies $1,500 to $30,000 a year, depending on their size, Mr. Gregory said. FastCare generally charges $1 per year per employee at a covered building, and $500 for the main location and $250 for each additional one. Both services also charge for each ambulance run, as the city's Emergency Medical Service does with 911 calls, and both usually bill that charge to a patient's insurance company.
New York City's 911 medical system is a hybrid of the Emergency Medical Service and the ambulance corps of dozens of hospitals. Hospitals have long used their participation to win patients; a hospital ambulance answering a 911 call is likely, all things being equal, to take the patient back to that hospital.
Similarly, FastCare, whose operating costs are shared by Roosevelt and MetroCare, also produces revenue for Roosevelt, as hospital officials acknowledge frankly. About 85 percent of the people it takes to emergency rooms go to Roosevelt, they say, and a handful are admitted to the hospital on an average week. This can be significant in an era of precarious hospital finances. MetroCare, meanwhile, collects the fees that FastCare charges.
Most FastCare patients work for big corporations, so they are far more likely to have insurance than patients who come in through 911 calls. "Certainly, they're as profitable as anyone we bring in here," said Dr. Richard F. Daines, president and chief executive of St. Luke's-Roosevelt.
Mr. Gregory says that Emergacare makes no effort to steer patients to the affiliated hospitals of N.Y.U. Hospitals Center, though "it is standard in the ambulance world." But in fact, for many cases in Lower Manhattan, N.Y.U. Downtown Hospital's emergency room is a logical destination.
Ambulance industry executives say they know of no similar services elsewhere in the country, and doubt that other cities have the concentration of people and large employers to sustain them. 
The 911 system has a mix of basic life support units and advanced life support units with better-trained crews and more equipment. Emergacare and FastCare operate only advanced life support units, and their affiliated hospitals provide the clients with services like training in cardiopulmonary resuscitation and in emergency preparedness.
Mostly, though, what customers pay for is time: the promise of precious minutes saved in an emergency.
The 911 system has greatly improved its speed in the last decade, so that on average, an ambulance responds in less than seven minutes in life-threatening situations. Also, in some of the most serious categories of calls, when the patient appears to be having a heart attack or is unconscious or choking, a nearby fire engine is dispatched in addition to an ambulance, and the fire crews have some medical training and equipment like cardiac defibrillators.
"If you add those numbers in, in those serious cases where you want to get there as quickly as possible, our average response time is actually under five minutes," Commissioner Gribbon said. He added that bypassing 911 could also mean bypassing an appropriate police response, as when someone suffers a drug overdose or is injured in an assault.
In terms of speed, an official response time is to the address, not to the patient, a distinction that the corporate ambulance services say matters.
Emergacare promises a response time to the address of less than eight minutes, or the call is free. Mr. Gregory says the company has a faster average time than 911. 
FastCare does not promise specific response times. Roosevelt officials do not claim that FastCare is quicker than 911, though they hint at it, and MetroCare officials say so outright, although they do not give a specific time. 
Judging such claims is impossible with the limited information available. But it does seem that the calls-to-ambulances ratio is lower than in the 911 system. In essence, corporate customers pay for the knowledge that ambulances run by private services spend much of their time roaming or idling in nearby, strategic spots, waiting for their calls.
On a recent weekday afternoon, two paramedics, Natan Mandelbaum and Ivor Edwards, sat in a FastCare ambulance, on a traffic island in Times Square. Calls to 911 came and went, and an occasional ambulance sped by, but they stayed put.
"We get anywhere from one to eight calls in a 12-hour shift," usually closer to the low end of that range, Mr. Mandelbaum said. "That's not a lot compared to working 911."
FastCare keeps one ambulance on the street around the clock, with another ready at Roosevelt, and company officials say they plan to run both full time on the street soon. Emergacare covers business hours on weekdays, and will not say how many ambulances it operates at a time. Both say that as parts of larger ambulance companies, they can quickly call in more units, but that it is rarely necessary.
Both companies say that familiarity with their clients' buildings is as important as curb-to-curb response times. The ambulance crews practice drills with the customers, and develop a protocol for each building.
"There's no pulling up at the main lobby, with all the confusion and the crowds, or pulling up at the wrong loading dock at a building you've never seen," said Alfred F. Kim, vice president of MetroCare and a former New York City paramedic. "In a high-rise, delays like that are inevitable with 911. With our teams, it's choreographed, the security staff knows our guys, everybody meets at the right entrance, and they've got the cargo elevator waiting with the override key."

HEADLINE: Poor and War-Weary, Africa Turns Eyes to Bush for Help 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA with MARC LACEY

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 5 

 BODY:
At a checkpoint here bristling with boys both armed and anxious, a giant billboard shows two figures -- a small Liberian youngster and a large Uncle Sam facing each other at the end of a long curving road. The Liberian figure looks up and says: "We've come a long way, big brother. But it's still rough! We are suffering."
 "For true?" is Uncle Sam's woolly response. 
 It may come as a surprise to many Americans, but Liberians do see the United States as their big brother. Freed American slaves settled Liberia 150 years ago and their descendants have remained its elite ever since. Until the end of the cold war, when its utility as an anti-Communist ally on the strategic West African coast ran out, Liberia was among Washington's most reliable partners on the continent. 
Today, after more than a decade of on-and-off war, Liberians want desperately to capture America's imagination once more: they want American troops to come in and stop the fighting. 
Certainly, Liberia has a peculiar relationship to its big brother across the Atlantic. But the billboard on the Monrovia street corner captures a much more widely popular sentiment in Africa. As President Bush begins his first official trip to the continent on Monday, African eyes are on America as never before. 
Africans have never forgotten the comment that Mr. Bush made during his presidential campaign. "While Africa may be important," he said, "it doesn't fit into the national strategic interests, as far as I can see them." 
The president's view has clearly changed. The fight against terrorism that has become a central part of his administration has forced him to focus on the Horn of Africa, where Al Qaeda is known to operate. He has also leaned on African heads of state to support his agenda, most recently, securing promises of immunity for Americans in the International Criminal Court. 
Beyond that, he has surprised many critics with the attention he has paid to Africa, meeting with nearly half the continent's government leaders in Washington and offering numerous pledges for turning Africa around. 
Still, many Africans say Mr. Bush, representing the richest country on earth, must prove his commitment to some of the poorest.
"Africa has always been on the bottom of the list as far as America's priorities," said Maria Nzomo, director of the Institute of Diplomacy and International Studies at the University of Nairobi. "How is this president going to help us?" 
Not everybody is after American military might. "We don't want him to send his troops all across Africa or to just view us in terms of international terrorism," Ms. Nzomo said. "There are roots to the violence here, and poverty, weak institutions and the devastation of AIDS are tied to them."
On his trip, Mr. Bush will avoid the continent's worst trouble spots, dropping in instead on success stories. He will visit Senegal (with its long democratic tradition), Botswana (where the economy is booming), South Africa (America's largest trade partner in Africa), Uganda (which has successfully reduced the spread of AIDS) and Nigeria (which has replaced a succession of military coups with elections, however flawed). 
Kayode Fayemi, head of the Center for Democracy and Development, which is based in Lagos, said that while he was "cautiously optimistic" about Mr. Bush's promises, he worried about Washington's increased focus on the oil-rich -- and human-rights-poor -- states of West Africa. Nigeria, for one, had done little to share its oil wealth with its own people, he said. 
"The focus on oil in the Gulf of Guinea would probably ensure that the United States looks the other way when it comes to human rights, accountability and transparency," Mr. Fayemi said. "In Nigeria, the example of that would be how does the United States respond to campaigns from local communities for equitable and local management of resources." 
Moreover, Africa finds itself roiled by numerous conflicts, and Mr. Bush will be pressed at every turn to beef up American involvement in peace efforts. War, however, is far from the only killer. Disease takes the lives of even more Africans than fighting does, and entrenched poverty is the fate of most of those who survive. 
This president will find an Africa that is markedly different from the one his predecessor visited in 1998 on the first of two official tours. When President Clinton arrived, Ivory Coast and Zimbabwe were zones of stability. War had not yet brought Congo to its knees. Liberia was in the hands of its warlord-president, Charles Taylor, but the country's meltdown was not imminent. Now those countries are among the most troubled on the continent, along with Sudan, Burundi and Zimbabwe. 
Mr. Bush will also hear about famine in broad swaths of Africa and about economies that suffer despite the tariff-lowering African Growth and Opportunity Initiative. Thanks to American agricultural subsidies, the United States market is virtually impenetrable to African farmers. 
When it comes to peacemaking, Mr. Bush has devoted considerable political capital to the decades-old Sudanese conflict, which pits the Islamic government against Christian and animist rebels in the south. He named a special envoy and spearheaded talks that have gone further than any others. But such activism has been less focused when it comes to other battle zones. 
At issue in Congo is whether Mr. Bush will accede to calls by Secretary General Kofi Annan to fortify United Nations peacekeeping forces. Once ruled by an anti-Communist ally, Mobutu Sese Seko, Congo has been ravaged by four and a half years of war; more than three million people have died. 
Of particular concern is the country's east, near the borders of Uganda and Rwanda, where armed factions battle for control over the riches of the land, despite a peace deal. United Nations peacekeepers have been able to do little to stanch the bloodletting, a point Bush aides are quick to offer. In the northeastern town of Bunia, a multinational force led by the European Union is in place to restore security. When it leaves, on Sept. 1, fighting is expected to flare up again. 
Mr. Bush has yet to back Mr. Annan's request to increase the Congo peacekeeping forces to nearly 11,000 troops. The United States pays a major portion of the United Nations peacekeeping bill and the administration has concerns about the effectiveness of the Congo mission. 
In Burundi, the conflict is more contained, but it is just as brutal to the people caught up in it. Two rebel groups made up of ethnic Hutu who did not join a peace deal struck in 2000 continue to fight in the bush. 
Mr. Clinton attended the signing of that peace agreement in Arusha, Tanzania, saying pointedly at the time that the Hutu holdouts were a grave threat. 
The African Union, an alliance of African nations intent on handling more of its trouble in-house, recently sent peacekeepers into Burundi, in central Africa, but the rebels have only increased their offensives. 
Nigeria, the West African behemoth, is as important to the United States as ever, with its oil shipments helping to relieve Americans of their dependence on the Middle East. Olusegun Obasanjo, a former military leader, won re-election in April, but the victory was marred by rigging and violence. Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, may have put an end to its string of military coups, but it has hardly shaken off a legacy of politically motivated killings, rampant corruption and poverty. 
But nowhere is American engagement sought more than in Liberia. Britain and France have taken the lead in the conflicts in neighboring Sierra Leone and Ivory Coast. Liberia's strong links to the United States have put the onus on Washington to sort out the mess. 
The links between the countries are hard to miss. The Liberian flag is a derivation of the Stars and Stripes. Its currency is the Liberian dollar. The American Embassy in Monrovia is among the oldest in Africa, having opened in 1949, a time when most of the continent was still carved up among colonial powers. 
Liberia stood beside the United States throughout the cold war, supporting its proposals in the United Nations, allowing it to erect a strategic Voice of America radio tower to spread the anti-Communist gospel and playing host to what Liberia's outspoken Roman Catholic archbishop, Michael Francis, recalled as a small village of C.I.A. agents. Today, the archbishop is among the loudest voices calling for American intervention to stop the war. 
"The U.S. has a moral obligation," he said in a recent interview. "We need an intervention force to keep the peace, to disarm the belligerents, to create an atmosphere where there is some security."
He spoke from the study at his home because the Catholic Secretariat had been ransacked. A member of the House of Representatives claimed responsibility and threatened to kill him next.

HEADLINE: As Putnam Develops, a Bid to Protect the Water Supply 

BYLINE:  By MARC FERRIS 

DATELINE: PUTNAM VALLEY 

 BODY:
IN Putnam County, Westchester's less developed neighbor to the north, the talk is of an invasion. Refugees from New York City and from Westchester are coming, Putnam residents say, and the county needs to protect itself from willy-nilly development coming from the south.
 But in the last few months, the tables have turned, and now people in three towns and the gritty river city of Peekskill are seeking powers to protect their water supply from development pressures in Putnam County. 
 Two months ago, 40 residents of Peekskill and Putnam Valley, Yorktown and Cortlandt, organized a group, Hollow Brook Water Watch, to challenge any development proposals that might harm the Peekskill Hollow Brook watershed, said the group's president, Andrew Fischer, of Cortlandt. The watershed supplies about 10 percent of Cortlandt's water and 90 percent of Peekskill's water, Mr. Fischer said. Westchester has designated the 48-square-mile watershed as a Critical Environmental Area. 
 Rising housingprices near the city have pushed developers and home buyers farther north into Putnam's woodsy lands, raising prices of Putnam County homes and acreage to levels hard to resist for owners. 
 That development has brought a backlash of groups ranging from grassroots advocates like the Hollow Brook Water Watch to the Nimham Mountain Singers, specialists in American Indian values and music of the Wappinger tribe, which once called all the land that could be seen from atop the 1,350-foot Nimham Mountain home. 
 Putnam County's motto, "Where the Country Begins," is apt: It is possible to drive for miles on some roads without seeing a traffic light. Most local water is drawn from wells, though several of the county's reservoirs are links in the chain that supplies the majority of Westchester's and New York City's tap water. The city owns about 9 percent of the county's land, which is kept pristine to protect the watershed. 
 Water is just one of the development issues in Putnam. Antidevelopment forces say sprawl -- and the potential for more -- threatens to destroy the largely rural way of life enjoyed by longtime residents and by newcomers. Historic preservation, building moratoriums and tough environmental laws are on the agenda of the Putnam Valley Residents' Coalition, whose slogan is "Putnam Valley: Worth Fighting For." 
 "When you cross from Westchester into Putnam off of Route 6, it's like coming out of a rabbit hole into what looks like Vermont," said Wendy Whetsel, president of the coalition. "That sprawl has already begun to spill over here." Just behind her 1800's farmhouse, a 15-unit subdivision consisting mostly of modular homes, selling in the $500,000 to $600,000 range, is under construction. 
 Joining the Concerned Residents of Southeast and the Concerned Residents of Kent/Mahopac, formed in the late 1990's, along with the Web site www. planputnam.org, which is a forum on development issues, the 250-member Putnam Valley residents' coalition was incorporated last year. The coalition consolidated several neighborhood groups after a New Jersey-based developer floated the idea of building a hotel with a conference center, a small college, stores and 124 units of senior housing at Bryant Pond, just off the Taconic State Parkway. The proposal has since been scrapped. 
 "That project was the epitome of smart development, but they were opposed even to that," Carmelo Santos, Putnam Valley town supervisor, said of the residents' coalition. "It would have created a community confined to 40 acres on a 100-acre plot. The issue is, can you stop the influx of people coming into the county?" 
 Last month, both houses of the State Legislature passed a bill to empower the city of Peekskill with the same enforcement capabilities in Putnam County that New York City has over its water supply system, said State Assemblywoman Sandra R. Galef, who represents parts of Westchester and western Putnam County and sponsored the bill in the Assembly.
 Watershed areas in the eastern part of the Putnam that feed New York City and Westchester, including the East Branch, the West Branch and the Croton Falls reservoirs, situated in the towns of Carmel and Southeast, sites of the county's most concentrated development, are impaired portions of the city system, said James Tierney, Watershed inspector general for the state attorney general. 
 "The leading cause of pollutants is not wastewater treatment or dumping, it's polluted runoff from impervious surfaces," he said. "Sprawl harms water quality. In order to have built-up places like New York City and Westchester, you need places like Putnam County to stay rural."
 Similar pressures threaten the Putnam Valley watershed. Unlike New York City, which owns the 14,460 acres in the county that it patrols, Peekskill enforcement officers would have jurisdiction only over dumpers or loiterers, said Ms. Galef, not over zoning or planning in Putnam Valley that might affect the watershed, because of the state's home rule statutes.
 Protecting the land is part of the American Indian values that are celebrated by the Nimham Mountain Singers, who appeared in Queens last weekend -- just days after their "Circle of Drums" celebration on Mount Nimham in Putman had been held despite sheets of rain. The group's founder is Gil Tarbox, who said, "To us, the drums are the heartbeat of the earth; that's what we were there to celebrate," he said. 
 One potential site of development battles is Oregon Corners, Putnam Valley's main crossroads. A proposal to open a cafe along a 307-foot stretch of Oscawana Brook, which feeds the Peekskill Hollow Brook, prompted the the Peekskill planning department to write to the town of Putnam Valley in March, expressing concerns over the potential impact on water quality.
 During tough economic times, increasing real estate values, tax revenues and jobs are appealing, said the county executive, Robert Bondi. "We pride ourselves on our ability to be able to balance the future with the past."
 Even Mr. Fischer conceded that the middle ground is wide. Golf courses, for instance, have long been targets of antidevelopment forces. But now, he said, things are different. When he heard about a proposed golf course along the Peekskill Hollow Brook in Cortlandt, for instance, "I was the first to say 'no way, let's run these guys out of town,"' he said. "Now, I fully support it. The developer worked with the town government and we negotiated our concerns."
 Divergent views of progress are at the core of the problem, said Ms. Galef. "My Putnam constituents like their dirt roads and want the keep them that way. In Westchester they beg me to pave them."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Waving the Flag for Artistic Freedom

BYLINE:  By PAUL LUSTIG DUNKEL; Paul Lustig Dunkel is music director of the Westchester Philharmonic.

 BODY:
HERE is a quiz for you to take: 
 Rubato is: a. Tony Soprano's middle name; b. A four-star Italian restaurant in Yonkers; c. An opera by Verdi; d. None of the above. 
 If you guessed "d" then treat yourself to a post-Fourth of July hot dog. If you knew "rubato" was Italian for "robbed," then throw in a beverage. And if you knew it referred to freedom in musical performance - literally robbing one beat at the expense of another -- you're eligible for a grand prize. 
 Freedom in performance is something I take for granted. My teachers taught me to play musical phrases with flexibility, but only after I could play them in strict rhythm. "You will play the music without fooling around first, and then you can break the rules," my piano teacher said to me in her thick German accent, adding encouragement with a ruler directed at my offending fingers. It was not a lesson that fell on deaf ears or bruised knuckles. All performing artists go through the process (hopefully less bruisingly). Only after one has painstakingly mastered the mechanics is the ingredient of rubato added to the mix. 
 Freedom of performance is something I have also taken for granted. I've been privileged to perform music that I find challenging and lovable with colleagues I admire in places where I'm appreciated. I play for children and older people and everyone in between. On top of that I get paid. What a country! 
 But events of late are giving me pause. No, the Department of Home Security hasn't quashed Handel's "Fireworks" and the State Department hasn't ruled out Handel's "Israel in Egypt." The House of Representatives hasn't weighed in against Gershwin's "American in Paris" nor does the Christian Coalition object to "The Marriage of Figaro," though it features a little cross-dressing. 
 This is what's troubling me. Here in the United States, the government is using its economic and political system to wage a war against artistic freedom. Here are a few examples:
 A change in the tax codes that makes any corporation think twice about supporting the arts. Why should their employees and neighbors enjoy a night at the symphony or an afternoon at a museum when the bottom line comes first?
 The crippling of the National Endowment for the Arts. Remember the war over the Robert Mapplethorpe photographs?
 What about arts in our schools? Not when we need more time for state-mandated testing.
 Not to mention rolling back inheritance laws and bigger interest on college loans.
 All of these are deadly weapons against artistic freedom and the exchange of ideas. Artistic messengersdie a slow but painful death. And so do audiences.
 Wouldn't it be efficient if the news media were owned by a handful of conglomerates? Fewer issues and a select editorial clique. 
 If America hasn't led the league in great orchestras, opera and ballet companies in the 20th century, it's news to me. If we haven't produced outstanding composers, artists and writers, that's news to me, too.
 It has happened because we have invested in the arts. The arts enhance the quality of our lives. The study of the arts shapes mind and character. Exhibit A: Albert Schweitzer played the organ. 
 Our most important national holiday has just gone by and people are turning their attentions to shopping for Christmas. 
 We need to worry about freedom for a few more days. The National Rifle Association is doing a swell job protecting our freedom to bear arms. 
 It's freedom of expression that needs your help. Let's make this the Year of Rubato.

HEADLINE: Views of the Bridge 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
ALEXANDER SAUNDERS, a foundry owner from Garrison, wants a Tappan Zee tunnel. Robert Hintersteiner, a freelance engineer from White Plains, wants a three-deck Tappan Zee bridge with six lanes on each level. Jeffrey Anzevino, a planner with Scenic Hudson, wants a bridge about the size of the current one, in the hope of preventing further sprawl. John Shields, the mayor of Nyack, wants to keep every piece of property in his town intact during the rethinking of the Hudson River crossing. Stan Kachnowski, a father of two young children from Tarrytown, wants clean air during construction of whatever is built or rebuilt or changed. 
 And Christopher A. Waite, project manager, and Janet Mainiero, deputy project manager, the experts who lead the team to create the next incarnation of the Tappan Zee Bridge (or tunnel, or both), want to hear the views of all these people, and morel. 
 "The public deserves no less," Ms. Mainiero said in an interview in her office on the future of this crucial link between Westchester and Rockland Counties on Interstate 287 across the Hudson River. 
 To make everybody happy is impossible. "I don't envy you," John Edwards, a resident of White Plains, told the experts sympathetically at a forum this spring on the bridge's future. "You've got to consider light rail. You've got to revamp the Bee-Line. You've got to think about the cost. You have a monstrous job."
 It seems, at least for now, that the Tappan Zee team is trying to listen to everyone as part of a process that is expected to include myriad public forums, decision deadlines, studies, comparisons of options and other steps designed to winnow the current list of choices from 156 down to a final design by the end of 2005. A few people have each spent thousands of hours and dollars to turn themselves into engineers, tunnel experts and public health specialists to contribute to the process of making a decision on what to do with the bridge: whether and how and when to replace it or rehabilitate it. 
 There is no doubt the Tappan Zee Bridge is well past its prime. Designed to last half a century, the bridge is 47 years old. It handles 130,000 vehicles a day on average. It was built to handle 100,000. 
 During rush hours, cars frequently line up bumper to bumper in a honking, immobile fury. The bridge, with three lanes in each direction and a seventh, central and reversible lane used to handle commuting traffic in peak hours, is an indisputable bottleneck. Weekends and holidays can be a nightmare; people have been known to carefully plot trips to avoid the bridge.
 The New York Thruway Authority has declared the bridge, officially called the Governor Malcolm Wilson Tappan Zee Bridge, safe for now, and says that if it is properly repaired and maintained, it could last another 50 years. But prolonging its life will require an initial $1 billion to enhance its ability to withstand earthquakes, according to data released by a governor's task force in 2000. Maintenance costs are another factor; they are much higher for an old bridge than they would be for a new one.
 Building a new, wider bridge -- with at least four lanes in each direction, and possibly two levels -- would cost about $4 billion, according to the same task force. 
 No money has been appropriated for any Tappan Zee repair or rehabilitation project, beyond money for the initial study. 
 LAST summer, the Thruway Authority and Metro-North Railroad created the project group on the Tappan Zee crossing's future. Mr. Waite is a highway engineer with the Thruway Authority, and Ms. Mainiero a transportation planner with Metro-North. And with that, the project, officially called the "Tappan Zee Bridge/ I-287 Corridor Alternatives Analysis and Environmental Review Process," began.
 Wraps, salad and lemonade were served at public meetings where state engineers and consultants solicited opinions. At an early morning meeting in April, vociferous (and sometimes cantankerous) residents voiced their concerns, while Mr. Waite and Ms. Mainiero patiently listened. Survey sites were set up three months ago at more than a dozen shopping malls across Rockland and Westchester to collect information on commuters' preferences. Outreach centers -- small offices in Tarrytown and Nyack -- opened their doors in late March to serve as de facto town squares for the Tappan Zee study. Surveys were also handed out at toll booths. 
 "This is more than usual for government agencies in terms of public outreach," said Christopher S. McBride, a traffic specialist with the New York office of the American Automobile Association, which has monitored public projects involving New York State drivers for decades. "They are trying to get people involved right from the start. They are trying to get everybody's perspective before narrowing down the options." 
 Sherwood Chorost, a trustee of Tarrytown, said, "They seem to be working closer with those who breathe the pollutants." Mr. Chorost has campaigned for a state study of the epidemiological effects of I-287 on the neighboring communities.
 The extensive outreach is a far cry from the days when the current Tappan Zee Bridge was designed in the 1950's. The release of its engineering plan in 1950 took many by surprise. Only three weeks earlier, Thomas E. Dewey, then governor of New York, had said no such plan existed. 
 The public nature of the process is also a far cry from events in the spring of 2000, when a study of the bridge was released by a governor's task force. The state's engineers and consultants -- haughtily, in the eyes of many residents -- declared the bridge decrepit and recommended that the state build a new one. Local residents felt the report failed to take account of the opinions and knowledge of people who lived near the bridge.
 Federal and state environmental laws make public involvement a requirement for federal and state financing. The National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 requires any governmental agency to disclose the full environmental impact of any project. The New York State Environmental Quality Review Act of 1978 specifically requires public participation in determining the environmental impact.
 Ms. Mainiero said, over a plate of salad at one meeting, that the team has been trying to follow "the spirit of the laws" instead of merely "the letters of the laws."
 The project team held three public meetings in Westchester, Rockland and Orange last January to solicit ideas. 
 In April, the project team invited interested individuals and organizations to a meeting where the team released the dozens of options generated by the public and crystallized by the project team. Many among the audience took notes and asked questions when the speakers used engineering jargon.
 "Have we heard you?" Mr. Waite, the project manager, asked repeatedly. "Is this what you have imagined?"
 A week later, the team held three public meetings where the options were presented and the team engineers explained the engineering challenges of the major models and answered questions around the large tables. 
 "Is an immersed tunnel cheaper than a bored tunnel?" a woman asked. "Not necessarily," answered John Eddy, an engineering consultant hired by the team. He then explained the costs involved in each type of tunnel. 
 While common perception holds that tunnels are more expensive than bridges to build, engineers said that was not necessarily the case. The team, which has not yet studied the quality of the rock beneath the Hudson River, declined to give even a rough estimate of a tunnel's cost. Nor has the team considered the cost of land for tunnel exits.
 Tunnel construction costs could vary widely. "It depends on whether you are drilling through rock or soil or chalk and what the tunnel diameter is," said Edward S. Plotkin, the co-chairman of team from New York Society of Professional Engineers to monitor the Tappan Zee project. 
 The English Channel tunnel, a 31-mile behemoth, cost $21 billion to build in 1994. The Tappan Zee tunnel would be 7-1/2 miles long at the longest. But inflation and other factors must also be reckoned with. 
 For the rest of this year, the Tappan Zee project team will narrow down the choices from the current 156 options, which could be mixed or matched -- a light rail system from Rockland to Westchester, for example, as well as a new bridge or tunnel. 
 The team plans to winnow the choices to about 15 semifinalists, using criteria including environmental impact, cost and the amount of traffic that option could handle. In the next step, which will span most of 2004, the choices will be narrowed down to about five finalists. A final decision is expected at the end of 2005. 
 Mr. Saunders, with the air of an absent-minded professor and unruly hair, has been a fixture at the public meetings. A 63-year-old foundry owner who studied metallurgy at M.I.T., Mr. Saunders has turned himself into a tunneling expert. He visited, at his own expense, many German and Swiss tunnels, attended tunneling seminars, and studied in detail the costs of building and maintaining a tunnel and bridge. He wants not just a Tappan Zee tunnel, but rather a tunnel that originates in Suffern, Rockland, traverses Westchester, crosses the Long Island Sound and ends in Syosset on Long Island. 
 Mr. Saunders's tenacity has won him respect and increasing access in the close-knit community of tunneling engineers. Herrenknecht A.G., one of Europe's largest tunneling companies, invited him to its German factory to discuss a Tappan Zee tunnel. The Robbins Company, an American tunnel maker, invited him to descend below the East River to watch the Queens No. 3 Water Tunnel in the making. 
 GOVERNMENT "people are usually gun shy about public projects," Mr. Saunders commented. "But Chris and Janet have even listened to the very antagonistic ones. They are unusually complete."
 Mr. Chorost is an "antagonistic" advocate. A Tarrytown trustee, Mr. Chorost, known as Sherry, is a former professor of statistics at the City University of New York and a clinical psychologist.
 He said he has spent thousands of hours on the Internet investigating the links between the proximity of major highways and diseases like cancer and asthma. He has sent officials with the Thruway Authority more than a 100 academic papers proving that traffic pollutants cause severe illnesses. He has founded an organization of elected officials from about three dozen towns and villages in the lower Hudson valley, Government United in Action for Responsible Development, to press public health concerns.
 "The Thruway doesn't want that," Mr. Chorost fumed recently in a telephone interview. "They don't want an epidemiological study."
 Although the Tappan Zee team will scrutinize any environmental issues, Mr. Waite said the kind of epidemiological study that Mr. Chorost has demanded is not feasible within the team's $15 million budget.
 Mr. Chorost, ever suspicious of government secrecy, has also been smoldering over something else. While his organization, sent two independent observers to watch the project team preparing for its first public meetings in January, the team has denied his request to dispatch another two observers to watch the engineers winnow down the options. 
 "There is still some trust issue," he said. 
 Mr. Waite and Ms. Mainiero responded that they wanted the engineers to make their choices without constant public pressure.
 The list of 156 options for the bridge's future include mundane ones, like reducing tolls for car pools and adding more buses, and fantastic ones, like creating a tunnel that emerges from a man-made island in the middle of the river to become a bridge for the rest of the crossing. 
 How to improve the life of a commuter is a focal point. Commuters by the tens of thousands drive from Rockland to Westchester every day to go to work in Westchester or New York City. The questions are many: Should free parking be offered to those using mass transit? Should the Port Jervis Line (from Port Jervis to Hoboken) be made more frequent so that more people from Rockland could cross over to Manhattan from Hoboken? Should ferry service be created between Nyack and Tarrytown? Others have suggested a bridge for vehicles and a tunnel for trains. One person has called for a three-deck bridge that connects with a Rockland and Westchester subway system. A third has proposed building a Yonkers bridge connecting the Cross County Expressway with the New Jersey Turnpike.
 The project team has carefully included every suggestion in their list of alternatives, which is posted on the Internet at the team's Web site, tzbsite.com. 
 For Mr. Waite, a stocky 53-year-old with mild manners, imagination is not enough. Every time someone suggests a project, he envisions the practical challenges. 
 Building a bridge linking Yonkers and Bergen County would mean having to consult with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, since a bridge at this location---- unlike the current one -- would lie within its jurisdiction. 
 "We could work with the Port Authority and New Jersey," Mr. Waite said, but bringing in two more parties could mean more delay.
 Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said no one has consulted with the agency about a Yonkers-Bergen bridge. He declined to comment further.
 A tunnel is what many in the community have clamored for. For one thing, building a tunnel would not displace the waterfront communities. Also, a tunnel would make it possible to filter automobile exhaust before it was released into the environment, reducing pollution. 
 Mr. Waite and his engineers have tried to tackle the challenges of crossing at what is one of the widest points of the water, and a spot where the banks are high on either side. Neither tunnel entrance could be too steep; if an entrance were, trains simply could not climb out of the hole, and cars would need to burn a lot of fuel to exit. All this means a tunnel would have to be very long. The experts say any tunnel would start between Exits 7 and 9 on I-287 on the Westchester side and end between exits 11 and 12 in Rockland. This makes a tunnel somewhere between 6 and 7-1/2 miles long; the current bridge is 3.1 miles long. "Will people living near the banks be willing to turn around after exiting the tunnel and drive back?" asked Mr. Waite. "Will they be willing to add 10, 20, 30 minutes a day to their commute time?"
 There is also money to consider. The economy is shriveling and the state, which is cash-strapped, has not set aside money for any new Tappan Zee crossing.
 But Mr. Waite, who has worked for the state's highway system since the mid-1970's and seen significant construction, said he was not too worried. 
 Perhaps Congress would appropriate money for the bridge, Mr. Waite said, or federal agencies might chip in. Perhaps the state could float bonds. As a last resort, he said, a private company could finance the project, and the state could pay the company back with income from the tolls.
 "When you have the right project," Mr. Waite said, "there will be money."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Montauk Takes Out Some 'Rainy Day' Insurance

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
WHEN it's raining in Montauk, what's there to do?
Not enough, apparently. And there's a growing sense among the merchants of Montauk, the easternmost point on Long Island and proud of it, that Montauk needs to be a little less isolated and a little more "Hamptons" if its visitors are going to be entertained when the weather doesn't cooperate.
 Last month, board members of the Montauk Chamber of Commerce voted to recruit businesses from outside Montauk to join the chamber. The idea is to give tourists more things to do when it rains, even if that means going as far afield as Connecticut. 
 The chamber hopes to recruit businesses like the Foxwoods casino near Norwich, Conn., and the Splish Splash water park in Riverhead. The chamber wants to include their marketing materials alongside those featuring such local stalwarts as Gurney's Inn and Spa, Viking's chartered fishing expeditions and Gosman's Restaurant. 
Not that Montauk lacks for attractions. Its appeal includes horseback riding at Rita's Stables, going out for bluefish on the Lazybones from the Johnny Marlin Dock and of course, 20 miles of sandy beaches.
Since much of Montauk's fun happens outdoors, its appeal all but disappeared last month, when more than six inches of rain fell, about double the usual amount. 
"Business is down by 20 to 30 percent" at many Montauk stores, said Jimmy Hewitt, a chamber director and the owner of the Shagwong restaurant, where visitors can rub shoulders with local fishermen at the bar, under the stuffed hammerhead shark. "We usually get a lot of seniors who come in May before rates go up. They didn't come this year."
So the chamber took a step toward making Montauk a little less weather-dependant by recruiting attractions outside the area as members. "We opted to allow membership from outside the village," said Paul Monte, a chamber director and the general manager of Gurney's Inn. "People who come to Montauk should have more options of things to do that are within an hour's drive."
Kiri Finnegan, the chamber's executive director, said: "The weather has such an impact on what people can do. The season got off to such a bad start, and the big debate in town is if it's the economy that's responsible, or the weather."
Some Montauk businesses beat the chamber to the punch. Last month, Joan Cass, a motel owner and a chamber director, started a jitney service that goes as far as the Tanger Factory Outlet Center in Riverhead on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Ms. Kass said she expected her ridership would be divided between workers who don't own cars and tourists who want to avoid driving in the famously congested East End summer traffic.
But the chamber directors' vote irked some local business owners. Ken Giustino, who publishes The Montauk Sun, a weekly newspaper, opposes the decision. "I think it's a bad idea," he said. "If there aren't enough things to do in Montauk, we need to create them. We need to do it ourselves, here, not start telling visitors to leave Montauk to find things to do."
By way of example, he said he backed a plan to build a museum at Camp Hero State Park. Theodore Roosevelt and his Rough Riders were quarantined at the camp after they returned from Spanish-American War. 
Others applauded the chamber's decision. Michael Hollander, the executive director of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, said he thought the chamber was moving in the right direction. 
"People look to do a number of different things on their vacation," he said. "They may want to go shopping, go to a museum, go to a park like Splish Splash. They can do these things" from Montauk, broadening its appeal as a destination.
Montauk's 3,000 motel rooms constitute nearly 20 percent of the Island's inventory, Mr. Hollander said. 
Using Montauk as a home base for day trips to the Hamptons and beyond is a strategy that travelers "in the know" have long used, said Mr. Monte of Gurney's. Montauk's motel rooms are generally far cheaper than the bed and breakfasts that prevail in East Hampton, and the boutique hotels in Southampton. 
This isn't the first time that Montauk has sought to cast a wider net. Andrea Gurvitz is the executive director of the Hamptons Visitors Council, a tourism promotion organization whose members are five village chambers within the Town of Southampton. "Montauk used to be part of the council, but they dropped out several years ago, when the Town of East Hampton did," Ms. Gurvitz said. At the time, "they said that what goes on in the Hamptons is not relevant to Montauk," she said.
Were they right?
Ms. Gurvitz paused a moment. "How do I say this? These are moderate-income places to stay. Montauk doesn't have the veneer of sophistication that the rest of the Hamptons have. It's a fishing destination. It's a family beach destination. Everything takes place on the beach or the wharfs."
But since bad weather is unavoidable, "it behooves them to market themselves" more broadly, she said. 
"I think that when they dropped out of the council, they missed a big opportunity," she added. "Now it's biting them on the foot."
John Keeshan, a real estate broker and director of the Montauk chamber, said that any plan to promote Montauk needed to keep the village's character in mind, because it was this character that attracted visitors in the first place. "Montauk is a little bit Carmel and it's a little bit Coney Island," he said. "That's what's special, and you don't want to change that."

(Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Link to the Past, Back in Its Element 

BYLINE:  By CAROLINE B. SMITH

DATELINE: WEST SAYVILLE 

 BODY:
The Priscilla, one of four remaining oyster sloops to have commercially dredged the waters of the Great South Bay for scallops and oysters at the turn of the century, is back in its home waters.
 After a $400,000, 16-month restoration project by the Long Island Maritime Museum in West Sayville, the 115-year-old wooden boat, built in Patchogue in 1888, was relaunched last weekend at the museum's yard. Curators plan to put the boat back to work as an educational tool, sailing the bay while teaching passengers about wooden boats and Long Island's marine industries. 
 "We were always very confident that this day was going to happen," said Doug Shaw, director of the Maritime Museum, which took ownership of the 40-foot Priscilla in 1976. Federal, corporate and foundation grants and $50,000 raised locally provided the resources to save the boat, which was in desperate need of repair. 
"We spent about 20 years using her," Mr. Shaw said. "We sailed her actively. She went and represented the museum in two Operation Sail regattas in New York City." But an inspection six years ago revealed "that everything from the deck up -- the deck beams, the wheelhouse, everything -- was just rotted beyond any reasonable maintenance effort," Mr. Shaw said. 
Visibly moved as she recalled Priscilla's connection to her family's past, Audrey V. McCoskey, a great-great-granddaughter of George and Priscilla Rhinehart, the boat's original owners, said the restoration and relaunching ceremony brought back a lot of memories for her entire family, all of whom grew up around boats.
"She's beautiful," said Mrs. McCoskey, 71, who traveled from Ocala, Fla., for the ceremony. She said the family only learned of the boat's existence a decade ago but has been closely following its whereabouts and the restoration project ever since. 
Priscilla was built by Elisha Saxton in 1888 for the Rhineharts, who dredged the bay for oysters and scallops. After World War II it was converted into a yacht, rerigged from sloop to schooner and "made very pretty," Mr. Shaw said. Various owners used it recreationally, primarily on the North Shore, until Richard Dowd, the boat's last private owner, donated it to the museum in 1976. 
"The boat itself was beautiful but there was no single part of it that was worth keeping," said Josh Herman, lead builder in the museum's restoration of Priscilla. "The whole thing had to be replaced. Essentially, we replaced everything but the keel." 
Mr. Herman, a shipwright trained in Rockland, Maine, and Ricardo Vicente, another shipwright, worked steadily on the boat since March, with volunteers pitching in more than 150,000 hours of their time. 
Mr. Shaw said that Priscilla won't carry any passengers until it gets Coast Guard certification, which is expected in August, but that its rig will be raised and its seaworthiness tested the third week in July. 
Mr. Herman said, "I'm really looking forward to seeing it sailing and to have a bunch of people being able to see what this Great South Bay used to be full of.
"Oystering was a huge part of the economy on Long Island in the 1800's," he added. "So it's amazing to be able to work on a boat like that, rebuilding history." 
Of the approximately 700 oyster boats in Long Island's sailing oyster fleet in its heyday, four remain, including the 35-foot sloop Modesty, which also part of the Long Island Maritime Museum's 114-boat collection, Mr. Shaw said.
Modesty has national historic landmark status and Mr. Shaw said he was confident that Priscilla's application for such status would be granted when it is reviewed in November. Christeen, a third Long Island oyster boat, sits in the Waterfront Center in Oyster Bay, and Mystic Seaport in Connecticut is home to Nellie, the fourth survivor. 
Mr. Shaw said the sailing oyster boat gave way to motorized vessels in the 1920's and 30's. "The fate for a lot of these boats was to have their sailing rig removed and have a power motor put in them," he said. "But somehow, Priscilla and Modesty avoided that fate."
Mr. Dowd said the museum's decision to save Priscilla was an easy one. "Priscilla is a very important boat," he said. "But there are some old, wooden boats that sadly, you can't save them all. There are some that sort of fall by the wayside. It's just fortunate that this boat happened to come here and we had a board that was dynamic and interested in doing this project and were able to find all the key resource people that we needed." 
David Voehl, a great-great-grandson of the Rhineharts who traveled from Pine Brook, N.J., for the relaunching, has a more personal appreciation. "It's a fantastic thing to realize that part of your ancestry will be around museums for years to come," he said. "It's a continuance of something good."

HEADLINE: FILM; 
The Stars Are Out For Movie Lovers

BYLINE:  By BARBARA DELATINER

 BODY:
ASK Alan Inkles, director of the Stony Brook Film Festival, why film festivals are so popular, and his response is because "festivals are very sexy."
 Festivals, Mr. Inkles said, enable film enthusiasts to see movies before everyone else does. "It's very cool, very sexy to see a film that's not out there yet," he said. 
 Debra Markowitz, director of the Long Island International Film Expo 2003, agrees that festivals offer "independent film aficionados the chance to see films not available anywhere else and right in their own neighborhoods."
She added, "A lot of our filmgoers are there because they know the people who made the films."
Over 16 days, Long Islanders will get to indulge their tastes for what is new in films at both the Expo, which is showing 17 features from Friday through July 17 in Malverne, and at the Stony Brook festival, which is showing 21 entries from July 16 through July 26. Between them, the two events are also showing 57 short films, some as short as three minutes.
Sponsored by the Long Island Film-TV Foundation, the Nassau and Suffolk County Film Commissions and the Nassau County Sports, Entertainment and Tourism Commission, the Expo emphasizes local productions. Ten of its features were filmed on the Island, most by local filmmakers.
These include "The Blue Lizard," a drama from Fred Carpenter of Shirley, to be shown on July 17; "First Person," Richard D'Angelo's look at reality television, scheduled for next Sunday; and "Malevolence," Steven Mena's thriller about a kidnapped child, to be shown on July 14.
"We had about 2,000 entries, and I guess because of the economy, most of them were shot as videos," Ms. Markowitz said.
Nine of the entries are world premieres, including "Dead Canaries," a gangland saga starring Dan Luria, Charles Durning and Dee Wallace Stone, to be shown on Saturday. The opening night film, "The Stand-In," with Kelly Ripa, David Ogden Stiers and Judith Ivey, is a Long Island premiere.
The festival winners will be honored at a gala on Aug. 21.
At Stony Brook, the feature line-up has three world premieres, including the one film shot locally, "Shelter Island," a thriller with Ally Sheedy and Stephen Baldwin, to be shown on July 18.
Eighteen entries are making their New York or regional debuts. These include "Resistance," a World War II drama with Bill Paxton and Julia Ormond, that will open the festival on July 16, and the closing film, "The Secret Lives of Dentists," Alan Rudolph's comedy about marriage with Campbell Scott, Hope Davis and Denis Leary, to be shown on July 26.
"Many of our films already have distributors and will have theatrical release later in the summer or in the fall," Mr. Inkles said.
Also to be shown is "September 11," a collection of 11 short films from international directors made in response to the terrorist attacks, which will be shown on July 20.
The 12 features in competition include the world premiere of "Dog Gone Love," a romantic comedy with Alexander Chaplin, Richard Kind and Lindsay Sloane, to be shown on July 17, and "American Gun," a drama that was James Coburn's final film, to be shown on July 23.
The Long Island International Film Expo 2003 is at Malverne Cinema 4 on Hempstead Avenue. Information: (516)571-3168. The Stony Brook Film Festival is at Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York. Information: (631)632-2787.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hope Davis and Campbell Scott, left, in a scene from "The Secret Lives of Dentists," and Stephen Baldwin and Ally Sheedy, above left, in a scene from "Shelter Island." Both films will be shown at the Stony Brook Film Festival. At the Long Island Film Expo, Keith Chambers and Heather Magee can be seen in "Malevolence."

HEADLINE: Holdouts in Suburbia 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
LOOKING east from the Rottkamp Brothers Farm, fields of growing vegetables stretch as far as the eye can see, with rows of cornstalks disappearing into the horizon.
 The view to the north, though, is quite different. 
 There, a massive brick mansion, built a few years ago, looms over a neatly manicured berm that rises next to the dirt road alongside the 50-acre farm. So while the eastern vista could just as easily be in rural Iowa, the scene to the north is unmistakably suburban Nassau County and more precisely, Old Brookville.
The Rottkamp brothers, Ray and Richard, are fourth-generation farmers. They were just children when the family moved the farm from Elmont to Old Brookville in 1953. "When we came out here, it was country yet," said Ray Rottkamp, now 56. 
But over the years, other farmers have sold their land to developers and moved east into Suffolk County or gone out of business altogether, making the Rottkamp farm one of a handful of survivors in Nassau County. In fact, county officials say there are only four others, all smaller than the Rottkamps' farm.
The Rottkamps say they are constantly approached by developers seeking to buy their land. "We're not interested," Ray Rottkamp said. "We've been here too long, and we're going to stay as long as we can." But he acknowledged that he and his brother were likely the last farmers in their family: they each have two daughters who have shown no interest in going into the family business. 
It is precisely the fear that the Rottkamps' farm could be gobbled up by developers -- that McMansions would sprout in place of tomatoes and corn -- that prompted Nassau officials to start looking for ways to help preserve the county's farmland.
Wherever Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, talks about his vision for economic development, he talks about the need to preserve farms as a way of keeping open space in the county.
He reminds people that not too long ago, Nassau County was almost entirely farmland. Until the 1930's, it provided most of New York City's food. In 1945, he notes, Nassau had 14,000 acres of farmland; now there are less than 140. In 2001, Nassau's farms produced only $3.3 million in cash receipts, compared with $169 million in Suffolk, according to state figures.
"The marketplace, left to its owndevices, would have no farms in Nassau County because the land values are so high," Mr. Suozzi said. "But we don't want to be known just as the land of strip malls and Joey Buttafuoco." 
The county created an open-space fund last spring that will receive 5 percent of the proceeds of any county land sold, which Mr. Suozzi anticipates could bring in $5 million to the fund in the next few years. But with land in Old Brookville running as high as $1 million an acre, the fund clearly would not go very far toward buying development rights for existing farms.
So Mr. Suozzi has his planning department looking for federal and state grants. Given the county's precarious fiscal condition, it has no money to spare to further Mr. Suozzi's goal. "So we have to be creative," he said. "But at least we've put the issue on the radar screen."
The owners of the five farms identified by county officials each said they welcomed Mr. Suozzi's interest. Richard Rottkamp, 54, said that no one from the county government had ever before talked about trying to preserve farmland in Nassau County. "It's something to think about, sure," he said. "But we're really kind of isolated here, and realistically, who's going to want to buy it and take it over?"
Certainly, the Rottkamps and the other Nassau County farmers lead a way of life completely foreign to most of their neighbors, and farmers who are looking for land are not likely to consider Nassau and its suburban sprawl as a likely place to put down roots. But for the foreseeable future, Nassau's farmers said they were committed to staying where they are. Being the county's last farmers seemed a point of pride.
To survive, each of the farms has evolved over time and developed its own unique operation. The Rottkamps' vegetable farm is the largest and the only one that runs a farm stand and also trucks produce to the Hunts Point market in the Bronx.
Three much smaller farms sell all their produce at their own farm stands. Youngs Farm in Old Brookville is well known for its greenhouse tomatoes and its bakery. Grossmann's Farm in Malverne has a thriving greenhouse operation that sells garden plants in the spring and a country store that sells everything from scented candles and teddy bears to old-fashioned stick candy. Meyer's Farm sells all of the produce it grows in Woodbury at its farm stand there, supplementing the offerings with vegetables the family grows on another farm in Suffolk County. And the last farm is a vineyard operation, Banfi Vintners in Old Brookville with 47 acres of grapes. Banfi, which also owns Castello Banfi in Tuscany, produces Nassau County's only wine, Old Brookville Gold Coast Reserve Chardonnay.
While other farmers have sold their land and moved east, the Grossmann family never considered it, even though land in Malverne is going for as much as $500,000 an acre. "This is what we had, and this is what we did," said Liz Grossmann Rung, a fourth-generation Grossmann who works on the seven-acre farm, purchased by the family in 1895.
The family used to rent 25 more acres nearby until it was turned into a subdivision with 43 homes in the 1920's, shortly after the Southern State Parkway was built. After that, the Grossmanns decided to farm only their own land and to go into the retail business exclusively. 
"We're in a good spot for that," said George Grossmann, Ms. Rung's father. "We're where the people are, and we have our own niche." Mr. Grossmann turned 80 last month, but he still works on the farm, which he owns jointly with his 89-year-old sister, Barbara.
The Meyers are equally possessive about their 10-acre farm in Woodbury, which the family bought in the 1920's. It opened its farm stand in the 1950's, supplying it from the Woodbury operation and from 100 acres the family farms in Calverton. "But our primary location has always been Woodbury," said Stephen Meyer, who is 25 and is the youngest of three brothers in the fourth generation of Meyerses working on the farm. "The market's better because we're the only ones left her." 
Ms. Rung, 40, runs the Grossmann's greenhouse operation, and she says she doesn't have farm expertise. "Whether I could pick it up, it's not something I want to think about," she said, getting teary-eyed at the thought that one day her father will not be around to run the farm.
But she seems determined to keep the farm going. "We're surrounded by residential homes and two major roads, and it's not your normal farm picture," she said. "But it's important for school kids to see this. They think that chicken comes wrapped in cellophane and carrots come in plastic bags, but here they can see the real thing."
But while being in the heart of a heavily populated area is a boon to Nassau County farmers when it comes time to sell their produce, it can be a curse at other times. Instead of having neighbors who are fellow farmers and who are familiar with farming practices, they are surrounded by suburban homeowners who may be less understanding about the noise irrigation motors make at all hours or about the dust kicked up when the soil is plowed.
Bob Whiting, the estate and vineyard manager at Banfi, said neighbors have complained about noise from their pesticide sprayer and also about the imposing warning signs they are required by law to post around the vineyard when the grapevines are sprayed. "We try to abide by noise ordinances, and the signs are there for their own safety," he said. "But some people don't like the signs because they look at the vineyard like their personal park, and they don't like being told they can't use it." Mr. Whiting once had to call the police to stop one of the neighborhood boys from riding his dirt bike through the vineyard.
Along with the occasional clashes with the neighbors, the farmers said that being in Nassau County can also be a liability because they are so isolated from other farmers. In fact, there is so little sense of a farming community that each of the farmers was hard-pressed to name the other Nassau County holdouts. 
Mr. Whiting said being the only vineyard in Nassau County often makes Banfi "feel like an outpost in the middle of nowhere." 
Jo-Hana Youngs Gooth, who runs Youngs Farm with Paula Youngs Weir, her sister, said that they feel their isolation the most whenever one of their tractors breaks down and they have to have it towed out to Riverhead for repairs. "It's not like you can just run down to the corner and get a spare part," Ms. Gooth said. .
Ms. Gooth, 54, and her sister, 52, have built the farm stand, known as the Annex, into a local institution famous for its pies and pastries. The bakery, in an old potato barn, turns out 100 to 200 pies a day at the height of the summer season. "We're still here doing the vegetable part of the business because of the baking part," Ms. Gooth said. 
The sisters' main concern now is what will happen when their 82-year-old mother, Vivian Youngs, dies, and they inherit the 15-acre farm. Ms. Gooth said that until 1979, when their grandfather died, the family farmed 90 acres, but their father sold off 75 acres to help pay the inheritance tax. 
The land her father sold stayed in agriculture because it went to Banfi Vintners. "It was the only good thing about having to sell," Ms. Gooth said.
Families who live near the farms sing their praises and say they have been good neighbors and pillars of the community. Lucille Fletcher has lived in a house adjoining the Rottkamp farm for the last 15 years. "Their farm is the reason I bought this house," she said.
To be sure, there were certain things Ms. Fletcher's suburban family had to get used to. There were the crow guns, machines that emit intermittent loud bangs to frighten away birds that might devour the Rottkamps' crops. And then there are the flies, which seem to come every August as the crops ripen, and the heavy manure smell, which fills the air when the Rottkamps fertilize. 
"But these are all things we put up with because it's so beautiful to be able to look over my fence onto their fields," Ms. Fletcher said. "It's priceless."
Polly Kahn, who lives in Old Brookville near the Banfi vineyards and Youngs Farm, said she, too, enjoyed the simple beauty of the farmland. "It's a great pleasure to be near them," she said. "Heaven knows if they ever sell that property, there would be a hundred houses there, and that would be awful."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
An Antagonist's View of Dean Skelos

BYLINE:  By HELENA WILLIAMS; Helena Williams, a resident of Garden City, is a deputy county executive of Nassau County.

 BODY:
AN Antagonist's View of Tom Suozzi" was an apt headline for State Senator Dean G. Skelos' essay opinion, June 29 . Senator Skelos's personal attack on the county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, was unwarranted and untrue. 
 Terming Nassau's fiscal problems "primarily self-inflicted," Mr. Skelos's view grossly distorts history. Nassau's financial troubles stem from two sources: decades of mismanagement by the Nassau County Republican administration and the untenable burden of state-mandated expenses. As a longtime Republican leader and a state legislator, it's no wonder Mr. Skelos would seek to deflect criticism. 
 The taxpayers of Nassau County elected Mr. Suozzi to fix the mess after decades of Republican failure. In just 18 months, our administration has balanced the budget and eliminated more than 1,000 county jobs, cutting the work force bymore than 12 percent. We have canceled expensive politically connected contracts, cleaned up scandal-ridden departments and rooted out waste, fraud and abuse. "Smart government" initiatives have saved nearly $100 million in taxpayer money. For the first time in more than a decade, Nassau County's credit rating was upgraded by Standard & Poor's, Fitch, and Moody's Investors Service.
As part of our approved four-year financial recovery plan, we needed the help of New York State to save $25 million per year.
In April 2002, we submitted to Albany legislation to create a sewer and storm water authority that would consolidate the current hodgepodge of 27 sewage-collection districts and 3 sewage-disposal districts. Reorganizing the county's sewer and storm-water operations into a single authority would allow it to refinance debt at interest rates that are much lower than those available to the smaller, scattered districts. Employees performing storm water-related functions would be transferred to the new authority, relieving the county's General Fund budget of their recurring salary expenses. Our proposal guaranteed no increase in sewer taxes for four years. This is a win-win for county government and county taxpayers.
This proposal received the unanimous support of NIFA, the state's fiscal watchdog, which includes appointees of the state's top two Republicans, Governor Pataki and the State Senate leader, Joseph Bruno. The proposal received the endorsement of the three major Wall Street rating agencies, the county and state Civil Service Employees Association, Newsday's editorial board, News 12's editorial department and almost every Long Island business organization, including the Long Island Association and the Association for a Better Long Island. The League of Conservation Voters hailed the plan as "a model" for storm-water management and financing. 
While the proposal did not pass by the close of the 2002 legislative session, Mr. Skelos said, "In the weeks and months ahead, we will continue working with Mr. Suozzi and NIFA to refine the county executive's sewer and storm water authority proposal."
Following the end of the 2002 session, our staff worked extensively with Mr. Skelos's office and Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli to achieve the results needed -- a stronger bill, with considerable protections for the county's taxpayers and the environment.
It is clearly a myth to assert that neither the Senate nor the public had any involvement in the legislation, as it was refined over the 15 months from our original proposal. There was painstaking work done on our proposed bill for many months. These efforts included over a dozen meetings in Albany with Senate and/or Assembly staff, easily 100 telephone calls and more than 30 e-mails. The proposal has been covered extensively by the news media, and Mr. Suozzi personally briefed participants at more than 15 economic development meetings all across Nassau County.
In fact, Mr. Skelos's chief of staff led a delegation of more than 30 government officials from the Senate, Assembly and the governor's office to Nassau County on Oct. 17, 2002, to join Nassau County and NIFA staff in analyzing our proposed legislation. The senator's office used outside counsel and an outside engineering company to review the complexities of the bill. 
After more than a year of work, the bill passed the Democratic-controlled State Assembly last month but failed in the Republican-controlled State Senate.
The truth be known, there was no governmental reason left to oppose the bill. The failure of the State Senate to pass this legislation was, in fact, a politically motivated rejection of our sound and well-considered proposal, denying the residents of Nassau County much-needed recurring fiscal relief. We urge the Senate delegation to reconsider their position.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A Leader Who Showed the Way for Generations of Artists

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

DATELINE: Newark 

 BODY:
DOES Spike Lee owe his success, in part, to Gordon Parks?
 You'd have to ask Mr. Lee, I guess, although Mr. Parks's early success as a photographer and filmmaker was an important source of inspiration for a generation of aspiring black artists, in the way that Sidney Poitier became a role model for a generation of black actors. Mr. Parks was the Jackie Robinson of the art world, you could say. 
 Mr. Parks, 90, is the subject of a touring retrospective at the Newark Museum. It is a huge show, with nearly 200 photographs spanning his 60-year career. Significant works from Mr. Parks's major series of photographs are here, including his gritty 1940's work for the Farm Services Administration, important assignments as a staff photographer for Life, and more recent forays into color fashion photography. 
 Mr. Parks was very good at what he did, which can best be described as photojournalism. But claims that his photographs should be regarded as fine art are misguided.
 The message of his retrospective is that while competent, technically, Mr. Parks's photographs have little consistent personality or style of their own. He was a camera for hire, shooting subjects rapidly and emotively, to meet a pressing deadline. Thinking of these images as art would be a bit like mistaking daily newspaper journalism for literature.
 Mr. Parks's best photographs are his early individual and group portraits, particularly those that document black America. "Children With Doll" (1942) shows two poor black children, oblivious to the racially divided world in which they are growing up, playing on the dirty floor of a tenement with a brown-haired, white-skinned wooden doll. Taken years before such images became trite, and commonplace, the picture stands as a powerful metaphor for the nastiness of segregation. It also suggests that, in the innocence of childhood, humans are colorblind. 
 Other early portraits worth looking out for are "Ella Watson and Her Grandchildren" (1942) and "New England Family" (1943). Both are carefully staged group ensembles, and remarkable for their compositional sophistication.
 The doorframe running down the center of "Ella Watson and Her Grandchildren" splits the image in two, contrasting the older woman and her grandchildren with a mirror image of her daughter, the mother of the children, pictured next to a photograph of her grandparents. It's all about the bonds of family and the passage of time, and the way love freshens up even the most impoverished of homes. 
 The rest of Mr. Parks's prolific output shows a high incidence of failure. When a work succeeds, however, it stands out a mile.
 For instance, "Red Jackson and Herbie Levy Study Wounds on Face of Slain Gang Member Maurice Gaines," part of a 1948 series on Harlem gangs for Life, is captivating. Stripped of their bravado, the two young men stare with a startled expression at their friend in a coffin, his face tanned and greasy from the cosmetic paint used to hide his wounds. They cannot hide their horror.
 Perhaps the best portrait in the show is "Gambling Woman" (1949). Partly what's special about this tough image is that it is not derivative, like many of Mr. Parks's photographs, and partly that, with a startling economy of means, it tells us so much about its subject. The elegant simplicity of the woman's pendant suggests taste but not wealth, while the absence of rings and low, strapless dress point to her being a courtesan. But most telling is her face; hardened from years of disappointment as she stares absently at the roulette wheel. It's her last hope.
 "Gambling Woman" stands alone as a complete and coherent image, telling us all we need to know about this woman at a gambling table. Her name is irrelevant, as is the place, for we recognize immediately who and what she is. This is precisely what's missing from so many of Mr. Parks's journalistic photographs, which often seem reliant on a text caption to tell you what's going on. Perhaps this is a legacy of his years at Life, where his images were usually published as photo essays accompanied by captions. 
 Aside from photographs, the exhibition contains cabinets filled with copies of his novels, image books and musical compositions, as well as an autobiographical film downstairs.
 Craig Rice's biographical film, "Half Past Autumn: The Life and Works of Gordon Parks," will be shown at the museum on Wednesday as part of the 29th Annual Newark Black Film Festival. With its message of hope in the face of adversity, it is sure to give courage to a new generation of African-American artists and filmmakers. Whatever we might think about Mr. Parks's photographs, his example and influence live on.
 "Half Past Autumn: The Art of Gordon Parks" is at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, through Aug. 31. Information: (973)596-6550 or www.newarkmuseum.org.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gordon Parks's photographs are on display at the Newark Museum. Included in the show are "Gambling Woman," left, "New England Family," above, and "American Gothic."
