HEADLINE: Shinnecocks Defy the State Over Casino 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON 

 BODY:
A TEMPORARY restraining order signed by a judge last Sunday at Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's request failed to deter the Shinnecock Indian Nation from breaking ground on Monday morning for a casino in Hampton Bays. In an ebullient ceremony attended by about 250 tribe members, their leaders said repeatedly that they would not be turned from their chosen path to economic self-sufficiency.
 The Shinnecocks gathered in a clearing in the woods near where they plan to build a 65,000-square-foot casino, which will also include a bingo hall. They prayed, sang, drummed, applauded and shouted until the sounds of their defiance echoed off the trees. 
 "Our documentation is ready!" shouted Lance A. Gumbs, one of three elected tribal trustees, waving legal papers. "Our history stands for itself, and we will take this to the next level." The audience cheered as Mr. Gumbs explained that the papers, filed on Tuesday, seek to move the attorney general's case from State Supreme Court to federal court. 
Many tribes, including the Mashantucket Pequots in Connecticut, the owners of Foxwoods casino, sued in federal court to win federal recognition and later, for the right to operate a casino. 
Denis J. McElligott, the assistant state attorney general in charge of the Suffolk County office, said that Mr. Spitzer was acting on affidavits from the State Department of Environmental Conservation and the state Racing and Wagering Board, which contend that the Shinnecocks lack authority to open a casino. 
Since reports began circulating last winter that the 1,500-member Shinnecock tribe was planning a casino, state officials, including members of the governor's staff, have repeatedly said that an Indian nation could not open a casino unless it was federally recognized as a tribe and won legislative approval for what is known as a gaming compact, which would have to be negotiated with the governor. A bingo hall would not need a compact but would require a state permit, Mr. McElligott said.
The Shinnecocks, who own an 800-acre reservation surrounded by the Town of Southampton, are recognized as a tribe by the state, but their application for federal recognition is pending. Still, they claim the right as a sovereign nation to do what they please with their land.
At Mr. Spitzer's request, Edward D. Burke Jr., an acting Supreme Court justice who lives in Southampton, signed the temporary restraining order on Sunday. That afternoon, Mr. McElligott went to the Shinnecock reservation to serve the papers himself.
The order prohibits "any steps whatsoever to build and/or construct any structure intended to be used as a gaming facility" on tribal lands, including the 79-acre Hampton Bays parcel known as Westwoods, until the case is heard in State Supreme Court in Riverhead. On Wednesday, Justice James Catterson said that state courts had no jurisdiction in the case until a federal judge rules on the Shinnecocks' petition to move the case to federal court. 
The restraining order also bans the Shinnecocks from advertising or buying equipment for their casino and bingo hall. Mr. McElligott said on Wednesday that his office would decide later whether to file a motion asking a judge to hold the Shinnecocks in contempt since they went ahead and held groundbreaking ceremonies on Monday. 
Neighbors and town, state and federal officials have been outspoken in opposition to the casino, which would be in a residential neighborhood. They contend that it would create traffic problems. 
Shinnecock leaders confirmed last month that they intended to build a casino and began running newspaper and radio ads explaining their side of the issue: that a casino would make the tribe self-sufficient and would bring jobs and revenue to the surrounding area. 
 On Monday, just a handful of neighbors watched from Newtown Road as members of the tribe arrived for the ceremony.
A drawing of the casino showed a one- and two-story log building with a gabled roof. It resembles the tribe's museum and cultural center, a smaller 5,000-square-foot building on Montauk Highway. A floor plan showed a section for bingo, but most of the ground floor would be devoted to slot machines and gaming tables. 
Tribe members said the casino, parking lots and driveways would cover some 15 acres south of Newtown Road. A proposed access road from Sunrise Highway would require state approval.
In his speech, Charles K. Smith II, the chairman of the tribe's trustees, said gambling profits would be channeled into education, jobs, medical care, better housing and other services now lacking on the reservation. He did not provide any projected income figures. 
"We need to do what we have to do for self-reliance," he said, adding that since the tribe had no other significant source of revenue, "the burden is getting harder and harder on each and every one of us."
Seated in the audience, Mr. Gumbs's 82-year-old mother, Harriet, a tribal historian, said the tribe's newfound assertiveness was long overdue.
"They have a nerve," she said of the public officials who oppose the casino. "We gave them the town to begin with, and they have been taking and taking and taking until we have just our reservation and our little woods." 
"But we no longer feel we have to be the last people on the totem pole," she continued. "We are embarking on one of the greatest things our nation has ever tried to do: we're creating our own self-reliance."
On Monday, as a bulldozer backed into the woods from Newtown Road, the Rev. Holly Haile Davis, a member of the tribe, exclaimed: "Yes! We have turned a page in history. Today's the day! Today's the day!"
With the bulldozer parked in the woods, Mr. Gumbs, Mr. Smith and the third trustee, James W. Eleazar, each drove a shovel into the ground. "Applaud yourselves for the hard work you have done, for the hard work you are about to do," Mr. Smith told the crowd.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lance A. Gumbs, one of three elected Shinnecock trustees, after groundbreaking, despite a state injunction, for a new casino, as seen in an artist's rendering. (Photographs by Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Wary After a Slump, Hotels Keep Prices Down

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
THIS summer is shaping up as a time for hotel bargains around the country.
 With the war in Iraq over, the threat of SARS fading and tentative signs of economic revival, travel industry experts say they expect hotels in the United States to begin recovering from one of their worst slumps in decades. 
 But, they say the hotels are so shell shocked after two years of dispiriting occupancy rates hovering at about 60 percent, that they will probably not try to increase their rates anytime soon.
 With discounting widespread, said Bjorn Hanson, a consultant on the hotel business at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the safe business approach is to keep on discounting. "The fear is that should an individual hotel not offer discounts, the hotel next door will continue to discount, and all the business will go there," he said. 
 Moreover, he said, the industry worries that the market is so fragile that if discounts were abandoned, Americans would simply stay home. 
 By late June, hotel prices around the country were averaging $82.22 a night, according to Smith Travel Research, down from an industry peak of $89.43 in late October 2000, but not as low as in the months immediately following the Sept. 11 attacks, when prices dipped into the high $70's.
 In Boston, the average daily cost of a room was $120.27, down 6.2 percent from a year earlier. In San Francisco prices were down 12.3 percent to $123.83 and in Miami the daily rate was $82.73, nearly 4 percent cheaper than a year ago. In New York, prices were down 4.6 percent to $162.65.
 According to the latest data from the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Bureau, rooms in Las Vegas were going for an average of $83.42 in April, down less than 1 percent from a year earlier. John Piet, the bureau's senior researcher, said some hotels were offering rooms for as low as $29 to attract players to their casinos and shows.
 "There are some great deals out there, especially for leisure travelers," said Adam Weissenberg, a partner at Deloitte & Touche, who specializes in the hotel and restaurant businesses.
 The low prices might suggest to the really frugal that if they could figure out where the hotel business has been worst, they could get the best of all possible prices. But Mr. Hanson said that such a strategy probably would not work. 
 Yield management, the use of computers to vary prices to fill the most rooms, has become so fine-tuned, Mr. Hanson said, that on some days, rooms in cities with relatively high occupancy rates may be selling for less than those where business has been miserable. "Rates are all over the place," he said.
 In those circumstances, people who are willing to make a few phone calls will get the best deals.
 The price one ultimately pays, Mr. Hanson said, can be significantly lower than run-of-the-mill bargains. But true bargains can take a lot of work.
 First, Mr. Hanson says, scan some Web sites for hotel bookings like Hotels.com, Hotwire.com, Priceline.com and Travelocity.com, to get a feel for prices. Then, pick a hotel and a price and phone the hotel. "Say, 'It's a little more than I wanted to spend, can you do something for me?"' Mr. Hanson said. "And about a third of the time the answer will be yes."
 To drive the price down even further, Mr. Hanson said, repeat the process every three or four days with the same hotel. "If you find a lower rate and the hotel accepts it, you cancel the original reservation and make a new one." he said. Hotels didn't usually object to a switch for a lower price, he said, because they don't want to lose the business.
 But, though the price may be right for a hotel room this summer, in many cases, the frill is gone. 
 Striving to bolster their bottom lines, travel analysts said, many hotels have been cutting amenities. The coolest, most extreme services are the first to go: dog-walking concierges, for example. Twenty-four-hour room service has become daytime room service or, in some cases, limited menu offerings during late-night hours, said Robert Mandelbaum, the director of research for the hospitality group of PFK Consulting in Atlanta. 
 Some hotels are charging for services that once were free, like newspaper deliveries and use of the gym.
 But mindful of the customer alienation that airlines have suffered, hotels are striving to maintain their tone, Mr. Weissenberg said. Still, he added: "You may have to wait a ring or two for someone to answer the phone at the front desk."
 For hotel owners, the picture has been grim. In 2000, the industry's last good year, average annual revenue per room rose 7.7 percent to $41,335, according to PFK Consulting, and profits before taxes rose 10.1 percent. The next year revenue dropped 9.9 percent and pretax profits fell 19.4 percent. In 2002 revenue fell another 4 percent and pretax profits fell 9.6 percent, PFK Consulting said. 
 PFK is predicting an industry profit this year, but mainly as a result of cuts in expenses. "We think room rates are not going to grow substantially in 2003 and 2004," Mr. Mandelbaum said. "It may not be until 2005 that we see a recovery in rates."
 And that assumes that nothing really bad happens to drive Americans back into the comfort of their homes.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
The online journals known as Web logs are finding favor as an efficient way to communicate within the workplace.

BYLINE:  By William O'Shea 

 BODY:
For Nicholas Tang, the deluge of work-related e-mail messages became overwhelming. "It got to the point where I was getting hundreds of e-mails a day, sometimes more than a thousand," said Mr. Tang, director of operations at Community Connect, a company in New York that operates AsianAvenue.com and other online communities with an ethnic focus. 
 For several years Mr. Tang viewed this daily surge of e-mail messages as an unpleasant but necessary part of his job managing a team of eight engineers. Then, a few months ago, he began using an alternative to e-mail, a Web log. 
 Web logs, or blogs as they are known, are a type of frequently updated online journal, often featuring excerpts from news articles and links to other blogs. So far, Web logs are best known as a medium for communicating with the general public -- like the blog by the noted journalist Andrew Sullivan (www.andrewsullivan.com), which is devoted to culture and politics, and sites like the Veg Blog (www.vegblog.org), which is about all things vegetarian. In the corporate context, some chief executives, for better or worse, have adopted blogs as a way to share their personal wisdom with the wider world.
But a growing number of businesses, government organizations and educational institutions are using Web logs to manage and improve the flow of information among employees. These blogs, not accessible to the public, typically allow many people to contribute entries that can be read by others in the organization.
It may be too soon to tell whether the corporate blog will emerge as a genuinely useful tool for business communications or simply another way for bores and blowhards to blather. But a growing circle of adopters, like Mr. Tang, swear by their blogs.
At Community Connect, Mr. Tang's engineers use a service called LiveJournal to post updates about tasks like fixing server computers or configuring software. Hitting the upload button sends the text to a private site, viewable by the authors and their managers, including the date and time of the postings and, often, links to relevant Web pages. 
"When I want to know something I check the Web log," Mr. Tang said. "It saves me the trouble of e-mailing people or yelling across the room to get a status update." 
Mr. Tang has also used blogs to coordinate group projects, like the recent process of interviewing job candidates for a programming position. The various people at the company who spoke to each candidate posted their comments on a password-protected Web log. 
"One person wrote that a candidate was 'quiet,' " Mr. Tang recalled. "There was a whole discussion about this. 'What does that mean? Is it a bad thing? Does it mean he's antisocial?' There was more back and forth with the interview process. It helped everyone to get on the same page more quickly." 
Because of their informal nature, blogs can lead to digressions. Shirley Palma, a Community Connect systems administrator, said that after meeting one job candidate, a woman posted this message on the interview blog: "I think he's so cute! I want to take him home!" 
Ms. Palma noted that "it was in a motherly way; she didn't mean anything by it." But the remark prompted a male colleague to blog back, "I think if I said that it would be considered sexual harassment." 
The cute candidate ended up getting the job, having been praised by others on the blog for being easygoing and an apparently fast learner. "We interviewed lots of candidates," Ms. Palma explained. "Can you imagine remembering 10 people after the fact? The blog helped keep track of everyone." 
Google, the provider of Internet search services, has become a big user of blogs for communication among its employees and managers -- a result of the company's acquisition of Pyra Labs, the creator of the Blogger Web log service, earlier this year. On one internal blog, called Google Love Notes, the customer service staff posts thank-you notes from users. One is from a woman who nursed her sick dog back to health after researching the illness on Google; the posting includes a photograph of the healed dog frolicking in a stream. Another came from a woman who was able to find a long-lost love through Google -- and who happily reports that she wound up agreeing to marry the man's brother. 
"It's a good pick-me-up," Jason Shellen, a Blogger manager at Google, said of Love Notes. 
Less relevant to the corporate mission was a posting on a blog operated by Notiva, a Silicon Valley software company, by a staff software designer who posted photographs from his vacation to France. Another employee posted the official rules for foosball. 
But Tim Dawson, Notiva's director of system architecture, says he does not mind if people have fun with the blogs, because he sees how valuable the medium can be for sharing information about software bugs and fixes. "We went from 11 people to 50, and that all happened in the space of 15 months," Mr. Dawson said. With the blogs, he said, new employees "can come in and see what's out there."
The telephone and wireless giant Verizon Communications uses a Web log to collect news and intelligence about the industry and competitors. "We used to spend lots of time e-mailing articles around but not keeping track of them," said Sean Byrnes, the lead architect on Verizon's project for Wi-Fi wireless Internet access. His group now consolidates such information in a series of topic-specific blogs.
But opening a pipeline to comments from employees can produce a torrent of information, essentially defeating the purpose of the tool. "You reach information glut very quickly," Mr. Byrnes said. 
And the free flow of information does not necessarily promote communication, says David Jarvis, an analyst at the Naval Undersea Warfare Center in Newport, R.I. The center is running an experimental program using Web logs to explore how naval technologies can be applied to homeland defense. The blogs are meant to disseminate news, project updates and new ideas. 
"People are going to the blogs every day as a source for news," Mr. Jarvis said. But, he added, "I am disappointed in the tool," because the hoped-for exchange of ideas among departments has not spontaneously developed. "You need specific goals," Mr. Jarvis said. 
Typically, though, such experiments are not expensive to mount. LiveJournal's blogging service costs companies $25 a year. Corporate editions of Manila, a Web log program produced by Userland Software, costs $899 a server computer, but one server can accommodate hundreds of people. TeamPage, a corporate Web log program offered by Traction Software, begins at $10,000 a server, but small-group versions cost much less. 
As business interest in Web logs grows, more companies are moving into the market -- or expanding into it, in the case of software developers that had focused on personal Web log tools but are now aiming at teams and organizations. One such company, Six Apart, plans to begin selling its corporate product in the next few weeks. And 20six, a British company, plans to introduce blog software for teams in the fall. 
Time will reveal how many Web log software companies the market can support. But corporate blog enthusiasts like Mr. Tang, of Community Connect, are convinced that the medium is here to stay. 
"People are starting to use Web logs to archive data that would have otherwise been lost," Mr. Tang said. He noted that much of the company's internal communications had been via instant messaging -- and was lost as soon as the correspondents closed their chat windows. Now, though, employees are starting to post transcripts of relevant discussions on the Web logs, he said. 
"It's not just making life more convenient," Mr. Tang said, "but actually giving us something new we didn't have before."

HEADLINE: Capturing the Cultural Revolution 

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 6 

 BODY:
It was Li Zhensheng's job in the late 1960's to photograph the happy face of Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution for a provincial Chinese daily newspaper. But as he dutifully fed the propaganda machine with uplifting images, he gradually understood that he was also recording history, and so he took a major risk: on his assignments, he began including disturbing aspects of the revolution and then hid the negatives under the floorboards of his home.
 Now, more than three decades after the Cultural Revolution began, Mr. Li is for the first time making public his remarkable visual testimony of that violent and chaotic era. A selection of 152 images are on display at the Patrimoine Photographique here through Sept. 21. Mr. Li has also published a book, which includes 285 pictures and a memoir of his life until 1976, when the decade-long revolution ended. The book, "Red-Color News Soldier" (Phaidon), is to be published in the United States in September. 
 Although other pictures of Red Guard abuses in Beijing have documented the social upheaval accompanying the Cultural Revolution, what distinguishes Mr. Li's collection of 30,000 negatives is that it shows in shocking detail what was happening at a grass-roots level in a remote Chinese province far from Western eyes. His work also reflects the instincts of a journalist and the eye of an artist. 
In the exhibition and the book, he brings to life the fanatical joy of rampaging Red Guards, many of them teenagers, and the coldblooded humiliation and even execution of "enemies of the people." Only once, during a 1966 visit to Beijing, did Mr. Li photograph Mao himself, but Mao is ever present in photographs, in statues, in the little red book of his sayings and in spirit.
Today Mr. Li looks back and sees a different China. The excesses and leaders of the revolution were denounced after Mao's death in 1976. Communist capitalism is now entrenched. Mr. Li, 63, lives in New York and Beijing. He is confident that his book will soon also be published in China. 
But in his book and in a recent conversation through an interpreter, it was apparent that Mr. Li had not forgotten the past. As a teenager he showed a talent for painting, but he chose to become a cinematographer. When his film school was closed in 1963 he was assigned as a photographer on The Heilongjiang Daily in the northern city of Harbin. After his first day's work, he wrote in his diary: "I am not going to die in Heilongjiang Province."
With China still in turmoil after the catastrophic Great Leap Forward economic program that began in 1958, its government was trying to reawaken revolutionary fervor. Soon Mr. Li was required to join the Socialist Education Movement, which sent urban youths to the countryside -- in his case to Acheng County, 30 miles southeast of Harbin -- to experience peasant life. There he trained with a local militia, farmed and took part in self-criticism sessions.
But he also took pictures. They show the expected images -- peasants working and holding endless sessions studying Mao's teachings -- but also more arresting ones of gatherings in which "antisocial" peasants were publicly denounced for cheating and forced to stand for hours with their heads bowed in the kowtow position to beg forgiveness. Even these early images reveal Mr. Li's sense of composition, his understanding of lighting and his ability to convey emotion.
Then, with Mr. Li back at his newspaper, history suddenly accelerated with Mao's proclamation of the Cultural Revolution in May 1966. "I was excited like everyone else," Mr. Li said. "The happiness was real. We felt lucky to be living the moment. Mao had said it should be repeated every seven years and we thought we'd be lucky enough to live several cultural revolutions. We all believed in Mao."
Just as political leaders in Heilongjiang Province were soon overthrown by Red Guards, Mr. Li's editors were ousted. "I noticed that people wearing a Red Guard armband could take photographs freely," he writes. Inside the newspaper, he promptly formed a self-appointed Red Guard unit called the Red Youth Fighting Team and acquired an armband. "After that, whenever I wore it I could take all the photographs I wanted and no one bothered me," he notes in his book.
Yet within weeks, he recalled, he grew alarmed over Red Guard excesses, which he witnessed and photographed: the ransacking a Russian Orthodox Church and a Buddhist temple, raids on private homes, ceremonial book burnings and attacks on individuals. "As a young man with a good education, I did not think this was normal," he said. "So while we photographed the joy, violent and cruel scenes were more and more evident."
His newspaper published only positive images of the Cultural Revolution, but Mr. Li photographed everything. "I had had a teacher, a famous photographer, Wu Yingxian, who said we were not only witnesses of history but also recorders of history," Mr. Li said. "I felt the positive images were only part of history, so I also photographed the negative scenes so that one day there would be a complete history."
So, while showing cheerful youths waving flags and holding little red books, Mr. Li captured moments when ousted senior officials were being abused and humiliated in front of crowds, their heads shaven, ink or paint splashed on their faces, insulting signs hung around their necks and cloths stuffed into their mouths. Some were forced to wear paper dunce caps covered with slogans.
In 1968 Mr. Li began hiding negatives of such scenes in his modest home. Their images included an execution of six ordinary criminals and two dissidents. "On the barren ground of the Huang Shan Cemetery, they were lined up, hands tied behind their backs, and forced to kneel," he writes. "They were all shot in the back of the head." Mr. Li, who documented each step, adds: "No one asked me take close-ups of the bodies, but that's what I did."
By then, the situation in Harbin was still more confused as different bands of Red Guards fought for power in Mao's name. At The Heilongjiang Daily late in 1968, Mr. Li was accused of various crimes, including being a "newly born bourgeois." First he was demoted, and then, in September 1969, he and his wife, Zu Yingxia, were sent to the Liuhe May 7 School in the countryside for "rectification."
"Things there were more and more foolish," he said. "Everyone was cold and someone would shout, 'Anyone cold?' And we replied, 'No, because we have a red sun in our hearts that is very warm.' 'Is the work difficult?' someone else would shout. 'No, not at all. It was far worse for those on the Long March.' "
When Mr. Li and his wife left the school in May 1971, the Cultural Revolution was foundering. His negatives remained safely hidden. One year later he was back at his newspaper job and was able to photograph the official visit to Harbin of the exiled Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia. Mr. Li said that he finally felt safe by 1976, after Mao's death and the ouster of the Gang of Four, the radical Communist leaders blamed for the worst turmoil and persecutions of the Cultural Revolution.
Only then did he begin to organize his hidden photographs. "At that moment, I believed that the politically negative images would one day be presented in public," he said.
In 1982 he began teaching at a Beijing university, and it was there, in 1988, that 20 of his images were first exhibited. "A competition was organized of three decades of photos, 10 years before, 10 years during and 10 years after the Cultural Revolution," he said. "But they couldn't find any for the revolution's years. I didn't want to participate, but the organizer begged me and I sent a series called, 'Let the past speak to the future.' I won the top prize."
Among those who discovered Mr. Li's pictures then was Robert Pledge, president of Contact Press Images, a photo agency. The two men hoped to work together, but that notion was dashed in 1989 by the repression in Tiananmen Square and the political clampdown that followed. But in 1996, after Mr. Li was invited to lecture in the United States, he again met Mr. Pledge. And in subsequent trips, he gradually carried all his negatives to New York, at first surreptitiously, later with little fear that they might be seized. 
"Li estimates that he took 100,000 photographs between 1963 and 1976," Mr. Pledge said. "He had already eliminated one-third. Of the 60,000 remaining, many were of daily life. There were 30,000 with historical and journalistic interest related to the Cultural Revolution."
For the book, Mr. Li and Mr. Pledge decided that the photographs should be accompanied by a personal essay and historical background. 
Jacques Menasche, a New York-based journalist who helped draft Mr. Li's memoir, also wrote a chronology of the Cultural Revolution. Jonathan D. Spence, an authority on China at Yale University, wrote an introduction.
As the exhibition opened here on June 27, Mr. Li said he felt vindicated. Thanks to what he describes as his "rebellious nature," having defied a system that no longer exists, he can now "show the world what really happened during the Cultural Revolution." But he still wants that world to include young Chinese. "Only when they see these pictures," he said, "will they know that what they have been told is true."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 12, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Credits in The Arts on Monday for three pictures by Li Zhensheng with an article about an exhibition of his long-hidden photographs of the Cultural Revolution in China misstated the supplier. The pictures -- of two party secretaries being denounced, of eight people being executed and of swimmers studying the words of Mao Zedong -- should have been attributed to Li Zhensheng/Contact Press Images.

HEADLINE: Shares Are Up, But Lawsuits May Unsettle AOL's Future 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
The shareholder lawsuits accusing AOL Time Warner of accounting fraud are just getting started, but a slip-up by a federal judge may have offered an early clue to the outcome.
 In what one legal scholar called "the judicial equivalent of a Freudian slip," Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of United States District Court in Manhattan responded to a preliminary letter from shareholders' lawyers by ordering AOL Time Warner to turn over millions of pages of documents before the lawyers filed a formal motion or the company had a chance to respond. When AOL Time Warner's lawyers complained, she quickly rescinded the order. 
 Judge Kram's slip does not establish how she may ultimately view the case, but securities lawyers called the move a bad sign for the company. Her readiness to order the disclosures immediately -- an unusual step in any case -- suggests how credible she considers the suit, which asserts that AOL executives used bogus transactions to inflate advertising revenue around the time the company acquired Time Warner. 
"I think the defendant should sense that they are facing an uphill battle," said John C. Coffee Jr., a professor at Columbia Law School. 
One year after AOL Time Warner disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department were investigating its accounting, the company's share price is up more than 50 percent from its lows last summer, to $16.30 a share last week, and some analysts are again recommending the stock.
But the investigations and lawsuits remain among the biggest questions hanging over the company. Costs could well be higher than many expect, in part because the accusations involve statements made around the time that AOL, led by its chairman, Stephen M. Case, bought Time Warner in 2000.
S.E.C. fines or settlements are typically relatively minor, up to tens of millions. But shareholder suits can end up being far more costly. Almost all shareholder suits that survive a motion for dismissal end in a settlement rather than a trial.
The average settlement of a class-action suit seeking more than $5 billion in damages in the last eight years was 2.8 percent of the plaintiffs' estimated damages, according to the consulting firm Cornerstone Research. In the case of AOL Time Warner, the total damages claimed might range from $30 billion to $100 billion. But the percentage in settlements can go far higher in prominent cases. The most expensive payment was made by the real estate and travel services company Cendant, which three years ago paid $2.85 billion to settle shareholder suits over accounting problems in a previous acquisition.
Samuel D. Heins, a Minneapolis lawyer suing AOL Time Warner on behalf of the Minnesota State Board of Investments as the lead plaintiff in the class-action suit, declined to comment on possible settlements.
But legal experts say that the settlement in this case may well exceed previous benchmarks and formulas because of the political impetus among judges and regulators these days to crack down on corporate fraud.
"There has been a regime change," said Joseph A. Grundfest, a law professor at Stanford and a former member of the S.E.C., adding that "settlements are more difficult for companies to negotiate in the post-Enron environment." 
A spokeswoman for AOL Time Warner declined to comment. The company disclosed last year that it had overstated its financial results by $190 million over 21 months beginning in the fall of 2000. It said it had inflated the results through a series of bogus "round-trip" deals, in which it appeared to pay another company for goods or services but then recycled some of the payments back to itself as revenue and profits. 
Then, this spring, AOL Time Warner disclosed that the S.E.C. was questioning its accounting in a further $400 million in payments from Bertelsmann as another possible form of a round-trip deal. AOL is still defending its accounting for the Bertelsmann payments in talks with the S.E.C. (Legal experts say the commission is likely to block other moves requiring its approval, like AOL Time Warner's planned initial public offering of its cable division, until the matter is resolved.)
AOL Time Warner's acknowledged overstatements amount to 1.9 percent of its cash flow over the period. And the company has only restated payments that took place after shareholders approved the acquisition of Time Warner in June 2000. To prove securities fraud in the normal course of business after the merger closed, shareholders' lawyers would have to show that company executives intentionally or recklessly misled investors. 
But in the complaint filed in federal court in Manhattan, shareholders' lawyers argued that to take advantage of the Internet boom, and then consummate the merger, AOL was deceiving investors in a significant way as early as January 1999.
The timing could make a crucial difference in the case. Securities laws impose stricter requirements on companies issuing new shares, as AOL did in acquiring Time Warner. Proving fraud in issuing new shares only requires evidence of significantly misleading statements, regardless of the executives' knowledge or intentions. "It shifts the balance of advantage very much to the plaintiff," Professor Coffee said.
"Plaintiffs have an easier burden leading them to be able to extract a bigger settlement," said David Tabak, a vice president at National Economic Research Associates, which tracks class-action settlements.
The largest overstatement that AOL Time Warner has acknowledged occurred in the third quarter of 2000, after shareholders approved the merger in June 2000, but before it closed in January 2001. The company has said that improper accounting added $30 million, or about 5 percent, to AOL's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a common measure of performance. 
Lawyers for shareholders are expected to argue that the real date for the issuance of new shares in the merger was at its closing, after those acknowledged overstatements. But the complaint also contends that bogus round-trip transactions were more significant than their share of the company's revenue suggests. The bogus deals specifically inflated the AOL Internet service's highly profitable online advertising and commerce revenue, which analysts and investors considered the main propeller of the company's growth and the principal reason to buy its shares. 
Drawing mainly on news reports, company statements and related lawsuits, the complaint cites at least three reciprocal or round-trip deals -- with Sun Microsystems, Gateway and Hughes Electronics -- that it says improperly inflated AOL's results and prospects even before the shareholders approved the deal. 
AOL Time Warner has said that it accounted properly for all three transactions. Legal experts say its lawyers are likely to argue that the effective date for issuing the shares was when shareholders approved the deal, in June 2000, not the closing six months later. Most of all, they are expected to argue that investors cannot contend they were deceived by a pattern of reciprocal payments because these were fully disclosed.
Indeed, Robert W. Pittman, the former president of AOL and chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, had made the two-way deals a point of pride, often boasting that AOL tried to sell advertising to anyone it paid for goods or services.
When it comes to settlement talks, lawyers for AOL may argue that its shareholders lost far less than those of Lucent Technologies, where the share price fell to less than $2 from more than $60 after hidden financial problems came to light. In March, Lucent agreed to pay $315 million to settle a shareholders' suit, a favorable post-Enron benchmark.
Still, lawyers for Lucent shareholders said at the time that the size of the payment was limited mainly by Lucent's ability to pay. But AOL Time Warner remains large and profitable. The company declined to comment on its insurance policies, but they will probably cover some of any settlement, although most policies have ceilings far below the size of major payments like Lucent's or Cendant's. 
In any event, some settlement is almost certain since Judge Kram appears unlikely to grant a motion for dismissal. As she wrote in her original order, the lead plaintiff "is not in any sense engaged in a fishing expedition or an abusive strike suit," suggesting that it was a matter of time before its lawyers got their hands on those millions of pages of documents.

 BODY:
Adelphia Creditors Sue Banks, Claiming Duplicity
Creditors of Adelphia Communications filed suit against dozens of banks that lent billions of dollars to Adelphia and its founding family. The creditors claim the banks enabled the looting of the money from Adelphia, which is now bankrupt.
 The suit is the first major step to hold anyone but the family, the Rigases, responsible in the downfall of Adelphia, a cable company. The strength of the case is unclear. Page C2. 

Zahn Is in Front of Camera Again
Paula Zahn is back in prime time on CNN after a six-week absence, which she and network executives say was in part a vacation, not a work stoppage, as was rumored at CNN. Still, they said, she was not happy with her new program, "American Evening," which was to be two hours long and is now one. C7.

Little Effect From Hacker Game
Computer hackers vying in a six-hour global contest defaced a number of Web sites, but the damage was confined to the Internet's backwater of small, unsecured sites, security officials said. C2.

Prince May Rescue Hotel Chain
The struggling Meridien chain of hotels, which have suffered from the drop in luxury business and leisure travel, could be saved from liquidation by a Saudi Arabian prince who has bought stakes in other European and American companies. C2.

Blogs in the Workplace
The informal, say-anything approach used in online personal journals has gained popularity among corporations, which use the Web logs, or blogs, to open communications throughout their operations. New Economy. C3.

High-Quality Cameras, Lower Cost
Camera companies are moving closer to appealing to a mass market for digital single lens reflex cameras as the prices have fallen near $1,000. But the trend is frightening news for makers of film. C3.

Fighting Over Web Real Estate
A federal judge has ruled that Web site publishers cannot block competitors' pop-up advertisements from appearing over their pages. But a written decision that will determine any widespread impact of the ruling is still awaited. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

A Stocking for Sandals
Women may like wearing thong sandals in warm weather, but even fancy ones do not work well when stockings are called for. A new patent offers a solution for getting around the big toe: hosiery woven into a mitten shape at the foot, called Tohos (as in "toe hose"). The inventor, a former race-car driver, says she tested the prototypes while racing around a track. Patents. C2.

Simplified Encryption to Be Unveiled
A Silicon Valley start-up company plans to unveil a new approach to sending secure electronic messages and protecting data. It is based on the recipient's e-mail address, a simpler alternative to current encryption systems, which use long digital numbers. C4.

Addressing Nanotechnology Safety
A trade group focused on nanotechnology says it will work to address health and environmental concerns that could be associated with microscopic products. It is not worried, it says, with the types of disaster that have provided plots for science fiction. C6.

Interactive TV Makes Inroads
Digital cable systems have given viewers greater ability to interact with their TV sets, though the question remains whether couch potatoes care. C7.

HEADLINE: Saudi Prince Is Said to Offer Millions to Save Hotel Chain 

BYLINE:  By HEATHER TIMMONS 

 BODY:
The struggling hotel chain Le Meridien, which has suffered from the drop in luxury business and leisure travel, could be saved from liquidation by a Saudi Arabian prince who has bought stakes in other European and American companies.
 The prince, Walid bin Talal, has approached some of Le Meridien's largest investors about a turnaround plan that would provide the company with $:125 million ($208 million) in capital, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. 
 Le Meridien owns 135 prominent hotels and resorts worldwide, including the Grosvenor in London and the Venetian in Las Vegas. The company was purchased by a group of investors that included a private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners, in August 2001, shortly before travel plummeted as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks. Since then, saddled with heavy debts and high costs, Le Meridien has struggled to pay its bills. 
The hotel chain missed a $:20 million ($33.3 million) payment due last week to the Royal Bank of Scotland. The bank, in turn, has threatened to give Le Meridien's British hotels, which it owns and leases to the hotel company, to another chain. A spokesman for Terra Firma would not comment.
Prince Walid, who is a nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, earned a reputation for shrewd investing in downtrodden companies with his purchase of Citibank shares in the early 1990's. Bad real estate deals had driven the shares down then to less than $10, and the prince made billions when the share price of the successor company, Citigroup, rose through the late 90's. His investment vehicle, the Kingdom Holding Company, has stakes in other hotel chains, including the Four Seasons.
If the prince decides to invest in Le Meridien, he and his investing partners will be competing with Lehman Brothers. The brokerage firm, which has lent Le Meridien about $400 million, has been discussing a plan with other banks to put about $167 million into the company to keep it solvent. On Thursday, Lehman Brothers and Le Meridien each gave the Royal Bank of Scotland $:2 million ($3.3 million) toward the overdue payment.
Merrill Lynch and CIBC, with about a dozen other banks and financial companies, have lent Le Meridien an additional $1.2 billion and can therefore be expected to play a major role in the company's future. Under the terms of the Lehman plan, these banks would have to accept lower interest rates for the loans they hold, and any would-be rival could appeal to the banks by offering them more for their loans. A Lehman spokesman could not be reached for comment.
In October 2001, the prince was rebuffed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York when he offered to make a $10 million donation to a World Trade Center fund. The prince had said that the United States should take a more balanced view on Israeli-Palestinian matters. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 2003

While the Venetian has a marketing relationship with Le Meridien, it is owned by Las Vegas Sands Inc.

PERSON: Robert M. Batscha 

HEADLINE: Robert M. Batscha, 58, Dies; Archived Television and Radio 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Robert M. Batscha, who worked to preserve, archive, study and permanently exhibit two of the more ephemeral modes of mass communication as the longtime president of the Museum of Television and Radio, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 58.
 The cause was cancer, said Diane Reed, the director of public relations for the museum. 
 In his more than two decades as president of the museum, Dr. Batscha vastly expanded its collection, moved it to Midtown Manhattan, opened a branch in Beverly Hills and brought together industry leaders, stars and academics at seminars.
Museum visitors can listen to Franklin D. Roosevelt's fireside chats or Orson Welles's "War of the Worlds." They can watch tapes of the lunar landing, the Nixon-Kennedy debates, "Beverly Hills, 90210" or "The Sopranos." And they can rerun famous commercials. 
Dr. Batscha long argued that television was worthy of study and that old programs, those that recorded history and those that highlighted the frivolous aspects of popular culture, were museum pieces. "Criticizing TV is second only to watching TV as an American pastime," he said in 1992. "Now, we want to give TV its day in the sun. It's a medium that has got to be recognized."
The museum was founded in 1975 by William S. Paley, the television pioneer and former chairman of CBS. It was originally the Museum of Broadcasting; the name was changed to the Museum of Television and Radio in 1991 so it could include programs transmitted by other means, including cable and satellite. 
Dr. Batscha, a political scientist by training, became the museum's president in 1981. 
Born in Rochester, N.Y., and raised in New York City, he graduated magna cum laude from Queens College and received a Ph.D. in political science from Columbia University. Before going to work at the museum, he was a senior consultant at the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. 
When he arrived at the museum, it occupied two floors in a converted office building and its catalog included about 5,000 titles. It now has 120,000 titles.
Dr. Batscha became a prodigious fund-raiser, and he oversaw the museum's expansion on two coasts. In 1991, the museum moved into a tower at 25 West 52nd Street. In 1996, it copied its entire collection and opened a branch in Beverly Hills. 
The museum is financed by the radio and television industries, corporations, foundations, individuals and government agencies.
The chairman of the museum's board of trustees, Frank A. Bennack Jr., said Dr. Batscha had expanded not only the museum's collection and display space, but also its mission. "When you put it together, he was the architect of something that very faithfully carried out the mission envisioned by Mr. Paley, but clearly expanded on it," he said.
Dr. Batscha is survived by a son, Eric, 21, of Manhattan, and by a former wife, Francine Sommer, also of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Dry Prospects 

 BODY:
It was so wet in the Northeast last month -- the wettest June in a century -- that it was almost hard to believe it was dry anywhere else in the country. Yet it is dangerously dry in some places, as the wildfires in Arizona have demonstrated. The depression many New Yorkers felt as rain fell day after day was an unimaginable luxury in most of the West, where a drought that has already lasted five years is limbering up for another summer. 
 There has been a little relief here and there, along the Front Range in Colorado, in portions of southeastern Montana and northern and eastern Wyoming, where snow and rain fell recently. But in the Southwest, the drought looks chronic and perpetual, and it is reinforced by brutal competition between farmers and metropolitan areas for scarce water resources. A city like Phoenix, which depends on the snowpack feeding the Colorado River hundreds of miles away and which gets less rain in a normal year than New York had in June, could begin to look like an unsustainable proposition. 
 The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation has issued a new report called "Water 2025," intended to guide local and regional planning for water use in the West. It comes not a moment too soon. The ongoing drought inspired the project, but so has the dramatic population growth in arid regions over the past decade, particularly in Nevada and Arizona. If the West were still sparsely settled, the severity of the drought would be serious enough. Now, the drought is bearing down on an enormous number of people -- cattle ranchers, farmers, vacationers and city dwellers alike. Brown lawns aren't the same, in economic impact, as parched rangeland, desiccated farmland or ashen forests, but they make themselves felt nonetheless. What "Water 2025" recognizes is that unless the right plans are made, the potential for future conflict over water rights is very high. 
The water-starved West can no longer bet on "normal." Even normal precipitation from here on out will not quickly do away with the effects of such a prolonged drought. Drought plans have been adopted all across the West, and even Arizona, which has been slow to act, is developing one. What those plans describe for the foreseeable future is a new reality, a reality of careful water usage, careful storage and even more careful conservation.

HEADLINE: Feeling Shortchanged by a City in a Crunch 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
For 35 years, whenever a neighbor or friend has walked into the Francisco Funeral Home, members of the Francisco family have been there to offer their kind of Ozone Park compassion -- a gentle hug, a feathery pat on the hand and a mention of the correctly remembered name of the deceased's mother or father. 
 But these days, the family is looking for a little compassion of its own. On the rare occasion when the three generations of Franciscos can steal enough time from their hectic schedules for coffee or lunch in the funeral home's reception room, they complain that the city, intent on taking care of its own fiscal problems, has turned a deaf ear to people like them. 
 "What did they do, forget about us in Ozone Park?" asked Antoinette Francisco, 84, the iron-willed family matriarch, who lives above the funeral home and sometimes pads through in a house dress and slippers to join the others at the table. She is mad enough to spit because she has been trying for years to get the city to trim dead branches from a maple tree on the sidewalk beside the funeral home. 
In a city as large as New York, the everyday concerns of ordinary people can easily get lost. But when examined on the scale of a single block, like this one in Queens, they give a vivid sense of just how New Yorkers are coping with the burdens imposed by the city as it grapples with its biggest fiscal challenges in years.
Such close-up views also show how difficult it may be for city officials to satisfy New Yorkers, who have been hit in the last few months by higher taxes, transit fares, tolls and rents.
The Franciscos, who know the importance of service because they have all been in the business of providing it, were relieved last month when the city averted most of the cuts in services it had threatened. But they still wonder why, when they keep paying more in taxes, the city does not seem to have enough money to take care of the things that matter to them. 
For Leslie and Ralph Francisco, who run the funeral home, the city's cost-cutting over the last eight years has meant spending precious time driving not to funerals and burials but to a Manhattan records office to register death certificates. 
Their eldest son, Ralph Jr., a paramedic, and his wife, Erika, a nurse, are expecting their first child. But forced overtime because of staffing cuts has pushed them further into an income bracket that makes them ineligible for the city's moderate-income housing programs, and puts their first house further out of reach. 
The Franciscos' other son, Richard, plans to become engaged soon, but his limousine business has been hurt by the economic downturn, and he fears that the mix of tax increases and 4,000 layoffs imposed by the Bloomberg administration will make the city a less desirable place to live and work. 
And then there is Ralph Sr.'s mother, Antoinette Francisco. The gauge of her feelings about the city is a simple tree. 
When Mrs. Francisco and her husband, Salvatore, opened their first florist shop in 1945 in rented space on the northeast corner of 103rd Street and 101st Avenue, a skinny maple was already growing alongside the white house across the street.
Years later the Franciscos bought an empty lot on that block and built their own florist shop. And when the white house with the tree, cater-corner from the soaring sandstone facade of St. Mary Gate of Heaven Roman Catholic Church, went up for sale, Mrs. Francisco and her husband bought it. They eventually converted the first floor into a funeral home for their son Ralph's new business, and adopted the maple as their own. 
As the family's enterprises grew, so did the tree. They acquired more property on the block, and the funeral home prospered, its white stone exterior and delicate awning on 101st Avenue becoming a familiar beacon for generations of families. 
A few years ago, the maple's top branches turned black, and Mrs. Francisco, a widow now, called the Parks Department to have someone take care of it. After working in the flower shop for so many years, she could not stand to see the tree go untended.
The Parks Department put her name on a list and told her to wait. So she waited. 
And she waited. Last month she complained to her city councilman, Joseph P. Addabbo Jr.
Mr. Addabbo, chairman of the parks committee, said in an interview that the city's $2.7 million tree maintenance budget had been slashed, and that it looked for a while as if none of the city's trees would be pruned this year. But when the City Council and the mayor reached a budget agreement last month, the tree money was restored.
Mr. Addabbo has ordered his staff to review all requests for tree pruning, but he said it would not be reasonable for anyone to expect crews to show up immediately. "We're still in bad financial times," he said. 
The budget restorations did not impress Mrs. Francisco. "They haven't got the money, and then all of a sudden they've got it?" she asked. "What is that?"
While the other members of the family are happy that thanks to the budget agreement libraries will remain open and garbage will be picked up twice a week, they still feel shortchanged.
"We pay all these taxes," said Leslie Francisco, who devotes substantial volunteer time to community service, "and what do we get?" 
One thing they do not have yet is the modern system for registering death certificates that the city promised years ago. When faced with an earlier fiscal crisis, in 1994, the city decided to close vital-records offices in every borough but Manhattan. 
As a result, either Ralph, 60, or Leslie, 56, who live just a few blocks from the funeral home, spends more than an hour driving into Manhattan to file a death certificate for each funeral. Once there, they often have to wait in line another hour. The city reopened a burial desk in Brooklyn last year, but it takes the Franciscos almost as much time to get there as to Manhattan, and the lines are sometimes longer.
Eight years ago, at the urging of the Franciscos and other funeral directors, the city agreed to develop a computerized registration system. About $3.2 million was spent to design one, according to an audit released on June 23 by the city comptroller. Then the plans were abandoned when the prototype system developed serious problems, like registering some men as having been pregnant when they died. The city now plans to spend $1.8 million more for project design. The comptroller's audit called the aborted plans "a monumental waste" of taxpayer dollars.
So Mr. Francisco had to make the dreaded trip into Manhattan again on a recent Monday to file a death certificate. "It's ridiculous, a complete waste," he said, his voice rising above the hush of the funeral parlor.
Leslie Francisco, a lifelong New Yorker, sees the boondoggle over the computerized death certificates as a symbol of the city's diminishing ability to respond to the real needs of real people. "I really have a hard time saying I see things getting better," she said. 
New York's future also looks rather bleak to the latest generation of Franciscos. Ralph Jr., 32, a paramedic for the Fire Department, and his wife, Erika, also 32, a registered nurse at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital, have been living in one of his grandmother's houses alongside the funeral home since they were married in 2001.
They have been saving to buy their own house, preferably in the neighborhood, but have not found anything they can afford. 
With Erika expecting their first baby in January, they are afraid to take on too large a mortgage because she will have to stop working for a while. The average price of a house in Ozone Park and other Queens neighborhoods they considered is more than $350,000. But right now they make too much money to qualify for any of the city's moderate-income housing programs. 
Mr. Francisco is especially frustrated because the mandatory overtime he was forced to take after layoffs left the Fire Department shorthanded pushed his salary even higher above the qualifying threshold for the city's housing programs, and thrust him and his wife into a higher tax bracket. 
Last month they thought they had found a good deal when they read a newspaper advertisement for refurbished government-owned town houses in Harlem. Six of the 23 buildings are considered moderate-income housing, with prices starting at $331,000. But buyers must have a combined household income of no more than $60,000. Erika's salary alone exceeds that, Mr. Francisco said, and the starting salary for a Fire Department paramedic is more than $40,000. 
For buyers at their income level, prices for the town houses shot up to $689,000. "It's crazy," Mr. Francisco said, throwing up his hands. "Who can live in New York on a combined income of less than $60,000 a year?"
David A. Jackson, an assistant commissioner in the division of home ownership at the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said that he was aware of the difficulties facing working New Yorkers with moderate incomes, and that despite the tight city budget, work was being done to provide housing "for people like that." 
Mr. Francisco's younger brother, Richard, 25, may soon join the ranks of people like that. He lives in one of his grandmother's buildings and runs a limousine service from an office next to the funeral home. 
He plans to be engaged soon, but the economic slowdown and fiscal crisis have hurt him. As families try to economize on funerals, fewer people spend money on limousines. At the same time, Mr. Francisco says, the Bloomberg administration's tax increases -- especially the rise in the sales tax -- might backfire, driving out businesses and consumers alike. 
"Give it time, six months to a year, and you're definitely going to see a change for the worse," said Mr. Francisco, who has already begun exploring the option of living in Westchester County or on Long Island after he marries. 
This spring, Mr. Francisco got himself a bulldog he calls Hunter. He put a spiked collar on the dog, and on warm afternoons when there are no funerals, he walks Hunter on 103rd Street, keeping the dog away from the flowers by his grandmother's trees. 
When he sees the woeful condition of the maple, he too wonders what happened to the trimmer the city was supposed to send. 
"Maybe it's the rain," he said sarcastically, glaring at the forlorn maple. "Yeah, the rain."

HEADLINE: Prescription Drugs, Affordable for All 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 JacobHacker's warnings about the Medicare drug bills before Congress are well taken ("How Not to Fix Medicare," Op-Ed, July 2). 
But he doesn't offer a solution to the problem of paying for drugs. The projected cost of $2 trillion over the next decade is an unaffordable burden for both the elderly and the government. 
 Drugs are expensive because the government provides patent monopolies to drug companies. If the government directly financed biomedical research and allowed all drugs to be sold in a competitive market -- as is currently the case with generics -- drugs would be affordable for all, not just the elderly.

DEAN BAKER
Co-director, Center for Economic
and Policy Research
Washington, July 2, 2003

HEADLINE: Civil Rights, The Sequel 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
It's been more than 30 years since Whitney Young Jr. died and his name is no longer particularly well known, which is a shame.
 Mr. Young was the executive director of the National Urban League and one of the big four civil rights leaders of the 1960's, along with Martin Luther King Jr., Roy Wilkins and James Farmer. 
 He drowned at the absurdly young age of 49 during a visit to Nigeria in 1971. More than 6,000 people attended his funeral at Manhattan's Riverside Church, and thousands more lined the streets of Harlem to view the funeral procession. Mr. Young had been a giant in the movement and it was widely recognized that his death represented a terrible loss. 
What was not understood at the time was that an incredible decades-long slide into the horrors of violence and degradation for millions of African-American youngsters was already under way. More than three decades later we still haven't stopped the descent.
It is now absolutely normal in many circles for young black men and women (and, for that matter, little black boys and girls) to refer to one another as niggaz and bitches and ho's. Doing well in school is frequently disdained as a white thing. Doing time in prison is widely accepted as a black thing, and no cause for shame.
Few people are surprised to hear that a gathering at this party or that club degenerated into the kind of violence we used to associate with the O.K. Corral. Homicide, drugs and AIDS are carving the heart out of one generation after another, and suicide among blacks is on the rise.
Just before I sat down to write this column I happened to glance at an article that was on the front page of last Thursday's Boston Globe. Beneath a color photo of a black toddler, the article began:
"A 3-year-old girl remained in critical condition last night after a former high school basketball star allegedly ended a shouting match with a woman by spraying her Dorchester house with bullets, hitting the child in the back and severing her spinal cord."
My question is a simple one: When are we going to stop this?
I'm waiting for the mothers and the fathers, the aunts and the uncles, the older brothers and the older sisters to step forward and call a halt to the madness, to say: "Enough! This is not what we're about."
I mentioned Whitney Young Jr. because I had a conversation a few days ago with Marc Morial, the former mayor of New Orleans who has just taken over as head of the Urban League and is hoping to raise its profile to a level comparable to the glory days of the Whitney Young era.
He plans to lay out his agenda in a keynote address to be delivered later this month at the league's annual convention.
My suggestion: Hammer home the need to stop the self-destruction that continues to block the advancement of millions of black Americans.
I know there are serious economic problems, particularly the absence of good jobs, that are holding some people back. And I know about the abuses in the criminal justice system and the continuing plague of racism and discrimination. I've written reams about all of these things.
None of them are good reasons for parents to turn their backs on their children, for children to turn their backs on school, for a young man or a young woman to pick up a needle and plunge it into a vein, for a gunman to put a bullet into a rival's head or a neighbor's spine, for blacks to view themselves as niggers and whores, for entertainers to sing of the joys of rape and murder.
The paradox of black life in America over the past half-century is that so much real progress and such wholesale tragedy should have occurred in the same place at the same time. The task now is to reinforce the progress and bring the curtain down on the tragedy.
Young leaders like Mr. Morial (he's 45) and venerable institutions like the Urban League (it's 93) are perfectly positioned to begin the coordinated effort that's needed for this fight, which is the most serious to face black Americans since the demise of legal segregation.
Those who are looking to government to lead this effort are deluded. George Bush and Clarence Thomas will not be riding to our rescue.
What's required is nothing less than round two of the civil rights movement, the goal being to create a safe and constructive and nurturing environment in which all black Americans can thrive.

HEADLINE: South Is Posing '04 Questions For Democrats in the Senate 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 3 

 BODY:
The difficulties faced by Congressional Democrats in holding their strength in the Senate and House next year -- let alone regaining majorities -- are on vivid display in Georgia, a state that figured prominently in the party's loss of Senate control in 2002.
 Zell Miller, a Democrat, is quitting the Senate, and no prominent party member has yet stepped forward to contend for the job. But at least four Republicans, two House members and two businessmen, have begun campaigns to take the seat out of the opposition column. 
 "I think there is an excellent opportunity for a Republican to become the next United States senator from Georgia," said Representative Mac Collins, one of those who hope to succeed Mr. Miller.
Georgia is not the only Southern state where the Democrats face problems. It is unclear whether Democratic incumbents will be on the ballot in South Carolina, where 81-year-old Ernest F. Hollings has hinted at retirement, or North Carolina and Florida, where Senators John Edwards and Bob Graham are running for their party's presidential nomination. Their decisions on whether to seek re-election to the Senate will help determine how many open seats Democrats will have to defend in a region where President Bush is riding high. 
"In that part of the country in a presidential year it is kind of a perfect storm coming together for the Democrats, and it could get ugly for them," said Stuart Rothenberg, a nonpartisan analyst of Congressional races.
Nationally, Democrats have more Senate seats in play than Republicans, 19 to 15, and they concede that the South poses a challenge given Mr. Bush's strong showing in most Southern states in 2000.
But they see opportunities in Illinois, where Republicans have a troublesome open seat of their own, as well as Pennsylvania and a handful of other states where the party would like to make a serious run at incumbent senators. In Alaska, the former governor, Tony Knowles, a Democrat, could announce soon that he will oppose Senator Lisa Murkowski. She was appointed to the vacant Senate seat last year by her father, Frank Murkowski, when he left the Senate after being elected governor.
"I am not quivering in my boots," said Senator Jon Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, who is coordinating his party's Senate campaign operation. "I think we just have a tough, hard competitive election coming up."
But unlike in 2002, when the fight for the Senate was fought across middle America in states like Missouri, Minnesota and South Dakota, next year the South will get much of the attention.
"This is where the battle is this time," said Representative Johnny Isakson, a House member from the suburbs north of Atlanta who has already raised almost $3 million for a Senate run, his third statewide race. "No question about it."
Georgia was a significant setback for Senate Democrats in 2002 when Saxby Chambliss, a Republican with ample help from Mr. Bush and an emphasis on domestic security, defeated the incumbent Democrat, Max Cleland. The governor, Roy E. Barnes, another Democrat, also lost in a surprise, sending the state party reeling.
Mr. Miller, a popular former governor who often sides with Republicans, announced in January that he would not be going back to the Capitol after serving only the four years of the unexpired term of Paul Coverdell. Since then, a handful of Democrats holding statewide office have looked at the race and passed. They appear unwilling to give up their secure posts, content to bide time for a governor's race in 2006. One state senator, Mary Hodges, has said she will seek the party's Senate nomination.
"That tells you something about the state of play of the Georgia Democratic Party these days when you don't have Democrats lining up for an open Senate seat," said Merle Black, a political science professor at Emory University.
State and national officials are continuing to recruit and to put forth several names, including Representative Jim Marshall, who was elected last year to his first term in the House; Mayor Shirley Franklin of Atlanta; and a few wealthy people who would be able to underwrite much of their own campaign. Democrats promise the party will have a credible contender. And they say that what looms as a hard-hitting Republican primary could improve their prospects if the party can coalesce behind a contender.
"This time next year, there will be a fully funded, totally engaged Democratic Senate candidate running," said Jeff DeSantis, executive director of the state party.
But that person might have some catching up to do. Besides the two lawmakers, two businessmen are seeking the Republican nomination for the Senate race -- Herman Cain, a motivational speaker and the former head of the Godfather's pizza chain, and Al Bartell, who last year lost a bid for lieutenant governor.
All are raising money and putting together organizations. Mr. Isakson and Mr. Collins are already engaged in a spirited exchange over who has the real conservative credentials in the race. Mr. Isakson, 58, a former real estate executive who is likely to have a spending advantage, is emphasizing his long roots in state Republican politics and arguing that his voting record in Congress should dispel any claim by his opponents that he is somehow moderate.
"I was Republican when Republican wasn't cool," Mr. Isakson said after an appearance at a Kiwanis meeting.
Mr. Collins, a trucking company founder from the center of the state, is making a case for his ties to working Georgians and his appeal in rural areas outside Atlanta, an approach that helped Sonny Perdue triumph last year in his race for governor. "We are in touch with more of the people than a lot of folks who will enter this race," Mr. Collins, also 58, said in an interview.
Senator George Allen of Virginia, who is running the Republican campaign operation, would prefer not to referee a lot of disputes that he knows could make the general elections more difficult. "We don't need to be cutting each other up to help the Democrats," Mr. Allen said. Still, he would rather have too many experienced candidates than too few. And he views the Southeast as the key to keeping the thin Republican majority or padding it.
"We have got to come out of the A.C.C. with a winning record," he said, referring to the Atlantic Coast Conference, one of the region's popular collegiate sports leagues.
The Republicans already have candidates running in North Carolina and South Carolina who are in to stay, no matter what Mr. Hollings or Mr. Edwards does. In Florida, which was famously divided the last time Mr. Bush ran, two Republican candidates are in gear and as many as five Democrats are waiting in the wings if Mr. Graham does not run for the Senate again.
Mr. Allen acknowledges, however, that just as Georgia is confounding Democrats at the moment, Illinois is proving ticklish for Republicans as they look for a substitute for Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, who is retiring rather than run in an increasingly Democratic state.
Democrats think they can score there as well as against Senator Arlen Specter in Pennsylvania and are looking at Kentucky and Missouri, among other spots. Republicans would like to knock off two Democratic leaders, Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Harry Reid of Nevada, in states that went for Mr. Bush in 2000.
With the election 18 months off, the House picture has yet to take shape with few seats coming open through retirements. Democrats will face a challenge against a well-financed and practiced Republican operation intent on holding its control of the House.
In the Senate, Mr. Corzine says the soft economy and rising joblessness should give Democrats potent ammunition against Mr. Bush and the Republican Congress.
Mr. Allen says the accomplishments of the Republican-led Senate -- tax cuts and a possible Medicare drug benefit among them -- should help make the case for Republicans. "I would rather have our team and our issues going into this election than theirs," he said.

An article on Monday about the difficulty posed by the South for the Democratic Party in the 2004 Congressional elections omitted the surname used by a Georgia state senator who may run for the United States Senate. She is Mary Hodges Squires.
