HEADLINE: New Threats and Opportunities Redefine U.S. Interests in Africa 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6 

 BODY:
President Bush will leave Monday night for a five-nation tour of Africa, turning to a continent that his administration increasingly sees as a source of both threats and opportunities and no longer one that can be left at the bottom of the foreign policy to-do list.
 The official focus of the five-day trip -- which was originally scheduled for January but was postponed as the president prepared for war with Iraq -- is on fighting poverty and disease and promoting democracy. But it has taken on a new cast in recent weeks as Mr. Bush has assertively called for changes of government in Zimbabwe and Liberia and moved to the brink of sending American troops to Liberia as peacekeepers. 
 In his first trip to sub-Saharan Africa as president, Mr. Bush will visit Senegal, South Africa, Botswana, Uganda and Nigeria before returning home on Saturday. Each of those countries is an economic or political success by African standards, and Mr. Bush's presence is intended both to celebrate their progress and to encourage other African nations to continue the struggle toward free elections and free markets. 
His trip comes at a time when Africa is looming larger in calculations of American interests. In the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the United States is eager to keep poor nations with shaky governments from becoming breeding grounds and safe harbors for terrorists. It sees Africa as the world's last largely untapped market. It holds out hope that Africa's substantial oil reserves could play a larger role in fueling the American economy and perhaps serving as a counterweight to the influence of OPEC.
At a time when Mr. Bush is widely viewed, at home and abroad, as focused primarily on projecting American power and defending its interests by military means, administration officials say the president is determined to show another face of his foreign policy. They said the United States should be known as much for battling AIDS, helping villages get clean drinking water, supporting education programs and encouraging the resolution of armed conflicts as for exercising its military power.
The president "understands that America is a country that really does have to be committed to values and to making life better for people around the world, that that's what the world looks to America to do," said Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, in a briefing with reporters on Thursday. "It's not just the sword, it's also the olive branch that speaks to those intentions."
It is striking to African leaders and to many analysts in the United States that Mr. Bush, a conservative Republican who won less than 10 percent of the black vote in 2000 and has fought to hold down social welfare spending at home, has pushed this year for large spending increases to fight AIDS in Africa and to help poor nations nurture their economies.
They said they saw in Mr. Bush's engagement with Africa the hand of his two senior foreign policy advisers: Ms. Rice and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, the two highest-profile African-Americans in government. Neither Ms. Rice nor Mr. Powell has made a secret of the desire to have Washington play a more active role in a part of the world that American foreign policy long addressed only fitfully or as a pawn in the cold war and to acknowledge more fully the ties between Africa and the United States.
"Africa is part of America's history," Ms. Rice said. "Europeans and Africans came to this country together, Africans in chains. And slavery was, of course, America's birth defect. And we've been trying to deal with the consequences of it ever since."
There is still considerable skepticism, in Washington and in Africa, about the depths of Mr. Bush's commitment, diplomats and analysts said. There is concern among some Africa hands that Mr. Bush's interest will wane after he makes the point to the world that he is more than the unilateralist gunslinger he is often, fairly or unfairly, made out to be. With presidential politics increasingly coming to the fore at the White House, there is also grumbling among advocacy groups that the trip is little more than a way for Mr. Bush to flesh out his "compassionate conservative" platform for his re-election race.
Even diplomats and analysts who say Mr. Bush's interest appears genuine suggested that it is fair to question whether the trip, by a president who has never relished foreign travel, will be anything more than dutiful.
"Is this for real, or is this tourism?" asked Chester A. Crocker, who was assistant secretary of state for Africa in the Reagan administration, at a Brookings Institution symposium on Africa last week.
Administration officials say Mr. Bush's commitment is indeed substantial. They point to quiet but promising efforts made by the administration to broker a peace deal in Sudan. They mention the Pentagon's interest in forging closer military ties with friendly nations, and Mr. Bush's call last month to extend what economists say has been one of the most important elements of policy toward Africa, the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a trade law that allows many African products to be exported to the United States without duties and quotas.
"The president takes seriously Africa, African leaders and the potential of this continent," Ms. Rice said.
There are clearly risks for Mr. Bush, especially as he confronts more directly the problems of countries like Zimbabwe, whose economy is collapsing under the increasingly autocratic rule of President Robert Mugabe. If he sends troops into Liberia as peacekeepers, he will be putting American lives on the line for a nation that has been the site of brutal fighting and the source of considerable instability in the region for years. He would also be reviving the specter of Somalia, where 18 American soldiers died in a failed attempt at peacekeeping in 1993.
Somewhat to their own amazement, many advocacy groups that labored for decades to persuade the United States and other wealthy countries to do more for Africa say Mr. Bush appears intent on really making a difference.
"This trip needn't be just about tourism because there are the beginnings of an historic change in policy toward Africa, permitted by a Republican Congress, we hope, and led by, extraordinarily enough, a Republican president," said Jamie Drummond, executive director of DATA, a nonprofit group that calls for more assistance for Africa. "That's put us in a fascinating situation."
Mr. Drummond said the real test would be whether the president could win from Congress an agreement to finance fully the two programs that are the centerpieces of his Africa policy. One is a five-year, $15 billion plan to fight AIDS in 14 countries, 12 of them in Africa. The other, called the Millennium Challenge Account, is a pledge to channel $10 billion over the next three years to poor countries that can show that they are making nuts-and-bolts progress toward democracy and capitalism.
Budgets for both programs, however, are likely to be cut in the coming week below the levels sought by the White House. Even as Mr. Bush is putting a spotlight on the programs in Africa this week, a House appropriations subcommittee is planning to trim them back, both because of a budget squeeze and because Republicans on the subcommittee said the administration had not gotten either program fully up and running.
Asked about the $3 billion for next year sought by legislation creating the AIDS program, Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, the chairman of the subcommittee, said, "We're not really prepared in the first year to spend that vast amount on bilateral programs."
Mr. Kolbe said that he was a "big believer" in the Millennium Challenge Account program, but that the administration did not have people and systems in place yet to administer it. "We're not going to be able to do everything in that area, but we're going to do a lot," he said.
Ms. Rice said the president would take on his own party over the issue if necessary.
"The message to Congress is that the president requested funding at the levels he thought necessary to get the job done," she said. "And we are all of us actively engaging with the Congress to try and get full funding."

HEADLINE: President Bush's Africa Trip 

 BODY:
American presidents do not travel to Africa often. President Bush's five-day, five-nation visit, starting today, marks a significant step in America's deepening relations with the continent. For too long, Washington and other Western capitals treated Africa as if it were condemned to war, poverty and preventable epidemics. Mr. Bush understands that Africans are entitled to a better future, and that America can help them achieve it. 
 Turning that vision into reality will take more than whirlwind tours and inspiring speeches. Mr. Bush must press Congress to provide ample financing for his multiyear AIDS and development initiatives. He should also speak plainly with African leaders about steps they themselves need to take. More than 11 percent of the world's people live in sub-Saharan Africa. Their future depends on how well their countries handle the intertwined problems of H.I.V.-AIDS, ethnic and civil conflict, corrupt and abusive government and economic growth too feeble to provide jobs for rising populations. In each of the countries Mr. Bush is visiting -- Senegal, South Africa, Botswana, Uganda and Nigeria -- one or more of these issues belongs high on the agenda. 
 Senegal is a strong democracy, though plagued by a low-grade separatist insurgency in the Casamance region. Despite this, Senegal has set a healthy example in a deeply troubled neighborhood and has participated in efforts to negotiate peace in Sierra Leone, Ivory Coast and Liberia. 
South Africa has one of the continent's most developed economies and biggest H.I.V.-AIDS problems. President Thabo Mbeki is sub-Saharan Africa's most prestigious leader. But his failure to confront the AIDS pandemic has caused public health damage at home and hurt efforts elsewhere to overcome the stigmatization that undermines effective prevention and treatment. If Mr. Bush can persuade Mr. Mbeki to follow a more enlightened course, America's AIDS assistance programs will save more lives. Mr. Mbeki has also failed to do all he should to help resolve the crisis in neighboring Zimbabwe, where President Robert Mugabe has clung to power through repression and fraud. 
Botswana is blessed with mineral wealth, a relatively small population, vigorous democracy and enlightened environmental policies. But it is cursed with Africa's highest H.I.V. infection rate, with two of five adults affected. In contrast to Mr. Mbeki, President Festus Mogae has worked hard to contain the disease. Even more energetic steps could be taken, modeled on the anti-AIDS campaign led by Uganda's president, Yoweri Museveni. By mentioning AIDS in almost every speech and carrying the campaign into every village, Mr. Museveni has gone far to destigmatize the disease. That has helped reduce the infection rate by two-thirds, a remarkable life-saving achievement. Mr. Museveni's leadership would be far more impressive if he permitted opposition parties and free elections, a point Mr. Bush should insist on. 
The Bush visit concludes in Africa's most populous country, Nigeria. President Olusegun Obasanjo has been a consistent opponent of military dictatorship, but his first term as an elected civilian ruler was extremely disappointing. He has failed to crack down on corruption and army human rights abuses, neglected the economy and done little to heal dangerous religious and ethnic divisions. Now Mr. Obasanjo has become actively involved in efforts to bring peace and a transitional administration to Liberia. Yesterday the Liberian leader, Charles Taylor, said he would accept Nigeria's offer of safe haven. Mr. Bush needs to tell Mr. Obasanjo that he would be a more credible advocate of good governance abroad if he did more to practice it at home.

HEADLINE: After Upheaval of Scandal, Tax Office Is Still Under Fire 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
The same morning in February 2002 that Martha E. Stark walked in to start her job as the head of New York City's Finance Department, 15 of her tax assessors were indicted on bribery charges. If things did not get worse, they did not get much better.
 Ms. Stark, appointed commissioner of finance by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, found a department plagued by, among other things, an incomprehensible set of rules that made it nearly impossible for the public to figure out just how the city calculated most real-estate tax bills. And her department, she learned, was stuck with computer systems so antiquated and vulnerable to manipulation that they all but invited more corruption. 
 The chaos was no minor matter. Ms. Stark's agency is the single most important revenue generator in the city, collecting more than $16 billion annually in local taxes, as much as the gross national product of some small nations. And the city, facing huge deficits, needs every penny of it. 
In the year and a half since she arrived, Ms. Stark said, she has linked her agency into a state-of-the-art computer mapping system that will allow property tax assessors to use aerial maps to monitor new construction. She has also imposed limits on contacts between assessors and property owners and started to rotate assignments within the department, both measures intended to prevent yet another corruption scandal.
"There is a lot more to do," Ms. Stark said one recent Friday evening in her fifth-floor office at the Municipal Building. "But I feel like I've accomplished a significant amount."
Others are not convinced. Elected officials in Albany say a package of legislative reforms intended to help collect some of the hundreds of millions of dollars lost to corruption and to improve the training of city workers failed to get enacted, in part, because of insufficient lobbying by the Bloomberg administration.
Some officials in the Finance Department itself, as well as the expert whom Ms. Stark hired this year to help overhaul the agency, but who then quit in despair, say her efforts have been timid or, worse, counterproductive. The agency, they say, is in worse shape now than when Ms. Stark started, in no small part because of a recent round of layoffs and a restructuring plan that some have called naive.
"You have a lot of different interests raising red flags," said State Assemblyman Brian M. McLaughlin, a Democrat from Queens who is chairman of the Assembly's Real Property Tax Committee.
What all parties agree on is that the remaining work necessary to fix the city's property tax assessment system is enormous.
The Finance Department is charged with collecting a long list of different sources of revenue, including parking tickets and business taxes. Most important, the agency assesses and collects the property tax.
New York City's 984,000 pieces of property -- from single-family homes to apartment buildings, office towers and shopping centers -- are supposed to be evaluated each year to determine how much the owner must pay in property taxes.
The corruption scandal involved 15 of the 38 assessors working in Manhattan, who were accused of taking millions in bribes over a 35-year period to cut property taxes for the owners of office towers, residential buildings and warehouses, costing the city $160 million in just the four years prior to their arrest. All 15 have resigned or been dismissed and, after being convicted of charges including conspiracy and bribery, were sentenced to jail terms ranging from 4 to 41 months, city officials said.
But the trouble extends beyond this high-profile case, according to some critics.
One of the antiquated computer systems is used to do automated appraisals on one- to three-family homes, which make up 70 percent of all the city's pieces of real estate. Linda Yancey, hired by Ms. Stark this year as the assistant commissioner for the property division, and who served for several months, said the data maintained in this computer system and a formula it uses to process the data are both so flawed that it routinely generates assessments for homes that are inaccurate.
The result is that one home in Queens might be assessed at a value that is much higher than a nearly identical home in a similar neighborhood in Brooklyn, Ms. Yancey said.
The city also has far fewer assessors -- it currently has a total of 132 after 20 were laid off in May, compared with more than 300 in 1991. Assessors, Ms. Yancey also found, lacked essential equipment, items as basic as phones and tape measures. Finally, she determined, the city was routinely failing to move fast enough to add recently constructed or expanded city buildings to the property tax rolls, losing out on millions of dollars in potential revenue.
When Ms. Stark hired Ms. Yancey, she called her someone with a fresh set of eyes, and great experience, most of it in upstate New York, as an assessor and teacher.
What Ms. Yancey's eyes found shocked her. "I am surprised that the city has not had a tax revolt," Ms. Yancey wrote in a letter to the New York City Council last April, shortly after she resigned. "The quality of assessments is so poor now that it is a wonder that the tax roll could be considered legal."
Leaders of the union that represents the city's tax assessors have also expressed concern about Ms. Stark's reform efforts. They charge that the tax exemptions recently given to builders of multifamily homes in the city may not have been justified. The tax-break program is intended to promote the construction of moderate-income housing -- as a certain number of units within each building must be occupied by people with modest incomes -- but the assessors say they were not given enough time to check each of the applications to ensure the exemptions were warranted.
"There has been a lack of oversight and a lack of sufficient staffing to make sure that exemptions are being given to property that deserve them," said David Moog, president of the local union of city assessors and appraisers. "And this problem has only gotten worse in the past year."
Assemblyman McLaughlin, in part because of such complaints, has announced he will open an investigation into the city property tax assessment system.
Ms. Stark called the complaints "outrageous and destructive."
"The city does a timely job of adding new construction to the tax rolls," she said. Tax exemptions are properly screened before they are granted, she said, and the Bloomberg administration stood behind the legislative bills intended to help remake her agency, even if she was disappointed that just one of the five proposals was enacted.
Ms. Stark also provided an analysis of city assessments of one- to three-family homes, which showed that in all but Manhattan, the full-market values the city assigned to them, on average, are close to actual sales values. Her spokesman said that the department needs to do a better job on homes in Manhattan.
Ms. Stark's most prominent initiative to date -- to revamp the way office buildings and other commercial properties are assessed -- has struggled so far.
The problem she faced was that building owners have routinely ignored a city requirement that they submit information on how much money they make by renting out their buildings, figures that the assessors are supposed to use in calculating how much the property is worth. At other times, they submit information that is out of date. This has meant that the assessors have to make their own judgments on the likely income or expenses in a certain building, guesswork that left the city assessors vulnerable to being improperly influenced by property owners.
To remedy these problems, Ms. Stark proposed something fairly radical: eliminate the annual reports and rely instead on data generated by real estate and consulting firms that publish surveys of office vacancy and income and expense data for groups of buildings by neighborhood. Using this publicly available data and a computer, assessors could more quickly and reliably arrive at assessments for office buildings.
The proposal, first floated by Ms. Stark in September 2002, was immediately condemned by the real estate industry. "Dumbed-down, inaccurate assessments," is what this approach would produce, said one real estate lawyer, who asked not to be named because he did not wish to openly criticize the city.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York went on the record, saying that Ms. Stark's plan was "ill advised and contrary to law." The commissioner has since backed down, suggesting now that the annual reports of income and expenses still be used in arriving at the assessment, but that the information no longer be kept confidential, so that the process is at least not as obscure.
But even a compromise change in the system has yet to be put into practice. Ms. Stark, a lawyer who first worked in the Finance Department during the Dinkins administration, said she never figured that remaking the agency was going to happen overnight.
"Important projects take time," she said. "What you've got to be is steadfast and determined."

HEADLINE: Japanese Stay on Sidelines As Nikkei Stages a Big Rally 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 7 

 BODY:
A funny thing happened on the way to Japan's stock market rally: the Japanese did not show up.
 Since the end of April, when the Nikkei 225 hit a two-decade low, Japan's benchmark index has soared nearly 30 percent. But Japanese banks, life insurers and consumers, who hold the world's largest pool of savings, have mostly stood on the sidelines, even selling into the rally. 
 Instead, foreign mutual funds, hedge funds and other institutional investors from overseas have piled into the market here, investing 10 times as much money in Japanese stocks as local investors did in June, according to Finance Ministry figures. Since late April, the 57 United States-based Japanese equity mutual funds that AMG Data Services tracks have increased their investments by 61 percent, to $2.54 billion. 
The buying continued today when the Nikkei 225 index jumped another 2.6 percent, hitting a 10-month high of 9,795.
The divergent behavior of locals and foreigners is no small curiosity. Unless Japan's pension funds and investment trusts begin buying shares, too, the current rally could peter out before it really gathers momentum. If the nascent recovery falters or Japan's banks swoon again, foreign investors, who make up about 18 percent of the market, could lose confidence and start selling their shares.
Getting the locals on board, though, will not be easy, because their agenda differs from that of the foreigners. Many American and European fund managers looking at the global investment landscape say Japanese stocks are cheap, particularly blue chips like Matsushita Electric Industrial and Honda Motor. They are also encouraged by the recent 2 trillion yen ($16.7 billion) bailout of Resona Holdings because it signaled that the government would not let the country's financial system spin out of control, thus protecting shareholders.
While Japanese banks and insurers might agree that stocks are inexpensive, the government wants them to reduce their holdings to no more than 100 percent of their capital by 2004. To meet this goal, they must sell about another 4 trillion yen ($33.9 billion) in shares and shift the money into bonds and other less risky assets. The government and central bank have set up funds to make it easier for financial institutions to unload these stocks.
For their part, many Japanese companies are returning huge parcels of stock they have managed on behalf of the government's public pension system. A growing list of companies are also setting up 401(k)-style funds that shift the responsibility for managing pensions to workers.
Then there are the incentives that drive fund managers on both sides of the Pacific. American and European investment managers are paid bonuses based on how well their funds outperform the leading benchmarks, a system that pushes them to take bolder stakes. Japanese fund managers, who receive most of their compensation in the form of salaries, are more comfortable simply matching the broader market's performance.
This approach helps explain why in 1998, foreigners were also the first to dip back into the market after the government assembled a record 24 trillion yen ($200 billion) stimulus package and an even larger bailout of the banking system. It was only in 1999, after the economy had rebounded and the Nikkei 225 approached 20,000, that local investors felt secure enough to return to the stock market.
Unfortunately for them, the rally sputtered in early 2000 and, as foreigners headed for the exits, Japanese fund managers were forced to absorb huge losses.
"Psychologically, Japanese investors are very scarred," said Marc Desmidt, managing director at Merrill Lynch Investment Managersin Tokyo, which manages $7.8 billion in Japanese equities. "Now, if they see the market bounce up, they take their money off the table."
This caution has even affected the government, which typically tries to seize good news to trumpet its own policies. Last week, the chief cabinet secretary, Yasuo Fukuda, tried to play down the Nikkei's recent gains, warning that rising stock prices do not necessarily mean the economy has fully recovered.
Indeed, there are plenty of reasons to remain wary. The economy barely grew in the first quarter, and unemployment remains stubbornly high. Though interest rates are near zero, banks continue to reduce their loan books, which prevents the creation of new jobs. Companies are also under pressure to cut costs to offset the five-year decline in prices, which, perversely, may make the economy worse in the short term.
"Japanese have become used to deflation and think it won't disappear soon because there is still so much restructuring that needs to be done," said Katsumi Minai, a manager in the global investment department at the Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Company.
Still, if the Japanese stock market continues to improve, local investors are bound to take notice and increase their stakes. That will probably happen in October, when the second half of Japan's fiscal year begins. The crucial question is whether the rally will have exhausted itself by then, or will gain renewed momentum from the extra infusion of cash. If history is any guide, some fund managers say, the locals may have already missed the biggest gains.
"Japanese investors are late participants," said Atsuto Sawakami, who runs the Sawakami Fund, which has 49 billion yen ($415 million) in Japanese equities. "They are always the last ones in and the last ones out."

HEADLINE: Jobless but Not Hopeless 

BYLINE:  By Robert C. Pozen; Robert C. Pozen, a visiting professor at Harvard Law School, is the Massachusetts secretary for economic affairs.

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
When the United States unemployment rate climbed to 6.4 percent last week, the highest point in almost a decade, analysts were generally glum about the prospects for job seekers. They were being far too pessimistic, however: a close look at four other economic indicators point to the end of what some have called the "jobless" recovery. These indicators show significant declines in the rate of job losses -- and positive signs of new hiring in growing industries. 
 First, a set of surveys of corporate chief executives taken over the last month reveal that more than one-third of them are planning to hire in the third quarter and very few are planning to lay off workers. These surveys, conducted by the Center for State and Local Policy at the University of Massachusetts, polled 400 chief executives in Boston, Chicago, Dallas and San Francisco. The key question posed was this: In the next three months, the third quarter of 2003, will the number of employees at your company increase, stay the same or decrease? In total, 36 percent said the number would increase, 54 percent said stay the same, and 10 percent said decrease. These answers are quite upbeat compared with the employer pessimism that prevailed early in the year. 
 Second, in May and June, the Labor Department reported a rise in the number of temporary workers -- often a first hint of a rebound. Temporary workers are generally the first to be fired as times get bad and the first to be hired as times become good. In April, 1.6 percent of all workers were temporary employees, but that figure rose to 1.7 percent by June. This rise may be small in magnitude, but it represents a significant trend and a practical opportunity for unemployed workers.
Third, the number of wage and salary workers in the non-farm sector has actually risen by 266,000 since Jan. 1, according to the Labor Department's household survey. This rise contrasts sharply with the large loss of 1.4 million of those workers in 2001 and 2002. This sharp contrast strongly suggests a turnaround in the labor market, despite reservations about the statistics in the household survey. (The numbers for the total civilian population used for extrapolation in the survey sample haven't been adjusted for the call-up of reservists for the war in Iraq; but the absence of this adjustment probably accounts for only half of the increase.) 
Finally, the survey of employers also done by the Labor Department shows a modest decline of 30,000 jobs from May to June. This represents a big improvement in the rate of job decline over 2001 and 2002, a period when employers reported whopping losses of 2.2 million jobs -- an average loss of 90,000 jobs per month. 
In short, when the Federal Reserve Board talked in late June about "labor and product markets that are stabilizing," it was making an important point -- in its characteristically obscure and understated manner. The rates of change in recent Labor Department surveys, reinforced by the optimism in the recent set of chief executive surveys, strongly suggest that the job market is about to turn the corner. The trend in these surveys may mean an end to the "jobless" recovery as more Americans find work outside manufacturing -- in areas like education, health care and credit services.
The hot market for housing sales and mortgage refinancing means that jobs related to providing mortgage credit are growing. Because of retirements, high schools will be looking for new teachers, especially in math and sciences. And as the American population ages, more nurses will have to be trained, and so will pharmacy and radiation technicians. 
So job seekers should be flexible -- prepared to take temporary work that may lead to a permanent job, and ready to retrain in response to employers' evolving needs -- at this turning point in the labor market.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life; 
Just Can't Get Enough of That Romantic R&B

BYLINE:  By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 6 

 BODY:
"It's like Mardi Gras," Alfred Moses Jr. said as he tried to edge his airport shuttle van through the crowded streets of the French Quarter here. "This sure brings a lot of business down here." 
 The two events that New Orleans is best known for are Mardi Gras and the Jazz and Heritage Festival, each a pilgrimage for a different type of reveler. But with much less fanfare a third event, the Essence Music Festival has also been closing down Bourbon Street for a few days every year, drawing tens of thousands of tourists looking for fun, music and alcohol in to-go cups. 
 Now in its ninth year, the festival has attracted headliners like the Isley Brothers, Aretha Franklin, the O'Jays, Mary J. Blige and Boyz II Men. But these are familiar national touring acts, and the festival itself is linked not to the city's culture -- as Mardi Gras and the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival are -- but to a magazine, Essence. So to an outside observer, the Essence festival doesn't seem unusual at first glance. But step inside the Louisiana Superdome, where three nights of concerts took place this weekend with performers like Stevie Wonder, Anita Baker, Yolanda Adams and Smokey Robinson in front of some 35,000 fans, and it becomes immediately clear that this is not a concert but an experience. 
"Just wait until the closing night, with Frankie Beverly and Maze," said the mayor of New Orleans, C. Ray Nagin, as he ate dinner backstage on the first night of the festival. "When you see the entire stadium floor doing the slide, it's unbelievable."
Essence, the 33-year-old lifestyle magazine for African-American women, with one million circulation, caters to an audience that is largely neglected by Hollywood and the mainstream culture industry. If one looks at the charts, Frankie Beverly and Maze, for example, have never had a Top 40 single. But to see the stadium full of people on their feet singing along and doing the electric slide to "Joy and Pain" on Saturday night was to realize that the music has had an impact that can't be captured on a marketing-research spreadsheet.
"When this festival started in 1995, rap was the biggest thing in music," said Quint Davis, a producer of the festival. "But we didn't have any rap. We had Luther Vandross and Patti LaBelle and B. B. King, and we drew 100,000 people. And this came as a shock to the industry. The gathering of the Essence family of successful African-Americans who are middle and upper class hadn't been seen in New Orleans -- and perhaps anywhere else. I don't think people realized the large-scale economic influence of this community."
Edward Lewis, the co-founder of Essence, said the festival was the largest gathering of African-Americans in the country: "I try to tell people what it's like, but am not able to put into words the experience of being here and seeing this shared family from all over the country and the Caribbean. People come dressed to the nines to have a good time."
The discerning Essence Festival audience, however, is not the easiest crowd to play to, as Erykah Badu, the idiosyncratic soul singer, found out on opening night. She strode slowly onstage with a stick of clove-smelling incense burning in her mouth, calm and in control. But her cool facade soon cracked as the audience sat still and responded only tepidly to her singing. 
"What are you yawning for?" she asked one audience member. "You're too old to be here anyway."
To get the audience on its feet, she played songs by Dr. Dre and Zapp from her CD player, but it helped only marginally. "I hope you all don't treat Stevie Wonder like this when he's out here," Ms. Badu said. Then she added that he wouldn't know anyway since he can't see the audience.
The lesson here is that you can't demand an audience response. You must work for it. When it was Mr. Wonder's turn to perform, that's exactly what he did. Despite some technical glitches early in his set that might have soured a more temperamental performer, Mr. Wonder, performing his only scheduled concert of the year, was soon in a radiant mood. After a slower new song, "True Love," he found his pace and tore into hit after hit. For "Do I Do," he even climbed on top of his piano bench. In a set that stretched until after 3 a.m., he often improvised nonsense words and slightly naughty rhymes like a gleeful schoolchild, pausing between songs to sip honey out of a plastic bear.
A shirtless LL Cool J, performing his early hits the following night, was also effective in bringing the audience to its feet.
In the conference rooms of the arena, four additional stages were set up for smaller performances. Among the highlights were the indefatigable Chuck Brown and the Soul Searchers, the unearthly Bobby Blue Bland, the old-school rap of Doug E. Fresh and Biz Markie, and a back-to-his-roots Keith Sweat. 
Mr. Vandross was originally scheduled to headline the festival on the second night, but still recovering from a stroke, he was unable to make it. His band members did show up, and a variety of guests joined them for a tribute. Many of the younger pop stars, like Ashanti, Faith Evans and Jaheim, may all have good voices, but few were able to turn what seemed on the surface like cliched lyrics into affecting love songs. Usher worked admirably with "A House Is Not a Home" and "Never Too Much," but in the end came off as overwrought. 
In the end, Gerald Levert stole the show when he joined Ms. LaBelle for "If Only for One Night." Dressed in a pink shirt and a white suit with a matching pink handkerchief, he added playful energy to a tribute that for all its peak moments sometimes drooped.
Instead of engaging in histrionics to show how hard he was singing, he chose to goof off, like a comedian in a Luther Vandross karaoke show. But vocally he still delivered, sometimes with improvised jokes that sent peals of laughter echoing through the stadium. After the song's emotional crescendo, he dropped to his knees in front of Ms. LaBelle and ran the tassles on her canary-yellow dress through his hands as he bellowed, to her surprise, "I wanna play with your shingles, baby."

HEADLINE: In Sound's New Economy, Fewer Old Salts; 
Lobstermen Are Giving Way to Leisure Fishing and Shellfish Hatcheries

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: NORTHPORT, N.Y., July 6 

 BODY:
The traditions and values of earning a living from the waters of Long Island Sound find their purest expression around dawn. That is the moment of departure, the fisherman's great daily leap of faith: one little boat with a little crew sailing out of a mist-cloaked harbor to catch what nature and luck might bestow.
 But in the new marine economy of the 21st century that is unfolding all over the Sound's 110-mile arc from New York City to southern New England, luck is not what it used to be, and neither is nature. Predictable business models are in. Trusting to the beneficence of the sea? As dated as a tour before the mast. 
 For a glimpse into this new economic order, consider Chef Brett's Famous Crab Cakes. Until the late 1990's, Northport Fish and Lobster, where the cakes are sold, was a no-frills joint. Boneless filet was as fancy as it got. Lobster wholesaling was the volume business. As many as 9,000 pounds of wriggling lobsters passed through the store's tanks in a day, six days a week, bound for restaurants and markets all over the East Coast. 
Then, in late 1999, the Sound's lobsters began to die, for reasons that scientists have still not fully explained, and Northport Fish was thrown into crisis. So the owner improvised, reinventing the shop as an upscale catering and prepared foods business, and hired a trained chef, Brett Kaplan, to lead the transformation. Mr. Kaplan's crab cakes, selling for $2.50 a pop -- made from Maryland crabs, by the way -- became a best seller, supplanting the local lobsters. The lobstermen who once arrived in a daily cavalcade to sell their catches drifted away. 
"I felt for the lobster guys because I was kind of in the same boat," said Eric Gusew, Northport Fish's owner. "But I had ways to change my livelihood and adapt, and they didn't. I moved on."
Moving on is a sentiment one hears a lot these days in towns around the Sound's shore. The Sound generates at least $5 billion in economic activity, according to a study in the early 1990's commissioned by the federal government. But the mixture of that economy is evolving to a new place because of changes in the environment -- the result of deliberate human management and population growth. The question of who will win and who will lose is now playing out on the water and on the land.
Managed marine farming of shellfish like oysters, clams and scallops has surged, for example, even as the lobster trade faded. Hatchery-raised shellfish, sheltered from the vicissitudes of the wild, account for about half of the Sound's production, industry officials say, up from about 5 percent a decade ago.
The tourism and leisure trade -- from sport fishing to pleasure boating to vacation-home development -- also increasingly dwarfs the commercial fishing business of old. Where the two conflict, as they do more and more on the Sound's crowded waters and shores, residents and economists say, the recreation trade has the numbers and financial clout to put its agenda first.
Trends on land are accelerating those changes. Older residents in Northport, just a short hop east from the Nassau-Suffolk line, still remember it as a sleepy fishing village. But now it is an extended suburb of Manhattan, 35 miles to the west, and the many new long-distance commuters are changing the fabric that the fishermen helped define. The new people, residents say, were drawn by the pretty harbor and the small-town feel, not by the clamor and pungent smells of a fishing port.
And as the newcomers were filing in, the fishermen were filing out. Where there were 30 to 40 lobster crews sailing from Northport in the late 1990's, there are now on many mornings only one or two who quietly pack up and chug out into the sunrise.
"There's the old salts that care, but the new people probably love not having them around," said Paul Eliades, the owner of Tidewater Marine Supply, referring to the lobstermen, many of whom, he admits, were his former customers. "You don't have all the guys with their lobster pots, and their trucks filled with bait -- it would stink for days down there." 
John Nixon is one of the expatriates of the crustacean chase.
Mr. Nixon, 40, began fishing when he was 15, but now runs his own handyman business, Nix Maintenance. He trims trees, refinishes driveways -- whatever is called for. His wife, Diana, is pregnant with their first child. The lobsters might come back, Mr. Nixon said, or they might not. But he probably won't be around either way. 
"I can't be playing games," he said at his father's house, a few blocks from the water. "I can't wait around. I'm done."
Down on the docks, only the die-hard fishermen like Peter Ringen are left. He does electrical contracting work in the winter to make ends meet, and said he intends to continue fishing because it's his life. Some days he makes money, and some days -- by the time he has paid for gas and the salary of a deckhand -- he loses. 
"I told my wife I'm going to keep lobstering until I'm totally out of money," he said. 

The New Geography
New Borders Drawn Under the Water
The traditional way to think about Long Island Sound's geography has been the obvious political one -- Connecticut is on one side and New York is on the other. The Sound is also the dividing line on most maps between New England and the Middle Atlantic region. 
But there is a new borderline: within the water column itself.
Out on the Sound's eastern edge, the Mohegan Tribe, owner of the Mohegan Sun Casino, has committed $7 million to a shellfish hatchery and aquaculture program that will grow oysters not on the bottom where they normally sit, but in suspended trays mounted 10 to 12 feet from the bottom, extending up to 10 feet or so below the surface.
"Aquaculture is the next evolutionary step from fishing," said Dr. Paul Maugle, the aquaculture director for Mohegan Aquaculture LLC. The tray system, which has been used in British Columbia and in Asia but never on the East Coast, Dr. Maugle said, allows the animals to grow in cleaner water, and protects them from predators like starfish and crabs that live on the bottom.
New economic forms have emerged as well. In Groton, not far from the Mohegans, a group of small shellfish-growers from Connecticut and New York have combined into what they say is the first cooperative shellfish hatchery in the world. 
"It's about predictability," said Jim Markow, the president of the Noank Aquaculture Cooperative, which is growing millions of oysters, clams and scallops in bins and tubs in a small building on the shore. "We can't come close to competing with nature," Mr. Markow said. "But it's steady, and you can build a business on it."
The rifts around these new borders can run deep. Many boaters and fishermen in eastern Connecticut, for example, strongly opposed the Mohegan aquaculture plan. They said that dividing up the water column would put into private control a piece of the water that is now public domain for use by all, and that it would interfere with navigation. Federal and state regulators disagreed and approved the project last August. It is now under construction.
A similar proposal for the waters off the coast of Westport has also drawn fire from boaters who say the racks will destroy the use of a sailboat racecourse that has been used since the late 1880's.
The Westport developer, Dr. John M. Garofalo -- an obstetrician who founded his company, Mariculture Unlimited, two years ago -- said he specifically patterned his plan after the Mohegan project. The leases he has signed with the state give him the right to use the bottom, and he contends that the use of the water column above that, which requires a separate approval from the state and United States Army Corps of Engineers, would be far enough below the surface -- 17 feet at high tide -- to be unobtrusive. 
"We're asking for the same thing, the same kind of gear as the Mohegans, and if they don't give it to us, they have to explain what makes us different," he said. 
The new economic terrain is even coming with its own brands. At the Noank cooperative, for example, breeders are working specifically with a type of hard clam species that grows a characteristic stripe on its shell. The stripe occurs in the wild in only about 1 percent of the population, but the Noank breeders are using that genetic strain, as ranchers once labeled their steers with a bar X, to mark the borders of their clam beds and act as easily checked sentinels for the health of the crop. 

At Sea
The Stripers Are Biting
On a recent gray afternoon off the coast of Milford, Conn., aboard the research vessel John Dempsey, David Simpson gently cradled a big striped bass in his arms. The fish had done its bit for science -- it was measured and weighed in at nearly 18 pounds -- and now it was time to return to the water. 
Other people on the boat were flinging fish over the side without hesitation. Mr. Simpson, a supervising fisheries biologist for the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, walked to the boat's side and gently launched the big fish back into water, head first. In a silver flash, it was gone into the deep.
The striped bass population in the Sound declined to almost nothing about 20 years ago, and now the fish's numbers are back and booming. The resurgence has been one of Mr. Simpson's career markers, and he said he has a soft spot for the fish. But it has also marked a victory for those who said the Sound could be managed.
Some scientists and government officials argued in the 1980's, when the stripers had all but disappeared, that the Sound's environment had become too polluted to support the fish's return. Others said the striped bass could be restored through wildlife management and fishing restrictions. The people who said the fish could return won the argument. Striped bass has never been harvested commercially, but they are economically vital to the Sound as perhaps the most sought-after fish by recreational fishermen who spend millions each year on equipment, gasoline and supplies.
"In 1984, when we started these surveys, if we caught one striper, we'd go, 'Whoa,' " Mr. Simpson said, standing on the deck of the Dempsey. "Now in just this one pull of net, we got, what, 120 pounds or more."
The "nature can be managed" lesson of the stripers has rippled in many places.
At the National Marine Fisheries Service laboratory in Milford, scientists are working on ways to trick scallops into skipping their winter naps. Scallops, rather like bears, go into a dormant hibernation-like period in winter. But then during their scallop wake-up call in spring, many are eaten or die for reasons not well understood. The goal at the fisheries lab is to get the scallops to spawn in the hatchery in winter, bypassing the dangerous dormant stage.
"Technically we know we can do it; the question is whether we can do it economically so that value justifies the process," said Gary H. Wikfors, a research microbiologist at the lab. "It's engineering and economics together to make the biology work."
In the new managed world of the marine food supply, researchers like Dr. Wikfors say the next frontier will be all about the subtleties. The methodology of growing oysters in labs and hatcheries is now second nature. The science of making them grow faster or fatter is still being fine-tuned.
One of the discoveries: Oysters do better when they are a little stressed out. In the perfect conditions of the hatcheries, growers have found, oysters tend to get a bit too laid back. Giving the oysters a break from their dull routine -- from say, sudden jolts of temperature change in their water -- tends to make them healthier, with stronger immune systems that can fight off disease.

On Land
The Human Impact Is Evaluated
There is a deep paradox in the heart of the Sound's new economy: an improving environmental picture over the last decade coincided precisely with a profound challenge to the rhythms of the old commercial culture. Just as things were starting to get better -- very good for the recreational boating, fishing and tourism industry -- the fishermen who had hung on through better and worse did not get asked to the dance. Most of the Sound's oysters were killed in the mid-1990's by two shellfish parasites called MSX and Dermo; the lobsters followed suit a few years later.
Ecologists say that raises major questions about what sort of impact human beings are really having on the estuary.
Improving water quality, for example, is a boon to the housing industry, as more and more people pay top dollar for a shore view and shore access. And some scientists, along with many fishermen, feel that more shore development changed the habitats for both lobsters and their bivalve cousins -- the oysters, scallops and clams -- and perhaps contributed to diseases that took them. 
Many lobster fishermen, in particular, are vehement in their belief that pesticides sprayed in the summer of 1999 to kill mosquitoes bearing the West Nile Virus killed the lobsters, as rainwater from the torrential downpour of Tropical Storm Floyd, which struck the region that September, washed the poisons into the Sound from the newly built-up areas. Some of the new fishery management entrepreneurs say they worry about some of the same things.
"A lot of the shoreline has been developed in the last 20 years -- loss of marsh grasses, new trophy homes, a lot more hardening of the shoreline, a lot more activity on the water," said Karen Rivara, a marine biologist and founding member of the Noank Aquaculture Co-op. "The water is not the same as it was."
The resulting question, ecologists say, is who really lives most lightly on the Sound -- the working class fishermen, or the affluent newcomers who work in offices, but grow a chemically treated lawn right down to the water's edge? And if the improvement of the Sound leads to even more sprawl on its shores, might the goals of environmental management turn into a kind of Catch-22 -- the more they work, the more they fail?
"If we succeed, we may not like where we wind up," said Roger Tollefsen, a chemical engineer and president of the New York Seafood Council.
And there is the question of how the Sound's changes affect the economies of the communities on land. In places like Northport, officials say, a more attractive Sound, with its resulting higher property values, is squeezing out less-affluent wage earners, from fishermen to teachers and carpenters.
"I think it's healthy for the community, for the village, to have economic diversity -- I don't want it all white collar," said Peter G. Panarites, the mayor of Northport. "But truthfully speaking, I think we are slowly losing the diversity, just like we're losing our open space."

Human Nature
Over many years of settlement, Long Island Sound has been a breadbasket and a dumping ground, a private playground for the wealthy and a symbol of environmental despair. 
But when people reached for a new definition -- a repaired, restored, managed Sound -- nature did not respond according to the rulebook. 
For every push to achieve a certain end, the whorls of the ecosystem have pushed right back, often in unexpected ways. 
This is the fourth of a summer-long series of articles on the evolving nature of Long Island Sound. The fifth article will visit a popular beach on Long Island, where boaters, picnickers and nesting diamondback terrapins -- and a scientific team studying the little turtles -- somehow coexist.
Additional materials, including a preview of the remainder of the series, can be found on the Web at nytimes.com/lisound.

HEADLINE: Iran Confirms Test of Missile That Is Able To Hit Israel 

BYLINE:  By NAZILA FATHI 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, July 7 

 BODY:
Iran has successfully conducted the final test of a midrange missile, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry here confirmed today.
 The missile, called Shahab-3, was first tested in 1998 and has a range of 806 to 930 miles, which means it can reach Israel and American troops stationed in Saudi Arabia and Iraq. 
 The spokesman, Hamidreza Assefi, was responding to a report in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz last week, which said the test had been carried out just over a week before. 
"Apparently, the Israelis are late in getting the information," Mr. Assefi said at the Iranian Foreign Ministry's weekly news briefing. "The test took place several weeks ago, and it was a final test before delivering the missile to the armed forces. It was within the same range that we had declared before."
Iran contends that the missile relies entirely on Iranian expertise, but it is widely believed that the Shahab, or shooting star in Persian, employs North Korean technology. The United States Department of State imposed penalties on a North Korean company and five Chinese companies last week, saying they sold missile technology to Iran.
"We are very concerned, especially since we know that Iran is seeking to acquire the nuclear weapon," an Israeli government spokesman, Avi Pazner, said immediately after the Iranian confirmation, according to a report from Agence France-Presse.
"The combination of Shahab-3 and the nuclear weapon would be a very serious threat on the stability of the region," he added, according to the report. 
The United States said today that it had "very serious concerns" about Iran's missile programs and that it viewed them as a threat to the region and to American interests. But American officials said that the latest test flight was one of several in recent years and that it was not a particular surprise.
"We have long had very serious concerns about Iranian missile programs," said Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman. He said the United States had noted Iran's efforts to develop its missile abilities for nearly two decades.
He said that the missile program was "a threat to the region and a threat to U.S. interests in the region" but that it would be addressed with diplomatic, political and economic pressure with "like-minded countries" along with other Iranian activities, including its nuclear weapons program.
Last month, the International Atomic Energy Agency declared that Iran had secretly processed nuclear material. Iran has denied those accusations, insisting that its nuclear research is meant only for peaceful purposes like energy.
Foreign Minister Jack Straw of Britain, during a visit to Iran last month, said the European Union would cut trade ties with Tehran if it refused to open its sites to inspections.
Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, the director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, is scheduled to visit Iran on Wednesday. He is expected to urge the Iranians to sign a protocol that would allow the agency's inspectors to make surprise visits to nuclear sites and to take samples.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Fraud's Reach In Big Business 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Fraud and other kinds of economic crime have victimized more than a third of the companies surveyed by the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers and the law firm of Wilmer Cutler & Pickering over the last few months.
 About 36 percent of the companies whose executives completed the survey responded that they had been victims of asset misappropriation -- usually theft or embezzlement -- or some other kind of economic crime in the last two years. 
 The study also found that while executives feared that financial misrepresentation -- tampering with balance sheets or earnings reports -- was rampant, only two of the surveyed companies said they had suffered from such a manipulation. 
"One way of looking at that is the people who are in-house are like the rest of the public, in that there is a greatly heightened sensitivity" to games played with financial disclosures, said Andrew D. Kaizer, a partner at Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering who primarily represents institutions involved in investigations of economic crimes.
The survey was sent to several hundred of the nation's 1,000 largest companies and 91 responded; it was the United States component of a global survey of economic crime conducted for the first time by PricewaterhouseCoopers. Economic crime encompasses a range of activities, including cybercrimes, like attacks on corporate Web sites, and counterfeiting. The results are expected to be released today.
The survey found that half of the detected economic crimes at responding companies were found by auditors, but it did not distinguish between internal and external audits, Mr. Kaizer said. Another 36 percent of the frauds were reported by whistle-blowers.
Although 76 percent of the United States respondents were covered by insurance, fewer than half were able to recover from their insurers. And less than a third of insured companies affected by fraud collected more than 20 percent of the amount lost.
"The degree to which people have insurance and are unable to get recovery is a bit surprising," Mr. Kaizer said. He speculated that high deductibles or a practice of self-insuring might be the cause.
The results differed in a few areas from those of the study PricewaterhouseCoopers conducted in foreign countries. United States-based companies were found to be more likely to have some insurance coverage, for example, and executives in the United States were more worried about misrepresentation of a company's finances than their counterparts overseas. In companies in other countries, whistle-blowers were less likely to expose frauds, the study found.
The study of regions outside the United States, which has been conducted for three years now, also found that the reported incidence of economic crime had increased, rising to 34 percent of respondents in Western Europe in 2003 from 29 percent in 2001, and to 37 percent from 26 percent in Central and Eastern Europe, for example.
The average amount lost, according to the most recent survey results, was $2.2 million, and the highest levels of economic crime were reported in Africa and North America (including Canada and the United States).

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
How a Seed-Money Loan of $60 Turned Melanie Pico Into an Entrepreneur

BYLINE:  By ANDRES MARTINEZ 

DATELINE: CALINAN, the Philippines 

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine that there's anything cutting-edge about this hardscrabble town on the Philippine island of Mindanao, which is best known for the ferocity of its various antigovernment insurgencies. But just off the main road, down a dusty alleyway and past the naked children and the few stray dogs at play, Melanie Pico sits in her tidy, modest home acting out one of the hottest trends in global finance and development theory. She is an entrepreneurial client of a microfinancing organization.
 She looked up from her sewing machine to rattle off the arithmetic of her life. She clears 1 peso and 80 centavos in profit -- about 3 American pennies -- for each market shopping bag she produces from recycled cement wrapping. If the back pain doesn't get to be too much and she can sit at her machine for 16 hours in a day, she can stitch together as many as 420 bags. Her hard work brings in, on average, 3,000 pesos a week, the equivalent of nearly $60, a princely sum in a region where many farmers make do on a dollar a day. 
 Until recently, Ms. Pico, a 42-year-old mother of four whose husband works as a security guard, made less than half that amount. All it took to change her fortune was a $60 loan from the Mindanao Enterprise Development Foundation, a local microfinancing organization that promises clients a "hand up, not a handout."
"Sixty dollars may not sound like much to us, but in a place like the Philippines it can be enough to get a family going, allowing them to buy a cow or goods to sell in the marketplace," said Nancy Barry, president of Women's World Banking, a New York-based network and resource center for microfinancing organizations around the world. "The hope over time is that the $60 becomes $100, then $500, and before you know it, these clients are integrated into the mainstream economy."
The Mindanao development foundation is following the example of the famous Grameen Bank in Bangladesh by lending to groups of neighbors, who essentially guarantee one another's loans. It is focusing its group lending entirely on women clients, a trend in microfinancing. 
"Women manage most household economies," Ms. Barry said. "Low-income women think long-term. They plan not only for their children, but for their children's children, making them the bridge to the future and a good investment proposition." 
Ms. Pico is one of three in her group of borrowers. Once a week, they discuss their separate businesses and make payments on their six-month loan. "I keep a closer eye now on whether my neighbors work hard," Ms. Pico said with a laugh. The foundation says no group of borrowers has defaulted.
One of microfinancing's cardinal rules is that borrowers, though they may lack collateral, must be treated as serious business people, not charitable cases, so the Mindanao foundation charges 3 percent monthly interest. The rates reflect the fact that these organizations face high transaction costs. 
Prospective Mindanao borrowers are required to sit through 10 hours of rudimentary business training. "We are learning about business, about how to become more productive, so that we can improve our lives," Ms. Pico said. "My daughter Maricel is in college and someday, together, we will buy new equipment, put up a factory and hire people."
Nearby, Priscilla Magarin, a 43-year-old widow, invested the 3,000 pesos she borrowed from the Mindanao foundation in a typical village "sari-sari" variety store attached to her home. She makes anywhere from $4 to $8 a day.
That's not counting the intangible dividends. "If you have a business like this and run it properly, your standing in the community improves, and suddenly people are looking at women in a different way," she explained.
Microfinancing is a grass-roots development tool that works best when run as a viable business, independent of government. While the emphasis once was solely on making loans, the latest trend is to offer clients a range of financial services. Governments are rightly being exhorted to regulate microfinancing institutions as a legitimate part of the financial sector. The Philippines has done so, and the Mindanao foundation's clients participate in a savings plan, too.
Remittances, the private flows of money sent home to developing nations by workers overseas, are fast becoming the cherished "El Dorado" for microfinancing promoters, as they are for plenty of other development schemes. It is estimated that last year the amount of money sent home by migrant workers -- some $80 billion -- overshadowed for the first time the amount of total aid and credit (both private and public) extended to poor countries. In the case of the Philippines, long known for exporting labor, remittances are one of the few things the nation's economy has going for it these days, amounting to some $7 billion a year.
Outfits like the Asian Development Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank see a natural fit between remittances and microfinancing. The challenge for them, and for policy makers from Manila to Bogota, is to find ways to deliver on this promise, both by enabling microfinancing groups to help speed the transfer of funds to remote villages at a lower cost and by providing a pool of working capital for microfinancing. 
If microfinancing can indeed tap into these flows of capital in a significant way, overseas workers sending money home will have given their communities a "hand up" in more ways than one.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Information On-Ramp Crosses a Digital Divide

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. 

 BODY:
Children who show up this month for basketball camp at the Carl Russell Recreation Center here will find some unexpected drills on their schedule. 
 Aaron Bailey, the recreation center's director, plans to take advantage of breaks in the hoops action to send the campers to the center's newest addition, a computer room stuffed with 10 refurbished computers, all with high-speed Internet connections. The aim is to help make the youngsters as agile on computers as they are on the courts. "I might even send the campers in before I let them play basketball," Mr. Bailey told a visitor recently. 
 Mr. Bailey's center is being linked to 35 other sites around Winston-Salem -- recreation centers, churches in the city's poorest neighborhoods, libraries, schools and a homeless shelter -- in the first phase of WinstonNet, one of the most advanced and broadest efforts yet by public and private groups in an American city to bridge the so-called digital divide between the haves and have-nots. 
For years, community activists and politicians around the country have talked about the need to help people who have been left behind in the digital revolution because of poverty, disabilities or fear of new technology. Without computer literacy, the argument goes, disadvantaged groups will become more excluded in the high-tech economy. Yet many efforts have meant little more than making it possible for people to surf the Web from a library terminal. 
WinstonNet -- which is based on a fiber optic ring that surrounds the city center and links to Internet 2, the newest, highest-capacity piece of the Internet -- goes beyond providing free access to computers for those who do not own them.
It will allow any resident with a library card to have an e-mail account; transact business with the city, like payment of parking tickets; and store homework or other documents on a central server so they can be easily retrieved from any site on the network.
Documents can be stored in a private file, in a file available to a limited number of other users or in a file open to the public. Parents can gain access to school assignments and communicate with teachers by calling up Learning Village, a software program donated by the I.B.M. Foundation.
Perhaps most important, the plan focuses on giving first-time users plenty of computer training. Instructors at the WinstonNet site in the basement of the Union Baptist Church, for instance, helped teenagers from a nearby housing project learn to use computers in creating business plans for their own summer businesses. 
"The digital divide problem has been defined mainly in terms of access, but it needs to be defined more broadly as a matter of skill," said Karen Mossberger, an associate professor of political science at Kent State University in Ohio.
As a bonus, the training process can also open the door to mentoring disadvantaged youngsters. 
Winston-Salem officials say WinstonNet, in addition to doing social good, can be an economic catalyst for the city, best known as the home of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. The city is struggling to reduce its dependence on tobacco and manufacturing. 
The fiber optic ring will provide a broadband communications link for engineering and biotechnology businesses that need to send and receive huge masses of data. Targacept, an RJR spinoff that is developing medical products based on nicotine, is expected to connect to WinstonNet by the end of this year.
Tying so many organizations into the same system will make it easier to train many more users, said Johannes Boehme II, associate dean for academic computing at the Wake Forest University School of Medicine, who serves as WinstonNet's volunteer president.
"Very few communities do this holistically," Mr. Boehme said.
While that may be true, some social service organizations and communities had digital access programs long before WinstonNet. 
Boys and Girls Clubs of America, for example, has used $100 million in software and cash from Microsoft to create more than 1,000 community technology centers around the country where children use computers to do homework and learn skills like designing Web sites. 
The Blacksburg Electronic Village, a project of Blacksburg, Va., and the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, says it has helped 87 percent of the community's residents and most of its businesses become connected to the Internet, with more than 60 percent receiving low-cost high-speed connections from local cable and phone companies. 
And Atlanta estimates it has attracted about 15,000 residents, over one-third of them children, in the last two years to 15 community technology centers in poor neighborhoods. That program also includes a mobile computing center in a bus that carries 12 computers with wireless broadband connections to poor neighborhoods, according to William Lindsey, a spokesman for the Mayor's Office of Community Technology.
"We think we are making big strides to eradicate the digital divide," Mr. Lindsey said. 
But some experts have their doubts. Dr. Lynette Kvasny of Pennsylvania State University recently published a study that concluded that Atlanta's technology centers and a program in La Grange, Ga., offering free Internet access for subscribers to a city-owned cable television system, did little to improve the lives of the poor. The Atlanta model was criticized by some regular users of the centers for providing inadequate training, Dr. Kvasny said.
Some critics say the digital divide evolves so rapidly as technology advances that big initiatives, especially those driven by government policy, can lock users into obsolete technology. 
"It's misguided to look at it as a serious social problem that needs to be dealt with with aggressive subsidies," said Adam D. Thierer, director of telecommunications policies at the Cato Institute, a libertarian policy group in Washington.
In fact, Mr. Thierer said, computer technology is spreading to underserved segments of society unusually rapidly compared with other innovations. Nearly two-thirds of American homes now have a computer, according to Odyssey, a research firm based in San Francisco. 
But the gap between those who are able to use computers effectively and poorer citizens with little exposure may actually be widening, said W. Frank Newton, executive director of the Beaumont Foundation of America, which focuses on digital divide programs. 
Government has become less eager to pay to bridge that gap. President Bush has tried to eliminate technology access programs created by the Clinton administration in the Education and Commerce Departments to help communities bridge the digital divide. Just under $50 million of the cuts was restored by Congress in the spring after a lobbying campaign by a coalition of more than 180 groups. 
And while a controversial universal service charge on long-distance phone bills, established by Congress in 1996, helps some schools and libraries connect to the Internet, that multibillion-dollar fund cannot be used to finance broader projects like WinstonNet. 
State financing for such programs has also been sharply reduced because of budget problems, according to Kavita Singh, executive director of the Community Technology Centers Network in Cambridge, Mass.
WinstonNet began to take shape in flusher times. It grew out of Wake Forest University's drive in the 1990's to make itself a leader in using computers in education. Wake Forest has been giving every student a laptop since 1996. It decided in 1998 to replace the first-generation broadband lines connecting its medical school with the main campus on the other side of the city and a research center downtown, replacing them with the ultimate in broadband, a private fiber optic highway. 
That network, later sold to a telecommunications subsidiary of Duke Energy, had enough spare capacity to spur community discussions about who else might use it. Among the groups involved were Forsyth Technical Community College, which trains student volunteers to refurbish donated computers and wire them into the network; Winston-Salem State University, a historically black college that has extensive outreach programs into the city's most depressed neighborhoods; and several local government agencies.
"Turf was removed as an issue at the beginning," said Claudette Weston, who represented the library system in the meetings. "People came to cooperate." 
Each WinstonNet host site pays its own operating costs, including monthly fees to local phone or cable service providers for access to WinstonNet's broadband ring. Hosts are also responsible for developing their own filtering policies.
Now there are discussions about allowing individuals to connect to the WinstonNet system through local phone or cable lines, without going to a WinstonNet site. The local Habitat for Humanity group is proposing that all its renovated homes come equipped with WinstonNet access. 
"As people become more aware of it, the pressure will mount for more access," predicted Don Martin, superintendent of the Winston-Salem/ Forsyth County Schools. Mr. Martin said one possible WinstonNet expansion would create a site in the sprawling Hanes Mall south of the city. "One thing we've learned is that everyone can find their way to the mall."
