HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Reviving a global aluminum merger, and this time offering quite a lot less.

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
COULD it be that the secret to completing a hostile bid in France is to first have a friendly one rejected by the authorities?
 Alcan, the Canadian aluminum giant, surprised investors yesterday by renewing a bid it made in 1999 to take over Pechiney of France. It is offering a lot less than it did nearly four years ago, but since then the stock market bubble has burst and Pechiney's place in the industry has slipped amid consolidation. 
 Pechiney, which learned of the offer a few days before the public, made clear yesterday that it did not like the idea, saying that the price "seriously undervalues" the company. There is every sign Pechiney will resist the offer. 
Still, it represents a 20 percent premium over Pechiney's share price before the offer was made, and Pechiney stock leaped as investors hoped that something would happen -- either an Alcan takeover or a counterbid by some other suitor.
Alcan dismissed any thought that French protectionism might get in the way of its offer. In an interview yesterday, Travis Engen, its chief executive, recalled that there was a lot of support for the proposed takeover in 1999 and added that "if you follow developments in France since then, they have moved further in the direction of opening capital markets."
The 1999 proposal fell apart the next year after the European Commission, the executive agency of the European Union, indicated what divestitures would be needed to satisfy it. Alcan and Pechiney walked away without even submitting a revised proposal. There were reports that the two companies could not agree on a proposal to try to meet the antitrust demands.
This time, two factors are different. First, if the offer remains a hostile one, there is no need for Pechiney to agree to the required divestitures. Second, Alcan knows what was demanded last time. And while it has not exactly said it would meet those demands, it came close to doing so yesterday.
"Based on the requirements made by the merger task force last time, we believe we can satisfy those requirements," said Michael Zaoui, head of European mergers and acquisitions for Morgan Stanley, one of the investment banking firms retained by Alcan.
French government approval is also required because Pechiney is a military contractor. And that is another place where the recent history could help. There was no trouble getting that approval last time, and to not get it this time would inevitably raise cries of protectionism.
Given the strained state of relations between Paris and Washington, it may also help that Alcan is a Canadian company, rather than an American one.
Hostile takeovers remain rare in Europe, and the few big cross-border ones that have been successful have involved bidders from European Union countries.
If this hostile bid were to succeed, it would be interpreted as an indication that trans-Atlantic mergers were easier to conclude than had been thought, and could produce offers for other companies, particularly if merger activity in the United States picks up.
Indeed, American companies might find European company prices attractive. Since the end of 1999, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down about 32 percent. But in that time, many European indexes have fallen further, even though they did not rise as much in the good years. The benchmark French stock index, the CAC 40, is down 47 percent, measured in euros, and almost 40 percent measured in dollars, and even at those levels has outperformed the German market.
American companies wanting to buy European ones would find that cash prices are far lower than a few years ago and that all-stock transactions would be somewhat cheaper measured in shares.
For Pechiney shareholders, time has not been friendly. The 1999 proposal called for a three-way combination involving Alcan, Pechiney and the Alusuisse Lonza Group of Switzerland, now known as the Alusuisse Group. The Alcan takeover of Alusuisse went ahead after the companies met antitrust concerns, but the other part of the deal did not.
Yesterday's offer valued Pechiney at 41 euros a share; the bid in 1999 valued it around 62 euros. Alcan stock's price is down since 1999, but not nearly as much as Pechiney's. In this deal, Pechiney shareholders are being offered a combination of cash and Alcan stock, or a possible choice of either. Those who take Alcan stock would receive 1.5 shares for each Pechiney share. In 1999, the all-stock deal offered a ratio of 1.7876 Alcan shares to each Pechiney share.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Engen declined to say if Alcan was willing to raise the price it would pay. "We think we've made a bid that is quite fully priced," he said. "Demand and economic growth and metals prices are lower than they were then," referring to the 1999 offer.
Asked if he thought a competitive bid was likely, he replied, "Anything is possible," but added that he did not think Pechiney would be worth more to any other bidder.
To shareholders, let alone competitors in the aluminum industry, those questions are important. 
But for international capital markets, the most important question will be what happens if Alcan is not outbid, and if Pechiney management continues to resist the offer. An Alcan success would be seen as a sign that the European takeover market is far more open than many had thought.

HEADLINE: White House Seeks Revised Pension Rules 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is preparing this week to introduce long-awaited pension legislation that could reduce corporate pension liabilities by billions of dollars over the next two years, but would require companies to handle plans more rigorously after that. 
 At first, the proposal would increase the stress on the pension system because it would allow companies to put less money into their funds. After two years, however, companies would have to begin calculating their pension values in an entirely new way. In the past, companies have resisted this method, but independent analysts have praised it as more accurate and prudent than the current methods. 
 To keep shaky pension plans from unraveling during the initial two-year breather, the proposal would also bar companies with insolvent pension plans from promising greater benefits to their employees. 
It would require companies to start disclosing their pension assets and liabilities once a year, measured on a "termination" basis -- the most demanding of the various ways of calculating pension values. Companies currently disclose some pension information in the footnotes of their annual reports, but the accounting rules now allow for considerable blurring of the numbers. The pension accounting rules were written that way in 1985 in an effort to smooth away meaningless pension-fund volatility, but today the rules are widely blamed for distorting the true condition of company pension funds.
For some employees, the administration proposal would reduce lump-sum pension payouts. The reductions would apply only to lump sums from traditional defined-benefit pension plans, only about a third of which permit such payouts. Lump-sum payments from cash-balance pension plans and 401(k) plans would not be affected. 
The proposal, described yesterday by senior Bush administration officials, is expected to be added as an amendment to an existing pension bill in the House, sponsored by Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, and Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat. Certain elements of the administration proposal conflict with elements of the Portman-Cardin bill, and administration officials said those conflicts would have to be worked out separately.
The proposal comes after months of debate about how to keep traditional pension plans healthy at a time when they have come under greater pressure than they have since the government began regulating pensions in 1974. Companies have been warning that they cannot comply with the federal pension-financing laws in today's economic environment, and have threatened to stop offering pensions entirely if they do not receive some relief.
But even as companies have cast a shadow over the future of pensions, employees have developed a newfound appreciation for traditional pensions, after a long bear market that has eaten away at many 401(k) balances and other self-directed retirement accounts. Traditional defined-benefit pension plans offer predetermined lifelong payments that are guaranteed by the federal government and are not eroded when stock prices fall.
At the core of the administration's new plan to resuscitate the troubled pension sector is a proposal to replace the interest rate that companies must use to calculate the liabilities of their pension funds. This rate is controlled by statute and has been linked to the 30-year Treasury bond since 1987.
Companies have complained that the Treasury rate is now artificially low, making their pension obligations balloon. This is because of the way interest rates figure in determining how much money, in today's dollars, corresponds to the amounts that will be paid out in the future. When a company uses a low interest rate, it effectively assumes that its pension fund will compound slowly, making the overall liabilities look big. Using a higher interest rate makes the liabilities look smaller.
The administration plan would help companies by freeing them from the Treasury bond rate entirely. If enacted, it would allow companies to use instead a 20- to 30-year corporate bond rate for two years. Senior administration officials declined to specify which corporate rate they preferred, saying the details could be worked out during the rule-making process if the legislation is enacted. 
Because long-term corporate rates are higher than the 30-year Treasury bond, switching to a corporate bond rate would instantly shrink each company's pension's liabilities, at least on paper. The smaller liability measurements would, in turn, lead to smaller required pension contributions, tiding companies through their current financial difficulties. 
But after two years, the companies would be required to start calculating their obligations with a technique that would combine two new factors: workplace demographics and a corporate bond yield curve. 
Under this system, companies with many retirees and older workers -- like auto manufacturers -- would have to use the interest rate that applies to corporate bonds with shorter maturities. Such bonds normally have lower interest rates, so these companies would soon find their liabilities growing again. 
Companies with younger work forces, meanwhile, would be able to keep using the interest rates attached to longer-duration bonds, which usually have higher interest rates. So their pension contributions would not swell, at least at first.
Independent analysts favor this method, saying it would give a better picture of how big pension values are and when they will come due, substantially reducing the risk of plans collapsing unexpectedly. But when administration officials have floated bond-duration ideas in the past, they have met with hostility from business organizations in Washington. The business groups complain that yield curve concepts are complicated and will take time to carry out, and that they need pension relief immediately.
Administration officials stressed yesterday that their new proposed method would be phased in over three years, giving companies time to adapt. They also noted that the insurance industry already used duration-based valuation methods routinely, so the pension sector should be able to use it as well.

HEADLINE: Proposals Sought for Use Of Brooklyn Container Port 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Port officials asked maritime companies yesterday to submit proposals for using the last active port in Brooklyn as the city proceeds with a separate study to determine its future.
 Expressions of interest in the container port, at Piers 9 to 11 in South Brooklyn, are not binding but would let officials judge the economic viability of maritime activities there. American Stevedoring operates the piers. 
 "This is for people out there to tell us are they interested in operating this terminal for maritime cargo uses and what those uses would be," said Peter J. Zantal, a general manager at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which oversees the piers. "Talk's cheap," he said, "and it's kind of getting to the point where if people really are interested, it is time to put their cards on the table."
The request comes as the city hashes out larger questions about the waterfront's future in a study of Piers 6 through 12. The study, being conducted by Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, is to be completed by the end of September and has raised the possibility of other uses, including housing and cultural institutions. The Port Authority is giving up Piers 1 through 5, in Brooklyn Heights, for the creation of a park, and Carnival, the cruise line company, has indicated interest in putting a passenger terminal at Pier 7, near Atlantic Avenue.
Port Authority officials said some maritime companies had indicated that they would be interested in using Piers 9 to 11 and that they expected detailed submissions on those plans. Officials would not say which companies those were, but Mr. Zantal said proposals were expected from businesses like steamship operators and ocean carrier companies.
Sal Catucci, chief executive of American Stevedoring, already stung by the decision to study other uses for the piers that house his business, objected to this latest solicitation. He said that when the Port Authority agreed to his most recent lease, which expires in April, officials said they would investigate a variety of possible uses for the site. "Now they've gone out to find interest in the piers," he said. "They know that they don't have any."
Mr. Catucci said that he had transformed a failing venture into a thriving one and that he could do even more if he had the chance. Several companies were interested in leasing space, he said, but he added that the uncertainty over his future was costing him those contracts.
Many community development advocates also say they fear officials are insufficiently committed to promoting maritime uses for the piers.
Port Authority and city officials say they hope Mr. Catucci will be among those submitting proposals. Joshua J. Sirefman, chief operating officer of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the responses would help officials shape a plan to encourage commercial and job growth, rather than coming up with the plan and testing it later. Officials, he said, are "working to understand the whole of maritime commerce in the context of the harbor, in the context of a changing waterfront and in the context of the neighborhoods that surround it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
DRUGSTORE OPERATOR OFFERS BUYOUT TO ALL MANAGERS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Longs Drug Stores Corporation, which operates in the West and Hawaii, said it offered buyouts to all its store managers as the company seeks to trim its work force by about 2 percent to centralize operations. 
Employees have until July 21 to accept a buyout and will leave between Aug. 1 and Sept. 2. Longs, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., has about 22,000 workers. In May, the company lowered its forecast for the year, saying unemployment in California and customer worries about the economy were hurting sales. The managers will be replaced with executives the company currently employs, he said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: MONEY; 
Banking Overhaul and New Currency Planned for Iraq

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 7 

 BODY:
In a sweeping effort to revive the devastated Iraqi economy, United States officials announced today that they would replace the Iraqi currency later this year and restructure the central bank to give it new autonomy.
 The officials said the actions were intended to eliminate an unsteady currency that still bears the image of Saddam Hussein and remove the central bank from its longstanding subservience to political leaders -- a role that helped to spawn crippling inflation during the past decade. 
 To many Iraqis, the most important action will be the creation of a new currency that will allow them to exchange the 10,000-dinar notes that most Iraqi merchants refuse to honor at face value. Many Iraqis receive their salaries in the notes, and thus rely on them to pay for food and other necessities, but merchants typically do not accept them unless the customer is willing to exchange them for no more than about 7,000 dinars. 
The Iraqi dinar is currently exchanged at about 1,400 for every United States dollar. 
A common Baghdad sight in recent weeks has been Iraqis waiting for hours in 115-degree summer heat to exchange their 10,000-dinar notes for a thick stack of the 250-dinar notes that merchants will still accept.
But beginning Oct. 15, Iraqis can start exchanging the notes for new bills denominated from 50 dinars to 25,000 dinars. 
American officials said the decision to issue a new currency was also driven by a desire to remove Mr. Hussein's image and to end the dual monetary system that separated the Kurdish north from the rest of the country.
Also today, American officials announced that the budget for the rest of 2003 would be about 9 trillion dinars, or about $6 billion to $7 billion. Slightly more than half of that amount, or about $3.5 billion, will come from oil revenues, they said, and the rest from sources including money stolen by sons of Mr. Hussein and from frozen Iraqi assets. The current level of earnings from Iraqi oil sales is not clear.
The top American civilian in Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, said in a public statement that 350 billion dinars would be spent on security and justice; 440 billion on improving the nation's heavily looted electricity system; 315 billion on public health; 385 billion on construction; 110 billion on water and sewer improvements; and 225 billion on improvements to the phone system and other telecommunications infrastructure. 
"With this budget, ministries will be able to spend money on important projects," Mr. Bremer said. "Many state companies will be able to begin operating again."
Officials hope their actions will calm many Iraqis who are increasingly angry with Americans over the breakdown of law and order as well as basic services like electricity and water. 
Increasing violence against American troops suggests that the United States may be facing some level of organized resistance from remnants of Mr. Hussein's government. 
In a 12-hour period Sunday and early Monday, an Iraqi gunned down a soldier outside a cafeteria at Baghdad University, while insurgents killed two soldiers in Baghdad neighborhoods in separate incidents. In nearby Ramadi, four soldiers were injured after coming under fire from rocket-propelled grenades in an attack that left at least one Iraqi dead and further inflamed local residents who have turned the town into a nexus of anti-American sentiment.
While American officials said today that the changes would mark the first time in a generation the central bank was independent of Iraqi political leaders, it appeared that they might retain veto power over monetary policy and other decisions. Meeting reporters this evening in Baghdad, senior officials with the Coalition Provisional Authority, which is overseeing nonmilitary operations here, would not answer questions about whether Mr. Bremer would still be able to countermand central bank decisions.
"The key to making this a success is making the Iraqis part of the policy-making process and of the inevitable process of tweaking the policies for greater impact once they begin to operate," said Tim Carney, a former ambassador to Sudan and Haiti who served as a senior American adviser during the first two months of the Iraqi occupation.
Coalition officials, however, emphasized that they had had extensive consultations with Massoud Barzani and Jalal Talabani, the leaders of the two large Kurdish factions in northern Iraq, about details of the rate at which Kurds would be able to exchange their currency. Their exchange rate, the officials said, would be one "Swiss dinar" -- the currency used in northern Iraq -- for every 150 new dinars. In the rest of the country, the exchange will be on a one-for-one basis. 
Occupation officials said the sharply different exchange rates did not mean the Kurds would receive a more favorable rate. Instead, they said, the rate reflected the much greater value of the Swiss dinar, which had not been subjected to the same inflation that devalued the dinar issued under Saddam Hussein and used in the rest of the country.
Under Mr. Hussein's absolutist rule, Finance Ministry officials forced the bank essentially to print money.
The officials said the contract for printing the notes would probably go to De La Rue, a large British printing company.

HEADLINE: Anxiety in Candidate Edwards's North Carolina 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N.C., July 4 

 BODY:
Senator John Edwards's fifth annual walk along the beach lasted only about a quarter-mile, what with a hot sun beating down and a horde of journalists in tow. But at every other step, it seemed, his constituents hit him with another complaint.
 Why didn't he support the troops? asked one soldier's mother. "I did," Mr. Edwards, a Democrat, assured her. Why didn't he do something about the economy? asked an out-of-work man. Mr. Edwards steered him to an aide who promised to help him find a job. 
 Then there were those who had a more pointed concern: where on earth did Mr. Edwards, a freshman senator, get off running for the Democratic nomination for president? 
"He just needs to stay in North Carolina more instead of running around the country," said Paul Stout, 51, a businessman from Asheboro. "He ought to stay at home like Elizabeth Dole for awhile, then test the waters. There's too many Democrats out there now anyway."
For Mr. Edwards, 50, his home state may not be the coziest place now.
He was elected by only a narrow margin in 1998 when he defeated a Republican incumbent, Lauch Faircloth. And these days some North Carolinians are irritated that he did not serve out a full term in the Senate before seeking higher office. Others object that he is hedging his political bets, by running for president while refusing to rule out a re-election campaign for his Senate seat.
"He needs to decide," said Brick McDermott, 26, a mortgage broker from Charlotte who was relaxing in the sand when Mr. Edwards walked by and said hello. "Having it both ways right now -- that isn't working."
The senator clearly does not agree and is sticking to his own timetable for his decision. "It's going to depend on what I think is best for North Carolina and what the dynamic is in the presidential campaign," he told the reporters trailing him. 
Perhaps those most frustrated with Mr. Edwards are the Democrats who would like to run next year to succeed him in the Senate, but are waiting on the sidelines to see if he will pull out of the race. As they wait, a Republican candidate is out in the field, lining up support as Mr. Edwards's standing in his home state steadily erodes in the polls.
The Democrats-in-waiting include Erskine B. Bowles, a former chief of staff to President Bill Clinton, and Dan Blue, a former speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives who was the first African-American to hold that post. Both men ran for the Senate seat that was being vacated by Jesse Helms last year. Mr. Bowles handily defeated Mr. Blue in the primary but lost by a wide margin to Mrs. Dole.
Both men have urged Mr. Edwards to make his intentions clear by early September so they can begin organizing and raising money. By state law, Mr. Edwards could delay a decision as late as Feb. 27, the filing deadline for the primary -- after the results are in from many early presidential contests.
For now, Mr. Edwards is giving no green lights to other Democrats. "My position hasn't changed," he told reporters here after his walk. "Logic would tell you, I'm the incumbent Democratic senator," he said, "and our chances of holding the seat are obviously much better when an incumbent is holding the spot."
Mr. Edwards's advisers contend that putting off a decision is as good for the party as it is for him. "The best thing that could happen for the North Carolina Democratic Party, over all and also in terms of holding the Senate seat, would be for Senator Edwards to be the Democratic nominee for president," said the pollster Harrison Hickman, a North Carolinian working for the Edwards presidential campaign. "The second best thing would be for Senator Edwards to run for re-election. If you said he had to make a decision now, I don't think he'd say he'd run for re-election, so now you've given up your second-best possibility."
Still, there is reason for his would-be successors to feel a sense of urgency: Representative Richard M. Burr, a Republican who has the support of the White House, has already cleared the Republican field of any other competitors, amassed a war chest of $3.4 million, and begun reaching into Democratic ranks. He is recruiting Democratic fund-raisers and more conservative Democratic Party members from the eastern half of the state.
"We cannot afford to have peel-off conservative Democrats voting Republican when Bush is running," said Brad Crone, a Democratic consultant in Raleigh. "Senator Edwards needs to make a decision by Labor Day to enable those interested in pursuing the nomination an opportunity to campaign."
The real question, it seems, is whether Mr. Bowles will abide Mr. Edwards's delays much longer. Mr. Bowles did not respond to several telephone and e-mail messages. But some of his supporters and advisers say they now expect him to enter the race before Labor Day, with or without Mr. Edwards's blessing.
"As much as he is loyal to Edwards, every week that goes by that he's unable to engage fully in the campaign, he sees as a disadvantage," said one Democrat familiar with Mr. Bowles's thinking. "He's a former White House chief of staff, he's got a record of getting things done, and he wants to do this. He's not likely to sit around waiting for long for someone else to make a decision."
The tension between the two, who are friends and have supported each other's campaigns, is likely only to grow: Mr. Edwards's loyalists say that Mr. Bowles received the lowest percentage of any Democratic Senate candidate in generations, while Mr. Bowles's note that he also got more votes than Mr. Edwards did.
Mr. Edwards's presidential campaign is, of course, winning him an enviable amount of publicity in North Carolina. But the coverage is not always helpful to his standing with voters here.
In May, for example, he endorsed gay adoption, a position that could help him with voters in a national Democratic primary far more than in a North Carolina general election, political analysts say. And his lead over Mr. Burr in polls by The News & Observer in Raleigh, while still in the double digits, has been shrinking.
In the paper's monthly polls of the presidential race, Mr. Edwards is consistently drawing only about 40 percent in a statewide matchup with President Bush, though his aides point out that President Clinton was at about the same point in Arkansas in the summer of 1991.
As Mr. Edwards mulls his options and Mr. Bowles and Mr. Blue fidget, Mr. Burr, the Republican candidate, is hardly standing still. Not long ago he won the support of two Democrats who had helped Mr. Bowles exclusively last year. Mr. Burr said the two had raised more than $150,000.
No matter that the donors do not know for sure who the candidates will be. Mr. Burr says, flatly: "They're contributing to my race against John Edwards." He adds, "That's what I'm telling them."
As much as the uncertainty helps Mr. Burr, it is hurting Mr. Edwards, said Ted Arrington, a professor of political science at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. "It looks like he's indecisive," he said. "People do kind of like a senator who's their senator because that's what he wants to be."
One of those people is James Llewellyn, 63, a retired judge who said Mr. Edwards had impressed him in his courtroom as a plaintiff's lawyer.
"I don't want him to be president," Mr. Llewellyn said after greeting Mr. Edwards on the beach."We need somebody to be campaigning for Senate right now."
Spiro Macris, a retired orthodontist active in local Democratic politics, questioned whether Mr. Edwards had paid his dues.
"I wish he had tended to the Senate a little longer," he said. "Maybe this is a training run. I was hoping, maybe this is our vice president."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Finalists Chosen For Jergens Account

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
The Andrew Jergens Company has narrowed a review for the account of its personal care brands like Ban antiperspirant, Jergens lotion and John Frieda hair products. Although billings were not disclosed, Jergens and Frieda spent $90.1 million on advertising in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres. 
 Brad Kirk, vice president for marketing and strategic planning at Jergens in Cincinnati, confirmed a report on Adweek.com about the move. He identified the finalists as the New York offices of Arnold Worldwide, part of Havas; Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group; Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, part of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network; and the Wolf Group. Mr. Kirk declined to identify agencies that were eliminated. 
 The brands had been handled by Bozell in New York until it was merged by its parent, Interpublic, into a sibling, Lowe & Partners Worldwide in New York. The account was shifted to Lowe at the same time, leading Jergens to begin a review out of concern that conflicts could arise with a big Lowe client, Johnson & Johnson.
AAR Partners in New York is managing the review for Jergens, which is part of the Kao Corporation.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: POLITICS; 
IRAQIS WILL JOIN GOVERNING COUNCIL U.S. IS SETTING UP

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: SALAHUDDIN, Iraq, July 7 

 BODY:
Warning that increasing violence is rallying the remnants of Saddam Hussein's government, the main Iraqi political groups that supported the United States and Britain in toppling the Iraqi president said today that they would join the first postwar interim government later this month and press for greater powers under the occupation authority.
 The groups' decision marks the final stage of a two-month-long exercise in brinkmanship between former Iraqi opposition leaders and L. Paul Bremer III, the American occupation administrator, over how much power and authority the Iraqi leadership body will be given. 
 In Baghdad, Shiite Muslim tribes from central and southern Iraq met for the first time to discuss how they, as the country's religious majority, could help create a united Iraqi nation.
Also today, United States officials announced a plan to overhaul Iraqi financial institutions. They appointed a central bank chief, Faleh Salman, and took steps to give the bank autonomy from the country's political leaders. Starting in October, officials said, a new currency will replace the old dinar with Saddam Hussein's image on it. Page A14. 
It appears, though, that American officials may retain veto power over monetary policy and other decisions.
At the same time, several prominent members of the former opposition forces, including Massoud Barzani, the Kurdish leader, and Ahmad Chalabi, head of the Iraqi National Congress, said they were urging United States military commanders in Iraq to allow the creation of an Iraqi national security force to help thwart attacks that are destabilizing the country.
"We always told the Americans that the most difficult stage would be after the war and that it is not good for them to be in the forefront," Mr. Barzani said after the daylong session in this city in northeastern Iraq. 
"They should keep their distance," he added, "and support Iraqi forces as they try to solve the problems themselves."
The Iraqi political figures say they have support for the force from Gen. John P. Abizaid, who is taking over the United States Central Command from Gen. Tommy R. Franks, and from Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense.
The United States is training a police force for Iraq and a future army, but there is no third force, a Central Command official said tonight.
The force, its proponents said, would be a paramilitary army trained and equipped by the United States on a crash basis to confront the remnants of Mr. Hussein's Baathist government, which are believed to be responsible for killing 29 American soldiers since May 1.
Mr. Bremer swept aside plans made in May by his predecessor, the retired lieutenant general Jay Garner, to turn over significant powers to an Iraqi provisional government.
The United Nations resolution that recognizes the United States and Britain as occupying powers in Iraq calls for a swift transition to Iraqi rule, but Mr. Bremer initially said he preferred to appoint an advisory "political council" of Iraqis, taking a year or two to create a constitution and hold popular elections.
Today's decision comes as Mr. Bremer faces increasing pressure to put an Iraqi government in place to deal with a host of issues. Among them are the deteriorating security situation, in which guerrilla attacks on American convoys and bases have caused concern in the Bush administration about whether plans to build a new Iraqi state are working. Three Americans were killed on Sunday in separate attacks.
In negotiations with Iraqi leaders in the last several weeks, Mr. Bremer made a number of concessions, most prominently that they would have a governing role under the authority of the occupation powers. He promised, Iraqi political leaders say, to grant extensive powers to an Iraqi interim government, which will appoint and supervise an Iraqi council of ministers, set oil and other economic policies, issue a new currency, draft a budget and send ambassadors out into the world. 
Mr. Bremer has even designated the former Ministry of Military Industries building in central Baghdad as the future home of the interim government, so it will have offices separate from the occupation authorities.
In another symbolic gesture, Mr. Bremer began calling the new Iraqi ruling body a governing council, instead of a political council, in public statements in the last two weeks. 
It is expected to declare itself a leadership body later this month, after weeks of negotiations aimed at making it appear that its 25 to 30 members "emerged" after "consultations" among prominent Iraqi political figures and were not directly appointed by Mr. Bremer.
This fig leaf has apparently transformed attitudes among former Iraqi opposition figures, who were eager to take part in rebuilding the country, but fearful of risking their credibility with constituents.
"We need an Iraqi government, and we think now that the Americans realize that Iraqis are the only ones with the experience for maintaining security, administration and for filling the political vacuum," said Adel Abdul-Mahdi, whose grandfather served in the first Iraqi government in the 1920's and who now represents Ayatollah Muhammad Bakr al-Hakim's Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq.
One of Ayatollah Hakim's representatives made it clear last month that the group would not work with a "political council" that Mr. Bremer appointed. Other opposition figures made similar statements, saying they would boycott any interim administration that made them appear to be "lackeys" of the occupation powers.
Shiite leaders in southern Iraq have been particularly critical of Mr. Bremer's reluctance to grant Iraqis a significant role in transitional governance. Their frustration built to the point where Iraq's leading Shiite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, issued a religious edict, or fatwa, demanding that Iraqis elect a constitutional drafting committee.
"Sistani's support is essential for the constitutional process," Mr. Chalabi said.
In a joint statement issued today, the seven members of the "leadership council" of the former Iraqi opposition indicated that their negotiations with Mr. Bremer were not yet concluded.
"The meeting welcomed the formation of a governing council, considering it a step in the right direction toward the formation of a provisional government," the statement said. Several Iraqis who attended the meeting today said that a decision had been made that they would serve on the governing council, but that negotiations continued on who would serve with them.
Mr. Bremer clearly has put forward his own slate of candidates, including Adnan Pachachi, 80, the elder statesman of Iraq's diplomatic corps, and Dr. Lena Abboud, 28, a gynecologist who was part of a delegation of Iraqi women who met with Mr. Bremer during his first month in Baghdad. 
Representatives of Iraq's tribal groups, along with Turkmen and Chaldean and Assyrian Christians, are also expected to join the roster.
Mr. Pachachi said in an interview in Baghdad during the weekend that Mr. Bremer had agreed that a majority of the governing council members would need to be Shiites, to reflect their 60 percent majority of Iraq's population.
"There needs to be a Shiite majority, if for no other reason than to avoid criticism, since the Shiites have been the most deprived of their rights," Mr. Pachachi said.
Today, Mr. Barzani expressed satisfaction in the new formulation. He and another Kurdish leader, Jalal Talabani, are Washington's closest allies among the former Iraqi opposition groups.
"Now the governing council will have real power and authority and there will be no puppets," Mr. Barzani said.

HEADLINE: Conversing On the Arts By Clicking A Mouse 

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
For those lamentably addicted, the Internet is creeping toward a total takeover of our lives. But maybe addictions can be ranked as more or less beneficent. 
 Certainly the presence of a Web site called ArtsJournal.com has added something important to cultural discourse. 
What ArtsJournal offers is a daily summary, with links to the complete articles from print publications or Internet magazines, of what its editor and founder, Douglas McLennan, deems the most important high-arts articles in the worldwide English-language press. 
If you trust his judgment, which seems pretty solid, he has created what he innocently calls "the best arts section in the world." 
This may come as a shock to loyal loggers-on to the better-known ArtsandLettersDaily.com, which got started in mid-1998, a year before ArtsJournal. With some 2 million "page views" a month, Arts and Letters has five times the readership of ArtsJournal, although everyone concedes that such figures are slippery to measure.
Mr. McLennan, 45, is a former music critic and arts reporter who lives in Seattle. While Arts and Letters Daily appeals to an intellectual and academic readership, ArtsJournal covers what newspapers cover: art thefts, orchestras going under, music downloading, theater companies building new buildings and the like. Mostly it is reportage, with only occasional reviews of major events. Mr. McLennan calls his site "a conversation about culture."
His audience, he says, consists of arts journalists, arts professionals (curators, music administrators, even actual artists) and educated people from all walks of life with an interest in the arts. 
The two sites were created during the dot-com euphoria of the late 90's, and both survived in large part because their financial expectations were too modest for them to crash very far. Mr. McLennan resisted temptation and has managed to putter along as a kind of gonzo outsider.
"Two months after I started, I got a buy-out offer of $1 million," he said in an interview in New York. "The woman on the other end of the phone said, 'We can make you a millionaire by Christmas.' " 
Mr. McLennan was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, studied piano in Canada and the United States and spent a year in Manhattan as a fellow in the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University. As a journalist he has worked mostly in Seattle, for The Seattle Weekly and The Post-Intelligencer, but devotes himself now to ArtsJournal and the myriad spinoffs his teeming brain is always devising.
Mr. McLennan confines the journal's links to the articles he highlights each day. But he has additional features, most designed to make a modicum of money, to keep the operation afloat and maybe even allow him to afford more than the minimal help he can now employ.
There is a subscription. (You get the summaries with or without links in your daily e-mail.) There is syndication. There are articles by Mr. McLennan providing an overview of continuing issues, with links to related stories. There will soon be an ArtsJournal streaming audio sideline. Just this week there are ArtsJournal-sponsored blogs by leading figures in the arts. And Mr. McLennan himself consults for various publications, writes freelance articles and is working with Minnesota Public Radio on a possible arts-news project.
He also toys periodically with turning the site from its current for-profit status into a nonprofit organization, allied with a foundation or other institution. But so far Mr. McLennan, an incorrigible lone wolf, hasn't found a partnership to his liking.
If there is a cloud on the horizon, it is the possibility that more and more publications will decide to sell their material, rather than give it away. The Wall Street Journal, for the most part, already does that, and hence does not really appear on either site.
"It's not particularly in their interest to cut us off," Mr. McLennan said. "I can be their biggest deliverer of traffic."
Mr. McLennan's main problem right now is figuring a way, economically and conceptually, to ease the burden of putting out the site onto others. Were he to fall seriously ill, that would be it. More imminently, he is planning a monthlong trip with his wife and daughter this fall to Africa.
"One of the nice things about the site is that you can do it anywhere," he said. "But you can't do it from where I'll be in Africa. I'm hoping to be able to hire two or three people.
"But while you would think doing the site would be easy, if you're looking at 1,000 stories a day, you have to have a sense of context to tell you which are important. It isn't easy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas McLennan says his Web site, ArtsJournal.com, a daily summary with links to other articles, is "the best arts section in the world." (Gary Settle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Imported Foods Become Costlier As Euro Dominates the Dollar 

BYLINE:  By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
PRESERVES and biscuits from France are going up in price. So are cheeses from Spain and prosciutto and pasta from Italy. The increases may amount to only 50 cents a pound wholesale for now, but retailers predict that if the euro remains strong against the dollar, consumers may begin to register sticker shock in the fall, especially around the holidays.
 Yesterday, the euro traded in the range of $1.13. About a year ago, it was less than a dollar. 
 Ron Tanner, a spokesman for the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade, the trade group that runs the Fancy Food Show, which was held last week at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, acknowledged that for many consumers of these specialty foods, a price increase would not exactly be a hardship.
"A good olive oil that now costs $32 a bottle instead of $29 does not make a huge difference to a high-end shopper," he said.
But at a time when Americans are watching household budgets, many exhibitors at the show, and the retailers who sell their goods, were considerably more cautious. 
"We've already raised some of our prices as much as 20 percent," said Steven Jenkins, a partner in Fairway markets, which imports manyproducts directly from Europe. "Our private-label imported olive oil is up a dollar a liter, from $5.99 to $6.99. But we have a very price-sensitive clientele, so we have to be careful."
A number of European companies, like La Compagnia dell'Olio, which sells luxury tuna products, sauces and olive oils from Sicily, say they are trying to absorb some of the increases, which include higher labor costs.
"We've been able to convince some of our producers to tighten up and hold the line, so on average our prices have gone up less than 10 percent," said Andrea Moccia, a representative of the company. 
He said that at retail a bottle of oil or a jar of tuna might increase from $26 to $28. 
Rosario Safina, whose company, Da Rosario, imports mushrooms and truffles, said he had raised his prices about 10 percent, so a tiny bottle of truffle oil that sold for $6.95 is now $7.50. The price of fresh chanterelles from Russia and the Baltic countries has gone from $9 to $12 a pound wholesale, he said. 
"Even though those countries have their own currencies, they price everything in euros," he explained.
Based on the economy in the United States right now, "this is no time to raise prices," said Dane Neller, the president of Dean & DeLuca. "Right now, we're managing to hold the line. We have to because sales are already soft on the luxury end, but sooner or later we may have to pass on the increases. European producers are also faced with commodity prices going up."
With some products, like Parmigiano-Reggiano and pasta from Italy, importers were able to buy in bulk months ago and lock in the prices. But when the supplies are depleted, they will have to purchase more, probably at higher prices. 
"We're promoting grana Padano and extra-vecchio Piave at $8.99 a pound instead of Parmigiano-Reggiano for $9.99," said Joe Macaluso, a buyer for Citarella. "And we're seeing our customers shopping more carefully, looking for value and choosing alternatives."
Some European producers have already raised their prices, he said, to compensate for a potential loss in volume in the American market.
At the show, Marty Campbell, a buyer for the Fresh Market in Greensboro, N.C., said he had been trying to hold price increases to a minimum but that he was concerned about the last quarter of 2003. "By then, we may have no choice," he said.
At Crystal Foods in Lynn, Mass., John Ciano, the president, said some shoppers are indifferent to the price increases, "but today there are many others who have become price-sensitive.
"Bush thinks that a weak dollar helps the economy because it helps our exports," he said, "but a policy like that hurts, too."

HEADLINE: ARTS BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  By Lawrence Van Gelder 

 BODY:
 HIGHLIGHTS

FRENCH ARTS WORKERS STRIKE -- The opening of the Avignon theater festival fell victim yesterday to a wave of strikes across France by technicians, actors, dancers and filmmakers resisting efforts to reduce their unemployment benefits, news agencies report. In Paris volunteers and the police were called in to make sure that a Rolling Stones concert for 60,000 fans in a stadium tonight would go on as scheduled. The labor dispute has already forced cancellation of some festivals and the disruption of the opera gala in Aix-en-Provence. In the face of the walkouts, France's culture minister, Jean-Jacques Aillagon, told France-Inter radio: "Every time a festival is canceled, the fallout is appalling, and their futures are often compromised. I believe I've gone to the limits of what is possible, of my responsibility. I will not take any new initiatives." Performers have rejected his proposal to maintain the current unemployment system until the start of 2004 while a settlement is negotiated. At the 57th Avignon festival, which usually draws more than 100,000 visitors, the board scheduled a meeting today to consider canceling the three-week event. In Paris workers responsible for loading and unloading the Stones' stage, lighting and sound gear stopped work in sympathy with the strikers. The police were summoned to remove 50 to 100 protesters barring access by the trucks to the Stade de France. A spokeswoman for the French leg of the band's "40 Licks" tour said, however, that volunteers and other personnel helped the equipment reach the stadium and asserted that the show would "go ahead whatever."

ART: A PAPER TRAIL -- The names are celebrated: Chagall, Degas, Ingres, Leger, Matisse, Picasso and Signac, to name a few. The time span is 150 years. The mediums are drawings, watercolors (like Signac's "St.-Tropez: Evening Sun," left) and pastels. The exhibition, at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, is "Classic to Modern: French Works on Paper, 1800-1950, From the Permanent Collection." In 150 years of political, social and cultural upheaval in France, artists interpreted and reinterpreted their world. The exhibition, from tomorrow through Sept. 7, explores these reactions in five thematic groups: "The Body (Un)Wrapped," focused on the human form; "Head and Shoulders," examining portraiture; "Nature Denatured," about the world; "Orientalism," reflecting the artists' romance with the Orient; and "Labor and Leisure," juxtaposing nostalgia for a rural society with images of Parisians savoring the wealth of the industrial age at resorts, the racetrack and cafes.

IRAQ'S LOOTED ART -- The director of the Iraq Museum said yesterday that at least 10 percent of its contents had vanished. Speaking at a news conference at the British Museum in London, the director, Dr. Nawalaal Mutawalli, said some 13,000 objects had vanished from the museum's storage room, which has been only partly inspected, the BBC reported. In addition, he said, 47 pieces, 7 of them described as "very important masterpieces," had been taken from the exhibition room of the museum in Baghdad. The start of a thorough search of the museum was delayed until the staff could obtain a generator to provide electricity. The museum's director of research, Donny George, said about 1,500 missing treasures had been returned, many by local people who said they were safeguarding them until troops could protect the museum.

FILM: DELON RETROSPECTIVE -- In 75 films made in 50 years, he has gone from pretty boy to tough cop, contract killer, thief and ex-con. He is the French star Alain Delon (born 1935), left, a school dropout and Vietnam veteran who broke into movies in the role of a hit man in 1957 and achieved stardom in Rene Clement's "Plein Soleil" (1960), an adaptation of Patricia Highsmith's "Talented Mr. Ripley." In the years to follow, Mr. Delon starred in films like "Rocco and His Brothers" (1960) and "The Leopard" (1963) for Luchino Visconti, "Eclipse" (1962) for Michelangelo Antonioni, "Le Samourai" (1967) and "Dirty Money" (1972) for Jean-Pierre Melville and "Mr. Klein" (1976) for Joseph Losey. Mr. Delon also became a writer, director and producer. From Friday through July 21 and from July 30 through Aug. 7 at the Walter Reade Theater, the Film Society of Lincoln center will revisit his career in a two-part 18-film retrospective, "Man in the Shadows: The Films of Alain Delon."

MUSIC IN THE PARK -- A new free summertime music series makes its debut at 7 tonight. Running each Wednesday through Aug. 13, it is Madison Square Music, presented by the Madison Square Park Conservancy on the Oval Lawn of the 6.2-acre Madison Square Park, between 23rd and 26th Streets and Fifth and Madison Avenues. The opening attraction is the folk-rockers Dane Zanes & Friends.

FOOTNOTES

Here's the lineup: Alec Baldwin reading "The Dinner" by Roddy Doyle, Molly Ringwald reading "Friendly Skies" by T. C. Boyle, and Buck Henry reading "I Can Speak" by George Saunders. The event is a New Yorker magazine presentation, "Fiction Live." Its tickets priced at $15, this night of readings of contemporary fiction from the pages of the magazine is scheduled for 7:30 Saturday at the Stephen Talkhouse, 161 Main Street, Amagansett, N.Y. Directed by Gregory Mosher, the 13th in a series, is a benefit for the Child Development Center of the Hamptons. The doors open at 7.

HEADLINE: U.S. Pact Lifts South Africa Car Exports 

BYLINE:  By NICOLE ITANO 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 8 

 BODY:
This is a left-hand-drive country, where most cars have standard transmissions, and where even humble features, like the cup holder, have yet to be widely adopted. But such accessories, and others, like air bags, are standard in most of the more than 200 luxury 3 Series BMW sedans that roll off the production line in South Africa each weekday, in luminescent colors like Titanium Silver and Mystic Blue.
 More than 80 percent of the cars made at BMW South Africa's plant in Rosslyn, about 10 miles outside of the capital, Pretoria, are for export. Half of those, an estimated 25,000 this year, will make the nearly 9,000-mile journey, first by train and then by ship, to consumers in the United States. The cars will enter duty-free, under a preferential trade agreement intended to stimulate African economies. 
 South Africa historically has never appeared high on the list of the world's auto manufacturers. Since the end of apartheid in 1994, however, the industry has undergone a significant transformation -- from an inward, highly protected industry to an export-oriented one with average compounded annual growth of 39 percent in the last seven years despite the global economic downturn. 
This impressive growth has come from a base of almost nothing, since sanctions during the apartheid era prevented any exports. Considering that past, the auto industry represents one of South Africa's greatest post-apartheid economic successes.
With a large percentage of this production being exported to the United States -- 15 percent of new cars and 10.5 percent of car parts -- the sector also shows how preferential trade agreements like the African Growth and Opportunity Act, which President Bush is expected to highlight during his trip to the continent this week, can help promote investment and growth.
The program gives nonreciprocal, duty-free access to products from 38 African countries that meet certain criteria, like a market-based economy, political pluralism and adherence to the rule of law. AGOA, the widely used acronym for the trade pact, is scheduled to run until 2008, though Mr. Bush has indicated that he would like to see it extended.
Although South Africa's auto industry is still small in global terms, ranking only 18th in size, its transformation and expansion is a model for the kind of economic successstory the United States would like to promote in Africa. The automotive industry is South Africa's largest export sector under AGOA, and is one of the few industries to capitalize on the program. In 2001, the first year of the program, the industry's exports to the United States rose by 387 percent, to $359 million. Last year, they grew again, to $572.9 million.
"The growth in the industry in general has been quite phenomenal," said Nico Vermeulen, director of the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers of South Africa. "AGOA has played a role by adding impetus to automobile exporters in South Africa to enter what is the largest automotive consumer market in the world, as far as vehicles are concerned."
The industry's experience, however, also shows the program's limitations. Despite hopes that it would help small businesses, it has generally been large multinationals like BMW that have benefited most.
Nor has South Africa's entry into the competitive, global market after the end of apartheid necessarily translated into more jobs at home. According the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa, which represents most auto workers, jobs in automobile and auto-component manufacturing fell by 16,200 between 1995 and 2001. Manufacturers say the cuts were needed to trim a bloated industry.
"We are delighted that some of the companies are now able to export, but the picture is not that rosy in terms of job losses," said Dumisa Ntuli, a spokesman for the union. "Employment has been precarious in most of these companies, despite the growth."
For much of its history, the South African automobile industry has largely been a domestic matter. Import tariffs that reached 114 percent during apartheid made it cheaper for companies to build local plants to assemble a variety of cars almost exclusively for sale at home. By the end of apartheid, small numbers of more than 40 different models were being produced here, a huge number for a country representing only 1 percent of the global car market.
"Seven years ago, the generally accepted viewpoint was that half the country's companies would be closed because they were producing at high cost and low quality," said Clive Williams, executive director of South Africa's National Association of Automotive Component and Allied Manufacturers, speaking of the businesses in his organization. "In retrospect, less than 10 percent have closed down and the rest have made an incredible transformation from being fat to being lean."
In 1991, with apartheid nearing its end, global sanctions against South Africa were dropped, opening up the possibility of exports. When South Africa's new government took over in 1994, it moved quickly to encourage a more modern and competitive industry, producing fewer models more efficiently. The effort reduced tariff protection while at the same time giving companies incentives to specialize and begin exporting.
The country's seven major car makers, which include major players like Ford, Toyota and DaimlerChrysler, began to streamline their factories, focusing on a smaller number of models to be sold locally and exported. Car-component manufacturers, which produced small numbers of a wide variety of parts, began looking for new markets.
BMW South Africa was one of the first companies to turn its sights to exports. In 1998, the company invested 250 million rand (about $45 million at the time) to upgrade the Rosslyn plant, transforming it from a factory that assembled about 12,000 cars and at least four different models, to one with the capacity to produce 60,000 ofthe popular 3 series sedans, in both right- and left-side-of-the-road versions. Also, unlike the old factory, BMW's new plant has the capacity to produce made-to-order cars with features like sunroofs and specialized stereo systems.
When the trade pact took effect in 2001, ending the 2.5 percent import tariff for most South African cars, BMW began exporting to the United States. Over the last five years, the company has more than quadrupled its business, with exports to the United States under AGOA producing half that growth.
The expansion has led the company to add a second shift at its factory and hire 900 new employees. Most of the parts, except for the engine and transmission, are made locally, and the company's managing director, Ian Robertson, said that component purchases have pumped an additional 3.5 billion rand (about $470 million) into the country's economy.
"In essence, we moved away from what we call a knockdown facility, which means a lot of components come in, in boxes, and are assembled using local labor, to now being primarily concentrating on one model that is primarily export-bound," Mr. Robertson said. "Eighty-two percent of our business is now export. Five years ago, nothing; today, 82 percent. So it's been a remarkable transition, but one I think that we've benefited from and I think the South African economy has definitely benefited from."
So far, BMW is still the only South African car manufacturer exporting under the pact, although at least two others are looking into the program and a number of component manufacturers are exporting to the United States under AGOA or the Generalized System of Preferences, another duty-free program.
Mr. Robertson said technology was the major reason more automobile manufacturing companies have not taken advantage of AGOA. Unlike BMW, other companies have not made the investments to allow them to produce right-hand-drive cars.
But with BMW's success, an increasing number of South African companies are looking to the United States. For its part, the South African government is working to inform local companies about export opportunities and connect them to buyers across the Atlantic.
"You just have to look at the statistical data to see that our companies are slowly waking to the fact that AGOA does open markets in the United States," said Gustav Meyer, senior manager for automobiles at Trade and Industry South Africa, a government agency involved in encouraging exports. "We considered the United States our biggest potential growth market."

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rises, Led by Credit Cards 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer debt rose in May as shoppers made more purchases on their credit cards, according to Federal Reserve statistics released in Washington yesterday. 
 Debt like auto loans and creditcard balances grew $7.34 billion in May, following a rise of $7.83 billion in April, the Fed said. Total consumer credit excluding real estate loans stood at $1.76 trillion in May. 
 With the unemployment rate at a nine-year high of 6.4 percent in June and consumer spending rising at half the average rate of the 1992-2000 economic expansion, some economists question whether the rate of borrowing can be sustained. 
"The current pace of credit suggests that the consumer isn't alarmed by the skittish economic recovery," said Rich Yamarone, an economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York, before the report's release. "Despite lackluster job creation, consumers continue to spend at a reasonably robust pace. This could prove worrisome if unemployment continues to creep higher." 
Before the report, economists estimated consumers in May added $4.8 billion in debt, based on the median of 43 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. 
In its initial April estimate, the Fed reported Americans accumulated $10.7 billion in new debt. 
The Fed's monthly consumer credit report does not track loans secured by real estate, like mortgages and home equity loans. Such debt increased 2.8 percent, to $6.219 trillion in the first quarter compared with the fourth, the Fed said last month in a quarterly report. 
Nonrevolving loans for vehicles and mobile homes, which make up almost two-thirds of household nonmortgage debt, rose 4.9 percent, or $4.18 billion, to $1.035 trillion, the Fed said. Auto sales in May dropped 2.4 percent from April, to an annual pace of 16.1 million units. 
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, rose 5.3 percent, or $3.17 billion, to $725 billion in May.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; 
An Interstate Begets a Home Improvement Center

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: PLAINFIELD, Conn. 

 BODY:
Lowe's Home Improvement Centers is planning an $80 million, 1.4-million-square-foot distribution center on a 200-acre site here off Interstate 395, to serve its stores in the Northeast.
 Site plans submitted to town officials show a building that would cover almost 30 acres, and a similar expanse for parking 600 tractor-trailers and 600 cars. The development would straddle a portion of Lillibridge Road, which would be rerouted around the distribution center at a cost of $7 million. 
 All local approvals are in place, and town officials said the only regulatory approval still to be obtained is from the Army Corps of Engineers, a requirement because of wetlands in the area. That approval is expected later this month. 
Chris Ahearn, a spokesman for Lowe's, based in North Wilkesboro, N.C., which operates almost 900 stores in 45 states, declined to comment on the proposal until all the permits were in place.
Lowe's representatives have said at zoning hearings that the site's easy access to Interstate 395, less than a mile away, made it viable as a distribution-center site.
Plainfield town officials are excited about the potential tax revenue, particularly this year, when a budget shortage has resulted in layoffs of employees and cuts in services. First Selectman David C. Allard estimates that after property-tax abatements -- the land is in a state-legislated enterprise zone -- and after paying off a loan for a new road, the town will net $14 million over the next 20 years, or $700,000 a year, a substantial figure for Plainfield, which has an operating budget of $34 million.
Town and state officials said Lowe's had shown sensitivity to environmental concerns. When surveys discovered two species listed as endangered in the state, the Eastern spadefoot toad and the vesper sparrow, as well as a threatened species, the blue-spotted salamander, Lowe's redrew its plans.
The Plainfield town planner, Louis J. Soja, said he expected the project to draw the attention of some small manufacturers that sell to Lowe's, which might see advantages to being near the distribution center. The town has an industrial park less than two miles away, with about 15 lots of two to three acres still available, and the new road the town is to build will provide access to more industrial-zoned land, in tracts ranging from a few acres to 20 acres.
Michael A. Saad, Plainfield's director of economic development, said officials also sought to attract other development, stressing proximity to tourism destinations like Mystic Seaport as well as Indian casinos and new hotels. Ground is to be broken for a 68-room Super 8 motel next month, and a 120-room hotel is in the final planning stages.
Mr. Saad and Mr. Soja said they hoped the advantages that attracted Lowe's would draw other large retailers looking for distribution sites. "We feel we can be in a position to survive the ups and downs of the economy if we have diversity in the tax base," Mr. Saad said.
There are critics of the Lowe's project, though, who have organized a group called Save Our Town. 
Hector L. Rodriguez, a lawyer and president of the group, said the warehouse and driver jobs that will be created are not comparable to manufacturing jobs being lost because of the closing this summer of a Kaman Aerospace plant. And as hundreds of trucks a day leave the property, he said, traffic hazards will be created.
Mr. Rodriguez also criticized the town's use of eminent domain to obtain property in the path of the new road and questioned the estimates of tax revenue, which he said were inflated.
"They're holding this project out as the town's savior," he said, "but no one has been able to produce a document that commits to any level of tax revenue. This isn't progress, and this isn't economic development. This is not how you go about creating a tax base in town." 
Another member of the group, Christine M. Bernier, said she would see acres of rolling farmland in front of her house disappear as the Lowe's project is built. She said that town officials had dismissed opponents' fears of air and noise pollution from trucks and that bright lights from the round-the-clock warehouse operation would severely change the character of the neighborhood.
"This whole process has been exhausting," she said. "I can't believe that no one will help us."
But many townspeople, even in what will become the shadow of the distribution center, seem to be resigned to its construction. Claire Potvin, whose property backs up to the Lowe's site, said she was disappointed at the hip-high trees the retailer will plant as a boundary.
"I told them I'm 71 now, and I'll never see those bushes grow to block anything," she said. "By the time they're big enough to hide anything, I'll be six feet under. We don't like it, but I think we're going to have to learn to live with it."

PERSON: Charles P. Kindleberger 

HEADLINE: Charles P. Kindleberger, 92, Global Economist, Is Dead 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
Charles P. Kindleberger, an economic historian who advanced the study of international finance and helped to devise the Marshall Plan for Europe's reconstruction after World War II, died on Monday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 92.
 Professor Kindleberger won fame for originating the idea that global markets could not entirely police themselves. He wrote that leadership, as shown by Britain in the 19th century and the United States in the 20th, was essential to contain monetary crises. 
 He was also known for investigating the role of mob psychology in financial manias and panics, dating back to the tulip crisis in Holland early in the 17th century.
Unlike many academic economists of his time, Professor Kindleberger followed his education with a decade of practical experience in government, a period that spanned the end of the Great Depression and World War II. Decades later, his early grapplings with the problems of the American economy led him to write "The World in Depression: 1929-1939" -- a work that drew him solidly into the field of economic history.
"He brought into international economics some theoretical background but a great deal of worldly wisdom along with it," said Robert A. Mundell, a former student of Professor Kindleberger's who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1999 and is now a professor at Columbia University. "He had a very well-developed, quick and imaginative sense of the real problems of the real world."
Charles Poor Kindleberger II was born in New York City on Oct. 12, 1910. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1932 and completed his doctorate at Columbia University under James W. Angell, a monetary theorist, in 1937.
When the United States became embroiled in World War II, he interrupted a stint at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to seek a naval commission. Dissatisfied with his proposed posting at a desk job, he instead joined the Office of Strategic Services, the predecessor of the Central Intelligence Agency, in 1942. He later became a major in the 12th Army Group in Europe, picking targets for Allied bombing based on enemy supply lines, and was awarded the Bronze Star by Gen. Omar Bradley.
After the war, Professor Kindleberger served as chief of the State Department's Division of German and Austrian Economic Affairs. He later spent long hours at the Pentagon helping estimate the costs of the European Recovery Program proposed in 1947 by George C. Marshall, then the secretary of state.
Congressional approval of the program, which came to be known as the Marshall Plan, coincided with Professor Kindleberger's move to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1948. He started as an associate professor and retired in 1976 as the Ford International Professor of Economics.
During his tenure, he was a consultant to the federal government several times, most often for the Treasury and the Federal Reserve. In 1985, he was president of the American Economic Association.
Though Professor Kindleberger's academic focus was often international, he was committed to education at home. He took a leave in 1967 and 1968 to visit the predominantly black colleges of the Atlanta University Center, where he taught courses and guided the development of economics curricula.
Professor Kindleberger wrote dozens of books, including a landmark textbook on international economics, first published in 1953, and a retrospective on the intersection of politics and economics in different countries, published in 2000. He also wrote an autobiography, "The Life of an Economist," in 1991.
"I have a strong impression that economics is a countercyclical industry that attracts adherents when times are troubled," he wrote. "Some are drawn to the subject by the opportunity to do good, to save the world, so to speak, by curing depression. The stronger drive in my view is curiosity. How does the economy work, and what has gone wrong?"
Professor Kindleberger was married to Sarah Bache Miles from 1937 until her death in 1997. He had lived in Lexington, Mass., since 1989. He is survived by two sons, Charles Poor III of St. Louis and Richard Stockton Kindleberger of Boston; two daughters, Sarah Kindleberger of Lincoln, Mass., and Elizabeth Randall Kindleberger of Machias, Me.; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: About New York; 
Small Strivers Are Uprooted By Big Plans

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY

 BODY:
CONSIDER the locksmith's story.
 Teddy Pazooki does not own a development company like Forest City Ratner. He has no pull with a state agency like the Empire State Development Corporation. He is not an executive with a media giant like The New York Times, although he reads the newspaper on occasion. 
 Mr. Pazooki is just a locksmith, which is misleading because no one is ever "just" anything. He is a native of Iran, a father of two, a Long Island homeowner. He also has a master's degree in applied science from New York University. But life is often about fumbling for keys, and the key he found opened the door to a locksmith's career.
For 21 years he worked out of a cubbyhole storefront at 262 West 41st Street, one block south of the 42nd Street glow and roar. His day's glitter came from the golden keys dangling about him; its music, from the grind of his key-making machine.
Above his machine's whir, though, Mr. Pazooki sometimes heard chatter: of plans to demolish half a city block, from 40th to 41st Streets on Eighth Avenue's east side, to help revitalize Times Square. But a recession quelled the talk years ago, leaving a clutch of small businesses to continue their Midtown striving.
There was Arnold Hatters, whose owners traced their Times Square roots to 1926. And B & J Fabrics, whose fine wares included the prophetically named "embroidered illusion." A barber shop here, a deli there, a couple of X-rated video stores -- and Teddy the locksmith, who relied on the foot traffic of commuters exhaled and inhaled daily by the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
But the chatter returned, louder this time. The Times wanted a new home; the state agency wanted to revitalize; the developer wanted to build. The city granted tax breaks to The Times, and Mr. Pazooki heard the rattle of other people's keys.
Last August the state took title through eminent domain. For the public good, the blight of that half-block would be demolished and a soaring skyscraper would rise in its stead. For the public good, the locksmith, the hatter and the rest had to find another mooring in the Manhattan roil.
The state presented modest financial packages to help the stores relocate. But it provided no compensation for the loss of future business; under New York law, dislocation does not affect the intangible "good will" between merchants and customers. 
Nonsense, said M. Robert Goldstein, a lawyer and expert in eminent domain who represents Mr. Pazooki. "If you move them a couple of blocks away, their customers don't know where to find them. It's not convenient anymore."
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said that hundreds of businesses uprooted by the Times Square revitalization have thrived at new locations. But he acknowledged that one or two always fall through the cracks. "It's unfortunate," he said.
Of the dozens of affected businesses, four remain on site, and they will be gone in a matter of weeks. Arnold Rubin, the hatter, is moving a few blocks south on Eighth Avenue, but he is so upset -- with the state, with The Times -- that with all due respect he did not want to talk about it.
Catherine J. Mathis, a Times spokeswoman, said the company regretted the disruption suffered by "some businesses that make a positive contribution to life in Manhattan." She added, "We certainly hope the businesses and their owners prosper in their new locations."
THE rest of the shops fled months ago, pulling down one last time the gates that bear the now-hollow warning, Post No Bill. To preserve "good will," some posted their new addresses. Others said goodbye; "It has been a pleasure repairing your shoes," said the note outside a shoe store called, simply, Shoe Store.
Mr. Pazooki moved in December to 304 West 39th Street, just two blocks south of his old store. Again, "just" is relative; two blocks in Manhattan is 20 miles anywhere else. The Port Authority parade no longer passes by his storefront, reinforcing one of the truths of this city: there is always another locksmith.
He is paying $1,300 more in rent and doing two-thirds less in business. "What time is it, 11 o'clock?" he asked the other day. "Stay until 1 and see how many come in. One, two, none."
This Times employee asked how he felt. "How would you feel?" he answered, with a grace that forgave the stupidity of the question. "I'm 57 years old."
Standing there, eyes down, Mr. Pazooki looked out of place in his own store, a locksmith who had lost his key.
