HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
S.E.C. Seeks to Keep Ban on Old Advisers' New Role in Bankruptcies

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Wall Street firms are famous for profiting in good times and bad. But their efforts to persuade Congress to let them earn fees advising the same companies in bankruptcy that they counseled in better days have met with opposition from their chief regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 William H. Donaldson, chairman of the S.E.C., has written a letter expressing his agency's opposition to a proposed change in the bankruptcy law passed by the House in March. A provision in the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2003 would allow investment bankers that have done business with a company to advise it even after the company has filed for bankruptcy, removing a restriction that has been in the bankruptcy code for decades. 
 The objections of the S.E.C. to the provision, which has been backed recently by lobbyists for the securities industry, may well doom its chances of inclusion in the bankruptcy bill now before the Senate. 
When the House passed the bill four months ago, it quietly removed the restriction barring parties that had been involved with a company, including investment bankers that had sold its securities, from advising it in bankruptcy. The restriction was intended to ensure that an adviser to a company in bankruptcy would be neutral and have no interests of its own at stake. Because advisers to a bankrupt company must go back and re-examine old transactions, conflicts could arise if the same firm that advised a company before its bankruptcy was hired to scrutinize that advice after the company collapsed. 
The S.E.C.'s view on the proposed change to the bankruptcy code was outlined in a May 22 letter to Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat and ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat and ranking member of the Senate Banking Committee. 
The two men had sought the commission's thoughts on the provision in an April 10 letter to Mr. Donaldson.
In his letter, which was provided by an aide to Mr. Sarbanes, Mr. Donaldson said that Congress should proceed "very cautiously" before loosening any conflict-of-interest restriction in the bankruptcy bill.
Conveying the view of the commission, Mr. Donaldson wrote, "While we recognize that this one-size-fits-all statutory exclusion is controversial, we believe that it would be a mistake to eliminate the exclusion in a similar one-size-fits-all manner at a time when investor confidence is fragile." 
The letter echoes testimony made by Mr. Donaldson in April before the Senate Banking Committee. He said then that although the commission had reached no conclusions on the matter, he thought it would be a mistake to change the law. But because the letter represents the opinion of the entire commission, it will carry considerable weight. 
A spokeswoman for Mr. Donaldson declined to comment further on the letter.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Sarbanes said the bill that passed the House "carries with it tremendous potential for conflict of interest and just on its face it certainly gives an appearance of conflict of interest. I think this is a pretty raw and wrong provision. We've had this definition of disinterestedness in the bankruptcy law now for quite some time." 
The requirement that advisers to companies in bankruptcy be disinterested has been reviewed several times over the last 30 years and maintained. In 1997, for example, the National Bankruptcy Review Commission found that "strict disinterestedness standards are necessary because of the unique pressures inherent in the bankruptcy process."
Proponents of the bill, which was introduced by F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the Wisconsin Republican who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said that it was inefficient and costly to bar investment bankers who were familiar with a company's inner workings from advising it in bankruptcy. Allowing former advisers to provide services to a company in bankruptcy would also expand the pool of professionals available to the company, these people said.
As the issuance of securities -- and the fees associated with such deals -- have declined in recent years, securities firms have sought the business of advising companies in bankruptcy. And the number of public companies filing for bankruptcy protection hit a record last year. It would be a boon to all of Wall Street if the restrictions on who can advise companies in bankruptcy were removed. 
Not surprisingly, Congressional aides said that the Securities Industry Association had been lobbying lawmakers hard on the issue in recent months. James D. Spellman, a spokesman for the association, said in a statement: "We are asking for reforms that create a level playing field by giving the bankruptcy judge an expanded pool of candidates to choose from in deciding which one best qualifies as a 'disinterested party.' There would be greater competition among the potential advisers. 
"The House has passed the bill," he continued. "It's time for the Senate to act and provide companies seeking bankruptcy with the quality of advice they need to rebuild their businesses, save the jobs of their employees, and restore value for their creditors and shareholders."
But Mr. Leahy said yesterday, "Rebuilding investor confidence is still important to the economy, and the last thing we should be doing now is to weaken conflict-of-interest standards for investment bankers. Chairman Donaldson's advice is timely, and Congress should listen to it."
